Don't buy it, don't rent it.  If you must, watch it when it's given away.  It's so hopeless I couldn't even be bothered to remember the peoples names.

I am a huge horror movie fan. I go to 24-hr film festivals, conventions, you name it. However, I just cannot stand this movie. I first saw it when it was released in theaters and HATED it, avoiding it and its sequels like the plague depicted therein. Tonight, 13 years after its release, I decided to give it another go.And I still just DO NOT get the appeal. Unlikable characters who garner no sympathy from me, intentionally weird supporting characters who seem to serve no real purpose other than to be inexplicably weird, and a plodding pointless story that has no real mystery to be explained or suspense as to what might happen. It reminds me of something a student might put together in an attempt to make a sloppy, unappealing homage to true pioneers of the strange in film like Lynch, Cronenberg, or even Tarantino. The difference is that those three (and others I'm not going to take the time to list) had a POINT to the oddities and strange, obnoxious weirdos they wrote and put out there for consumption. This film, like many of Zombie's films, feels like a cheap ripoff of much greater freak-shows on film.
Cheap horror at its not so finest. Brainless and dead like how the disease in the movie leaves its victims. Nostalgia may make some people miss this movie, but honestly, it's really not that great.

This film is more comedy then horror and you can see it is a work of man who clearly loves horror films. Eli Roth has fun deconstructing the genre, throwing in all the clichés, gore and laughable situations to keep the avid horror fan having fun for 90 minutes. And that is the only type of people that will understand the concept of this movie. Horror fans can have a laugh at certain, if it safe to all them 'homages' to genre classics, in terms of scenes, dialogue and even music. But the average cinema-goer will most likely hate Cabin Fever unless they like gore or live in the woods. But for those who complain; yes you don't give one about the characters, who are stereotypical and have their annoying traits; yes some of the scenes were just odd and totally pointless and yes what the hell happened to the plot, but isn't that a question all horror fans ask about recent, what are meant to be more 'serious' entries into the horror canon.6/10

For God's sake, DON"T spend money to see this toad. Wait 'til nothing else at all is playing and watch it when at least it's free.Terrible acting, thin plot, terrible camera work, amateurish special effects.... by the end I just wanted them all to die and put me out of my misery.However, the poster/cover art is really nifty and I enjoyed that a lot more than the movie.  It's worth framing, even.This looks like some film-school effort by someone who won't get much of a grade, and who hired a couple of his frat buddies as stars, along with the odd bimbo who they thought might at least put out if they got to be in a "movie" (to use the term charitably).  One hopes, frankly, that they were disappointed.  No one should be rewarded for this.

reviews.review_title: A Classic, somebody will like it in a few years.
reviews.content: The thing that sucks most of this movie is the comments about this movie! Most of the people really seem to loose the whole point of watching a movie. They expect to see something... I hope they never go to watch a Bergman movie thinking they'll see a drama, when their idea of a drama is Titanic. They wouldn't really know what they're going to feel for the next hours, they'd feel sick! There is a misunderstanding in the concept of genre. Ok, the distributors have to sell it. What should they say? "This is a movie that's straight forward in the future without losing its roots in the past"? They have to sell it as a horror movie, of course. This is a horror-apocalyptic-end of the world-lost in the woods-menaced by rednecks-drama-comedy-grotesque... how can you define a masterwork? Well, this is actually not a masterwork, but sure a good attempt at. I'm sure Scream-like fans (and i'm cool with Scream-like movies) will hate this movie, but this one is just in the line of 28 Days Later and My Little Eye, this is not a slasher movie! Don't expect your usual popcorn/girliesqueezing flick. And ok, i have to admit the last minutes are pretty wack (but the last joke that some PC guy labeled as "racist" is a great piece of comedy). Anyway guys, c'mon! There's Deliverance in there (but without the obviousness of Wrong Turn - a really wack piece of crap), and there's Evil Dead, and there's The Night Of The Living Dead. A lot of inspiration but no copycat here, just the roots that a good tree need to grow (Nicotero and his team are some expert gardeners too!).  This is a really good original movie, somebody will like it in a few years, this is a step forward.If you are into horror movies only for the thrill of the moment, you should step back and get your gasp watching some Wrong Turn lookalike. My only regret is the photography turning red sometimes, without any visible reason (in the beginning is a first person view, but then...?). 8/10

This movie was a total joke. I wasn't sure which they were trying to do, gross you out or turn you on?? (see sex scenes and then extreme violence) The constant battle between to gain control of the group was distracting, and the action started and stopped way too much. The rate of infection varied widely among the people which made it less believeable. You just felt you spent the whole film trying to get in the "groove" of the movie, only to be constantly side-tracked on already presented facts. The make-up and special effects were good, and the actors did a good job playing their roles its just the plot/story needed to be more consistent. In the end, I was glad it was over and would not suggest anyone rent the movie.

This film is full of horror movie cliches, but it feels self-aware. It's a yearly rewatch for me. Why? Because there exists some really great pay-offs of horror and suspense in this film despite the usual horror tropes. The characters are not likable for all the right reasons. They are all self-revolving, and selfishly trying to survive by the end of the movie. The violence and gore in this movie are pretty surprising. Some great twists along the way, as well as some great tongue and cheek humor. The fall back drop and anamorphic 35mm look are classic. I believe this is one of Eli Roth's great films.

reviews.review_title: Mediocre...fails to establish any true horror - SPOILERS
reviews.content: Cabin Fever could have been so much better, if only Eli Roth was more concerned with building some clever ideas into his premise of a flesh eating virus, that reduces some pretty looking horror fodder into less pretty looking dead corpses.  The film never really establishes a consistent sense of threat or danger: the kids of the film always feel like they're only a few steps away from help or civilisation, with people wandering in and out of frame throughout the film but who are for one reason or another unable to help.The film, trying hard to be a homage but, without a really well developed central conceit, seems more to be a rehashing of old ideas that have been used in horror from the '70's onwards, copying and pasting scenes from better, more original and bolder horror movies.  Kids going into a cabin for week of 'fun' and some OTT splatter is borrowed straight from The Evil Dead; Last House on the Left's songs (by David Hess) are thrown in for good measure here, there and everywhere, used to recreate a sense of forboding but feeling slightly out of place in such a threat-free teen movie; the ending basically reeking of Night of the Living Dead, where cops, thinking mistakenly that the guy crying "I made it!" is infected with the disease , blow him away; even the scene with Anne Heche in I Know What You Did Last Summer as a hidden-away poultry slaughterer is replicated. However, Cabin Fever fails to create even the slightest bit of tension that any of these films managed to evoke.It is an entertaining enougth movie, there are a few laugths, a few surprises and some pretty nasty moments of gore - the dead dog at the films beginning splitting apart at the ribs and spraying blood in a mans face; one hapless teenager giving his hopeful girlfriend a 'finger massage', only to realise after fondling her that her lower half seems to be rotting away; the remains of a flesh devoured victim, the face eaten away.  The film is ultimatly more involving when the decaying kids are on the run from the hill-billy locals.  But ideas of paranoia and flesh eating disease are not milked of their potential, and Eli seems content to make a incoherent, generally illogical movie that could have been a classic, but instead tries only to replicate classics, and ends up with something more along the lines of American Pie - The Exema Years.People slag off Scream now more than ever, saying that it laid the way for all these ironic, wink-wink, nod-nod horror movies, but the makers of these more recent traditional horror cannot think of an original idea between them - The Ring remake, Dawn of the Dead remake, The Wicker Man remake etc, etc...but Scream had more wit, more shocks, more entertainment and intelligence than any of these combined, with some sort of emotional resonance and a genuinely satisfying cartharsis, managing a different, postmodern approach to a genre which before has been afraid to adopt any new angle.  Scream - a homage to horror in the true sense, with style.  Only one word kept occurring throughout Cabin Fever - mediocre.

It's hard to decide if the movie is corny or just plain goofy.The movie revolves around how people react to others who have a fatal flesh eating disease. The whole, "Eww!!! I don't want to get sick" premise. But you really couldn't tell that from watching the movie. Cause their reactions seemed more comical and farce like rather than horrid or scary. It's verminophobic feel seemed cheesy at best. For your information, I looked up verminophobia, the fear of germs.The movie's over all pace was severely lacking. Except for the course of the disease, meaning the gore, there are hardly any memorable moments. in fact, mostly forgettable. And what was with ninja boy? The only thing really scary about this movie is that it was made. Totally pointless.

"Cabin Fever" is an uneven mix of parody, horror and clumsy attempts at comedy which often falls short and it's probably best described as "Evil Dead" for the MTV-age. Well I may have loved "Evil Dead", but this is basically a pale imitation with a lot higher budget, added sex scenes and less spooky atmosphere. The story is OK, and it could have been a good movie but the unlikeable characters, mostly dumb attempts at humor and constant stupidity lowers the experience. It also goes completely over the top at the end and destroys it's chances of being regarded as a solid horror movie.The reason it's given 4 instead of 3 is solely for the weirdest case of death by suffocation I've seen and that sequence alone almost makes this movie worth watching.It still, despite all it's faults, manages to come across as reasonably entertaining if you watch it with a couple of friends and a case of beer.4/10

CABIN FEVER does not break new ground. Having said that, the same applies to most of the movies that have been released so far this year (2005). CABIN FEVER is a surprisingly entertaining little horror flick, written and directed by horror aficionado Eli Roth. It's the story of a group of teens who decide to have a weekend party at some old cabin in the woods of North Caroline. OK, so the premise is nothing new and neither are all subsequent events, but one thing is sure: CABIN FEVER entertains! And that's what movies are for: entertainment. Well, these kids in the woods find themselves victims of some unidentified skin virus and thus puts them in awkward situations; like isolating one of themselves in order prevent the virus from spreading and infecting the rest of the teens. Shades of movies like Texas CHAINSAW MASSACRE, EVIL DEAD, DAWN OF THE DEAD and Friday THE 13th are all present in CABIN FEVER and I see this movie more like a tribute to all those slasher/splatter films of the late 70's and early 80's, when really gross films actually played out in theaters. Sure, there are a lot of plot holes and unresolved answers in CABIN FEVER. There's one scene where a trio of locals plan to kill the infected teens and one of them is carrying a little box in his hands. I mean, if you're gonna take someone out, shouldn't you also carry a gun??? We never know what this guy's carrying. We also never know where the virus came from; we only know that a dog dies from this virus and infects his owner, early on in the movie. There were little things in the movie that could have been turned into interesting plot twists, but Eli Roth keeps it raw ands simple and without any fancy plot twists. All in all, CABIN FEVER was a fun movie to watch, It's not the perfect horror film, but like I said, it was fun to watch and seems to have been made by people who are true fans of the genre!

This movie was pretty entertaining. Earlier this year, I had said I would never watch an Eli Roth movie because I thought there would be too much gore. After watching Hostel, I felt fine. So I decided to check out Cabin Fever. Overall, it was pretty good. It had some good twists, and the gore wasn't unbearable. I still feel squeamish when watching the shaving scene. The effects were pretty solid. Also, the comedy was actually pretty funny. The final shot with the water being sent out was such a good addition. Makes you think of everyone else who'll get the virus. I felt bad for Paul and Karen. She died in a shed by herself, and he had to kill his friend/crush. Finally, people act like how Jeff did with COVID-19. Funny how a movie from 2002 can still be relevant almost 20 years later.

reviews.review_title: The 70's were bad the first time through...
reviews.content: What's up with the horror movie these days?  They seem to come in three flavors: 1.) the "intelligent" horror flick ("The Ring," "Sixthe Sense") which goes for creepy atmosphere and careful characterization. 2.) the poorly plotted, but brilliantly filmed "technical" horror perfected by the Dark Castle group with films like "Th13teen Ghosts" and "Ghost Ship." 3.) And then there's the most recent trend, the homage to the 70's.  Rob Zombie's "House of 1000 corpses" provides one cogent example, and this film another.  They have all the weak characterization, scenery-chewing acting, grainy film stock, over-the-top gore and inside jokes you could want from a 70's schlock-horror-fest.But why bother?Frankly, there's nothing to be gained here.  Writer/Director/Co-Star Eli Roth hits all the right notes, but it's strictly a karaoke performance. The cast of pretty-young-things go through a number of grisly death sequences, and they're clearly having fun doing so, but this ends up feeling more like a film-school effort than a professional movie.  If they were trying to recapture the operatic scope of an "Alien" or the creeping psychological "gotcha" of "Diabolique," or even the old-school tension of a "Psycho" or something, they might at least be aiming for something worthwhile...but WHY would we want to recapture one of the poorest periods for Horror in Hollywood history?  Remake the "Excorcist"?  Good luck, but you're welcome to try...but this film tries to remake "The Hills Have Eyes," and that's frankly a much less worthy goal.  There are some gestures at a 'moral' or 'point,' but they're lost in the noise.  There's nothing redeeming about it, and, perhaps more to the point, not that much entertainment either. C+.

this is the worst mix of genres I have ever seen in my life. the director tries to pull off a very gruesome horror movie and mix it with some off the wall comedy.  Personally I haven't seen anyone pull that off since the evil dead trilogy.  I will say that there were some memorable, and incredibly sickening scenes(which is a good thing). But overall, the movie is absolutely terrible, with one of the worst endings I have ever seen in a movie period.  What was the point of the joke with the old man at the end?  Stupid!!!!  Do not waste your money.  And if you absolutely have to see it, keep an eye on your watch and make sure not to see the last 30 minutes, you'll regret it.  I certainly did. 1/10

With the excitement of the Horror genre well and truly back in full force in 2003... it's clear we will see more from this first time Director Eli Roth, as he prepares to bring us his first feature film "Cabin Fever".Writer and director, Roth tells the story of 5 friends escaping school for their Summer Break and in the tradition of "Evil Dead" the kids decide to spend it in the middle of nowhere in the Woods. With only their shack around them, campfire for "horror story telling" and a water stream (to bathe in) the story takes rather a long while to reach any point of climax, which when we do get somewhere fails to produce "scary" or "horrifying".When the 5 come across a stranded man in the woods, who appears to be badly affected by some type of skin condition, he asks for their help. When the 5 decide not to help the man in need, he seeks refuge in their 4WD, but when this goes horribly wrong, this is when the trouble starts. Slowly, the weekenders find themselves in a situation they'd all rather be without.The story itself, was written by Eli Roth back in 1995, which is based on a true life experience. In an interview after the screening he explained that he got the idea while he was working on a horse farm in the South of Iceland when he was 19. He had been cleaning out a barn and got a skin infection on his face. He woke that night scratching his cheek, thinking it was a mosquito bite. He looked at his hand and found a large chunks of skin under his fingernails. The next morning he went to shave, and literally, shaved half his face off....A lot of this adolescent story can be seen in this film, although with the regular twists and turns we'd expect to see from a modern day horror film. The gags, the girls, the gore... Roth is a hardcore "HORROR FAN LOVER" and his love of the 70's and 80's horrors come shining through in his first picture. References to films like "The Evil Dead" and "Friday the 13th" are littered in the picture with scenery, cinematography and direction. And again, Roth's love of these early Horror films are seen in his movie.The cast does a fairly good job of the script that they have been given. They're all fun characters and it doesn't take long to find a favourite.Strong performances from Rider Strong (TV's Boy Meets World) and Cerina Vincent (Not Another Teen Movie, Darkened Room) make this film a slow, but mildly entertaining Horror flick. We will see more of the "SICK" Eli Roth and his love of horror films in the future. But his first, somehow misses the mark for me, it lacks depth and interest, Some good horror effects though keep you semi interested.Cabin Fever - Scratching into theatres September 12th.6/10

reviews.review_title: I cannot believe this was released.
reviews.content:
This is nearly the worse movie I have ever forced myself to sit through. I cannot believe it has an above average rating on this data base. This movie is so bad, it encouraged me to register to state my opinion.
The movie starts slow, and slows down from there. The only thing that even came close to being entertaining was seeing a former power ranger naked, and a joke from a store clerk.it was silly, there was no plot to speak of and was missing a major component of a horror film, you didn't care one way or another whether the stars lived or died.be warned, do not waste your money on this flick.

Wow, I'm really shocked by all the positive posts.  I'm a big horror movie fan and I don't want to be mean since this seemed like an earnest attempt, but this is a dull, dull, dull movie.  The technical aspects are fine; the acting is decent and the photography is very good.  However, all the gore in the world can't make an interesting and engaging film.  I don't need likable characters, just semi-believable ones.  And I'm even fine with a movie disregarding plot for the sake of cool visuals and ambiance, but this just rambles.  Go see 28 DAYS LATER and see the right way to borrow from horror classics.  CABIN FEVER just stews bits and pieces from movies like EVIL DEAD together into a mess.

Mindless drivel with plenty of Hollywood stereotypes as to what young people are like these days.  Thank God today's young people are nothing like the shallow idiots in this film.  The "F Word" is used as punctuation for every other sentence, gratuitous sex and violence is thrown in here and there, everyone smokes dope, and even an ounce of suspense is totally lacking. "Like wow, Man, what's the point?  This is not gooood stuffff."

reviews.review_title: Despite the teenage angst the film is fun.
reviews.content: Most viewers will find the movie fun to watch. It has decent pacing with good direction. Even though the film was't the best, it does alot right compared to other horror films. The effects used are good and threat presented is real enough to create anxiety for the viewer. I find the acting suspect but its not all poor. Its overall story is some what average and follows the structure of other horror films.

Appalling acting, appalling script, A film that has no direction The story makes no sense The plot holes are enormous The reasons for the characters actions is beyond belief How anyone can say it's good is beyond me don't waste your time on this pile of crap, you`ll thank me for it Don't waste your money buying it Don't waste your money renting it The End

reviews.review_title: PETER JACKSON IS FULL OF CRAP MAN
reviews.content: "The Movie Horror Fans Have Been Waiting For" This was a blurb by Peter Jackson on one of the commercials for Cabin Fever.  Knowing Mr. Jackson got his start in Horror Films, Dead-Alive, and seeing the trailer for this movie, which seemed very scary, I decided to see it.  I was very dissapointed.  Not that the movie really sucked, I just felt that I was cheated.  It was not scary at all.  It went for the gross-out instead of the scare.  Now if they would have marketed it as a gross-out movie, rather than a real scary horror movie, I may not have been as dissapointed.  One of the other reviews here said that it was scary and Friday the 13th, the original wasn't.  I totally disagree.  Friday had very scary suspenseful momments in it, whereas this had none.  As I was watching I felt I was seeing a teenage version of Outbreak.  I just hope the remake of Texas Chainsaw Massacre fulfills the hype, unlike Cabin Fever.  Again, I say it wasn't a bad movie, but nothing like the previews showed.  I did however enjoy some of the humor.  But the humor was not mixed with horror.  It was mixed with gore. If you want to see a movie that mixes humor, horror, and gore brilliantly, rent Evil Dead 2, and save yourself a couple bucks on a movie ticket. Spidey Oh yeah, I did however like Party Cop.  He was the best Character in the movie.  Seriously.

Cabin Fever was hyped to be something great and different for the usual muck that studio churn out every year in this genre. This was bad. Wait that was an understatement. Its horrendous. The horror was overused to the nth degree and the comic relief and humorous moments fell flat on its face. This seemed more like a shock the audience with as much red cellophane as you can rather than scare or an attempt at real horror. The line between when to laugh and when to be scared/horrified is extremely blurred. The acting well... what do you think? Terrible. Its safe to say that Oscar didn't need to have a reason to "snub" this film. lolGrade: F- (My first F on imdb) a landmark

reviews.review_title: WILL DEFINITELY MAKE YOU FEEL TRAPPED IN THE THEATER...
reviews.content: Cabin Fever Is the most overrated, overhyped mediocrity since... well...28 DAYS LATER (kudos to David Poland for that set up).And just like DAYS, this film has a lot of promise if only the filmmaker had spent an extra couple of weeks on the script. But you get the feeling that Roth spent more time checking out what cool gross things his make-up effects guys had come up with than worrying about making the characters believable or the plot logical.I will give him credit for attempting a horror movie that tries to avoid any supernatural BS (although the psycho dog comes close). He lets the virus and the paranoid self-protection of the characters do the work of boogeymen. And a few times this works, but not enough.This isn't even worth renting unless you are a 12 year old taking a break from sniffing gas however.

I don't know if Roth was leaning more toward horror or more toward humor. In the end it doesn't matter, because Cabin Fever botches both elements.I'ts obvious that he has incorporated many movie plots and scenarios into his (Evil Dead, Texas Chainsaw, Friday 13th, Pulp Fiction, etc.) which ultimately robs the movie of any individual voice that it would need to succeed. It's alright to pay homage to some of the greats, but one also needs to stand on his/her own without COPYING VERBATIM its predecessors. But mostly, when it comes down to it, the predecessors were thousands of times better, in terms of execution, style and story, than this wannabe.Summation: Embarrassing 'humor', been-there-done-that feeling, no suspense, many head scratching Huh?! moments, an absolute poor attempt at film-making.

I had high hope for this movie, thinking this may be a good mix of Outbreak, 28 Days Later, and The Evil Dead. Unfortunately, a movie with good ideas just falls flat and doesn't go anywhere. When five friends stay at a cabin, they all catch some form of flesh eating virus. Some good gory goodness, along with some very interesting scenes and a few likable characters couldn't save this film that just doesn't really go anywhere with it's direction (the characters just run in circles) and the adding of characters that were both annoying (the Rednecks), forgetable, and some with no point to them (like the druggie with the dog). Along with a disappointing ending, this film could have been great but was screwed by bad writing and directing.

Do yourself a favor and never watch this movie. The characters seem to do things totally at random, the script is incredibly stupid, the actors are totally unbelievable.  This is the worst movie I've ever seen.

reviews.review_title: How to I go about getting 94 minutes of my life back?
reviews.content: I was looking forward to this film, I really was, the basic premise sounded great; lock a bunch of brainless kids together to get eaten alive by a flesh eating virus which they couldn't escape if they tried. NICE! Die, yuppies, die.But, no, you cant even see dumb people die in a horrible sickening helpless way if the antagonist isn't wearing a mask or starring in a battle royale with an equal evildoer (Jason had it won from the start BTW).Quite frankly, Eli Roth (Director/Writer) treats us as though we are stupider than the cast. **PLOT SPOILER** >>>> Everything was going swell, Badalamenti's music was giving the film a nice Twin Peaks feel, some guy gets burned up by accident and we know there's gonna be problems, and then we see the burned guy in the water catchment and we are treated to the obvious, a nice 20 second long shot of a pipe running from the water catchment through the grass, through the grass, through the grass (etc) and running into the cabin where the kids are staying. I don't know about these film festival people, but if I have to be told that this guys gonna contaminate their water, then I really have to be told how to do the most basic things, like think!Why does stupid hunting hat boy not tell anyone about the guy he accidentally shot? Why do they take so long to search for someone to help them? Why did the stoner guy's dog go freaking crazy? Why did that loser guy hump the blonde yuppies girlfriend when the love of his life was melting in the barn? Why, if no one wanted to touch the melting blonde girl, do they pick her up with bare hands, touching the mattress and blanket that she's lying on (which is covered with ... her)? What does the hillbilly decide to hunt down hunting hat boy after his monkey boy son bit him, when he clearly saw monkey boy attack him for no reason. How the hell did yuppie blonde boy manage to evade the virus, and what was with his crazy antics at the end ("oh, all my friends are melted and shot on the floor, but "I MADE IT") and hey this film sucks so much, I can see why the original Night of the Living Dead climax was ripped, there had to be at least one redeeming feature (the director recognized that the climax of NOTLD was good), but even that was screwed up because yuppie white boy was the least outcast of the group!Why can't I remember any character names? Because I didn't care about anyone!I have seen some bad horror flicks in my time, but I never thought I would say that this is possibly the worst film I have seen that came from any year after 1981.

Cabin Fever was corny Hollywood crap, but it was so for Hollywood crap's sake, whatever that means. I bought it pre-viewed at a video store for 9 bucks. Needless to say i paid too much. We have a group of bratty college kids going to spend the weekend getting drunk and having sex at a cabin (sound familiar?) who meet up with a few weird townsfolk who tell them not to go (of course). Well they don't listen, one guy gets attacked by the storeowner's kid. Note: The dialogue between the kids and the store owner at the beginning is funny and also important to remember for the ending, which is even funnier. Anyway, to make a long and ridiculous story short, the kids run into a crazed bum with a bad skin disease. He scares them away but comes back to their cabin later that night after they unpack (and get drunk and have sex). He pukes blood all over the kids' car and touches one of the kids (blonde girl) who becomes infected. The blonde girl eventually is put out in the shed so that no one else becomes infected (they think.) However, slowly, VERY slowly, each of them become infected except for Rider Strong's character. He escapes to the woods and hides out for a few days. After everyone dies (one character gets ripped apart by a dog) Rider comes back surprisingly relieved to have survived. The only body visible is his true love, the blonde girl, whose, as Rider soon finds out, face has rotted off and has been long dead. Rider shouts "I MADE IT!!" victoriously then gets blown apart by a firing squad. The end. Oh yeah, and don't forget the ending. If you paid attention to the store scene in the beginning, you'll crack up at the end.What I didn't like about the film is that it didn't have anything new to offer. The story was like a modified Friday the 13th. And it WASN'T VERY GORY AT ALL! What's up with that? I mostly got it because of the thumbs-up Peter Jackson (Dead Alive) gave it. A LOT of the deaths are off-camera (the girl being eaten by the dog) and the skin disease they get is fairly tame. I was expecting hideous oozing sores and flesh rotting off bones and stuff. Instead the characters got something that looked like really bad sunburn, then they died. Although there were a few really gory bits, they were too sparse to keep my attention. They should have made another sequel to Final Destination than this, at least it would have been more graphic.
This is one of my all time fave movies! Its funny, its scary, its bloody, its brilliant! Always up for another rewatch

reviews.review_title: Cabin Fever is NOT a horror movie!!
reviews.content: The first thing that I want to get out of the way, is that Cabin Fever is not a horror movie. A lot of the reviews on this site refer to Cabin Fever as a horror film. The movie is not scary at all. The movie is extremely gory. I will give it that. But mindless gore, does not equal horror.I just came from watching this movie, and I must say that it has to be one of the worst films that I have ever seen in my life. A friend of mine that was with me, likes practically everything that he sees. He even loved "House of 1000 Corpses". However, even he wanted to walk out of the theater. I found myself just praying for the movie to end as time went on. Nothing that happened led to any type of signifigance at all. The movie was hilarious at some points. I will give it that much. However, it is not supposed to be a comedy. From the great press that this film got, you would think that it was the next "Evil Dead" or something along those lines. Not even remotely close.So if you want bad acting, extremely annoying and stupid characters, a horrible ending, and basically a plot with no point whatsoever then Cabin Fever is for you. However, if you are a person with any intelligence at all, steer clear of this film at all costs!!1.5/10 - I added the half a point because of the fact that the film was quite funny at some points and one of the actresses was EXTREMELY HOT!!

As one who has been somewhat of a horror thriller fan for over a half century, I was surprised to see that a 2002 film had somehow totally escaped my attention, so I recently rented it on Netflix. It has been so thoroughly reviewed on this site I won't go into the plot itself. The early scenes got me interested and hopeful. I always enjoy when movies show a rural gas-station general store that has some strange people, as in "Texas Chainsaw Massacre" for example, or more recently, "Population 436", and the girlie looking Dennis certainly fit the stereo-type of strange or weird, with a sign warning people not to sit next to him, apparently with good reason. Then I heard a song by David Alexander Hess called "Wait For The Rain" which was written for the original "Last House On The Left" from 1973. Also the infected man with the flesh-eating disease was genuinely frightening. So I was hooked and hopeful I had overlooked a minor horror gem. I was wrong. As others have noted, the 5 teenagers (who look older than teenagers) have little resemblance to any college students I have known. More like itinerant construction workers on beer. Then too much time was devoted to their sexual appetites, slowing the pace somewhat, so the 90 minutes seemed much longer than that. Also it was hard to tell who was who, with a lot of unnecessary characters. The sequences often seemed confused and illogical. I think it had the potential to be a truly scary and rather original idea, but by the end it was a convoluted retread with some homages to better films. By the way, two other films about the water being a source of danger were 1986's "The Curse", with Wil Wheaton, and a slightly older minor indie "Nightmare At Noon" filmed in Moab, Utah. Neither were great films, but at least they were coherent, and I liked "The Curse" infinitely more than "Cabin Fever". Not as bad as some say, but not very good either, despite a promising beginning. Update: Repeated viewings have raised my opinion of this to about a 7 or 7.5.

This movie is so bad I can't even imagine why I am wasting even a few sentences on a brief review. Just do yourself a favor and rent even Friday The 13th part 48 before you even start to enrage yourself by watching this junk. This is by far one of the worst movies you can ever hope (not) to see. Just utter garbage. And by that I mean not the sort of movie that's 'so bad you have to watch it once'. Uh uh. No way. Don't waste your time. The time you spend watching this movie would be better spent playing in traffic on a four-lane highway with a speed limit of 70MPH. Horrible s*&%.DO NOT WATCH THIS MOVIE!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

reviews.review_title: Eli Roth makes horror films fun again
reviews.content: Low budget horror films have been on a downward spiral ever since Michael Myers took his first swipe at Jamie Lee Curtis way back in 1978.  Most of them are nothing more than an excuse to parade a group of dimwitted teenagers out in front of the camera to become fodder for some deranged killers personal version of the Veg-O-Matic.  Slice 'em, Dice 'em and Chop 'em seems to have become the order of the day.  You can't begin to imagine my surprise and delight when I finally sat down to view Cabin Fever, and found out there is still hope for the genre thanks in no small part to Director Eli Roth's off-beat take on the genre.Right away Director and Writer Roth let's us know that his killer is not an ax-wielding cannibal, but is a virus that eats human flesh from the inside out. That alone is enough to put any director ahead of the game in my book. He does assemble the usual motley crew of young people who are headed to an isolated cabin in the woods (was there ever a cabin in one of these films that wasn't isolated and in the woods?).  Paul (Rider Strong from Boy Meets World) is the sensible good guy. Karen (Jordan Ladd) is the friend Paul has known for years, but would like to know her in a lot more ways if you get my drift. Bert (James Debello) is the obnoxious loud-mouth who likes to shoot squirrels because he thinks they are gay.  Jeff (Joey Kern) is the equivalent of a living breathing Ken Doll with about the same amount of personality.  Marcy (Cerina Vincent) is his equally beautiful Barbie doll playmate.  They are a mixed bag but the film excels in giving each of the four some original odd character traits that clearly distinguishes them from the usual bland assortment of teens we get in these films.  Even good-guy Paul has a few strange ideas about sleeping women.  It also helps that all four of these actors manage to breathe some much needed life into the type of roles that are usually dead on arrival.   While out shooting the aforementioned squirrels, Bert accidentally shoots a stranger who has become infected with the deadly virus.  Instead of helping the guy, Bert panics from having shot him, and runs off to join the others without mentioning his little misadventure.  It isn't long before the virus-infected fellow shows up at the cabin, and is accidentally set on fire before escaping through the woods.  Shortly thereafter, through a strange set of circumstances that I'll not give away here, some of our intrepid explorers begin to show signs of having contracted the disease also.  Having had their vehicle wrecked, they are literally trapped in the woods.Roth also gives us some refreshing red herrings in the form of some truly oddball characters who come and go.  In the early part of the film, the foursome stop at a small General Store where a young boy named Dennis (Matthew Helms) sits in the front, waiting to take a bit out of anyone who sits next to him.  The store is run by an old Mountain Man (Robert Harris), who sells everything from fox urine to  guns.  There's also a party loving perverted deputy named Winston (Guiseppe Andrews) who comes along to investigate the goings on but seems as menacing as a bunny rabbit.  As if that isn't enough, throw in a friendly pot smoking college student who shows up with his guard dog.  All of these characters might have been just props as they are in most horror films, but Roth weaves them in and out of his story with a purpose in mind.  You may think you know what that purpose is, but you will probably be wrong.As for the gore, it's gruesome but not overly done.  There is one scene where Paul has some dishonorable intentions toward Karen as she sleeps.  We know what he's doing, and yet we know before hand what the outcome will be which makes the scene that much more excruciating to watch.  There is another atrocious scene in this film that may have many women throwing away their Lady Gillette razors once and for all.Most of all, even Roth doesn't take his film too seriously.  There are some obvious scenes which if played strictly for horror, I would be ranting and raving about the stupidity of it all, but Roth let's us know he's winking his eye at us and having a little fun in the process.  And to top it all off, there are some final scenes where one can't help but remember some pod hauling trucks from the original Invasion of the Body Snatchers. Intentional or not, that's what I thought of.  Yes the ending is sequel setting, but just as everything else in this film, it is done with a certain kind of unabashed playfulness.  And if any film can convince me not to lower it's grade because of an ending that yells sequel, Cabin Fever can and is the first to do so in a long time.  And if you can make me do that I have no choice but to give you my grade which for Cabin Fever is a B+.

Okay, this movie was rank!I really hate it when you see a trailer, and it really sells up a movie so much that you can't wait to see it.Then when you pay to get in you feel like asking for a refund.  That's how I felt after Cabin Fever.  The movie was boring, trivial and seemed to rely mainly on stomach churning scenes for its frankly limited sense of tension.
The characters were so self-centred and obvious that you couldn't care at all what happened to them.  The best bit in the movie was the credits when I was finally free to leave in the hope that the next movie I went to see would be better.  It probably isn't possible for any film to be worse.

This so called movie is aweful. The story line is so weak and lacks in continuity. The acting is bad, I wasnt aware people could be such bad actors. The directing is non-exsistant. The shots were fairly good in its defense but all the other elements of this amatuer film need help. Its a real shame this kind of direct to the trash film got any theatrical release. With less and less filmmakers making movies these days,you would think there would be some integrity left for the art of making movies and films in there some where.

reviews.review_title: One of 10 worst movies I've ever seen
reviews.content: No, this movie is not good. don't be fooled by anyone on this site. If I can do anyone a favor and stop them from seeing it I will have made the world a better place. The directing was terrible, and I seriously thought it was written by a 14 year old until I found out it was written by the director. There is no point to this film, and I don't mean to say I expected meaning or much merit from this genre, I mean it really had no point- it started with nothing and ended with nothing. There is no horror to speak of, no enemy, you basically wait for each character to start throwin up blood and then croak- some in more gruesome ways than others, but always without any point. The acting was fine, in that it didn't make the movie any worse. There is a high level of gratuity and "oh this would look cool" nonsense (ie the guy in the bunny suit at the hospital). Finally, the ending was insulting beyond belief. I really don't know what annoys me more, the fact that this movie was made or that people love it so much. Believe me, its bad. 1/10

Cabin Fever (2002) ** 1/2 (out of 4) Five friends head out to a cabin in the woods for a week of fun but before long one of them are being eaten alive by a virus, which soon starts to effect the others.Eli Roth's CABIN FEVER is a fairly good movie for the most part but I think it tries to do a bit too much and in the end it remains entertaining but I think had it been more focused then it could have been better. I say this because the film wants to gross you out, make you laugh, tries to be scary and it also tries to wink at itself while also being serious. The film simply goes off into too many directions for it to be a complete success.I say this because the film is certainly never scary because of the wink nature of how everything is handled. With that said, the comedy really doesn't work as well as I'm sure everyone hoped and especially with some of the characters actions. The film and especially the director knows a great deal about the genre so we get little nods to other movies and this here is fun.The performances for the most part are quite good but there's no question that what sets the film apart is its rather gory and extremely goo-filled violence. There are some great effects on display here and I especially loved the scenes where the skin is basically just falling off the bone and this is best seen when one of the characters scratches his hands against a tree. If you're a fan of gore then you'll certainly be happy with the high volume on display here.

Don't waste your time viewing this garbage. It's looks like was written by five different writers. Bad directed, bad actors, bad camera placement,stupid characters, etc. This thing looks like the son of 28 Days Later with Friday the 13. The scene with the pancake child ? I'm still looking for a reason for this scene.Where the virus come from? This movie leave so many questions with no answer, It's made Donnie Darko looks like a Disney movie. A ridiculous screenplay made by people that think we are going to watch every piece of garbage they send to the theaters. Make yourself a favor and stay away from this poor excuse of a movie.

reviews.review_title: how awful is cabin fever? let me count the waves...
reviews.content: Aside from the hot Cerina vincent, this has to be one of the worst movies i've ever seen. gory, disgusting, contrived, cliche, filled with plotholes and horrible acting, this is one of the worst. Eli roth should never be allowed near a film camera.

reviews.review_title: Forgettable B-movie horror from Eli 'Hostel' Roth.
reviews.content: Cabin Fever, Eli Roth's directorial debut, is a fun slice of schlock horror that is worth a watch, but is in no way deserving of the praise that is plastered all over the box. "A modern horror classic" it certainly isn't!Roth's tale of a group of teenagers vacationing in the wilds, who fall victim to a contagious flesh-eating virus, is pure B-movie fodder; fun while it lasts, but instantly forgettable. The story, which admittedly has a lot of potential, is weakened somewhat by some poor characterisation and quite a few ridiculous plot turns.Roth compensates a little for the less than perfect script with some disturbing scenes of gore, a pervading atmosphere of gloom, and some welcome gratuitous nudity courtesy of the lovely Cerina Vincent (unfortunately, Jordan Ladd only strips down to her bikini), but my overall impression of the film is one of a wasted opportunity.As was the case with Hostel, I can't help feeling that Roth has no problem coming up with the basic premise for a good film, but has no idea about how to actually make the best of it.

reviews.review_title: Why couldn't I get this disease!?!?
reviews.content: Seriously, if I would have gotten the disease before I went to the movie, death would have been welcome. Instead, I had to endure 90 minutes of pure headache. Amazing.***Spoiler***THIS MOVIE SUCKS ***Spoiler end*** Do something more valuable with your time, like go to the bathroom, cook some muffins, or hit yourself with a tackhammer. All these are 10000x more enjoyable than watching this movie! It would have been half decent if there wasn't so much lame humor in it. Was this supposed to scare you or make you laugh!??! I never was sure. I wanted the characters to die about 10 minutes into the movie. Is this what they were aiming for!? Please, don't get me started on the actors/actresses. It was like they picked a few random people off the streets and threw them in the movie.I'm still trying to recover from this, I take many aspirin a day from this "movie". Unless you want headaches for the rest of your life, avoid this movie.

reviews.review_title: What an absolute waste of time!
reviews.content: This film is so awful I 'had' to take just a minute. I can find worth in most anything and if I 'had' to find something here, I'd say the camera work wasnt grade school level and thats it! Other then that, this movie is soooo slow, predictable, unimaginative and an absolute bore!Finally toward the end it picks up however, it picks right up into stupid sillyness that you just cannot believe. What I cannot believe more is the person who gave the green light distributing this hunk, still has a job, 'that' I wouldnt believe. Only one opinion however I 'know' 90% of you will find this an utter waste of time.

reviews.review_title: Bad editing, untidy plot development, no interesting characters, no tension
reviews.content: A movie like this one makes you aware of the incredible talent of some other first-time directors like my heroes Peter Jackson (Bad taste), Robert Rodriguez (El Mariachi), and Sam Raimi (Evil dead). It is not easy making a movie. You have to have an interesting story, based on interesting idea's, played by interesting actors. (When I say interesting, I mean: talented, multi layered, coherent.) Eli Roth is not the talented man he is said to be.Editing: Sometimes in supposedly thrilling action scenes he cuts so bad that all the tension is taken out. Many times the screen turns black without making a point, besides "I don't know where to go to with this scene". In the beginning of the movie there is some rough cutting (when they are in the car on their way to the cabin). It is like a mixed up slide show. The camera movements are the same over and over, not very inspired (horror is THE genre in which you can be very creative in moving the camera, isn't it, Sam Raimi?!)The story: The illness develops not very gradually. The blond girl first is very ill and nearly not able to speak and when she's put in the shed, she seems very much alive. And just for more tension, let's split the group up, let them come together again, split them up, let them come together again and so on, ... Let's make it easy for them to refined the cabin, let's make every direction you walk into eventually end by the cabin. and just for tension, let's put a dog into the story. What a mess, what a mess.I didn't care for either one of the 'characters' both youngsters and townspeople. I thought they where all rather annoying. I read in other comments (also the Ebert-review), that there where some good idea's. I didn't see them. So what's horror all about: some good scares and hoping one or two heroes survive. Well I couldn't care less.Eli Roth, you have got no talent, at least you didn't use it writing and directing this very bad B-movie.

Where do I begin?  What a damn waste of money and time!!  This has to be one of the worst movies of all time!!  Some of the lamest acting I have ever seen.  Worst directed movie of all time!  Scenes that go nowhere, like the stupid biting boy the knows karate.  What in the hell was that all about? Don't waste your time on this piece of crap!!  Awful!

reviews.review_title: Scary, bizarre, disturbing and funny, what a great combo!
reviews.content: Suffice to say that although I loved this movie I'm not all surprised to see the low rating it received, it's not for everyone. It seems to be specifically written and directed for those of us inclined to appreciate the nuances of the old fashioned cheesy/horror/gore flicks.Don't get me wrong, it is a good horror film. The plot though not complex, is solid and once the gore begins it doesn't stop. The dark comedy spliced throughout will not be lost on the fans of it's genre, but will probably go entirely unnoticed and unappreciated by someone looking for a movie like The Excorcist...but if you're the kind of movie goer that had to see Evil Dead 2 more than once, you'll enjoy this movie. I know I did.

With Evil Dead, Sam Raimi made a good, solid horror movie. With Evil Dead 2, Sam Raimi made a very funny horror parody. With Cabin Fever, Eli Roth tries to do both, and comes up short either way. Cabin Fever has some intense moments, but they are undermined by too much comic relief.  I think there was also supposed to be some social commentary in there, about the mistreatment of people with diseases, but that does not work either.  Maybe the movie was just trying to be stupid.  In that case, Eli Roth forgets the important rule:  a movie is only bad enough to be funny if it is trying to be good.  Try to make a bad movie and you just have a bad movie.  Cabin Fever has a few shocks, a few laughs, but nothing that impressive.

reviews.review_title: Utter Crap derived from 80s straight-to-video horror
reviews.content: During the additional features option on the DVD of Cabin Fever, Eli Roth's (rich) Dad explains that Eli was "destined to make horror movies" because as a child he vomited during the gross-out scene in Ridley Scotts movie "Alien". Play that backwards, symbolically, and you get the impetus for every reason Eli Roth shouldn't make movies.This film is, really, bargain basement trash - almost like a 1987 straight-to-video slasher in so many ways; the young adults look like extras, or amateurs, complete with bland TV-hairstyling (in the remote wilderness, for some reason?), and the foul mouthed and generally unlikeable young adults get in trouble when a hideous disease, sort of a scabby, zombified necrotising fasciitis breaks out and starts turning the characters into gore covered corpses. The solution? There isn't one - the movie has a premise and no plot development whatsoever.Worse still, the film has a "comic relief" character thats supposedly a sleazy, sexist policeman, who IS weird, but ISN'T funny. Numerous scenes are dedicated to the pretty young female cast members appearing semi-naked or having chaste porn sex on screen, usually to be revealed later to be covered in massive, pus filled sores, their skin literally peeling off from a devastating virus.The worst, and I mean, easily the worst thing about this film is its use of "uneasy racial humour"; a local redneck in Cabin Fever refers to some black kids as "niggers", which the city folk take as shockingly intolerable, but later on, its all, like "hey, my niggaz, wassup??" as if, supposedly, the redneck kook that fixes rifles at a small rural community store is so in with local black community that he affectionately calls them "niggers". In all honesty, a lot of viewers won't get to the end of the movie, so they won't see this quick turn around into a type of black comedy that betrays Eli Roth's inept sense of humour and poor taste as a filmmaker.Lastly, there is a bizarre, slow motion kung-fu segment featuring a disturbed hillbilly kid that feels, perhaps unintentionally, like a homage to Claudio Fragasso's Troll 2.Cabin Fever is utter crap, as I stated above, but ultimately, its very cheap filmmaking, meaning that its nominal profit margin will allow for sequels, same as the garbage 80s slasher movies that Eli Roth is "paying tribute" to. Essentially, this is a cheap 80s-style slasher without an actual bad guy in sight.

reviews.review_title: Not so much horror as complete and utter bore.
reviews.content: This movie tried very hard to be a modern teen gore fest but failed. Now I love my horror and many so called "gore fans" will tell you that bad acting is what horror movies are all about. Well I'm sorry to burst all those horror guru wannabes bubbles but guess what guys - bad acting is bad acting, it doesn't matter if your watching Pride and Prejudice or Toxic Grannies - it is horrible to watch and in the case of Cabin Fever it was truly terrible. The cast failed to bring anything to their cardboard cut out, stereotypical, bland, middle American characters. The usual suspects of tough jocks and cheer leaders, nerds and rednecks, not one of the characters had a single memorable line. If only the gore had been as horrible it might have had some redeeming features.Gore: well no, not really - remarkably tame. Anyone who has watched Cannibal Ferox would say that this was barely even blood thirsty. Only a true newbie to the horror/gore fest genre would find this movie overly gory, all the gore fans will just be bored by it. The projectile vomiting of blood, something which was done far better in 28 Days later and incidentally the actors in that film could actually act, supposedly makes this film gory but really it is just lame.Cabin Fever brought nothing new to the genre, a typical rehash of old horror films with a modern setting and annoyingly stereotypical American teens played by people 10 years older than their characters. The woodland setting was straight out of a Friday the 13th movie. The disease ridden locals idea was about as unoriginal as you can get. Nothing about this movie was remotely scary. The only reason I can recommend watching this movie is as a cure for a particularly bad case of insomnia and I actually did fall asleep trying to watch this - no joke, middle of the day I zonked out and woke up 2 hours later, rewound the movie and realised why I had fallen asleep in the first place.A couple of redeeming features: it was so bad it made me laugh, although I did not laugh at one of the cheesy jokes that were written into the movie..... all in all, do yourself a favour and watch 28 Days Later, Friday the 13th or Cannibal Ferox since these movies did it better and they did it first.

This was by far one of my most anticipated movies of 2002. I saw the trailer and eagerly awaited it's release. Then I saw it. I saw a movie that introduced a flesh eating virus as it's main villain. OH NO!! To compensate for the lack of any real "villain" It spewed forth gallons upon gallons of blood. I'm a huge fan of 70's and 80's B movie Horror. However, this movie has no shock value and no suspense. I don't think I've ever been so disappointed in a movie. The kid from Boy Meets World was so unconvincing as a hero. Even the gratuitous nudity was unsatisfying. I'm doing this movie credit by giving it a 1 out of 10, and the fact that anybody ever liked this movie is baffling to me. Just a horrible horrible film. My eyes are still burning.OH NO, THE FLESH EATING VIRUS IS IN OUR BOTTLED WATER!!!! AHHHHHHH, Weak.

reviews.review_title: Should have been called CRAP FEVER
reviews.content: I am so tired of the hillbillies vs. city folk idea that it makes me wonder why I watched this! Obviously the same moron critics who thought Blair Witch (bleah!) was high concept, saw this and suckered me in. This was one of the dumbest films ever made. They didn't even go with the strong female role, both women are there to either be a)Naked or b)killed.  The entire cast was virtually unlikable and deserved death. Mind telling me why people are drinking and bathing in water that's coming from a virtual mosquito breeding ground pond? No? Didn't think so. And what was with the nutty kid biting people? Where the hell did that fit into the story? Ah, at least the hillbillies get theirs in the end, thanks to the Lemonade Stand. This was a lame, boring, silly film and was just too stupid to ever watch again!

No wonder this byproduct of digestive system does not go anywhere, in order to do so it has to take off first. So many horror movies, so many reasons to read a rag on the loo.
Questions abound and life is short. Decomposing body in the water supply - check, policeman offering to party at the sight of a blood splattered car - check, infected girl spray-coughing blood dragged underarm by her healthy friends - check... the list goes on and on.
Luckily I was having breakfast and doing dishes at the time hence 90 minutes well spent. Be advised.

All I will say about this "film" is PANTS!!Avoid at all costs!!Never watch!!Do not waste your money and more importantly....you time!!I have had constipation that has been less painful to sit through than this film!!Having your nuts kicked is more entertaining...and makes more sense!!What were the producers smoking....cause I want some!!You have been warned!!

Beware, SPOILERS below...What an unexpected disappointment, I was expecting good things about this movie. Started off as a bog standard teen horror, metamorphosed into a quasi comedy, ended up a clumsy mishmash of crap editing, unexplained plot developments and an illogical and random ending based on a racist joke!
Good points: Nice shot of a still living girlie with her lips chewed off by a rabid dog.Screwdriver rammed into hillbilly's brain - always a good one.Lovely 'shaving legs in bath' scene.Bad points: The cardinal sin of horror movies - PINK BLOOD! This does my head in, it should be the simplest thing to get right, but the blood was not the colour of blood! Unnecessary comedy character: hillbilly cop obsessed with sex.Dodgy editing, jumping about with no style whatsoever.
And the disease itself? Simply a rash that makes you feel nauseous and cough up some blood. No unrelenting rage, no exploding chests, no limbs dropping off. just a rash.Overall verdict?? Well below par.

Well, that was funny if you seen the movie, but that is about it forthis stinker.  The scary part is I spent 17 dollar for my wife andmyself to see this stinker.  Low budget, no script etc this was comparable to a 70's college movies.  The only good part is themissleading trailer.   Except for a few laughs I would give this filma 3.  There is some social message about helping people out andhow their problems become your problems.  Simple solutions willnot fix them.

reviews.review_title: An amusing hoot -- good solid mindless trash like a grocery store novel
reviews.content: Front to back, this flick is a hoot. Genuinely scary in parts, and successful overall in its attempt to bring back the good old days of 70s horror. Far better than either of the offerings in the later "Grindhouse" by supposedly better directors, it almost became a cult classic and deserves the status. Despite a few clumsy sequences and hard-to-decipher shots, the film survives and leads the viewer relentlessly into a cesspool of destruction, decay and mayhem.The finish is an hilariously macabre and deadly twist that won't fail to delight. (I don't mean the homage to Night of the Living Dead, but what follows. You'll never stop at a lemonade stand or purchase bottled water with quite the same confidence.)The movie is a non-stop quote fest that will send you to IMDb to see if anyone else noticed such gems as "Pancakes! Pancakes!" and "Yeah he's a professor -- of being a dog!" Then you'll need to check out UrbanDictionary.com in search of definitions for neologisms like "Faced!" and "Scratch moded!"The writers are good at twisting your neck. References to gay bashing and shooting African-Americans turn out funny. Kids are brutally killed by their friends, and you're glad. Sex scenes steam you up and then make you sick. When quirky anecdotal scenes included just for kicks don't fit the storyline, you're happy they weren't cut, because they're so rich and hilarious or just ominously creepy.Finally, a horror movie where the villain isn't a guy in a mask or a rubber suit. In fact, one can debate at intelligent length just what or who the villain is. And contrary to current cinematic trends, there are no build-ups that don't pay off with a genuine moment of true disgust.

Mastermind horror genius new on the block Eli Roth director of Cabin Fever, A story of 5 college friends on break who decide to hire a cabin in the woods, when a flesh eating-virus is introduced into the group it's a fight between the friends and there will to survive. Rider Strong, "Boy Meets World" plays Paul, "Joey Kern" plays Jeff, "James Debello" plays Bert "Jordan Ladd" plays Karen and "Cerina Vincent" plays the sexy Marcy also with the funniest appearance from cartoon animator "Giuseppe Andrews" For a disgusting, violent and adult horror movie Cabin Fever was a masterpiece that's all I was expecting and that's what I got. Very entertaining with comic scenes but did not stray away from the struggle between this group of friends who basically destroy everything around them. Entertaining, believable storyline and special effects, Roth has the qualities of a true horror director. In Cabin Fever aspects of Tobe Hooper's "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre" Wes Craven's "Scream" and other flashes of Dawn of the Dead and Evil Dead and other horror classics are used just relating to horror fans I guess. Roth just seems to have a knack for the horror genre. Great Cast with exceptional chemistry.

reviews.review_title: just not scary enough for a horror film
reviews.content: Its a bit of a cliche but also a truism that in horror films involving youngsters going off for a vacation in the woods, we as an audience, immediately begin to anticipate the order of their deaths. Usually there are a couple of annoying characters that we are glad to see go while we trust that the others might survive. At least this is the usual formulae. Here by accident (director's first film) or design (he really has proven to be most capable) we don't like anyone. The are either dumb, uncaring, naive or just plain stupid. Add to this a rather far fetched plague element and this is never going to reach the heights that now and again it deserves. One more important problem is that it is not scary. Nasty, horrible and unpleasant but just not scary enough for a horror film.

reviews.review_title: fun, crazy, and inspiring...HAIL ELI ROTH!
reviews.content: When was the last time you loved a movie so much that you spent more money renting it over and over than you would have if you had bought two copies? When I first heard of Cabin Fever, I was foaming at the mouth. I had read nothing but praise for it, and was just dying to see what Eli Roth had committed to film. I read all the flack about "...return to 70s" and interviews with Eli about what he was trying to accomplish. I thought, "Thank God, someone has come along with enough love for the genre that he could possibly resurrect from the stream of crap that it has become. All this just made me want to see it even more. When the day finally came, I was there, in the theater waiting with glee, wishing there were some way that I could hit the fast-forward button and skip through the trailers. I was a little nervous. Had I built it up too much? Had I set myself up for a big let down? No and no. "Cabin Fever" was even better than I had anticipated. My (then) girlfriend was repulsed and furious that we hadn't gone to see "Matchstick Men" instead. Me, being the selfish jerk that I am, found myself in the theater again, the very next weekend for a second viewing. I couldn't get enough. I was completely hooked.Why am I so obsessed with this movie? Well, I'm not exactly sure why. Maybe a shrink could figure it out, but I can tell you what I LOVED about this movie: First would be the characters. I loved every single one of these guys and gals and was with them all the way. For one, they were all REAL, not some cookie-cutter stereotypes that we're so used to seeing. These are real, flawed human beings. Ryder Strong did great as Paul and Joey Kern was very good as Jeff. He's the one that you love to hate. Cerina Vincent was wonderful as Marcy and Jordan Ladd was good as Karen. My personal favorite (aside from Deputy Winston) was Bert, played with great energy by James Debello. Yeah, he's the "comedy relief" and all and he's supposed to be annoying, but I love his carefree attitude and his laugh had me laughing. His squirrel shooting antics were hilarious and I still laugh when I think about the Snickers bar. Many have complained about Deputy Winston (Giuseppe Andrews) showing up midway through the movie and supposedly "wrecking everything". To me, these were some of the comic highlights and he gets most of the best lines in the movie. Just the idea of a party-hard Deputy puts a big smile on my face and his reaction to the truck still gets me. In fact, his reaction to anything odd gets to me.I love the look of the movie. I guess it's supposed to be Spring, since they're on Spring Break vacation, but to me, it looked like Fall. Whether this is a goof or not, I don't really care. It gave the film a great look. I loved the set-design of the cabin. That cabin is a character in itself. Next time you watch it, pay close attention to the detail.The pacing: I love it. The first half is relatively tame and plays more like a comedy. You meet the characters, spend time with them as they party and do their thing, and begin to feel sorry for them because you know all is about to be ruined. I especially loved the campfire tale about the bowling alley. Classic indeed. Once things finally kick into gear, the last third moves at a breakneck pace. THAT was great directing and as for the ending, well, (notice how I'm avoiding spoilers for those who haven't seen it) I really hope that Eli gets it in him to do a sequel because I want it to continue.In short, I love this movie so much it's downright scary. I don't know for sure how many times I've seen it over the last years and there's no telling how many times I'll watch it for years to come. Clichéd as it may sound, this is by a horror fan FOR horror fans. Easily in my top 5. HIGHLY Recommended

reviews.review_title: Not very good. Bad writing. Bad Directing. Bad Acting (by the guys).
reviews.content: OK, so I just saw this movie on cable tonight Feb. 16, 2006 and I have to say it was pretty bad.In fact the only reason I watched it and kept watching it was because it had two good looking girls in it. After they were dead I had no interest to further watch the rest of the movie -even though I did because nothing else was on TV at the moment.It also kept dragging on when it should have ended and it contained some strange scenes that didn't make any sense to the story but yet someone felt they should be in the final cut for humor.That's bad film-making, leave your 'little darlings' on the cutting table, or in modern terms on the hard drive. Include the nonsensical crap on the DVD for the 'dropped scenes' or the 'Directors cut' or whatever the hell you want to call it, but keep them out of the story.Yes I'm talking about the weirdo kung fu monkey kid who repeatedly screamed 'pan cakes!!!' and bit bad actor #1's fingers. The writing was bad, predictable and stale.Obviously this thing had a micro budget or no budget so the writer had to make do with basically nothing but the single location (the cabin) and the out doors. Even still there are great movies that take place in basically one location but of course they had good writers and good actors.I also don't know why this movie had an R rating, I was really disappointed with it, it should have been PG 13.The male leads acted too much like stereotypical morons and they did a fairly poor job of it, none of them showed any decent acting ability except maybe the guy who played the 'wuss', and he just so so but that could have been bad writing as well.Whether this was due to bad directing or just bad acting is hard to say and us viewers don't really care who's to blame.The two lead girls did a respectable job, especially the cute blond ( even though she didn't get naked which of course every guy wants to see ) .It was pretty retarded (for lack of a better term) that the girls die so early in the movie and it would have been nice if one of the girls (I prefer the blond) had survived.No one cares if wussy boy in the stream is alive (or dead).The filmmakers obviously wanted to keep the door open for a possible sequel in the event this thing made some money.Best thing about this movie:The casting of the two girls, especially the blond.The next best thing about this movie:Nothing.Recommendation:If you're under 18 and it comes on cable you MIGHT enjoy it, but more likely you'll just be disappointed when the girls don't really show much and nothing interesting happens.If you feel like discussing any of these comments or this movie please email me at Yahoo.com. (My IMDb posted username @ yahoo.com) .

reviews.review_title: Don't Waste your Time or Money
reviews.content: Dull, Dull, Dull.The only thing that keeps this from being a "1" is a little teen movie skin, but there wasn't even enough of that!  Do yourself a favor and rent any other scary movie.

Just awful. I'm a fan of good horror films, which this definitely is not. Half of the actors are good actors unfortunately caught in a bad script, the other half cannot act in the first place. The script has to be one of the worst, most nonsensical, rambling bits of drivel I've ever seen. Makes no sense. None.You need to care at least marginally about characters for a movie to have some impact. That includes not writing all the characters as complete idiots.I give this a 2, one for each of Cerina Vincent's breasts-- the only worthwhile thing about this tripe.

I have to say, I thought this would be a good movie, but I was mistaken.  I should have checked reviews before I saw it.  When I heard about it I thought hmmm.... seems interesting.  Since there haven't been any good Horror movies released since, Oh I don't know about the early 80's, I just decided to go see this.  I wish I hadn't.  I had no idea that this movie was an independent film.  I think Blair Witch was much better and much more convincing.  I shortly figured out what was going to happen when the kids got to the cabin and once The Dufus shot the "squirrel" -->guy, I knew the movie would be stupid from then on out.  The only reason I stayed and kept watching and didn't walk out is because right down to the last minute of the film, I actually thought it would get better.  Actually finally the point was made, but then it reminded me of how much of a plot the movie was missing.  The plot was not organized or clear at all.  I'm just glad I've seen enough Horror movies and movies altogether to know that this was not necessarily a winner.  It's got the feel of a good horror flick with no substance.  I guess what the people at the Toronto Film Festival saw was future promise.  With the help of some of the best horror film writers and directors, this could have been better.  But, then again look what they did to the Blair Witch Project II.  First movie was much better than the second.

A thoroughly nasty and thoroughly brilliant horror movie from Eli Roth which should have you squirming in your seat and averting your eyes in all the appropriate places. It's like a hybrid of "The Evil Dead" and "Deliverance" and there is a deliciously mean streak of black humour running through it.It begins like so many of its ilk with a bunch of over-sexed kids heading off to the woods for a week's fornication but things quickly go downhill when they encounter a guy running around who seems to have been eaten out from the inside. Yep, it's that old chestnut, the flesh-eating virus movie. Actually, that's what makes it so good. In this movie you don't get to see 'the monster', just the very horrible results of what it does. Nor does it fully explain where it came from. We're not in the medical procedural genre here, just good old gross-out horror. The acting is appalling but Roth really does pull out all the stops and never lets up. Relentless, somewhat sick fun.

reviews.review_title: About as shocking or surprising as watching paint dry...
reviews.content: As utterly formulaic as any episode of "Scooby Doo" I have ever cringed through (my son watches it...), this movie had some interesting performances, but little else to recommend it.  All the "shock moments" were utterly predictable, clearly advertised far in advance, and if you couldn't see them coming, you were probably asleep at the time - probably because you were watching this movie!  And just *what* was that deputy supposed to be all about?  I was convinced that he was so obviously not a deputy by his weird behaviour (my wife was convinced that at age 15, he was too young to be a cop...), and I was amazed when he turned out to be even more absurd.If you want to see a more shocking movie, try "Resident Evil" (and don't forget to keep a tally of the number of times you see the mike in shot - it almost deserves star billing!) which I didn't like either, but was much harder to outguess.

reviews.review_title: The early 2000s had some of the worst horror! And you people ate this one up too lol
reviews.content: Can't believe how people who clal themselves horror fans loved this film so much... It's played out like a sitcom because it's super dull and looks like a TV movie...It's gross but not a good film... This one was a little too cheesy for me and Hicks don't make me laugh.

Fresh out of college, five friends (Nadine Crocker, Matthew Daddario, Samuel Davis) face the horrors of a carnivorous virus while staying in a remote cabin.I love the horror style in the middle of nowhere, bloody murderer, southern countryside, prejudice, brainless young people, the good thing is that we don't feel sorry for the bloody deaths, we even cheer for the murderers, and we already know who dies and who survives after a lot of fighting for their lives ... Cliché, worked on irony, almost trash, I love it anyway... Soundtrack reminded me of "Lost", not with the same mastery, but adorable, kept in due proportions...

.....is what they should have entitled this embarrassment, because that's how you feel after the first 15 minutes.  After all of the HYPE from the STUDIO and so-called MOVIE CRITICS touting this head-cheese as DESTINED TO BE A CLASSIC.  Yeah, it's a classic alright. A CLASSIC MESS!  No plot.  Bad acting.  Whack jokes.  Cheesy effects.  Stupid, offensive dialogue. I suppose since they couldn't come up with a plausible story they tried to go for shock value.  Well, that didn't work either.  And did I mention "No plot"?  And, it's suppose to be a HORROR MOVIE right? WRONG !  This movie is about as scary as a sleep-over at Michael Jackson's house.  Well, o.k. maybe that would be scary.  But the only thing frightening about this movie was the nervous look on the theatre manager's face. He stood at the exit with FREE PASSES to another movie.Some films with no box office potential go straight-to-video, but this one should have gone straight into the vault of WORST FILMS EVER MADE IN ITS GENRE -- or even better...the trash can.

The single worst movie I have ever seen in my life, no question. Everything was just terrible with this flick. I have never felt more violently angry after watching a movie than I did with this. What an absolute waste of my life. I was trying to make the movie a joke, laughing at the hokey storyline as if it was a parody, but the fact that this worthless tool of a director acutally thought he really made something to be proud of... well... I am dumbfounded... how unbearable that this no-talent hack could get funding and great camera's to shoot this piece of kindling and there are so many more with talent, how unbearable. I hate this, I hate this, I hate this, I hate this, I hate this, I hate this, I HATE THIS MOVIE AND EVERYONE INVOLVED

Solid horror flick for a mainstream horror audience. Cabin Fever combines the well known theme "young guys and gals without much for brains on vacation getting in some serious troubles in some remote place" with the virus/infection theme.I wouldn't say that Cabin Fever is a must-watch or masterpiece of the genre, but still a good one to pass some sparetime and enjoy some moments of nice horror and spitting blood.

I remember watching 'Cabin Fever' in the cinema when it first came out. If you'd asked me what I thought of it after I came out I'd have said, "Yeah, it's okay," and left it at that. It wasn't until after I saw it did I keep hearing how it was a 'homage to Evil Dead.' Now, I'm a big fan of the Evil Dead trilogy (excluding remake) and I didn't remember much in Cabin Fever that could be considered a 'homage.'
