So I watched it again when it came out on DVD and I guess I saw what I'd missed the first time round.Basically, Cabin Fever is hardly original – five college friends go to a remote cabin in the woods and meet a sticky end. However, it's done just differently enough to make it worth watching. It's not perfect by any means – there are still a couple of 'plot points' which I always objected to – namely because I felt that I could see them coming a mile off and I could tell that the writers were trying to make what happened a surprise.However, despite the odd wrong turn, the narrative is pretty good. It's worth noting that the man responsible for the soundtrack to (the brilliantly-weird) Twin Peaks did the music for this, too. And, like each other, they have more than their fair share of 'weird/surreal' moments which makes the whole thing stand out.The five characters aren't that nice. You won't really like them, but that doesn't really mean that you won't root for them. Even the annoying one with the really bad haircut is stupidly-annoying enough for you to enjoy watching him, but special kudos to 'Bert' who is a total wally and yet he's still quite entertaining to watch.I won't go into too much detail as to what happens to our five, daft teens as you probably already know or, if you don't, it'll hopefully be a bit of a surprise. But, I will say that it is a definite horror movie, therefore you'll get more than you monies worth of gore from this outing.After all these years I've now watched Cabin Fever a number of times and I seem to enjoy it more and more each time. Like I say, it's not perfect, but if you're looking for a nice little tongue-in-cheek film with plenty of gore and sets out not to take itself seriously, then this is it. And, yes, there were a fair few nods to Evil Dead which completely went over my head the first time round (just don't ask me for 'pancakes' after this film).

reviews.review_title: it wasn't meant to be scary...
reviews.content: instead its more funny, in a bad way.  There's nothing scary about this movie or original. You know what will happen to the college kids from the beginning.  Once we see the infected guy show up at their cabin, of course, they will get the disease. But, I was surprised that the kids did some mean things to the guy, ie... set on fire, but then again all the kids were portrayed as being very selfish.  There are many comedic moments throughout: all the actors trying to act scared, the hog lady, dennis the biting kid, the store owner(the gun explanation), the deputy drinking with high school kids, Marcy suggesting to Paul they are going to die so they might as well do it, Paul going psycho seriel killer, and the list goes on.It was disgusting with all the blood the infected spewed out. But, there's so much of it, it gets to be funny.  The one good horror scene was when Marcy was shaving her legs.  I never got why the dog went crazy and wanted to kill. And they really set Jeff up by making him so selfish, you knew he wouldn't make it. And I guessed what would happen to him and I was right!FINAL VERDICT:  If you like campy, funny "horror" movies, then you may want to watch it. Otherwise, you will think it's too stupid, so don't waste your time.

There isn't much to say about this film beyond, don't bother. It's genuinely a waste of your life.It's your typical teens-go-into-the-woods film but this time, instead of a hockey mask wearing fiend or werewolves etc. etc. it's a flesh eating virus that is on the loose! The only real tension this injects into proceedings is the potential for infection, otherwise it might as well have been any other device to inflict a body count. There is little in the way of character development, plot... they're all cardboard cut-outs who act like total idiots from the start and even worse once things kick off.It's impossible to empathise with any of them, I willed their gruesome demises. If you have to watch this film - do it under the influence of something.

I still have 27 minutes into this movie as I write this review.I watched it because it came up in a list of 'top 10 most gory films of all time', and also because it's Eli Roth who is usually pretty good at gore. For starters, there hasn't been an ounce of gore so far, and I can't believe Roth would make something so boring!if you like dumb teenage 'horror' movies where nothing happens maybe it'll be your thing.

reviews.review_title: A gory and twisted future horror classic
reviews.content: Cabin Fever has all the elements to make it a classic horror film. It takes place in the woods, it involves a group of teenagers, it has a lot of gore, sex, and intentional comedy. It may not sound original, because it is not, but that is the point it is going for. It is paying a homage to all those classic horror films, especially the Evil dead style in the film. It is very satisfying in terms of horror. It might be stupid at the same time, but it is aware of this fact and plays around with all of those horror clichés. It has gruesome, suspenseful, hilarious scenes, sometimes all in one. It achieves so much by trying just to be like films before it, and for that, it is one of the best horror films of the last 10 years.

I'd heard a lot about this movie but wasn't particularly interested in seeing it. When I saw an opportunity, I thought I'd give it a try. 'Cabin Fever' is pretty much what it looks like. A low-budget slasher movie. It pays tribute to other cult hits like 'Friday the 13th', 'Dawn of the Dead' etc. Expectedly, the story is quite silly but the tension builds quite well in the second half hour. In the last half hour, it just comes back to plain silliness (e.g. deer's feet stuck in the windshield). Some of the characters, especially Bert, were irritating to the point of being a moodkiller. The Bert character made me cringe and I couldn't wait for him to be killed off. Unfortunately, it doesn't happen any sooner. The special effects are quite good. The acting is passable (with the exception of whoever plays Bert) for a movie like this. To sum it up and repeat myself, 'Cabin Fever' pretty much is what it looks like, a typical slasher virus flick that is only mildly better than the usual B-grade teen slashers but that isn't saying much.

reviews.review_title: Were they trying to make the worst film ever?
reviews.content: Seriously though. What is this film? I caught one night coming home late from work when I couldn't go to sleep and kept watching out of morbid curiosity that a film could be so bad.This is the most disgusting, vile piece of trash I've ever seen. But upon seeing the ending I burst out laughing with some confusion. Well, it was an attempt at comedy by the 'writers' but why? It was as if they had come to the end of the film and, realising how much of joke the film was they attempted to go out with a laugh as if to say 'it was all in good fun'. Truly bizarre.Blast, not 10 lines. I think they should make an exception with this film, its not worthy of two. Better re-cap the 'plot'. Group of teenagers go into the woods on vacation. A man comes to their cabin late at night and infects them with some flesh-eating disease, turns out it's coming from the river water. They all become infected, and die, gruesomely.Ten lines yet, brilliant. Why can't you vote for zero? Guess that would mess up the rating scale

reviews.review_title: Not as scary as I'd hoped
reviews.content: Well, this movie was not at all good, but it wasn't really bad, either. The plot was OK and kept you wondering who may die next.  However, I was expecting a more "scary" scary movie...instead it was a pseudo-gore fest, and comedic portrayal of Rednecks in the woods.  I suppose the film lost all hope when *****SPOILER***** the main male character turned "postal" and seemed to stop worrying about who he killed next.  I guess the best part of the movie was the very end when we finally get the comment about the "gun" and who it was for...and that yummy lemonade!!

The title sequence and the following 60 seconds are promising. But that's a promise that gets broken.  When all the cabin dwellers seem to be infected, one of the characters says that it feels like being on a plane that you know is going to crash.  I got the same feeling watching this movie.  Poor direction, bad editing.  It had some laughs; it looked good; the music was fantastic.  But the pilot of this plane (Eli Roth) just couldn't keep it in the air.  3 outta 10.

reviews.review_title: A Nasty excuse for a horror film with few-to-no scares, brainless scripting and a screenplay that runs so far out of ideas, it's laughable.
reviews.content: Rather recently, it would seem that Cabin Fever director Eli Roth has become very 'chummy' with fellow American directors Robert Rodriguez and Quentin Tarantino following some work on 2007's 'Grindhouse'. If we take each debut film from these three directors we can see that Tarantino's Reservoir Dogs (1992) could be marked down as genius and Rodriguez's El Mariachi (also 1992) could be marked down as pretty good but over rated. Ten years on from those two and after viewing Roth's debut film Cabin Fever; it would seem Tarantino and Rodriguez see something in him I don't.I watched Roth's second film; 'Hostel', several months ago and I was impressed at how he managed to get across an intense atmosphere of hopelessness and how he managed to play out the final third like it was a gritty revenge film, even though the script left much to be desired given the first third. With Cabin Fever, I appreciate it was his first film but still expected some things that made Hostel watchable to remain with this one. Unfortunately, what was there was minimal. You can't dispute the fact that Eli likes his horror films; he's obviously spent the last ten years watching them and thus manages to reference the 'Evil Dead' films, the 'The Texas Chainsaw Massacre' films and even throws a bit of 'Deliverance' into the mix. What he doesn't do that these three examples did is make it memorable.Through techniques used in Deliverance and The Texas Chain Saw Massacre, we are expected to build up pity, remorse and sympathy to a bunch of teenagers driving to a remote cabin in the woods that isn't really that remote. We are expected to evoke these emotions to characters who like to shoot squirrels, whom like to jump into bed with any one they lay eyes on; characters who smoke drugs and think camping in a wood getting high and laid is 'fun'. Very much like the beginning of Hostel, the build up and script is not great.Forgive me if I'm incorrect but Cabin Fever is listed as a horror film, is it not? I did not actually find myself genuinely scared during this film; nor did I feel the bleak, hopelessness and pity I should've felt towards the lone character towards the end  something I DID feel during Hostel as Paxton acted against all odds to at least TRY and succeed. In Cabin Fever, Roth has done the same thing with the whole 'lone guy in a gore-fest scenario' but I can forgive him for not pulling it off first time round. Along with this and despite the opening credits being the eeriest thing the film possesses, there were one or two jumps thanks to the editing such as the face of the girl following the virus' wrath but these sort of schlock scares are nothing more but a rush of adrenaline.Not only this but the film as a whole towards the end when we're having this attempt of a climax presented to us falls so far short of anything remotely good, it's worrying. The script as well as the actions of the characters are shocking; a character sees a dead body in the water but feels it necessary to climb down a rickety ladder to check anyway  needless to say, they fall in. Also, one character is in possession of a gun for most of the film yet when they go to the wood shed to check something, they leave it on the ground  resulting in having to run back to get it when something happens - brainless, brainless things being presented to us in a laughable attempt to create suspense.If this isn't enough, the film does actually creep over that line of normality  something that keeps films from becoming mere spoofs or shocking displays of film-making. The final fifteen minutes is nuts  it's just pure nuts. Rather than staying cool, the flesh eating virus has obviously eaten away at the lone character's mind as they choose to attack, attack, attack anybody they encounter rather than explain the situation. Screwdrivers, spades, sticks  anything they can get their hands on and would rather murder someone in cold blood than risk stopping and explaining. Even the police start to mistake the whole charade for a killing spree when in reality, it's the virus doing the damage and they know it.With an immediate ending that more resembles a 'Scary Movie' film; Cabin Fever is so lacklustre and silly in everything that it does, in the future people may be looking at Roth as someone who got progressively better rather than a guy who made an immediately impressive impact; alá Tarantino and Rodriguez.

reviews.review_title: So Much Going On, Yet Also So Little
reviews.content: I didn't actually know what the plot was for this before watching it, so when it turned out to be centered on a highly infectious disease that kills you fairly quickly, leading people to not wanna touch each other, I regretted the decision. Like Rob Zombie, it's a decently sincere love letter to the grindhouse genre, but never quite reaches the insane spiritedness of the best of that ilk. A classic almost-awesome roller coaster ride, in which there's both so much going (karate "pancakes", deer attack), yet also so little.

Five college students on break(2 girls and 3 guys)travel to the woods in an isolated area to spend time there in a cabin. Along the way they meet up with a child on a store front bench that bites one of their hands, a rabid-like dog(actually several), and finally a man who is bloodied that asks for help. Not only do these fine young people NOT offer this truly sick man any help but they end up shooting at him, beating him, and finally dousing him with flames. The spread of infectious disease then permeates their thoughts and soon they quarrel amongst themselves and begin to fall apart from within. Such is the basic premise of Cabin Fever. What else do we get? Some adolescent behaviour even for college kids, lots of bloody scenes with skin scratching, some weird surrealistic scenes that seem to make no sense at all, and some humour that doesn't quite work but has promise. I am not sure what the film was trying to do exactly - whether it is to be a horror film or a comedy, but I will go with horror film based on the blood, body count, and grisly gore that abounds not to mention the total lack of humanity the characters lack in the film. I cared for none of them as none of them were characters to care for in any way. The town is populated with stereotypes of backward country bumpkins. The kids are partyers all the way(until they start peeling away). At the core of the film is a neat little idea of the spread of contagions and what psychological effects they might have on an isolated group, but the execution is amateurish. The script is the biggest detractor for me as virtually none of the character motivations make any real sense. Why would good friends turn so quickly on each other with so little initial reasons? Why would they remain in and near the woods so that each one of them will get infected and die? What is the deal with the guy in the bunny suit? Many more question could be posed regarding non-existent logic. Did I like anything about the movie? The acting isn't the worst I have seen. Rider Strong as the principal guy is okay and none of the college kids is horrible in terms of performance. They are nothing great either. Robert Harris and Guiseppe Andrews are real hoots in their scenes as the local color(shopkeeper and deputy respectively). The director Eli Roth has a small role as Grim - a character for no other reason put in other than to escalate the body count and give the director a cameo. Roth has some promise with both the horror elements and the comedic bits. He just needs to finely tune the blend if that is the direction he wishes to pursue. He did direct the "Thanksgiving" segment in Grindhouse and that was one of the funniest little spoofs I have ever seen. Cabin Fever is an earlier work and a work chock full of flaws.

Rider Strong, Jordan Ladd, James DeBello, Cerina Vincent, Joey Kern, Giuseppe Andrews and Richard Fullerton star in this 2002 horror film. This begins with a hermit in the woods getting food for his dog and becomes infected by a lethal flesh-eating virus. We then meet a group of college friends, Paul (Strong), Karen (Ladd), Bert (DeBello), Marcy (Vincent) and Jeff (Kern) who head to a cabin in the woods for a week. Soon, Bert encounters the infected hermit and the nightmare begins when he and the others start catching the disease and fight to stay alive. Andrews plays Sheriff Deputy Winston and Fullerton plays the Sheriff who discover what's happening with them. This isn't a bad horror flick and the make-up effects by K.N.B. are great as usual. The film pays homage to "The Evil Dead," "Outbreak," "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre" and "Night of the Living Dead" with a bit of humor and the director, Eli Roth also makes a cameo as Grim. I recommend this.

I'm surprised that this movie is very popular because it's raw, gory, and violent. I agree with everyone that says that it's already a cult movie. Eli Roth's debut couldn't be better. With this budget he created one of the best horror flicks from the new millennium. The f/x are gruesome but very effective. At first I thought that the death scenes and gore was un called but I couldn't be more wrong. The movie asks for brutality. I liked the plot very much and it is supported by solid acting. Roth knows how to create an intesting, violent movie. Eli Roth has a brilliant future and he demonstrated that he has the capacity to create a good Horror movie. He took the correct influences and he applied his own style. The result is an effective movie that will serve as a reference for future movie making.

I respect any indie filmmaker who gets the job done.  I even respect those on this site who appreciate Roth's efforts to return us to the golden era of gore horror flicks (reminiscent of that wonderful period from 1978 to 1986). But come on ...First of all, there's no real horror.  Nothing is in the woods trying to get these kids.  They're just melting slowly from a flesh-eating disease, and even though they do a few amusing things you never really feel that "what's in the shadows" unease that makes flicks like this so great.  These kids are just waiting to get sick, then waiting to die.  Sure, a few rednecks come hunting them, but there's nothing else to really chase them.  And horror movies need things coming after the victims.  If they plan to be amusing horror films like this, that is, not serious treatments of serious issues like that Dustin Hoffman killer virus flick.Second of all, there are two many scenes set up to be funny that bog the narrative down: a running motif with a horny deputy who looks like Brandon Cruz on "The Courtship of Eddie's Father"; Eli Roth's cameo as a pot-smoking hiker; the ridiculous joke about the old guy at the shop who may or may not be a racist ... whatever.Finally, the film telegraphs its best moments too much.  For instance, at one point, a character realizes he has survived, and walks through the cabin pumping his fists and shouting, "I made it!  I made it!"  Now, we all know these rednecks are in the woods with guns, so if you've seen "Night of the Living Dead" you know what's going to happen here.  It just annoys you because you're waiting for it, but Roth treats us to about half and hour of this kid shouting, "I made it!  I made it!"  Long set-up for the punchline, pal.And I'll tell you another thing ... ZZZZZZZZZ[This comment has been discontinued because the author has fallen asleep while watching "Cabin Fever"]

reviews.review_title: Liked the title, enjoyed the movie
reviews.content: Here is a movie that is dealing with a flesh-eating disease caused by a pollutant. It sounds familiar, but that's what "Cabin Fever" is about. I liked the setting of the movie, and the cast was great too. Cheryl Ladd's daughter Jordan, very beautiful. The others very cool looking as well. I liked the part where they go to the general store and they see the rifle on the rack, and the old man used a racial slur that angered the teen couples. Don't blame them whatsoever. When they go out into the cabins. The movie title proves its point, but in a different way. Find the source of the pollution way easy, but how would a corpse would cause such damage? For the people at the general store, I sure was fooled. The old man wasn't as racist as anybody thought he was. The African-American travelers were into hunting as well as anyone. And he was talking hip-hop like, he was cool. Depsite what went on in the movie, it was very watchable. I wish the critics were easy on this film. What's their problem? I've never complained about it. It was great! Rating 3 out of 5 stars.

reviews.review_title: . I want more like this film gushing blood vomit fest .
reviews.content:
I kept reading about members of this thread talking about Eli Roth and the AMC s Eli Roth's History of Horror. I have not seen any of his films . I decided to check out ' Cabin Fever ' . I know I am probably the only person in this thread to not see it as I always thought I look like garbage . But since I started following this thread I have expanded my Horror repertoire. I was right 'Cabin Fever' was garbage . Well not so fast . I was bored with the lame acting and was suffering the Net as I watched . But about 2/3rd through the film . Eli Roth really stared ti ramp up the entire film by like 100% . He introduced a black sheep deputy sheriff who was hilarious. Spoiler but not to bad . At one point the deputy sheriff gets a call from the 'Sheriff' asking if he had found the crazy party in the woods at this point the deputy sheriff had found the crazy party and was in full participation drinking beer and smoking weed instead of busting up the party. Funny as hell. That when I shut off my PC and was engaged . Then 'Cabin Fever' went for a crap film to a blood bath of gore and black comedy . The red necks out for revenge was graet. The weird kid that bits " Pancake's pancake's what a trip. The infection that ramps up and spreads killing in glorious blood soaking vomit splashing gore fest . Bottom line the film did a 180 and it turn out to be very satisfying. And the bluegrass music at the end of film was the cherry on top. I want more like this film gushing blood vomit fest .
First hour 2/10 Last 32 minutes 10/10'Cabin Fever' 8/10 order it on Blu-ray for my collection.

Hello, world ! an interesting plot, variation about the young-squad-in-a-cabin-lost-in-the-woods... Seems familiar ? Yes, of course ! Evil dead, friday the 13th and so on comes in mind, and this one is as good and as gory as any other.Quite good ! Beyond the cliche there's some ideas.  No slasher, no monster and no demon, but an unknown flesh eating virus. and the acting is good. Does it make difference ? It's up to you. If you are looking after a good teen-gore movie and have seen Evil Dead too many times, you could try this one. I won't dare to say it's refreshing, but... let's say it does something new with old ideas, and it is not disappointing.After reading many comments on this movie I wonder why some people are so upset by the very tame 'sex scenes'... Seems it is alright to show people shooting, killing, and butchering each others, but a couple in bed or the seeing of a pair of tits is unbearable, even in such a gory movie ! Sure, children wouldn't watch it, BECAUSE of the sex scenes :-)The DVD contains some bonus. Not really interesting, but some people do like bonus... some cartoon, the kung-fu kid and the usual 'making off' or 'behind the scenes' uninteresting stuffing. THis too is amazing. I read more about the bonus on the DVD than about the movie itself.I personally don't buy a DVD for the bonus but for the jacket. And it is nice with a skull hologram and good graphics.

reviews.review_title: ELI ROTH'S DEBUT FILM IS A BLOOD SOAKED MASTERPIECE!!!
reviews.content: I have absolutely loved Eli Roth's now cult classic CABIN FEVER, ever since i first saw it in the cinema on a rainy Autumn afternoon & i just loved everything about it. Actually it's always been a favourite Horror movie of mine & one of my most watched films ever!!!A very very rare thing about this great film is the bunch of "kids" are a group i really liked, except maybe "Bert" lol he was an idiot but funny. I really like that group in Cabin Fever as most, or nearly all Horror films have a bunch of kids/ teens that you hate & really want them to die except maybe like one person!!!Eli Roth also served us the best possible mix of Horror & Comedy, so we are shocked at the gore but can laugh at the kids reactions or over panicked state, it's the best blend I've ever seen in a Horror-comedy.It's now 2018 & i still think Cabin fever is Roth's best film, everything is just great Horror fun with excellent performances & a group of kids you actually like & want to survive.Yep back in 2002 when Cabin fever came out it was a huge Horror hit & made on a tiny budget but Eli pulled it off as a fun throwback to the crazy, silly & funny 80's Horror flicks!!! It's pure late night entertainment!!!The cast is excellent especially the underrated "RIDER STRONG" who really is great as the lead in this film, he's the guy you really want to survive & Rider gives a great performance like a young "Bruce Campbell" did in the first 1981 "Evil Dead" he's that good in this & infact Rider Strong became a go to guy for lots of low budget Horror movies after Cabin fever, some are good like the terrifying Borderland (2007) & the fun Tooth & Nail (2007) & some that was terrible like Pulse 3 (2008) & Cabin fever 2 (2009) both terrible lol but another good Horror Thriller flick Rider starred in was Death Valley (2004) that was a good film so He became a new Horror icon in a way like how the brilliant Tom Atkins started out!!!Cabin Fever is just so ridiculously entertaining & bloody good fun. I would put Cabin Fever up there as one of the all-time best Sleep over horror's ever!!! If ever there was a fun bloody shocker to have a good time viewing with a bunch of friends on a Saturday night sleep over then this is definitely it.Cabin Fever is equally as great as the "classic" Horror's of the past such as those that inspired this movie such as Evil Dead (1981),The Thing (1982), Texas chainsaw massacre (1974), Deliverance (1972) & many more that's how BRILLIANT Cabin Fever is & how important this is to the Horror genre!!!!This has become one of my favourite "Horror" films of all time & one of my personal favourite movies of all time!!!"ELI ROTH" completely gets WHAT we all love in Horror, that balance of deranged humour & gory scares & because Roth was a Horror film geek before becoming a director he so knows what horror fans wanna see, he nailed it with Cabin fever & he won't ever beat the impact this had on the Horror genre at the time!!! Thank you Roth for being a perfectionist & that's why his Cabin fever looks beautiful & not just a cheap looking indie film.Cabin Fever has that proper vintage throwback feel of filthy-nasty-savage 70's & early 80's trashy grindhouse cinema but made with more skill & style than those made back then.I can't praise the excellent performance by "Rider Strong" enough as his "Paul" character goes through hell & goes from average timid teen to savage survival Hero, through the movie his character is the best written & Rider gives it his all with alot of emotion, heart & brings it up way above average for a low budget Horror!!! Infact Paul is one of the best written Horror heroe's in the genre & to me he's as good as "Bruce Campbell" in the first "Evil Dead" as both characters are put in similar survival circumstances & go from average joe to badass hero.Also "Rider Strong" at the time of getting the role in "Cabin fever" really wanted to get as far away from his wholesome wimpy heartthrob character from the t.v series "Boy Meets World" & that was a great move for him as here's this young guy from the world of sickly sweet "Disney" series to a bloody gruesome gritty splatter flick, where he has sex & kills rednecks & gets absolutely covered in blood!!! A great part for him as the audience gets a nice comforting familiar feel seeing him in the movie, but he is becomes a savage killer in order to survive, he was perfectly cast in my opinion.It's a shame "Rider Strong" didn't become a breakout star after "Cabin fever" as he proved he is a great actor & can be a great unexpected lead.Well in my opinion he made one of the best Horror movie hero characters come to life from the pages of Eli Roth's debut masterpiece classic & roth has still never done better!!!Eli Roth does know the Horror genre & his Cabin fever is a brilliant homage to those old school 70's & 80's glory days of Horror like i said & it was so refreshing when it came out & with that decent cast!!!Also another excellent performance is from "Joey Kern" as Jeff that's my 2nd fave performance after "Strong's" Performance.My favourite scene is the Awesome sequence where "Paul" savagely kills the three rednecks that come to the Cabin to kill the teens, it's such an exciting,intense & bloody scene, just amazing!!!Cabin fever is a great Horror film that is gross out & fun & very violent but with great characters & a sense of fun, the cabin looks beautiful & old & full of history like the cool "Evil Dead" cabin, you feel there's a deep history behind that lonely old Cabin in the middle of the woods!!!The flesh eating virus is terrifying & all too real, the local rednecks are scary but all done with that 80's sense of fun & when there is some very serious scenes the mood & atmosphere is perfect!!! Eli Roth just gets it all right in this movie, his other films are very good but it's his Debut that is the "Classic" or "Masterpiece" of his career.There's so many good elements to this movie it's hard to name them all & so many nice little gems of scenes & imagery, like the Fall setting with all the crispy leaves falling & the ground covered with the colours of Autumn it looks beautiful!!!Also the music score by Nathan Barr is amazing!!!I am a "Rider Strong" fan because of his excellent performance as "Paul" in Cabin fever!!! A Nostalgic Horror CLASSIC to me & one I've watched hundreds of times & it never gets boring & that's the sign of a classic film!!!Also it's a perfect Horror to watch over the Halloween season as it's set in the lovely Autumn time & the over all tone is very primal survival Thriller & bloody virus body Horror with some humour & heart full of 80's Horror fun.The people that hate on this excellent film are the ones who really don't get that demented blood soaked comedy Horror from the 80's but i do & i loved it probably even more than most Horror's from that era!!!Cabin fever is still director Eli Roth's best film & it came out way back in 2002 but that's how good & how much fun it is as a proper well made bloody survival Horror film with some funny moments but at it's heart it's a proper Horror movie loving crafted like the one's we all grew up on so thank you Eli Roth.Cabin fever is in my top 5 fave Horror movies of all time & it's genuinely one of my top 10 fave movies of all time.Perfect late night entertainment & as said, definitely one of the best Horror choices at a sleepover it's that good.

This dreck is simply awful.  There is no other way to describe it.  Scary? Not in this lifetime.  Suspenseful?  Suspense depends on the audience being able to follow the plot, of which there is none here.  As for the Peter Jackson reviews?  He must have this film confused with another.  The one star?  IMDB will not permit less than one star, and because of this, I grant it to actress Cerina Vincent, who never fails to find a reason to lose all her clothing.

Here we go again into idiocy and mediocrity, or so I thought with my first viewing of "Cabin Fever," another tailor-made, teen horror flick ready for consumption by the braindead, MTV-energized masses of blood/sex-crazed adolescents.Five friends have (unwisely) chosen to venture into the woods for a week-long vacation. They end up spending their time in one of those big, spooky cabins that brings back memories of another classic horror film that took place in the woods ("The Evil Dead," anyone?). As you would know it, the friends all start coming down with the symptoms of an unknown contagion, and alas, they realize that they've all been infected with a flesh-eating virus, which causes all kinds of nasty scabs and copious amounts of blood to form on the skin through no visible wounds. The friends all naturally start to panic ("Don't touch him/her!" or "I am getting the hell out of here!") and pretty much everything starts to come apart between them (pretty much like society would if there really was a deadly virus on the loose; more on this later)."Cabin Fever" took a lot of people by surprise last September. I noticed that the film was completed in 2002 but its release was delayed until last year, probably because of the very real and scary S.A.R.S. outbreaks in Asia and Canada. The movie itself has quite a lot of tension, shockingly gross special effects (watch out for that bathtub shaving scene), and some very bizarre dark humor, mostly involving the locals. For a horror film, I wouldn't recommend showing this one to the kiddies as they might be frightened by some of the horrific things that they see on screen.What I picked up from the film is that it attempts to be a parable on one of the great scare stories of our time  the unknown, out-of-control virus. It works on the premise that somewhere out there, maybe in the forest or a top-secret lab, lurks a virus so deadly that if it got out, would unleash hell on earth.To further deliver that terrifying notion, the friends pretty much serve as a stable society that's about to become very "unstable." ENTER: a dissident, a catalyst; something to throw this society into a panic that it would eventually fall into and never recover  in this case, that catalyst is a lethal virus that to quote Dustin Hoffman from 1995's "Outbreak," "Is one-billionth our size and it's killing us." This formerly stable society starts to crumble under its own paranoia and fear as the virus spreads and kills whomever/whatever it comes into contact with; the friends (society) start to become suspicious of one another, instead of trying to work together to stamp the virus out. And well, it is anarchy from that point on... ...And the ending further proves that anarchy will reign supreme if a sequel is ever produced.

reviews.review_title: There made little to funny to take serious
reviews.content: I thought it was time to re-watch this,as there are another two upcoming movies for this series.I have not seen this movie for years but i don't remember the acting being really bad the last time i saw it , The written for this felt all over the place but I did enjoy the main plot of the movie,it wasn't just another bunch of collage kids going into woods and getting killed by a mask killer but this is was some kind of infection that peels your skin off.Which i thought was really good idea, it could have been better if didn't have to many funny moment in this movie.The ending of the movie was really funny and it as it wss nod to The Night of the living dead ending!5 out of 10

Truly one of the weirdest films i've ever encountered, Cabin Fever starts out strong, but ultimately feels too messy and too uneven to go any of the bold places it tries to go. The film is a weird combination of zombie flick, comedy, horror, isolation, parody, and so much more- it's hard to understand what they were exactly going for while making it. I enjoyed the beginning of the film, an amusing and obvious tribute to films like Evil Dead but as it goes on, it takes itself to a strangely dramatic and underwhelming place. The acting is all over the place, the look of the film is super 2000's- whether that's a good thing or not I don't know- but the fun little soundtrack at hand proves to be the only thing along with the look that the film is consistent with. The pacing can be a drag, the last 15 minutes are certainly a step in the right direction, but in the end Cabin Fever is too much of a mixed bag to be worth watching- and too all over the place to be enjoyable.
My Rating: 5/10

reviews.review_title: Boredom will kill you faster than the flesh-eating virus...
reviews.content:
Cabin Fever covers the predictable misadventures of five thoroughly unlikeable twenty-somethings as they combat an esoteric virus that consumes flesh at a variable rate depending on... something. Usually movies like this have archetype prankster and archetype jerk. Watch as Cabin Fever combines them to make Bert the jerky prankster! From the start of the film you will wonder what this character is doing there. He has no redeeming qualities and seems the perfect mood killer for a couples get away. No amount of suspension of belief will allow you to justify the rock bottom stupid choices these characters make. The film just drags on and on with its lackluster cinematography and plot twists (if you can call them twists). Generally predictable except for the leaping conclusions of illogical action these dunderheads periodically make. Guaranteed to give the audience several groaning moments in a bad way.
***possible spoilers****
Where does the virus come from? We're never told or at least I didn't pick up on it.Notice the virus doesn't *actually* kill anyone? Everyone is killed by someone else. Perhaps this is supposed to be the black humor I heard about?
Pancakes?!!? What was up with that? Perhaps it was explained in the DVD extras. I was too numb at the end to do anything but hit OPEN on my player and get that disc back to the rental hut quick. It was a very annoying scene regardless.Burning this movie would be an insult to fire.0/10

reviews.review_title: This didn't receive great reviews but I sure had fun watching it
reviews.content: I liked this, granted it had its moments of weirdness. A real mix of horror, comedy and gross-out gore but it worked for me. Its a bit of a throwback film to the chillers of the 1970's, cliché in its initial set up following a group of college friends who embark on a last hurrah after college vacation deep into the mountains to spend a week at a remote cabin.They meet several strange/bizarre townsfolk along the way and then on their first night encounter a man who is "sick" his flesh literally melting off his face as he vomits blood all over their vehicle. In trying to get rid of the man they accidentally set him on fire and he runs off into the bushes. Before long our group starts to show signs of a horrible flesh eating disease, with the fear of contagion driving them to turn on each other.This didn't receive great reviews but I had helluva fun watching it. It was disgusting, disturbing, funny, full of WTF moments, bizarre characters and left me afraid to drink the water as well as seriously wondering about the motivation of (the director) and Kung-Fu kid yelling 'PANCAKE". 11/1/15

***SPOILERS****personally, i'm more of an underground horror fan, preffering jap/euro/korean splatter flicks to what passes as horror today, but i was somewhat pleasantly suprised by this movie. to be sure it wasn't great by any stretch, but it had all the decent elements of a typical horror movie especially by todays american, pop-culture standards.***major spoiler here*** not very gory but there were a few decent splatter scenes. what really impressed me most is that all of the main characters were killed off. this doesn't happen in many american horror films and even though there is a vein of comedy running throughout this film it still remained relatively dark in it's subject matter.though some people will find the reference in the beginning to african-americans offensive, the last scene is absolutely hilarious, and james debello is someone to watch for in the teen comedy genre.  if you like his goofy performance in this film, rent "100 Girls" if you haven't already seen it. Not a horror movie, but genuinely funny as an "American Pie"-esque teen film.  7/10 for new horror movies.

reviews.review_title: Note To Cerina Vincent: Call Me!
reviews.content: As a borderline hypochondriac myself, I must confess that the thought of necrotizing fasciitis--more popularly known as the flesh-eating virus--gives me the heebie-jeebies. (And for those viewers who think this disease is some kind of joke or urban myth, all I can say is, take a look at some of the hideous pictures that the Wikipedia site displays in its article for this subject!) Thus, I just knew that the 2003 film "Cabin Fever"--in which a group of teens rents an idyllic retreat in an autumnal setting but soon contracts this dreaded illness from a wandering bum--would be a fairly intense experience for me. And, thanks to the great work done by co-writer, producer and director Eli Roth, as well as his quintet of young actors, man, was I ever right!In the film, as our five teens drive to their wilderness retreat, David Hess' song "Wait for the Rain" is heard playing on their car stereo; the same song that had presaged the doom of the two young gals in Wes Craven's repugnant "Last House on the Left," and a sure sign, with its memorable line "and the road leads to nowhere," that trouble is brewing. (If I were to ever hear this tune played when I was outside, I would probably immediately rush back home to huddle indoors!) And for the five teens--three guys, played by Rider Strong, James De Bello and Joey Kern, and two truly beautiful young women, played by Jordan Ladd and Cerina Vincent--that trouble erupts fairly quickly. To the film's great credit, these five are all likable and differentiated types, and their reactions to their horrible health crisis--only compounded when the whacky locals decide they must be wiped out--are credible and realistic. "Cabin Fever" begins on a humorous note but quickly gets a lot more serious, only shading back toward levity, unbecomingly and ironically, in its final few minutes. Besides the Craven film mentioned above, the film tips its hat in homage to such horror classics as "The Texas Chain Saw Massacre" and, given the final fate of the Joey Kern character, "Night of the Living Dead." First-time director Roth, two years before working on his first "Hostel" film, displays great flair and imagination here; it is at times difficult to believe that "Cabin Fever" was his first go behind the camera! The film's special FX are just fine, though the gross-out images here are far less disturbing than those Wiki shots I mentioned earlier. The monster that Jordan Ladd's character becomes is perhaps the most shocking, especially when shown, contrapuntally in flashback, next to her gorgeous former self. "Cabin Fever" boasts many impressive and memorable scenes, especial standouts, for this viewer, being the gruesome spectacle of Cerina shaving her legs in a bathtub, that mentally disturbed kid screaming "Pancakes" as he sinks his teeth into one of the teen's hands, and those "Christian" rednecks coming after the De Bello character with their shotguns. In all, the film IS an extremely intense yet enjoyable experience, and a truly superior modern-day horror wringer. It was hugely profitable on its initial release, and deservedly so. To end on a lighter note, that Wiki article tells us that those prone to necrotizing fasciitis include people who are immunocompromised, diabetics, those with malignancies or chronic systemic diseases, and those who abuse drugs and alcohol. Care to take a guess as to which group our quintet of teens falls into?

Here is an exciting movie, with a good story, some really twisted humour, and plenty of chills and thrills.  I haven't been this satisfied by a scary movie in a while, and everything is just perfectly set up.  We get some really exciting jolts, and unexpected twists.  I couldn't help comparing it "28 Hours" and thinking how much better this one was.  Go in, and get ready for some serious fun.
I had watched in tamil dubbed...It was not great but still feel good horror movie... Thnks for tamilrockers to introduced this movie..

reviews.review_title: I would like to see what the edited version looks like.
reviews.content: This movie made little sense and followed no real sensible plot from the beginning up to where the first camper gets the "evil" flesh eating virus. I am only including this part of the movie in my review because that is as far as I could stand it.  At this point I turned the movie off.  The actors wandered around the movie acting in no sensible pattern.  Doing things that made no sense and then stumbling off to the next head scratching scene.  The most notable ignorant character was played by James DeBello.  Who wandered around shop lifting, shoting a gun at squirels, and for some reason lighting fires in the middle of the woods only to walk off while they blazed. ?????2 out of a 10.

reviews.review_title: Cabin Fever is full of references from big horror movies and try to inovate, however the cast and the screenplay make an experience difficult to watch
reviews.content: Cabin Fever is one of those works that, despite the poor publicity at the time of its release, became known basically thanks to comments made by fans of the genre. But pay attention, despite the good reviews, this is a film that probably won't please all horror film lovers.Director/Screenwriter/Producer/Actor Eli Roth was an unknown name before the success of O Albergue (Hostel, 2005). The film caught the attention of audiences and critics by presenting a very interesting horror plot that was mixed with strong scenes of explicit violence.Perhaps making a comparison is the best way to define Hell's Hut. But it won't be with O Albergue that this parallel will be drawn, as both productions are quite different. In fact, Cabin Fever can be considered an Evil Dead (1982) of the 21st century and that definition is enough to get any fan excited. The plot created and conducted by Eli Roth is quite simple. A group of college friends is taking a break from school to travel and spend a few days on a farm in the woods. Before writing any other word referring to the synopsis, it is already possible to imagine what lies ahead, right? Exactly, the group will face an evil force (here there are variations: assassin, spirit, nature phenomenon, chemical leak, etc) and each of the characters will fight to survive.In Cabin Fever, what stands out is the way of narrating and not the story itself. With good doses of gore, Eli Roth practically rehashes a well-known plot through small details that end up making all the difference to the final product. First of all, Eli takes the elements so common to the genre and leverages them to the fullest. As an example, we can mention the convenience store that students stop at the beginning of the film. Every horror movie worth its salt (or not) has one or a gas station and the employees of these establishments are beyond strangers. Because the Cabin Fever store is not far behind and still manages to have the most bizarre characters that have ever been seen by fans. And this is just the beginning. Law enforcement officers are usually prominent figures in these productions, but the one created by Eli is at least an attraction on its own. Thin, slight and more interested in sex than in keeping the peace, he ends up drawing attention precisely because of this set of "qualities". In addition, Cabin Fever is also a dish for admirers of the traditional bloodbath, popularized precisely by the Evil Dead. This virus is quite strong, which provides some scenes capable of making more sensitive people sick to their stomachs.However, it is important to make it clear that, like Evil Dead, Cabin Fever was also produced with a very simple budget when compared to productions of the genre. Of course, little money has never served as an excuse to make good films as a short budget can lead creative filmmakers to find creative solutions for their films. However, despite the effort, some scenes from Hut of Hell are clearly lacking in more features, but Eli Roth holds the camera well and finds solutions that, if not perfect, are within acceptable limits.Despite all the good points presented, it is important to make an observation regarding this production. Once again, we are facing a film that is aimed at a specific audience within the genre itself. Thus, if you consider The Shining (The Shining, 1980) as the great classic of the genre, you probably won't like Cabin Fever. In fact, they are different productions and have their own goals for each of their specific viewers. The film's story is worthy of saying that it is trash but that wins at an interesting point: instead of having a demon as a villain, he preferred a more real parameter, the film's villain is a disease, a kind of deadly virus that has consequences catastrophic such as high fever, migraine, delirium, vomiting blood (which is not little) and loss of skin. The script, it was to be expected, respects the norms of this type of genre such as scares, blood, sex, macabre characters, good doses of scares and a lot of violence. As the script is a trash movie, we can say it's bad, but we forget this detail with a highly ironic and apocalyptic ending.Cabin Fever is full of references from big horror movies such as Evil Dead, The Texas Chainsaw Massacre, and crude zombie movies from the 80s. Fan-to-fans" than an attempt to innovate the genre. You can't criticize him, just get into the movie and have fun! It's even interesting to see the movie because it doesn't have a villain of its own. It's just the disease, something a little exaggerated but banal. This is the kind of movie that for you to watch, you should follow this reasoning: "If he doesn't even take himself seriously, why should I?" It's a cheap diversion that many will enjoy because it revives that nostalgia for the 80's trash that we were so much amused by. As a curiosity, in 2016 the film got a remake produced by Roth himself and interestingly, using the same script as the one in question here, changing only a few details to update the story.

reviews.review_title: Cabin Fever fails horribly at rekindling the old 80's style horror feel.
reviews.content: After reading reviews before this film was released, I was somewhat excited by the premise that finally a director was going to take horror back to the glory days of the early 80's. I was SADLY mistaken.Cabin Fever was a horrible attempt by Director Eli Roth, and just a downright bad movie. I felt embarrassed and foolish upon leaving the theater. Old school 80's films like Friday the 13th should take Cabin Fever as a smack in the face and a childish insult for even trying to associate itself with that era.  The ridiculous humor was much too far over the top, and the plot and believability of this film was simply a joke. The ending of this film, with the surviving actor proudly proclaiming that "he made it" then only to be eliminated was just to much to take and a sour and ridiculous end to an already terrible film. Then to top matters off, the credits roll to a scene featuring some comical Hillbilly's with totally over the top country violin music playing in the background that begs you to ask yourself "what in the world I'm I doing in this theater watching this disgusting dog poop of a mess". I feel horrible...and should be slapped for ever stepping foot into the theater in the first place.Let this be known, I absolutely love "GOOD or even TOLERABLE" horror film, and Cabin Fever is a disgrace to the industry.

The seemingly endless parade of disappointing horror films continues, with this mess of a film stacking up somewhere between "House of 1000 (er, make it 7) Corpses" and "Freddy vs. Jason vs. Monica Keena's Cleavage". Swinging wildly between parody and gross-out movie, the film starts promisingly with a tacked-on credits sequence that sets up a foreboding mood entirely absent from the rest of the film. The movie is populated with dozens of stupid throwaway characters (which all but scream "I went to high school with the director and I'm really fun at parties!") and the last 5 minutes lapses bizarrely into a "Naked Gun" movie. There are a few icky gross-out moments, but nothing even remotely scary -- imagine a horror film of someone sneezing on a crowded bus for 90 minutes and you've pretty much got it. The words of the day are: silly, pretentious, uneven, and dull. Rent "Wrong Turn" instead.

This movie was basically a pile of crap!!!. The characters were awful who never gave a hint of acting ability! All of the cast are basically a bunch of inept dorks who don't appeal to 80's horror movie fans.It was a bunch of brain dead early 30 somethings pretending to be about 20!!! I could tell it was gonna be a pile of crap from the 1st 2 minutes of the movie. Lame script and even worse AHEM 'jokes'."Cabin Fever" didn't pay homage to previous horror films, it just blatantly ripped them off. And it didn't even have the imagination to add a twist...it simply ripped off the ending of "The Night of the Living Dead." This is a poor effort, but I suppose if you are hard up for horror and have VERY low standards, you might get some thrills out of it. As for me, I thought this was a very poor movie and it barely kept me awake.So i give this 2/10 and thats being kind for this pile of donkey shat!

There were so many directions this movie could have gone... unfortunately I guess the director was more interested in putting himself in a totally un-needed character to go in any of these directions.***SPOILERS***I don't usually yell at the characters in movies, but these kids are possibly the dumbest teens i've ever seen in horror. I mean, you roll into town you've never been in, and what's the first thing these kids do? P*** off the shop keepers... possibly the only link to the outside world since no one in the county has a phone.In every situation the kids did the exact wrong thing to do. Like, having unprotected sex while the object of your desires is rotting away in the tool shed. (did the thought of the blood borne virus suddenly escape you?) Or while running for help you stop to ogle the naked woman on the bed, and then act surprised when her husband waves his shotgun in your face and says you can't use the phone.Other than the rage-inducing teens, there were many unanswered questions... like what the hell was in the "kit" that the rednecks brought to the cabin? Why did we need like a minute of slow motion kung fu before the freaky little kid bites the infected teen? Why did the germ freak who didn't catch the virus go BACK TO THE CABIN WHERE IT STARTED?***END SPOILERS***The only thing that (sorta) kept me from demanding my money back was the cute little extras on the DVD. But how sad is it when a crappy claymation short is more entertaining than the full lenght feature? Plus the "chick-vision" in the extras was cute. Every time a tense situation came up, a pair of hands came up and covered the screen, not unlike a scared young girl. Heh heh.If you insist on seeing this movie, have someone else pay for it. You'll feel ripped off unless you're under 16 and don't know what decent horror is.

I went into this movie thinking that it would be a good story. And it could have been, really! But in actuality, this was one of the worst movies I have ever seen. It was boring, the amount of swearing was ridiculous, and I really didn't need to see the implication of a girl sticking her finger up her boyfriend's butt! Just a horrible, stupid, terrible movie!!!!

reviews.review_title: The Bear Jew's first feature film
reviews.content: First of all, if you haven't seen Inglourious Basterds you better see it as soon as possible, it's a great masterpiece from Tarantino. Now, in that film we have the proof that Eli Roth ain't a really fine actor but in that film he is, as the Bear Jew, simply as cool as hell and for my money that performance is the best Roth has made in his career so far. Of course I'm not just counting his acting credits but also his directing credits. Last night I finally saw Roth's first feature, the 2002 Cabin Fever, then I can report that none of Roth's three films (Hostel and Hostel Part II are the others) really impressed me. But I must say I actually liked the Hostel films (but certainly I'm not a fan) but this one was simply not good. I'm not a huge horror connoisseur (yet!) but recently I saw, and loved, Sam Raimi's The Evil Dead then I can begin my "real" comment of Cabin Fever by saying that in it we have basically the same premise of The Evil Dead: college students travel to have a very nice time in a cabin in the middle of the woods. It would be sort of unnecessary to compare Cabin Fever with The Evil Dead simply because, to begin, here we don't have, between other stuff, Bruce Campbell so I will try to stop writing about The Evil Dead or other movie aside of Roth's debut here. Anyway Cabin Fever has certain moments that by mentioning them I will try to let you know my points: first of all, we have five main characters, the sort of hero and his love interest of many time (Rider Strong and Jordan Ladd), the egocentric popular student and his girlfriend who at one point will realize that her boyfriend is an as***** (Joey Kern and Cerina Vincent) and the goofy friend that looks a bit like Vince Vaughn (James DeBello). At one point (one of the moments that will help me) these college friends meet a stoner with a dog (one of the two cameos of Eli Roth) and there's this part when the stoner ask them if he can join their reunion around the bonfire, the answer is a no but as soon as the stoner shows them his weed and says the classic "well I will have to smoke this whole weed alone" as soon as the friends change their minds and invite Eli Roth's character to the reunion around the bonfire. My point: Cabin Fever is not as funny as it wanted, while sometimes James DeBello's character delivered laughs the funny side of the film is mostly the type of stupid and not cool (take for instance one of the last jokes that is about finding the real meaning of the "it's for the ni******"). At one point Joey Kern's character, the blonde and egocentric one, realizes that all of his friends and his girlfriend are now dead. Is a scene that resumes a character and that works really well, is Kern's character happy, happy because he made it, he was the only one that survived, sure his friends and girlfriend died but he is more than glad because after all he is alive. Probably that scene was the one I liked the most in terms of "f***** up horrific moments" but certainly that says only bad things about Cabin Fever. The main issue deals with the main characters getting very tense after this and that happened and in the end there are not really great and original horrific things, maybe the end is a bit cool but frankly I don't see why Quentin Tarantino and Peter Jackson can watch the Bear Jew's debut film over and over again, and this time I'm a 100 percent sure I didn't missed something!PS: I was looking forward for the "Pancakes" famous scene and while the kid throwing kicks and stuff was nice the whole "subplot" with the kid's dad seeking for revenge was as unnecessary and bad as that annoying "party" cop (well maybe the cop was a bit funny in his first appearance)!

Some college students decide to spend their vacation in a strange house in a strange forest. Then, some weirdo guy shows up and their car breaks. I know it may not sound particularly original..."Cabin Fever" is one of those movies that you know everyone will end up dead-- and maybe one of them "makes it" in the end. The actors aren't known, but their acting is decent and enough for this kind of film. Hot girls, pretty guys and the party is ready. Direction, along with editing, deliver a scary and tense atmosphere that will probably frighten and entertain you. Some scenes are really agonizing to see, such as the bath's -- I confess I put my hand on my eyes in this part. The 93 minutes of running seem to go very quickly and the writer doesn't delay the story; things happen all the time. My only complaints are that sometimes it gets too gory for my young stomach, and the bizarre ending. Aside that, it is all that it promises.

reviews.review_title: Good Entry For A First Timer
reviews.content: Here is our buddy Eli Roth, the new whiz kid in horror (or so I've been told) I figured I'd give more then one of his films a chance (second chance actually). Cabin Fever stars Boy Meets World favourite Shaun Hunter, or by his real name Rider Strong, which is also a good porn name. Also, Jordan Ladd plays his girlfriend. Along with their friends they go up to a Cabin to celebrate graduating. Things go bad when one gets a flesh eating disease and the friends turn on each other for survival.Sound familiar? Well, it's basically a remake of Evil Dead, with changes here and there. Instead of the undead, it's simply a flesh eating disease. There you go, same movie. The big difference is Evil Dead is pure genius, where Cabin Fever is a poor imitator.Why doesn't Cabin Fever play out like a decent homage to older scary horror films, because it's tries to be better then what it actually is. Cabin Fever is a B horror film that thinks it's actually scary. I'm sorry, but it isn't.One main problem is the atmosphere. What made Evil Dead scary was that the cabin was in the middle of nowhere. They were stuck and had no place to go. Here, there is a town not ten minutes away. Get in car, go to town, or better yet go home, movie over. I just couldn't get into it knowing that salvation was minutes away. The suspense is all gone.If it's not ripping off Evil Dead (Roth can call it homage all he wants, but it was a rip-off) then it's Night Of The Living Dead. Straight up, one character dies exactly the same way as another in the original Night of the Living Dead. When a film has a homage, there is a wink and a nod, Cabin Fever never winks or nods, he straight up steals. Not to mention half the audience watching this probably doesn't even know what films it is 'homaging'.Now I know Roth loves horror films and I know his intentions might have been good, but it just doesn't come across in the same manner, to me at least. the guy isn't a bad director, he just needs better, more original material.I enjoyed the make-up though. That was probably the most scary thing. I do give credit for what he accomplish though. First film and all, much better then his later efforts with Hostel. Cabin Fever is something that I might like years later, which is why this rating is really generous.Also...pancakes?

Oh wow, just how boring is this film?  total stupid bunch of Amercian kids renting out a log cabin where one by one they die. Cabin looked a bit like the one in Evil Dead (which is a great movie) but the film would have been more interesting if they just torched the cabin and danced naked round it instead of pure rubbish mindless running around and dying!If you do decide to waste your money on this then please laugh loud when a stupid little boy (who looks like a girl as has long hair) shouts "Pancakes" and starts performing some BAD flying kicks for no reason at all! 
Who let this director loose???

This movie delivered the GOODS.  I liked the way that baseball hat wearing dude kept screaming CUSS WORDS.  That guy CUSSED BIG TIME.  I also thought that transexual on the PORTCH was odd.  He/she was super good at doing KARATE and screaming about PANCAKES.  That kid was odd.
I also liked the scene where the DEPUTY kept obsessing on partying.  That was FUNNY.  I liked that DUDE in detroit ROCK city.  That BLOND dude was a woosey boy.  He super dissed his girlfriend just to make sure he wouldn't get sick.  I wonder if Bruce Campbell was payed HOMAGE to when it showed the kid with BLOOD ALL OVER HIS FACE.  I was wondering why the kid didn't wipe the BLOOD off his face?And what was the DEAL with the blond chick looking like the COVER of EVIL DEAD TWO??  I mean, TEETH and NO LIPS???  haha!!!!

reviews.review_title: The worst movie in the history of movies
reviews.content: This movie makes "Freddie Got Fingered" look Oscar-worthy. No one working on this movie or acting in it should be allowed to ever work in Hollywood again. And that's an understatement.

saw this once before way back when and remember enjoying it. A lot of people don't like the work of Eli Roth. I don't think he is an amazing director or anything but I did enjoy Knock Knock and Hostel immensely. His films are often stupidly cheesy and full of graphic violence but I can appreciate that, the lowest form of entertainment. I knew I had to revisit this film after watching the terrible 2016 reboot (why the hell did that happen).The story of the film is quite simple. It's about 5 friends who are vacationing at a cabin. Little do they know that there is a type of flesh eating disease spreading around in the area that makes people's skin fall off. They also later find out that it is being spread through water. The film definitely is influenced by The Texas Chainsaw Massacre and The Evil Dead but this film is definitely of that calibre. It's still a dumb enjoyable bloodfest. Which is what is expected from this director.The scares (the few that are present) don't really work and use the often played out jarring sound as something pops up. The blood and makeup is quite good. The skin falling off looks quite real and some of it really does make your skin crawl. The dialogue is so dumb and you get the typical prototype of dumb sex fueled teens who get themselves into trouble (as is par with horror films).The cast aren't particularly great although it was nice to see Rider Strong in a lead role. Jordan Ladd kind of faded into obscurity soon after. The film also has a cameo from Eli Roth, who basically plays an idiot. It's a truly dumb film but mindlessly entertaining. I don't think it's Roth's best (Knock Knock has definitely taken that cake) but it's an entertaining bloody debut.7/10

reviews.review_title: Oh, m'God, was this an awful movie. Don't wast your money!
reviews.content: I'd give this a negative rating if I could. I went into this movie not expecting much, but I had an open mind. The whole thing is stupid! The gore was obviously fake and the first two kids that died looked like they poured ketchup on themselves. Oh how original; if I were a 12 year old boy I might laugh at that. I have no idea how this movie became so popular. Seriously,the worst thing I've ever seen. I wasn't entertained, it wasn't funny,I wasn't even bored! I wasn't anything. It wasn't even so bad it was good, it's just bad. Ridiculous actually. Please do not waste your money on this movie. Don't even rent this movie. No clue how it's getting such a high rating.

(spoilers)There are some good scares to be had here, but this works mainly on trying to disgust you. A have this theory that if you want to know if a movie's scary, try eating while watching it (popcorn doesn't count). This movie is not a good one to eat in front of, since its fairly high on the disgust-o-meter. It has a fairly good creepy atmosphere, but its terribly uneven.Cabin Fever labours under the fact that the bad guy is an illness, betraying the fact that the filmmakers have constantly struggled to make it scary, constantly resulting to scare and shock tactics to make the audience jump to compensate for the lack of a human bad guy. The tactics include Dennis, the dog, the men from the store and the lamb. The music doesn't help - Ennio Morricone's three songs stick out like sore thumbs next to the music the rest of the film has.All this would be fine if not for the fact that the characters are so obnoxious! Cerina Vincent is beautiful but very synthetic-looking (Areola the naked exchange student from Not Another Teen Movie!), James DeBello with his Oscar-the-Grouch voice is that same tired backwards-cap jock we're all tired of, Rider Strong is (another one of those clean-cut Jared Leto types) is that same frustrated quiet guy in love with his best friend (Jordan Ladd), who is an uptight manipulator.Interestingly, Cerina and Jordan are the two girls from Lynch's digital video short Darkend Room if you've seen that.

Okay horror movie that made me think it was going slasher movie style while is actually is a different style. It still has the classic components of teen horror and doesn't deviate much from the line. A couple of goos scares and that's it.

This movie was actullay not bad despite what most people tend to think. The acting was actullay good the plot was interesting and it had some edge of your seat moments.This movie is about a group of 20 somethings who go out to a cabin in the woods for the weekend. While partying one night a strange "hermit" apporoaches them with what looks like some kind of disease. They are scared of it being contagious so they attempt to scare the stranger off accidentally killing him in he process. Having their vehicle wrecked in the encounter they are stranded as the disease starts to pick them off one by one.This movie was pretty good don't listen to everybody on here. It was low budget yes but you cant really tell. The only negative thing I would have to say about this movie is that for no reason at all Roth throws in jokes here and there. They are quite amusing but it throws off the entire atmosphere of the movie.Good movie though give it a watch

reviews.review_title: First Half Was Good...Second Half...Not So Much.
reviews.content: I just watched Cabin Fever for the first time this weekend.  I actually bought it used at a used bookstore because my friends and I decided to have "bad movie night" in honor of Friday the 13th.I have to say, the movie started out pretty well.  Some clever dialogue and an interesting situation, but the wheels fell off at the halfway mark.  It was almost like they made up the screenplay as they went along and at one point said "Okay, so now what do we do?"This movie could have been great, but the shifting of gears in the middle from story and characters to gore for the sake of gore was disappointing and forced the movie down into the "below average" range.  I love gore.  LOVE gore.  But, much like Underworld, this movie becomes style over substance (in this case, gore over substance) and it's really not all that stylish.The characters go from understandably scared to just plain stupid, backstabbing and unlikable.  The director saw fit to insert himself into the movie as a red herring...appearing for one scene and then having little (nothing, really) to do with the rest of the film.  The director seems wacky.  Maybe I'll appreciate the movie more if I watch it with the commentary on.  Somehow...I doubt it.  I love B horror movies, but this one left me cold. If you haven't seen this movie, don't bother.  You're not missing anything.3 stars out of 10 (30%)

Tacky horror movie which in the right hands and with the right screenplay might have become a horror classic, but as it is it's an undisciplined mess. Director Eli Roth presents us with familiar characters and situations and a plot which lacks the fine tuning necessary to suspend disbelief long enough for us to question the logic of why people do what they do. The geography is a problem too - at some points the kids appear to be in the middle of nowhere, at others they appear to be just across the way from various homesteads which might potentially offer assistance. There's a presumably deliberate attempt to evoke a sense of the menace of "Deliverance", but the hillbillies seem more like caricatures than characters. I appreciate this was intended as a horror-comedy, but it didn't really work for me.

Eli Roth's directorial debut can be a bit dense at times and is full of shameless clichés, but has gained a cult-following over the years for being a halfway decent horror movie made at only a 1.5 million dollar budget. Five college graduates who rent a cabin in the woods (already two clichés in just half a sentence) fall victim to a flesh-eating virus. Idea came from Roth's experience of developing a facial rash from rotten hay during an Iceland trip. Sound mixer John Neff survived the real flesh-eating bacterium, which took 13 days of non-stop intensive care to cure. Despite the real-life inspirations from Roth and Neff who maintain the make-up in the film is 100% accurate, the movie never hooks the viewer into the story's reality.** (out of four)

reviews.review_title: Eli Roth's first film delivers on everything his second should have, and more
reviews.content: Despite all of the hype, Hostel has got to be one of the worst and most vile pieces of celluloid I have ever had the displeasure of watching. Not for the violence, but for the fact that it just sucked, horrendously. I would see and read how well liked Eli Roth was for making the movie, and it would just disappoint me even more. I kept asking myself why anyone would like such a horrible movie, and then I realized that I had to see Cabin Fever before I tried to draw anymore conclusions.Following in the steps of The Evil Dead and Night of the Living Dead before it, Cabin Fever tells the story of five friends who rent a cottage in the woods after graduating from college. A chance arrival from a stranger covered with a flesh-eating disease ends in a murder, and before you know it, one of the friends has the virus. From here, they all race to try and get help, before it takes them too.No, the film is not deep, and no, it is not very original either. But thankfully, Roth pays homage to the men who have clearly inspired him, and made a decent horror movie that could actually play for scares and laughs (and not just for the sake of pointing out how ridiculous it is). What this film has, that Hostel sorrowly lacks, is being completely devoid of seriousness. Never is there a moment in the film where the characters go all serious. It plays itself up as a parody, and it stays very much in that realm for the entirety of the film. Yes, they have some dramatic moments, but they never cross the line between parody and complete earnestness. For that reason alone, I can respect this film a whole lot more than Hostel.But while the laughs come as fast and furious as the scares, the film still reeks of having the random and completely demented moments that I imagine Roth loves. They work better here than they did in Hostel, but do we really need a whole hour to pass before all hell breaks loose in the final thirty minutes? Clearly Roth could not have been that desperate for filler that he sacrificed his slow brooding horror for moments that just seem rather, off. He brings in random characters all over the place (including one played by himself), and really, they do nothing for the movie. Having them come to the enigmatic town, catch the disease and then try to get help would have been a much easier way of getting this movie from point A to point B. Hell, he could have even kept the ridiculous nature of the town's residents after they see the destruction of the disease, and it could have played itself out to be so much stronger than it is.But then, I must ask, why does no one in this movie seem to understand each other? Clearly he could have used one character to be sympathetic, but no one is. Even Jordan Ladd's Karen, who spends two of the film's three acts locked in a shed, does not even wince out the tiniest bit of sympathy. Does Roth really feel the need for all of his characters to do terrible things, and not be likable one bit? I came away with an awful taste in my mouth after watching the behaviour in the characters in Hostel, and here, they act out much of the same behaviour, only with a hell of a lot more drama and proper parody. It just seems a bit bizarre to have such off-putting characters, despite whether or not they do not last the entirety of the film's running time.The film also benefits from not dwindling on any one thing. The violence is fast, furious and brutal. But never are we subjected to long and ridiculous shots of it. Here, Roth seems to know exactly what to show, and exactly what to cut out. He seems very cooperative with his material, and he seems to know exactly what he is doing. So how then, can we compare this to his manipulative and perversely repetitive sequences in Hostel? I just cannot seem to shake the fact that he seems to really have an avid knowledge of what to do in this movie, but does not seem to have any sort of idea what to do with the far better concept at work in his second film. Maybe I should just chock it up to the likes of Sam Raimi, George Romero and Peter Jackson for obviously influencing his work in this film. Like his own personal fanboy Quentin Tarantino (which hurts me deeply), Roth wants to ape the successful moments from the films these directors made, and their unique visions. Through his own concoction, Roth managed to come up with a half-decent horror film that has all of the modern day problems all horror films have, but still manages to do what it sets out to do from the start.Eli, this is the type of film you were born to create. It has just the right amount of laughs and the right amount of cheeky horror to set itself apart from the movies that just want to scare the bejesus out of its viewer. You knew how to direct this kind of movie, and you clearly demonstrated how well you could do it with this film. So why change the formula? Was it really worth it? I can only hope that Hostel: Part II has more parts Cabin Fever than it does Hostel. Because if it is just the genre-melding mess the original film was, I am going to have to stay with my original diagnosis of Roth as a filmmaker. And sit saddened, wishing there could be a successor to this film, flaws and all.6/10.

This movie had a great concept in trying to go back to the cult favorite Evil Dead, but came up unbelievably short in the overall quality.  The best part was the irony of the ending.  I love horror movies, even the bad ones, and this one just didn't do it for me.

This is a great little gem of a movie with a brilliant cast n good characters.The story is chilling with a good plot.Plenty of tension n suspense n gore galore.The ending was fabulous with a horrible twist.I highly recommend this movie especially if you like tense atmosphere n horror.

So many things in this movie were either generic/predictable, completely unrelated to anything else in the movie, or made no sense at all. The characters were all as generic as they come. A group of college kids interested in having a good time with the personality of a rodent between the five of them. Scratch that.. I would much have rather watched a hamster nibble on cheese and exercise on a hamster wheel for an hour than watched this rubbish.The script was horrible. It was trying too hard to sound typical of the characters (college kids), and the horrendous acting on top of it made it so unbearably.. what's the word I'm looking for? Boring? Crappy? Eye-roll inducing? The only remotely real character was Bert, yes the obnoxious one, he was the only person in the movie I was even remotely interested in finding out what was going to happen to him.
