The acting was horrible too. You don't believe the characters believe anything that they're saying, against except for Bert.Back to the unrelated or makes no sense issue. A good chunk of this movie involves scenes or characters or lines that have nothing to do with anything. The worst of these was the pancakes/ karate scene. Why is there a slow-mo karate scene in the middle of the movie, by a minor character, who also has pretty much nothing to do with anything, and why is he yelling "pancakes"? Well at least Bert's reaction was pretty funny. There are way too many unnecessary/ senseless things in this movie and none of them are clever or at least cool to look at or anything.The "mystery" of the infection is given away the first time the camera focuses on the water glass and plays some suspenseful music, so all that's really left in the majority of the movie is watching if and how the idiot college kids figure it out. With how obvious the focus on the water is made, I think the director must take everyone who watches this movie for a complete idiot. And he might be right because I feel pretty dumb for having spent my money on this so called horror movie. The movie has a decent plot but how the scenes come together wasn't thought out well enough, which in addition to a hastily written script and cruddy acting, intertwined with a lot of things that seem to be put in just for the heck of it, really make Cabin Fever a flop.

reviews.review_title: Quoting may cut both ways: Honor or insult the original. !!SPOILERS!!
reviews.content: Many great horror movies can be found quoted in Cabin Fever, but while I was watching this I could not loose the feeling that these classics were ripped off only superficially. Cabin Fever lacked both their dramaturgical tension and (if existed in the originals) their philosophical implications.I consider myself a horror-fan and the most important fact in horror stories for me is the question why people feel frightened watching, reading or listening to them. It seems not to be enough to include gore and blood, some of the archetypical fears of the viewer should be included.This is exactly what Cabin fever lacked. Some examples:1) The "Texas Chainsaw massacre" theme: The main point in this classic (although I didn't like the dramaturgy on that one) was the fear of the rationally enlighted, urban (in the sense of the french revolution) man to be lost in the land of the savage southern states of America which seem to be the apotheosis of nonrationality, brutality, racism, fascism, etc. All the negative Properties the Enlightment tried to rule out (if they managed is a different point). Another supporting fact for that theory is that the movie is set in the 60s. Similar motives can be found in Deliverance, 2000Maniacs and other southern states horror movies. Cabin fever however, starts with similar premises (the N***er episode) but turns them around at the end (the shop owner likes the black people, it was all a misunderstanding) to obtain a cheap laugh, but also to lose this narrative approach.2) The "Thing" theme: While the Hawks/Nyby Original portraits the monster of outer space as a metaphor of the (at the time of the movie most feared) communism, the carpenter approach (which i think is copied in Cabin Fever) twists this premise to show the paranoia produced by the monster in the classic "It could be anybody, There is no one to trust"-scenery. This approach is not only a tension building one it also is quite a smart comment on the US-Politics in the 50s (although i'm sure carpenter wanted to scare in the first place). Cabin fever uses the mistrust atmosphere to scare, but it lacks any deeper interpretative Level on that and fails also in scaring.Many other great movies could be named which may have inspired this one (the evil dead series for example, because of the cabin. But there is no other connection to evil dead) but the fact prevails that cabin fever didn't honor them... It couldn't because it obviously didn't understand them. If the director did he didn't put it in his movie. What remains is an nonhomegenous, untense horror-camp flick which is harmless, mediocre fun in the first half (as this half is so standard, its hard to get this wrong) and gets messed up, boring and senseless in the second half and the finale. It includes some blood and breasts, which are nice, but can't support a weak movie.If you're in for some sex and some gore watch it, if you think horror could be more avoid it.

reviews.review_title: not scary, not that gory, not that anything
reviews.content: After all the talk of gore, I was expecting a lot more than this movie. It doesn't go anywhere for most of the flick, and when it does, it does so with a whimper. Accept for amazingly hot women, one of which gets nude, this thing is not nearly as good as the movies it is imitating. Gore??? Come one, there's so much gorier and out there. Scary? NO! Stupid? Yes - but not in a good way.Overall, this movie is dull.For gore - see Peter Jacksons, "Dead Alive" For a good "Cabin" movie - see any of the countless movies from the late 70's early 80s starting, of course, with Evil Dead.

reviews.review_title: Ruthlessly goofy B-movie in the best sense for those who can enjoy first-rate schlock.
reviews.content: The old set up, with a bunch of brats going into the woods for a good time and getting what they deserve.  Some bits of mean-spirited humor make this one well worth the trip.  I find hard it to fathom so many bad reviews on this kind of trashy fun.  Only the most humorless of movie-going snobs could refuse to enjoy a movie featuring a bloody finger dittle!  The score was downright exceptional for a B-grade horror flick, too.

reviews.review_title: wish I could've been a victim...
reviews.content: Insipid, incoherent schlock dealing with a group of Horror Movie Teens who decide going into the woods to a lonely cabin would be fun. Didn't these dinks see Blair Witch?? They're too young to have the seen the obvious influence for this, Evil Dead. The problem is that the ED series was able to mix humor and gore because it kept it reasonable. This junk has stoner cops and stoner campers and foul-mouthed teens and unexplained illnesses. Pacing is a problem as well. EV went for a brainless laugh or soaked the lenses in blood every five minutes. Here they just lay low tones on the soundtrack as people constantly investigate everything. Doesn't help either when most of the heroes are intolerable geeks. One shoots squirrels cuz they're gay, one strips his girlfriend like a hormone drenched moron, some tease kisses a guy then bails on him. Thank God it bombed and the EV series is safe of any sequel rivals.

*******SPOILERS AHEAD!!!!*******"Cabin Fever" is not a perfect film, but it does has it's moments.The story is interesting, but a lot of the plot is not explained: WHERE did the disease come from? You know that most of the kids get it by drinking the water, but not where it came from. Oh, and what's with the town people? They apparently know about what's going on. HOW long have they've known about the disease?Interesting story though: 5 friends from college go to the woods to have fun (Of course, you get your drugs, sex and rock and roll). They end up becoming infected with the disease, which causes them to throw up a LOT of blood and their flesh to decay. The results are VERY unpleasant! A lot of silliness is around, too (What's with the stoner or cop?).Whatever you do, you don't want to watch this while having a drink of water. You may end up a bit paranoid (Like me. I had a large glass of ice water and watched the film!).

To get right to the point...words cannot accurately convey the revulsion and utter disgust I felt while watching this film.  Even in unrealistic movies there has to be some sort of basis in reality to accomplish suspension of disbelief.  Cabin Fever had no discernable plot, some of the worst acting I've ever had the misfortune of witnessing, and turned out to be a comedy instead of a horror flick.  Where'd they pick these people up....Dogpatch? Nary a one could act their way out of a paper sack.  The dialogue was written by fourth grader....in special ed.  I rented it and watched it in good company, whose clever quips and line substitutions had me laughing so hard my eyes teared up.  Had it not been for him, those tears would have had a whole other meaning.  I love a good swear word, especially to cap off a sentence or punctuate a thought....but the abundant use of the F word only served to drive home the point that this writer doesn't possess a single intelligent thought, has a double digit IQ and the monosyllabic vocabulary of five year old with down's syndrome.  If anyone deserves to have a flesh eating virus, its Eli Roth. Preferably one he can pass on to his children so as not to infect future generations of movie goers with his excruciating stupidity.

reviews.review_title: Very Enjoyable, Though Not a Masterpiece
reviews.content: It really took me a while to get around to watching this film. The plot sounded promising and appeared to be a combination of teen-horror and disease/infection/virus disaster movies.The most I can say about this movie is that it delivered exactly what it promised, nothing more nothing less. The acting was average, but not bad at all. The characters were your usual stereotypical teens ("easy to get" attractive girl and her douche boyfriend, a good girl, a good guy, and an idiot. Nothing even slightly innovative here). The story was textbook teen horror - going on vacation to a desolate old town, meeting some creepy locals, getting to a neat cabin in a creepy forest, the works! It's all there.Just when you'd expect Jason to appear and start hacking and slashing, the second ingredient of the combination appeared, and the disease outbreak began. One of the better things in this movie was how it portrayed the disease. Just enough gore to make it realistic, but not too much so as not to use gore as a cheap cheat. Another nice part of this movie was the relationship between good-boy and good-girl, which was quite beautiful.One thing was rather original, and that was the comic relief, provided this time not by "the idiot" (who wasn't all that funny), but by the weird freaky Sheriff's Deputy who spoke, behaved and looked just the stoner type idiot you'd expect to find in such films, only that he wasn't with the guys on vacation, he was the law! You know you're in good hands when that kinda guy is wearing the badge :)I fail to understand all the hate towards this movie. If one expected to be swept of their feet and utterly amazed, then yes, they would be disappointed. But not every movie can be the best one ever. Some are just fun to watch. So while this movie gave us nothing new we haven't seen before and nothing too profound or exquisite, it was fun to watch. I would recommend it to anyone modest enough to enjoy a good presentation without it being the decade's masterpiece.

When I first saw the trailer for Cabin Fever I thought it looked promising. I mean, horror movies have always been one of my least favorite genres, mainly because they just don't scare me. But this one looked like it could actually be scary. Plus, it had Shawn from Boy Meets World (Rider Strong) in it, and that's a bonus right there. So I guess you could say, I was somewhat nervous in watching it, as I wasn't sure what exactly to expect. I eventually built up the courage to pop it in my DVD player and give it a shot. And, as I should have expected, I was neither terrified nor captivated by the cliché and unoriginal ideas throughout the film, but I was only slightly amused.Allow me to explain. The plot is very simple. There is a disease in these woods. No back-story is given as to why it's there or where it came from or anything. But this disease is a sort of flesh eating virus that eats away at your skin until you die from blood loss. Five teenagers have rented a Cabin in these woods. They get the disease (or the Fever, if you will) and chaos, mayhem and buckets 'o blood ensue.Now, while some horror movies focus on psychologically frightening images and ideas (see The Ring), Cabin Fever focuses on the more widely accepted scare tactic, and that's the gross-out factor. The disease itself cause the victim to projectile vomit chunky blood, and eventually bleed out of various patches in the skin where the virus has fed on. There's one particular scene, where one of the girls has decided that for some reason in this time of peril and hopelessness that it's time to shave her legs. 'Well, two of my friends have died, one is missing, and I may be infected as well, but gee, my legs sure are hairy!' Anyway, she draws herself a bath and begins to shave. She is obviously upset about the events that have occurred and is crying while she is doing this. She is so upset in fact; she doesn't notice that some of the swipes of her razor blade are not only shaving those nasty hairs, but pieces of her skin as well. She keeps going, and we are treated with several shots of this skin shaving. It is probably the grossest scene, but at this point in the movie there's been so much blood and whatnot, it's just not as scary as it could have been.Some of the characters in the movie are so bloody annoying it makes me want to punch them. Most notably are Officer Winston and Justin a.k.a. Grim. Officer Winston is a huge creep who likes parties, rides a police bike complete with bell, and calls one of the characters 'The Party Man'. Although you have to pronounce it in such a way I can't even spell it out phonetically. It's hard to explain him, but trust me. He's annoying. But some of the characters are likable, or one of them anyway. This is Paul, the one played by Rider Strong a.k.a. Shawn. And while he is likable for most of the movie, he begins to act strangely near the end in such a way that it does not seem conceivable for the character. He goes insane, and while it's true there's some crazy stuff happening, I don't think it would be enough to make him go quite so crazy. I kept thinking Cory Matthews would show up and talk some sense into him. Or maybe Mr. Feeny. Oh, and I should mention the bunny. In one scene, where Paul is being wheeled through a hospital on a stretcher, he glances into one room and see a large bunny-suited man operating on someone. He wheels past the room and that's it. This was a completely irrelevant scene which I would be the writer/director threw in because he heard how popular Donnie Darko is and wanted to get fans of that movie to like this one. Well I think I can speak for all of us when I say, no bunny will ever be as cool as Frank.This is a very sad attempt at a horror movie and sadly not even Shawn could save it from complete and utter disaster. It was a very successful comedy however, as I was laughing at several of the scenes and dialogue, so it wasn't a complete disappointment. Cabin Fever is simply another movie that proves the fact that horror movies are just not scary anymore. If they ever were.

...buckets of blood, gore, and entertainment.What stinks is that I watched this movie on SyFy(channel 40) and most of it was cut.The movie still somehow managed to show at least some gross moments that were both disgusting and cool.The plot involves some teenagers who go to a cabin and they suddenly catch a virus that spreads to each person one by one.Now you know why it's called 'Cabin Fever'.What happens while they discover that their skin is falling off and start coughing blood is very gross and shouldn't be watched by those who have weak stomachs for gore.Still, 'Cabin Fever' delivers lots of gore and shouldn't be taken too seriously if it wants to be liked.

This movie was one of the worst movies I have ever seen. completely and utterly pointless.I was looking for a good horror film and made the mistake of reading a recommendation for this film in someones "best of horror" list here on I.M.D.B. I will not be considering any other movies on that list for viewing. This was essentially a movie about a severe case of the flu. One of my pet peeves about a bad movie is what the characters do in unusual circumstances that NORMAL people in the exact same situation would not do. In this movie there are many, many instances where I found myself laughing at the absurdity of the main characters choices when other clear and OBVIOUS choices were available to them. But then the characters lack of common sense is perfect for a movie of this sort since it serves the purpose of advancing the mindless script. One such example found a woman riddled with the "Cabin Fever" shaving her not so pretty "Cabin Fever" legs. Another had two of the main characters "making out" while one of their friends was under quarantine, deteriorating in a shed from the cabin "bug". Nice, huh? Another thing I found irritating was the predictability throughout the movie. On a few occasions I was calling out the outcome before it even happened to the point that my son, who was watching it with me, kept insisting that I had seen the movie before. I had to assure him that Dad was having the hardest time watching it right then and there let alone having sat through it once before. This movie is easily one of the worst horror films (or any other genre for that matter) that I have ever seen. I could have done better. Makes me think that I should have been a film director instead of a "can jockey" at the neighborhood grocer.

reviews.review_title: The Worst Horror Movie I've seen in theaters
reviews.content: After reading pretty good reviews from IGN.com and a Philadelphia newspaper article, I took a date to Cabin Fever and what a horrible mistake. The movie is complete garbage, and I'm not sure if it was meant to be a spoof on horror flicks or a comedy. "What???" must have slipped out of my mouth over a dozen times in the film. There's this one scene where a crazy little kid bites one of the characters and starts to do kung-fu kicks and crap. All of this is followed up by a quote about "pancakes." 'Sean' from Boy Meets World was in the film, and that was kind of funny (plus the one actress was pretty hot) but this film really sucked. It wasn't scary, it wasn't creepy, and it wasn't really that funny either. Stay as far away as possible from CABIN FEVER...what a horrible movie.

I didn't think this movie was all THAT bad. I mean, at least it was somewhat original. Instead of several unlikable young adults heading off into the woods to drink and have sex and eventually get killed and eaten by inbred cannibals, we get several unlikable young adults heading off into the woods to drink and have sex and get killed off by their own stupidity. A nice, creepy, flyblown opening sets us up rather well. A nasty virus (origin unknown and never explained) finds its way to the cabin via a backwoods hobo, and quickly infects our cast of beautiful people. Their truck damaged by the virus-maddened hobo (and their drinking water polluted by his rotting corpse, which has fallen into the nearby river), our group of five is virtually stranded, and it isn't long before the flesh- eating disease is turning the beautiful people into some pretty nasty looking specimens. I found it difficult to feel any sympathy for the infected city folk; they were all pretty annoying and not terribly unlike the college kids in my apartment complex who yell and scream (and puke) underneath my bedroom window at 2am when I have to get up at 5am. I did, however, appreciate the realistic reactions of the characters when they realize what is happening: instead of bonding together and fighting to survive, they scatter, bicker, regard each other with suspicion, abandon their lovers, act like immature jackasses and kill each other. In short, they're pretty realistic in all of their shallowness and selfishness. I also rather enjoyed the dark comedy that ran through this film; the pancake loving Dennis, the nightmarish rabbit, the pot smoking deputy, the bowling alley massacre and the supposedly racist old man. These scenes were few and far between, but they were the most interesting ones in the movie, usurped only by the ending which is a morbid punchline to a very long, sick joke.This isn't a perfect film, but as far as horror films go, I've seen a LOT worse. People who enjoy bloody splatter and black comedy may appreciate this odd little film. I give it a 6 out of 10. Sue me, I kinda liked it.

reviews.review_title: "Cabin Fever" will give you the chills.
reviews.content: As you have probably guessed, this movie is very uneven.  The first problem is that it is trying to be too many horror genres at once without achieving any semblance of hybridization.First it wants to make you think it is a typical 70's-80's slasher flick by having a bunch of youth go to a secluded location and get offed one by one (4 of ten points).  The director doesn't seem to care if you care about the main characters or not.  They have no chemistry and just say the "F" word about a cagillion times.  Then it tries to do "Deliverance" with some generic David Lynch by introducing the weirdo, inbred towns folks (8 points).  The only problem here seems to be inability to find anyone that can do their roles believably.   Then there is the obligatory sex scenes (6 points). Cerina Vincent is hot, but the director sadly underutilizes her (although she does most of the sex) and her boyfriend doesn't seem to notice (although the director does), except during the sex scenes.  Finally the real star, the flesh eating virus hits our heroes and it tries to be a psychological thriller by keeping you wandering where the virus will strike next (8 points):  I was pretty caught up in this part until the people started to speak. Again, better actors like those in "Rosemary's Baby" my have sent me jumping from my seat.  Of course today, what would be horror without gore (5 points).  Anyone that has seen more than 5 gore-fests have probably seen these tired old "skin eating" effects before and won't be to impressed.  For good measure they threw in some "I Know What You Did Last Summer", but did not pursue it enough to make it more than filler.  And last and certainly least is the "Government conspiracy, cover up" angle (4 points).  There seemed to be no clear motivation as to why officials handled it the way they did.In summary, this movie had a lot of great potential, but probably dropped the ball because of lack of money, talent, and time.  It definitely needs to be re-made if we can get that MPAA monkey off the box-office back (can you say "Hayes Commission"?)

What is not to like about this movie
First of all .2 of the most gorgeous chics ,you will ever see in a horror movie
It must be the first horror I've ever enjoyed while sporadically laughing out loud .Hilarious in parts .One of the babes shaving her legs while knowing she has flesh eating decease😂
Seriously enjoyable watch though

There is a quote from the famous Daffy Duck that goes, "if they like that MESS, they're starvin for some REAL hoofin!!" That is how I feel about Cabin Fever. I see variable ratings on this, from good to bad. While everyone has their opinion, c'mon!! This was a horrible movie that depended on flavor of the month actors, some blood and gore, and corny scenes. A horror movie still has to have REASON, right? What did the scene with the pancake child have to do with anything? Why is the water infected? Why are the townsfolk cooky, or are they? Do they know all that is going on? There are just too much crap that sinks this movie. If you like a lot of gore and blood and ugly wounds and such, you'll like this, but without a real plot, how can you appreciate it?For example, the scene near the end where the kids get the water to make lemonade; are we to assume that the town is "immune" to the water, or are they about to "reap what they have sown"? That was never answered. What's up with the dude with the box? What's up with the town? Is the beer made with the town's water, or is all the water imported? Why does the situation exist? You KNOW why Freddy Kruger exists, you KNOW why Jason and Michael Myers exist...oh, I forgot, there is NO SLASHER in this HORRIBLE film. Granted, not every horror film needs a slasher, but horror is based on some substantiated reason of fear. Even though it is fiction, it still has to make some kind of sense. What's with the guy with the pretty chick in the other cabin? Who is he? Is he infected too? What of the guys partying with the officer? If I had a whole day, I might tell you other wondrous things that make no sense, but I won't give this movie the respect of that. If they come out with a Cabin Fever 2, then prepare for the end of the world. I just can't seen anyone giving this a good review unless of course you were paid to.

Tis a glorious time for horror movies.  In the past year, we have been graced with HOUSE OF 1000 CORPSES, 28 DAYS LATER, FREDDY VS. JASON, and now, the terrific CABIN FEVER.  It's about time a few filmmakers brought the guts back to horror.The story is simple: a group of teenage friends travel into the woods for a pre-college vacation.  Once there, they are exposed to a flesh-eating virus, courtesy of some contaminated drinking water, a situation for which they are unwittingly responsible.  The virus then proceeds to melt, crack and eat away the skin of its victim, and the kids have to try and think their way out of their situation.What is particularly great about CABIN FEVER is it's refreshing lack of self-consciousness.  While it pays homage to lots of previous horrors (including LAST HOUSE ON THE LEFT, THE INCREDIBLE MELTING MAN and NIGHT OF THE LIVING DEAD), it is never itself "aware" that it is a movie.  Characters behave credibly and react in a way most people would probably react. There's not a "It's just like in the movies" line heard or a take-charge hero or heroine in sight.  The dilemma these kids are in is a mess--literally-and they scramble around helplessly trying to solve it.  The kids are also rather selfish, unreasonable and sometimes even cruel, character traits rarely seen in the "horror" movies of the past twenty years.I enjoyed this movie immensely.  While it echoes the grittier horrors of the 70s grindhouse era, it is not really a "tribute" to those movies.  It's simply a solid fright flick with a sense of true terror, physically as well as psychologically, instead of the antiseptic safety of a SCREAM or FINAL DESTINATION.  Highly recommended, but absolutely NOT for the squeamish.PS- Fans of LAST HOUSE ON THE LEFT will be tickled by a number of David Hess's songs used on the soundtrack.

reviews.review_title: Meets all the criteria for a really, really bad film. *May Contain Spoilers, but don't fret, nothing will be truly spoiled anyway*
reviews.content: In an attempt to be positive, i will run through the good points of this film... Point #1: There are two very attractive girls in the film, and, point #2: There's some nudity... But even those two very valid points don't make this film worth seeing.Now, on to the real review. The movie was obviously very low-budget... maybe Eli Roth called Uwe Boll for some directorial advice? This is evident in the lack of any well known actor or actress, the lack of quality special effects (not so much "special", just that the blood looks like red food coloring mixed in with water) and the lack of any damn bit of sense.The cast was less than stellar, and that reflected in the overall quality of the film. The acting was poor, the make-up was completely unbelievable, the scenes made absolutely no sense, along with the rest of the movie... Now, i know i sound like a broken record, but thats OK because this movie was completely repetitious and, for lack of a better word, crappy.Some food for thought: Where does this terrifying flesh-eating virus original? If i recall correctly, that poor, rustic woodsman contracted it from his dead K9, who, presumably, was attacked by a vicious squirrel... just kidding, we don't actually know how this disease came about, but honestly, who cares? Is it supposed to be funny? Its not, as far as i know, but it has its moments where it is quite hilarious... although i assume it is not intentionally so. Lets be honest, the idea of a flesh eating virus, hidden teenage love, and Daniel (Pancakes!) has no horror value in it at all. However, this movie was subliminally funny at times, for example, pancakes, another example, the star was that one kid from Boy Meets World, another example, the main conflict was some kids running away from a virus that eats your skin... and a final example would have to be at the end of the movie when they are shipping out the water... Oh, how i laughed so hard at that final scene... yes, I'm being very sarcastic.Why was this movie even made? Honostly, what in Gods name were they thinking? Did they think that the idea, which seems like a poor Resident Evil plot rip-off, would make for a good movie? If this was indeed the case, they were terribly, terribly wrong.In conclusion, Don't SEE THIS MOVIE. If i wasn't such a jerk i would leave it at that, but i am, and i am also enjoying this too much, it provides me with so much ammo to have dandy ol' time amusing myself. This movie does indeed fill me with horror, the very thought of this movie brings about fits of suicide and violence... Until i realize that, in hell, your torture isn't fire and brimstone, it is watching Cabin Fever, House of the Dead, and Get Rich or Die Trying' looped for the rest of eternity.

reviews.review_title: A Scary,Effective,Gory,and Darkly Funny Horror Film. Eli Roth's Best Film.
reviews.content: Eli Roth's Cabin Fever is a great horror film that combines scares,gore,frights and dark humor that wonderfully pays homage to Horror films from the 70s and 80s. This is Eli Roth's best film that deserves more respect and is very underrated.Cabin Fever tells the story of five college students Paul(Rider Strong),Karen(Jordan Ladd),Bert(James Debello),Marcy(Cerina Vincent)and Jeff(Joey Kern)who are on vacation and decide to rent a cabin in the woods. When there,the group discovers that there is a flesh eating virus that's spreading around the forest that threatens to to take them one by one. The group also has to deal with crazed local hillbillies,hermits,dangerous animals,cops and themselves getting into frightening and bizarre situations.Cabin Fever is a film that seems to have divided Horror fans since it's release in 2003 where some love the film and some hate the film I fall into the former category and truly feel that Cabin Fever is terribly underrated. Cabin Fever is a great Horror film that takes viewers back to the days when Horror Films were bloody,frightening,gory and truly politically incorrect and Roth just rolls with it paying homage to Horror classics from the 1970s and 80s such as John Carpenter's The Thing,The Texas Chainsaw Massacre and The Evil Dead working as an homage but it's own film as well. The film has a great atmosphere that changes when things fall apart. In the beginning of the movie it's very fun and lighthearted where you get to know the main characters and what they're about and who they are. When the threat of the flesh eating virus comes around the film becomes darker and there's looming sense of dread and fear and when the characters start turning on each other it's real and believable. The film ultimately works as metaphor for the AIDS and HIV virus where most human beings live in fear of getting a deadly disease whether by breathing,touching or sex. The themes in the film will be relevant to people who watch the film and will stick with you after you view the film. What is also great about Cabin Fever is how it's not a Scream-type film and how the film takes itself seriously. While the film makes reference and pay's homage to the classic Horror films of the 70s and 80s,the film and it's characters aren't self-aware and know that they're in a Horror film. Roth smartly takes the material very seriously and the characters are in a horrific situation that is real and frightening and avoids having main the characters make lots of Humorous references to Horror films and treats the film as if you are with the characters going through the very same thing they are going through,treating the situation as dark and realistic as possible. What I also love about Cabin Fever is the dark Humor and slow build up. The Humor in the film is funny,insane,well-placed,dark and at times surreal and unexpected where one minute you are screaming in terror and you are laughing your head off the next. With CF Roth balances Horror and Humor well and that's one of the main reasons the CF works. Where most Horror films now are fast paced and get to the point,Cabin Fever is more like the Horror films of the 70s and 80s where Horror films were done with slow build-ups with characters and the dialog and then when things go to hell you care for the main characters. Eli Roth doesn't use fast editing or fancy camera tricks to get the viewer involved in the story,but with old fashion storytelling getting the viewer into the dark,scary and sometimes bizarre world of Cabin fever. Roth shows us the cabin and the woods making the main characters feel like their isolated from the world where there is no escape or hope. The ending of Cabin Fever is fantastic because it's funny and disturbing and will have you laughing in tears and disgust. A great ending. The cast does a great job. Rider Strong(best known for his role as Shawn Hunter on Boy Meets World)does a great job as Paul,bringing depth and sympathy to the role. Jordan Ladd is wonderful as Karen Paul's long time friend. James Debello is fantastic as Bert the funny guy. Cerina Vincent is great and sexy as Marcy the highly sexual girl in the group. Joey Kern does a wonderful job as Jeff,Marcy's boyfriend. Giuseppe Andrews is funny and memorable as Deputy Winston,a cop who loves woman and wants to party. Arie Verveen is wonderful as Henry the Hermit and brings sadness to the role. Director Eli Roth has a fun and small cameo as skateboarder Grim,a guy who hangs with group a bit.Eli Roth's direction is excellent with Roth bring slow camera movements,a great visual style and camera angles and color changes. Great job,Roth.The score by Nathan Barr is amazing and effective and fits in with the films tone. The score definitely reminded me of the Horror scores of the 70s and 80s and it's great. I also loved the use of songs from the Wes Craven classic The Last House on The Left and they fit in well with the film. The special effects by the great K.N.B EFX group is great,memorable,realistic,bloody and gory and messy. K.N.B does it again.In final word,if you love Horror films I highly suggest you see Cabin Fever,a scary,Gory,funny and memorable and probably in fifteen or twenty years will go down as a Horror classic and be more recognized. Highly Recommend. 10/10.

reviews.review_title: I want those 94 minutes of my life back.
reviews.content: The plot, acting, storyline and everything was terrible about this movie. There were so many distracting and nonsense events. I recommend to everyone, that you do not watch this movie. I want those 94 minutes of my life back. If I could spend a few weeks trying to find something good about this movie, I might come up with something, whether it be a sex scene or an establishing shot that was photographically pleasing. If you like simple movies, with non-complex stories, and not so good acting, and just like being scared - then sure, rent it. Otherwise, you will just be in awe as to how ridiculous this film is. I can't even watch Boy Meets World anymore now.

Seriously?What a load of craptacular awfulness.And what's so sad is that there are people who actually thought this movie was good.I'd like a case of whatever they're drinking.HOW do movies like this, get funded? More importantly...WHY do they get funded?This film got theatrical as in major, world wide screenings and press.There are struggling film makers who will never get the backing, press or prestige this film has had and THAT is what's wrong with Hollywood.I've seen first-time filmmakers, with little to no budget, no fame and no fan base, do better.The only reason it got a 3, from me, is because the geezer in the general store, was hilarious.Is there a rewind button on my life so I can get back the time I wasted on this useless garbage?

A sneaky and surprisingly smart horror flick, Cabin Fever sets up all the clichés of its particular sub genre (what might be called the "sexy young people go into the woods" horror movie, featuring hostile redneck locals, dead animals on hooks, cars that suddenly stop running, etc.) and by the end has played a clever twist on every standard element, often to darkly comic effect. What's the plot? Well, five sexy young people (Rider Strong, Jordan Ladd, Joey Kern, Cerina Vincent, and James DeBello) go to an isolated cabin where they contract a nasty bacteria that eats their flesh; this, combined with a bad-tempered dog and a party-loving police deputy (Giuseppe Andrews, giving a particularly funny performance), leads everyone into confusion and bloody chaos. Some of the ironic twists are a little obvious, but most of them effectively subvert your expectations to entertaining effect.

reviews.review_title: Simple, almost plausible idea gets stretched into feature length and doesn't know how to wrap it up
reviews.content: Cabin Fever (2003) Rider Strong, Jordan Ladd, Joey Kern, Cerina Vincent, James DeBello, Arie Verveen, Giuseppe Andrews, D: Eli Roth. Five college grads rent a cabin for a week in the North Carolina backwoods after finals, but after a confrontation with an infected hermit, the quintet evades a flesh-eating contagion that eventually spreads. Uncertain of whether it wants to be a homage to 80s horror, a low comedy, or a gorefest, this watery plot dips into all three with a twist ending that makes no sense. Style later gets lost in lots of gratuitous spewed blood, gore, and grotesque scenes. Writers Randy Pearlstein and Roth (who also directs) know how to create dread and fear with the addition of revulsion. Running Time: 94 minutes and rated R for strong violence and gore, sexuality, language, and brief drug use. **

reviews.review_title: Truly appalling; a waste of life to be honest...
reviews.content: I've seen many modern teen horror's but this one takes the biscuit for being the most *appauling* film in that entire genre. The acting, plot, filming, soundtrack, very essence- of the thing- is purely dreadful. There was pointless nudity, pointless gore, and pointless everything to be quite honest- but not in the regular 'it's a teen horror so let's shock those crazy kids' way- it was more of a 'lets cheat perfectly innocent people out of an hour and a half of their lives, just because we can' way. No non-obscene words can even begin to summarise the level that this movie reached, in terms of being crap.It was worse than Dead End, it was worse then House of Wax, it was even worse than Wrong Turn. As a teenager, and a horror fan- take it from me, you don't even need to see this movie for a laugh- it's not funny, it's dire.

I like horror movies and when I heard about this movie first I was very excited. A film without an original killer but with a flash-eater virus!? Jeeez, that's sounds crazy! The idea is quite original and might be the base of an extremely powerful movie. But in the real life, it all goes wrong...... for the first, the plot is just stupid. The first murder in the story (the homeless guy's burning) doesn't even make any sense. Why do they kill that? But the most ridiculous part is still the end. The villagers are starting a manhunt against the ill ones, and kill them with no reason. Why don't they just call help? Like the ambulance or something? Senseless, again. And if we are here, then I must reply on the characters too. They are so unsympathetic that I've never seen before. There was no one who I could like or sorry in the whole movie! Why is it like that? The creators wanted to show us the today's youth's sins, or what? And why are so much nudity scenes? Oh God... this is just bad.I mentioned the ending before, but the real last scene was just ruins more. They wanted to ride the X-files "open ended" style but it just doesn't work as well. It only makes the movie more worse...I don't even know why I gave 2 points... Perhaps because the camera handing is not so bad...Chocho

The first thing I expected with Cabin Fever was that it would be all blood and no body. But to my pleasant surprise, Cabin Fever is almost quite intelligent, fun and quite a good movie. It is completely expecting, unpredictable and even quite funny at times. If you don't understand the horror parameters, this movie may fly under your radar, but a seasoned horror fan will appreciate everything in this film. A nod to B-Grade horror movies like The Evil Dead, Cabin Fever is surprisingly original and fun to watch. Unlike reviews that I have seen for this film, Cabin Fever is probably one of the most underrated and most under appreciated films ever made. Eli Roth really does know how to make a good movie.

This was Eli Roth's first film, and it is a doozy. It is an incredibly gruesome and dark story about a flesh-eating virus, basically made light of by the gallons of black humor from start to finish. Cabin Fever is populated with great characters, an intriguing cabin in the woods slash infectious disease story, some great gore, a wicked sense of humor, an attention to detail, AND it's filmed and edited well. What more do you want? Oh, the foxiest chick in the entire flick gets naked (more than once). David Soul appears in this! No, wait... It's just his hair. A gang of rednecks goes looking for the kids in the cabin, and one guy is carrying a fancy box. You never find out what's in the box! (a la Quentin Tarantino). Also, Roth tips his cap to Night of the Living Dead at the end. I think what makes this movie special is its merciless onslaught of gallows humor, which ends on a hilarious, off-color, very un-PC joke, something that would put great fear into today's modern horror filmmakers (and the people they have to answer to). A winner all around. I don't know if he topped this with Hostel, its follow-up, but that was stellar as well. I wish he was still creating killer horror. Frankly, I feel like he has kind of strayed.

"Cabin Fever" is truly a HORRENDOUS movie..a comedy/horror?? It was neither funny nor frightening. Five college kids go on a vacation/break to an isolated cabin to live it up before facing "real" life and are struck by a killer flesh eating disease...I actually wished they would all die so unlikeable were they. If you want to see teenagers dieing at the hands of a malevolent foe ,go rent "Jeepers Creepers 2" which is a masterpiece compared to this overblown tripe. I'm sorry I feel like this about "Cabin fever" as I generally give movies I watch a chance but I HATED every thing about this...sorry Mr Roth but this film sucks. 3/10 the three is for "Pancake kid's" kung fu routine and the partying deputy....PMSL.

It's now 2 in the morning and i can't sleep due to being baffled by such a terrible movie. there is absolutely zero plot, no point or underlying theme, just tons and tons of unnecessary blood. Parts in the movie that made no sense what-so-ever.. 1.) The part where the kid sitting on the bench (Dennis) that looks like a a girl, starts screaming for pancakes then proceeds to Hung Du all the way to Bert, who then proceeds to bite his hand with no resistance from Bert at all... 2.) What was in the box that the fat inbred was carrying around? before he was brutally murdered by taking a screwdriver though the brain... 3.) Why do they insist on drinking out of the reservoir that is contaminated with God knows what, as well as some flesh eating disease? 4.) what was the deal with the random black guys at the end of the movie? 5.) how does someone not notice a chunk of skin in the bottom of the water glass before drinking it? 6.) how did the X-Games stoner die? and why is he ripped in half? 7.) where do they take "Boy Meets World kid" at the end of the movie? 8.) what was the point of the lady chopping the pig up? 9.) what was going with the naked lady in the bed when the hick told boy meets world kid to get off his property? 10.) why were the kids at the end getting water from that gross excuse of a reservoir? 11.) why did they build up a relationship with boy meets world kid and hot blonde only to have her face eaten away then her insides eaten by a dog, then getting beaten to death by boy meets world kid for about 3 minutes when all it would have taken was one hit to the face? and then later the dog's owner found in a cave torn in half?i could go on forever, but i choose not to. my point is that this is one of the worst movies i have ever seen, i feel dumber for having watched it. how can a production studio pat money for this? you know a movie is bad when it ends and you have no idea what just happened for the last hour and a half. this caused me physical pain to watch and i only hope for humanity that this movie is retrieved by everyone who owns it and promptly burned until there is nothing left. i wish i would have gone to bed instead of watch that horrible excuse of a movie. that is my rant, thank you for reading and good night, finally...

Cabin Fever starts off with a group a friends going to celebrate their graduation with a trip to a rustic looking cabin pretty much in the middle of nowhere. Upon arriving, they meet a dying man(who got sick from his dead dog, of all things) who tries to steal their vehicle to get help, one thing leads to another and the man gets lit on fire, runs off and somehow winds up dead in the cabin's water resevoir, and, as you guessed it, helps to infect the college graduates. We are then "treated" to an hour(on top of the 30 minutes used to set the story in motion) of the kids dealing with getting the illness, a vicious dog, a scene with a kid yelling about pancakes and practicing kung-fu(those who've seen it understand), irrational rednecks who can't use basic logic, an ending that partly rips of the original "Night of the Living Dead" and is highly anti-climatic, some "humour" involving a group of African-Americans and a rifle, which essentially goes against the "horror" aspect of the film and a cheesy montage of Rider Strong's character and the love interest.This film is an absolute mess that doesn't make a whole lot of sense and deviates from the horror aspect with half hearted attempts at humour and drama.For the love of all that is good, skip it.

Sadly maligned as 'average' on its UK release, Cabin Fever is in fact the best horror movie to have come out of Hollywood for years. A lot of people seem to be harping about its over-the-top action and general silliness, apparently not realising that this is the point - Cabin Fever is a black comedy. Filled with great, quirky characters and an interesting streak of sadism, it's an expert subversion of the horror genre.A little like My Little Eye (another great recent film), the script-writer delights in killing off every one of the characters and cleverly inverting the standard kids/rednecks formula: turns out the hicks are more sophisticated than your average, and one kid in particular just loses all semblance of humanity, turning psycho and killing everyone that gets in his way. There's also some truly unpleasant moments of gore and (SEMI-SPOILER AHEAD!) a neat apocalyptic twist reminiscent of Cronenberg's Rabid.Great film-making.

Five teenagers(that look like adults) are going camping together but they suddenly find themselves among very strange people and the cabin which they are staying at itself is a little freaky. But the horror starts, when each one of them gets infected with a horrible disease, a virus that eats away at the flesh. This movie was VERY gross, there was way to much blood and gore but however, it was still a fun movie with hilarious moments. The acting was decent yet at times very cheesy. It isn't oscar material, but it sure is entertaining. I would give Cabin Fever 6/10.

reviews.review_title: Is everyone in horror movies an idiot?
reviews.content: I rented this movie today mostly because I loved Hostel movies directed and written by Eli Roth. I thought it would be interesting to see his earlier stuff. But funnily enough the most interesting thing about the whole thing is that it's listed as both "comedy" and "horror". Watching the film I had no idea it was supposed to be a comedy as well. Sure, it's slightly absurd, but not so much I'd see right away that it's comedy. There are jokes there, of course, but there are in several horror films, and they aren't automatically comedies. Well, you can always learn more about movies...The music in this film is completely unnerving. The soundtrack of this film is magnificent, and a good score always gives a horror film something extra. There are genres where it doesn't matter so much, but in horror it's surprisingly important. It keeps you on your toes. And even the lack of soundtrack is extremely effective in horror movies. But in Cabin Fever there is a soundtrack, and it works.The thing about Cabin Fever is that there's no serial killer hunting the young characters. The "bad guy" of the film is a disease. And what's the thing about that? You can't outsmart it. But still, the characters are idiots. That is of course a typical trope in horror, but sometimes someone does something so obvious you want to punch them. Someone is infected and you decide go touch them? Yeah that's definitely a great idea!Cabin Fever is thrilling, yet there's something about it that makes it slightly annoying. I enjoyed watching it this first time, when I have no clue what's going to happen, but I doubt I'm going to see it again.

reviews.review_title: Possibly the worst movie I have ever seen...
reviews.content: After watching this movie, I wanted to ask the video store for my money back. I now judge other movie's by how badly this one sucked. i.e "Well, it was better than Cabin Fever." Lame effects, bad acting, weak story... The trailer for the movie is better than the actual film itself. It gave the impression of suspense... That the movie was going to be somewhat psychological. The only thing I was on the edge of my seat for was the moment the credits would roll, and as far as psychological goes... You may need psychological help after viewing it. If you are a fan of B Horror, you might think it was OK. As my score shows, it's worse than B in my book.

Cabin fever tells the story of a group of friends who have just finished college and decide to stay at a cabin for a week or something. When one of the friends stupidly decide to go hunting with a gun for squirrels,he shoots a man who looks sick and infected. Then the friends tell story's around a camp fire when they meet a man who has a dog and is very violent threw out the film. Then this infected man knocks on there door and remember the man that shot him,he tells them not to let him in as the man try's to open there trucks door,the friends run out with weapons and the truck sets in fire and so does the man. The next day,everyone is scared by it and one of the friends who has a crush on a girl gets into bed with her when he finds out she has the infection. The friends put her in the shed as she just wants to go home. The next day,the friends go looking around for help when a weird sheriff who loves partying tells them everything is going to be OK. Soon,everyone starts getting the virus and spoiler everyone dies in the end. I loved this film so much,so original and cool. I saw all the sequel which were all crap. I mean the prom come on,I also saw the remake and to be quite honest it was the exact same as the original but very very gory but it was OK. Cabin fever is a class teen horror film for horror fans.

Five college kids go to a remote cabin for a little fun and end up contracting a flesh rotting disease that picks them off in gruesome fashion one by one...This grim, overly familiar horror movie is the type of effort that gives critics lots of ammunition and was obviously made by people that know nothing about making horror films, much less a good one. Filled with hateful characters and illogical situations, there's not a single believable moment throughout.Although technically sound, Cabin Fever is poorly photographed and uses plot devices liberally stolen from several much better movies, like Evil Dead and Friday the 13th to name but a couple. The multiple "twists" at the end are laughable and telegraphed far ahead of time. On the plus side, the film is refreshingly devoid of the camp tone that many desperate directors inject when they realize what a piece of junk they just made. Also of note is the excellent SFX makeup that doesn't rely on those cheap, cheesy computer generated effects popular with low-budget horror nowadays.That's faint praise, however. Unless you've never seen a horror movie, don't waste your time on this stiff.

Though it was silly at times, there were enough scenes that surprised me -- I actually jumped a few times. It was also rather gory, but in a necessary way. I did have to look away during the shaving scene, and the following scene with the dog. The "I made it" scene was predictable, and kind of corny, but better than it could've ended. I noticed that no matter how far anyone walked, ran, drove, boated, etc. away from the cabin, they somehow always ended back at the cabin. (didn't Jeff LEAVE). And, that truck was going fast enough, there is no way it could've stopped that fast. But, other than that, good enough to keep one on the edge of the seat. Though left open for a sequel, I doubt it would be better than the original.Watch late with the lights off. 3 1/2 ***

reviews.review_title: If you go unbiased into this film it's not that bad
reviews.content: This is a teen horror movie so the only rule it has to follow is that everybody gets killed off, one or two at a time, by a scary monster.The scary monster is given away in the title of the movie - it's a bacteria/virus. That was the first thing that was impressive, no matter how small. It always has to be about monsters, serial killers and other physical peekaboos. A teen horror flick with a virus is welcome change.The group of teenagers brought in for the slaughter is a group of not very likable city college students coming over to a strange small local community. They behave erratically and panic when under pressure. This unlikability and reactionary behavior makes them realistic, even though the specific actions of those characters are not.There is not that much happening in the movie and it could have done much more with the idea than it did, but the movie did creep me out - something a lot of horror movies fail to do.

reviews.review_title: A sick, twisted cabin in the woods horror movie
reviews.content: Cabin Fever 12/6/2009This film is the directorial debut for Eli Roth. Eli is a Boston native and horror fan boy at heart. Cabin Fever takes on several parts of well known horror films and put his out ideas and twists on them. This is a creepy cabin in the woods movie like Evil Dead. It's a mysterious virus movie like The Thing. Then throw in some crazy back woods rednecks like Deliverance. Cabin Fever is disturbingly authentic in the fact that this could actually happen. Eli got the idea from a real life experience, when he got a flesh eating bacteria at an Icelandic horse farm.Cabin Fever starts out like many recognizable horror flicks. A group of young people headed into the woods to a cabin for a weekend of partying. The main characters are Paul and Karen played by Rider Strong and Jordan Ladd. They have been "friends" forever, while Paul is always pushing for closer relationship. Bert is the not to bright football player like character played by James DeBello. Then there is the yuppie douche bag couple. The blonde haired Ivy League style jerks always get butchered and for good reason. The look of the film is set in the early to mid 1980's, so that rules out any cell phone usage. We don't ever learn the origins of the virus, although we do see a dead dog that infects a local hermit. Bert accidentally shoots and wounds the hermit while hunting for squirrels. That night the man comes to the cabin pleading for help. He is a horrible bloody mess who after puking infected blood all over their truck, is set on fire by the guys. The girls are upset by this and it creates a great deal of tension and dissension in the group. Paul finds the decomposing body floating in a lake. The virus has now infected the water supply for the whole town.Winston Olsen is a young sheriff deputy and quite the strange character. He is bored to death with his job and just likes to party with all the vacationers. Even when the story gets extremely gory he is only worried that that party is ruined. Another very unique character is Dennis, played by Matthew Helms. He sits on a swing in the front of the town general store. Don't get to close to him though because he bites, as Paul finds out. He is also known as the "Pancakes" boy who has a black belt in karate. Yes I know that sounds a little strange but you really have to see the movie.One of the most disturbing scenes in the movie is when Karen who hasn't been feeling well, lets Paul comfort her while she's napping. Paul moves his hand below her waist and you could say he has bad aim. He finds out that he is fingering a large flesh wound in her thigh. She is infected. Karen is then ostracized and quarantined from the others. She is locked in a shed with a grungy mattress and a blanket and then served food like a prisoner. The characters are now only interested in their own survival. Even though this movie was made in 1999, the main story line and the characters reactions to it seem to match today's fears of the swine flu and global flu pandemics. They all eventually get this virus and deal with it in their own separate ways. The leg shaving scene is quite possibly the most cringe inducing scene ever filmed. While the blonde guy take two six packs of beer and runs into the woods. If you look at the beer closely it's called "Arrogant Bastard Beer". He does how ever get his comeuppance for abandoning his friends. In one of the movies final scenes he is killed in a very similar fashion to that of the classic zombie flick "Night of the Living Dead" The last scene shows a semi truck full of tainted bottled water leaving the small town. There is a sequel, Cabin Fever 2: Spring Fever which is directed by Ti West. It is currently showing at various film festivals around the country and is not yet out on DVD. Eli Roth had no part in the filming or production. So see it at your own risk.

reviews.review_title: there are a few really really really bad movies...
reviews.content: In my opinion, there are 3 or 4 really really really bad movies. Wicker Park (2004), The Flight of the Pheonix (2004) and Cabin Fever (2002). The whole idea of cabin fever is stupid. A flesh eating virus. Don't get me started on the cast. You get the guy from boy meets world and a bunch of people i don't know. there.reasons this movie was horrible. ~everybody died. Many died from the virus, but i believe rider strong was run over by a truck. i think. ~pointless sex. there is stupid pointless sex. it's like AIDS. they know if they touch each other they'll get the virus but they are pressured to touch each other anyway. ~the end. in the end, when the virus has FINALLY gone away, a bunch of kids knowingly sell water, with the virus in the water. therefore spreading the virus again.If you want a movie to call your least favorite movie of all time, this is it. it is stupid, far-fetched and actually made me scared in reality. like, if a "flesh-eating" virus can be spread this easily, what makes me think i can't get it. yeah, it made me think.DON'T WATCH THIS. 1 out of 10.

A bunch of friends visit a remote part of America - not quite sure where - to spend a holiday in a cabin in the woods (clearly, none of them have seen Friday the 13th OR The Evil Dead.) Anyway, one of their number inadvertently contracts a hideous virus that eats the flesh. As one after another succumbs to the deadly virus, we get to share their true thoughts about one another.An interesting, gory, and often disturbing horror from the director of Hostel, this is shocking in places, and hangs together well as a movie. OK, it feels a bit like an extended episode of The X Files, but there's nothing wrong with that.A good movie.

Welcome back to a new age of horror.  We are not in it just for the gore but for the story as well.  This movie was near perfect.  It plays on fears of people.  What would you do to protect yourself and family?  How far would you go?  This movie shows you just that.I will own this movie and will definitely watch it again before it leaves the theatre.  Take a chance on this movie, I'm sure that it will be around for some time.Thanks to the makers of this film. It is good to see that new ideas are still there for horror films and not just the same crap.

I already know the sequel will suck and the remake is god awful but this film is good. I like this film and I do see problems in the film. I'm not saying the film is the best but it's really bloody for fans that like horror movie that's bloody. Now Bert in this movie is the rebel (he's better than the other Bert in the remake). This film is good not great or perfect.Score: 7.5/10

I think I read someone els say it best. This movie was terrible. I understand that the toronto film fest launched this film, but to this day I can't understand why, or....why. I, mean I really watched this film with a genuinely open mind trying to look at it in many a different way, but failed to place my finger on how this thing got labeled as good! I wouldn't waist your time. worst thing, I hear they're trying to do a sequel. brother... Eli roth is supposed to be coming out with a horror film inspired by the movie "Audition." Audition was awesome, but I cringe to think what Eli's next film will be like.

Apart from the rest of the recent cheap horror movies, this movie is loaded with shocking gore and scenes so gross and at times nightmarish that if nothing else, you will remember it for some time to come.Cabin Fever has your basic plot (like that of Friday the 13th) where a bunch of teenagers decide to go to some remote location for a camping trip.  But the killer in this film is a flesh-eating disease that rots away at your body at an accelerated rate.  What's worse is that once the disease enters the bloodstream you're...yep, a goner!  And the death is slow, painless, and pretty much ruins your chances of getting a date on a Friday night.Five hapless individuals start out having the time of their youthful lives, living it up with the stereotypical sex, drugs, and rock-and- roll.  Soon after, they encounter a local man who is infected with the strange disease. The forester is somewhat delusional having been in the woods rotting away. He tries to seek help from the kids but their fear of him and the unknown that is eating away at him scare them.  In a panic they end up setting the stranger on fire.  What they fail to realize is that his dead body ends up floating in the nearby lake, infecting the small town's water supply. Anybody thirsty?  Well, of course, one of them ends up drinking the water. The remaining members go nuts over how the disease was contracted and they each begin turning on one another in a "every man for himself" philosophy. To add to the dire straits, their vehicle is out of commission so that they can't go for help.  As they try to repair it, time slowly ticks by.  One of them sits in a locked shed (sequestered from the others) slowly decomposing from the outside.  The rest of them are...well...standoffish to put it mildly.The ridiculous which is already somewhat present, enters in full when some of the villagers go after the teenagers to kill them before they contaminate the whole town.  The gore and shock levels then go up to a twelve on a ten-point scale with unforgettable scenes like the sleeping sick girl, the Listerine disinfecting (guys I know you'll cringe in pain), and the bathtub shaving scene (girls, this will make you feel different when shaving).This movie stands apart from the rest in disgustingly creative shock treatment with a killer that you can't see - a disease.  Cabin Fever will make you think of stocking up on Zephyr Hills water the next time you go camping.  Happy trails.

reviews.review_title: a great throwback horror flick, sam raimi would be proud
reviews.content: eli roth's cabin fever is a great ride full of gore, laughs, homages to classic horror movies, and a cabin that looks suspicialy like the one from the evil dead, but isn't that the point. eli roth also makes a hilareous cameo as a stoner, a role he played again in 2001 maniacs. the script is never going to win any Oscars, and not all the acting is great, but in a way it makes it more of a purer horror film, group of unknowns, in the woods, buckets of gore, just like the good old days. im a fan of eli roth's work, and the movie has a much lighter tone than his hostel movies, but is too grim to be a comedy, so in many ways it is like sam raimi's evil dead in it works better as both, i highly recommend

Spoiler Alert! I sort of liked this film and I cant believe it's over a decade old! I saw this when I was like 6 years old on TV, and I was always grossed out when it'd show how gory it could be! I was always bothered when it showed the red vision of the dog attacking Marcy because the thought of the hot Cerina Vincent being eaten alive, saddens me! I also got grossed out thinking about the acid burning the guy (off-screen). The whole feeling of the film is just gross and it makes you want to shower (Off course not in water) but in alcohol or something to get the feeling of being dirty off. I liked the story though and the girls weren't too bad looking! This is a gross but actually cool film, I happened to see on TV. Overall I give it a 5 out of 10!

this movie is freaking scary and i bet there are people making fun of me but i don't scare easily it is just scary seeing all that gore and to think that there may actually be a virus out there that can do this. Eli Roth makes a great debut performance and i give him 2 thumbs way UP!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!. if u wanna just watch a movie and cant decide just go to the movie store and rent cabin fever and tell me how it is by posting your own comment. something i didn't like was the continuous use of the F word i mean it would have been way more enjoyable watching a great horror movie without all the cursing i also think thats y everyone says bad things about it is because of the cussing. JUST REMEMBER IT IS AN ENJOYABLE MOVIE. RENT IT!!!!!!!!!!! Heath ***1/2 out of 4

So I went to see this film twice opening day not necessarily cause it was a great horror movie but because i had promised people I'd go see it with them at two different times that day. My first initial reaction after leaving it the first time was extremely mediocre. I felt it was completely innovative and clever.  The acting was good, the spfx gory, the story decent and the direction a little off kiltered.  I'm probably one of the biggest horror fans you'll ever meet! So my expectations were pretty high and although I felt the film delivered on many levels.  I loved the homages to Texas Chainsaw Massacre, Mother's Day, Last house on the left, Night of the living Dead, Evil Dead and etc. And the film is definatly a powerhouse for people who have seen these movies. But what the film truly lacked was entertainment value. It was truly an unpleasent film filled with nasty things.  Not very entertaining at all.  However, on second viewing after seeing it with an audience my opinion has changed. It's an audience movie, something cultish to be shown at midnight with a bunch of people that know the film scene for scene.  The auidence had a ball with this film, there was screaming and laughing.  And groans of disgust as they showed the nasty and believable fx(especially the leg shaving scene). So my opinion changed and I found it quite entertaining. Sure it's a sick movie but it definatly gets a great reaction from the audience and thats the way it should be seen.  The film may not be top of the line but the director and creator of this pic Eli Roth has big time flair.  I eagerly await his next and more finely tuned offerings. 7/10 -Don't miss out see it in the theatres

Never pass up an opportunity to see teenagers meeting gratuitously grisly ends. If only the cellphone-wielding adolescent cretins who insist on cluttering up my local cinema would suffer a similar fate. Then again, it was foolish of me to venture out to see a horror flick on its opening night and not expect a barrage of unfunny comments accompanied by a symphony of annoying ringtones. I live, but I don't learn.Oh, the movie. Patchy and derivative, but packed with enough bizarre and delightfully stomach-churning moments to overcome any technical shortcomings. If you want serious, beautifully rendered, intellectual fare, go see The Hours. I'd rather take a blood-soaked trip into the woods with three bozos, a bunch of hillbillies and a couple of scantily or unclad chicks.Certainly the most fun I've have at the flicks this year, moronic audience and all.

This is about some kids who go to a secluded cabin in the woods for some heavy duty partying. But there's a guy living out in the woods who has a strange disease - flesh eating bacteria or something. He ends up dying and falling into the reservoir for the area's drinking water. So, the infection spreads.The good: Nice characters; fun, sexy, humorous, likable. These folks seem like they could actually be a group of friends, they more or less like each other. Most of the action is fairly believable, most of the secondary characters are totally over the top but also in a sort of believable way.The bad: The plot. We never learn the source of this bacteria, and the movie doesn't really have any ending as far as the spread of the disease. Sure, there's a climax to the movie, and it's rather clever, but the whole disease thing is just left up in the air.Overall, I'll give it a 5. Average, okay, a semi-satisfying waste of 90 minutes.

There is nothing - and I mean NOTHING - of interest in this "film" for anyone who truly enjoys a good horror film. The TV ads are stuffed with raves from Peter Jackson, which should be good for box office. But having now seen this mess I feel I must ask: Is Peter Jackson related in any way to Susan Jackson the executive producer? If not then I'm baffled how someone who made a classic such as Dead Alive could see anything of merit in this remedial effort.Rent Manos, the Hands of Fate instead and feel secure in the knowledge that, as bad as it is, it's better than Cabin Fever.

reviews.review_title: A Good Effort in the New Paranoia (possible spoilers)
reviews.content: While not a perfect movie by any means, Cabin Fever succeeds in  creating an atmosphere of suspense at appropriate times while not becoming entirely dependent on gore and violence to get there.  The acting was passable and the story was well-told, with enough specifics left to the imagination to allow the audience to fill in the blanks with their own imagination -- a trademark of a successfully executed horror/suspense film.  The pacing is excellent; there are enough tongue-in-cheek moments and nods to the films which influenced it (including Cujo, Evil Dead, Night of the Living Dead, and Friday the 13th) to let the audience catch their breath before they start waiting for the next crescendo.  Each of the main characters has their own story and their own moment of climax throughout the film, giving the whole enough energy to reach a conclusion that makes it obvious that there WILL be a sequel.  A few factors make this a foregone conclusion:* One of the main characters survives* What's in the box?  Hint:  The director is already at work on a film with the working title "The Box."* A truck full of the local water pulls out of town in the film's last scene.This film is part of a new genre.  In the 1950's and 1960's, the main source of paranoia was the USSR and nuclear weapons.  During the height of the Cold War, there were a long series of films about atomic mutants, creatures awakened by the bomb (e.g. Godzilla), and the world ending in nuclear war (On the Beach, for instance).  In today's new paranoia, the focus is on biological weapons, and hence we are seeing a new series of films that play to that fear.  "28 Days Later..." and "Cabin Fever" are excellent examples of this, and we can expect to see many more films of this sort coming at us in rapid succession over the next few years.All in all, "Cabin Fever" is worth seeing.  There's enough here to keep those who aren't going to faint at the sight of blood entertained.  It's not a great film, but it's definitely not a bad one.

Director Eli Roth is a rather clever man, as can be seen from this modern day horror film which has aspects of 70's and 80's horror in it. The movie should not be taken too seriously, it is a fun film, and it looks as though the cast are all enjoying themselves. The five main actors - Rider Strong, Jordan Ladd, Cerina Vincent, James DeBello and Joey Kern - are all great, particularly Strong and Ladd. The premise of the film is nothing new for a horror and blends the hillbilly outback of "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre" with the cabins of "Friday the 13th", and a deadly virus liken to "Monkey Shine". The combination, with great direction and a likable cast make for a good film that, while intense, does not require too much thinking. 8/10

I've seen this film twice now and my opinion both times still seems to be dazed and confused.  I didn't hate this movie.  But I did not feel it was the greatest thing since pancakes that everyone keeps yelling about.  I did like that they used real horror elements.  The virus and the cabin scenario were fine.  We didn't need a Freddy or a Jason here.  But I felt alot of the parodies with the cops and the redneck townfolks just didn't work very well and the film would have been much better played as a straight horror film. I would definitely leave Dennis in the film, though.  I think if I had to give an opinion, I'd have to say I liked it, but it wasn't real horror to me.  Having seen Redneck Zombies, a much older film, that one worked where this one failed.  As well as Texas Chainsaw Massacre, the original.  The reason I'm comparing these films is because Redneck Zombies really got the comedy right where I feel this film failed.  And Texas Chainsaw worked because it was played as straight horror.  Combining both elements just didn't feel right in this film.  So, I think I'm still confused as to what to call this movie.  I thought it dragged in alot of places.  The gore alone is not enough to save the film.  It's just one of those movies where you have to see it and make up your own mind on it.

reviews.review_title: The last "B" horror movie I will ever see.
reviews.content: From the opening dialog and scenes, I knew I knew I was in for a train wreck. Didn't want to look, but couldn't turn away. If it weren't for the meer eye candy of this film, I would have given one star. The fact that the interaction between characters and relationship behavior were so far fetched, added by poor direction and horrible story make this movie nothing more than a low-budget disaster. Money is definitely not a necessity to make a good film. But this movie fails so horribly there was no chance to rebound.If you were stuck out in the woods, your childhood best friend dying from an unknown disease, other friends dying around you, stranded in a strange place, what would you do?A.) Run away from everyone and try your luck on your own. B.) Have sex with your friends girlfriend. C.) Take a hot bath to relax your sorrows to include shaving your legs. D.) Bash in the head your childhood best friend and life-long crush with a shovel. E.) All of the above.According to Eli Roth, none of these answers are that far fetched. In fact, all are plausible and well represented in Cabin Fever. The total lack of reality and illogical attempt at explaining what people would do in traumatic situations throws this film in the bonehead bin at your local rental store. Stay away. Stay far away.

Upon it's release this film was very heavily hyped as the best horror film in recent years. It isn't. However it is far from bad. The story revolves around five teenagers who go to a remote cabin in the woods to spend a week of shooting squirrels, having sex and drinking, but instead end up with a flesh-eating virus.The plot naturally enough gives plenty of opportunity for gruesome special effects, which are good for the most part, and despite being riddled with implausibilities and some frankly ridiculous scenes, the film remains for the most part both suspenseful and fun. The teenagers are mostly adequate enough, but they are not really particularly likable or interesting enough to care for.Fans of "splatter" horror films will probably enjoy this.

Seriously, this flick is just gross.  It's not scary or thrilling at all. I love me some horror movies, and I don't mind gore, but this was just icky. I just wanted to take a shower the whole time I was watching it.  Or if I could have had some of that sanitizer gel in my purse, that would have been great.There wasn't anyone who was really likable, and they all pretty much deserved to die.  I want my $7 dollars back so I can go see Cold Stone Manor this weekend.

reviews.review_title: If you like downbeat 70s/80s style splatter horror, this'll be for you
reviews.content: Cabin Fever starts pretty much as it means to go on. Within about five minutes of the fairly odd opening credit sequence, we've seen a dead dog covered in flies split in two. If this makes you think you're gonna hurl, grab some sick bags or just don't watch the movie at all, as it doesn't get any better.You see, seems there's a virus passing around the backwoods. Cue braindead teenagers piling into said backwoods for a bracing weekend of beer and nookie. As they do, in the States at least. One encounter with an infected local leads to the virus getting into their water supply, and the rest is fairly self-explanatory.It's nice (in a way) to see something as uncompromisingly nasty as Cabin Fever. In a similar fashion to Wrong Turn and The Toolbox Murders remake, Cabin Fever is unrepentantly un-PC and downbeat, and honestly all the better for it. Nobody in this movie gets off easy, good guys or bad guys, and to be honest, the teenagers are such vile self-serving pieces of work that it seems almost right that something bad should happen to them.That said, the movie is totally unbalanced. An attempt to inject some Evil Dead style slapstick comedy is pretty badly judged, and the less said about the almost Dude Where's My Car style dialogue the better. The main reason both are unwelcome is that without them, Cabin Fever would pack so much more punch. The failure for the elements of frat-boy comedy, doom-laden plotting and visceral gore sequences to ever mesh means that you'll come out wondering what the hell you just saw.Basically, Cabin Fever is a brave, violent addition to the horror genre, but not without it's flaws.
