On a final note, if you learn anything from this film let it be this: DON'T SET FIRE TO PEOPLE WHO TRY TO ASK YOU FOR HELP. THEY MIGHT BE INFECTED WITH A FLESH EATING SUPERVIRUS.

reviews.review_title: Its So Bad It's Not Even a B-Horror Movie
reviews.content: I am a fan of scary/horror movies, some of which fall into the b-horror movie category and some that do not, and I even like a good comedic horror flick like an Evil Dead 2 or anything that falls into Peter Jackson's early zombie movie career, and so I can therefore appreciate films like that. With that being said Cabin Fever is the worst movie that falls into any of those categories that I've ever seen (not that I know what category it was even hoping it'd fall into because yes whether it was meant to be comedic or whatever I have no idea). I was just too amazed at how dumb it all was. The teens in this movie are of course stereotypical of what you would find in a b-horror movie (though in my opinion worse than that actually I mean you expect a bit of stereotypical nature when you see these movies, but when you start hoping everyone will soon just die off you know something must be wrong here).All in all save your time and your money from this movie. Your brain just may thank you later.

reviews.review_title: Awful...I want my money and my wasted time back.
reviews.content: This was far and away one of the worst movies I have ever seen (and believe me, I see a lot of movies). The plot was ridiculous, the acting sub par, and the scares non-existent. I really feel that Eli Roth, the cast, and everyone involved in the making of "Cabin Fever" owe me $9 and 93 minutes of my life back. It might have been tolerable if they decided to camp it up, but they took it all so seriously. They couldn't decided on a consistent tone and it was not scary AT ALL. They just threw around a bunch of blood and gore in place of coming up with involving characters or story. On top of everything else, this movie seemed to have no interest in facts or logic. As a scientist, I can tell you that their handling of the disease was completely off base.

reviews.review_title: This isn't a documentary, let's see some gore.
reviews.content: Cabin Fever should serve as a warning to new film makers... don't try to be clever. If you are clever, it will show in your work; if you're not clever no amount of trying will compensate.The movie starts well and has a very good, very straightforward plot: college kids in a remote location that are infected by a flesh eating bacteria. They try to survive each other as they try to survive the bacteria. But we can't just stop there, we have to have sexual intrigue (an excuse for nudity), a killer dog and some mentally unstable town's people and they just don't mesh together.I would have liked some stronger effects from the bacteria. They get infected, they bleed some, they fall down, bleed some more and die. Whoopee. This isn't a documentary, let's see some gore.

I'm a HUGE fan of horror movies, but this was awful. You know it's gonna be a waste of time when the biggest name in the movie is the sidekick from "Boy Meets World." It had potential, but it wasted it. I didn't give up until the Ninja Inbred Pancake Boy scene. I'll give it some credit: the last scene is hilarious!

I saw this movie last night with my girl and I was expecting a great horror flick... The premise certainly sounded good and I was hearing some good reviews (albiet from internet sites). Well, to say it bluntly the movie was garbage. You know in horror movies where the person (i.e. victim) is doing something stupid and you want to yell out " Hey idiot, keep running" or "Don't go in that house!" EVERY scene in this movie is like that. This kids have to be the dumbest people on the planet. When one of your friends gets horribly sick from a virus, I personally would run until I found a hospital and if they couldn't help, I would call or assume they would call, someone who could help. The kids throw their friend in a tool shed and slowly all contract it. Sure there was some gore, but I have never wanted the "victims" to die as much as I did here.The script was poor, the acting subpar, the jokes fell flat, etc. etc. All of the people who have given this great reviews are seriously misleading you people. They might try to play the "I understand what this movie was trying to say" card and dare you to, but it is a ruse. There is nothing to understand. Except this movie sucks. 3 out of 10 simply for the bathtub scene which made me kind of ill, and thats why I went to see this, was to be grossed out and maybe a little frightened, but all I got was my IQ lowered twenty points.

I've saw this movie the other night and I have to say it was pretty good. A lot of this pays homage to Sam Riami's 1981 horror movie "The Evil Dead". But instead of a group of young adults getting killed by them becoming zombified something else was taking them out. A mysterious flesh-eating virus that's highly contagious. I loved the suspense in the movie which reminds me of the old school horror. However I don't consider this a horror movie but more like a suspense-mystery somewhat like an X-files. The character James Debello plays (Bert or Burt) stands out. He's obnoxious,vulgar,self-centered and colorful. This movie as some odd twist which could have been for a made-for-cable movie. Not bad Eli Roth just keep to the suspense.

As horror movies go. But remarkable for introducing Justin, the stoner and his dog, Dr Mambo. Twice in the past 2 years, the name 'Dr Mambo' has come to mind, and I had to search to find the name of the movie.Just the way the stoner said 'Dr mambo' and the pretension.needed to saddle your poor dog with that moniker, made me root for him to be a victim. (but not the good doctor)

Before I say anything about the actual movie I want to say that I love when detail is put into the menu. It's a minor detail but it adds a little charm as well as uniqueness. With that said I really liked the menu design. This was my first time watching Cabin Fever and I must say I'm surprised. I wasn't expecting it to be as good as it was. It kept it's atmosphere during the entire movie and the pacing was smooth. The writing was well done and the cast was perfect. This movie does make me miss the times when people could take a joke and not be so sensitive about everything. I would definitely recommend this to anyone who likes horror movies and hasn't seen it.

reviews.review_title: Try hard college student makes movie.
reviews.content: When a director tries to make a cult classic, it is indeed a sad affair. This movie is one of the stupidest most pretentious movies I have ever seen in my life. And I have watch millions of movies. Don't go see this movie you will be wasting your time, I found nothing amusing let alone scary about it. I found the homage factor to other movies, shameful, and boring. The whole movie was cheap college Junk rapped in pretentious direction.Overall:Try hard college student makes movie. Junk rapped in pretentious direction.

reviews.review_title: Scary, but not everyone cup of coffee
reviews.content: As we already known, Cabin Fever supposed to be a homage to 70/80's horror classic, so the atmosphere and style are very reminiscent of those. Watching Cabin Fever is as watching those prior flicks with a bit millennium touch. The result is a scary and intense gore-fest.Cabin Fever told us about a bunch kids spend their weekend in a cabin deep in the wood. Little do they know, a deadly virus spread over the wood. When they realize that their life in danger, it's too late for them! The act for survive can be deadly it self.There's a lot horror movies lately, but most of them could easily watch with our own entire family (they aren't scary). In this case, I think the director is well managed the tension and did a good amount between scary and funny moments. Despite the cliché character and plot (it's the homage, right?), this is a good movie, even I can say that it is a restless movie. I must warn those whose have weak-hearted, this is not your cup of coffee and avoid it like the virus it self, before you burst your intestines out. If you miss those American Horror Movies that ever glory in the yesteryears, you should watch this. But if you dislike the sickening scenes and gore, avoid this!7/10

reviews.review_title: If you're a germophobe with a nasty sense of humor and a love for grimy horror/splatter...
reviews.content: I am, of course, a movie lover who would fit such a description. This is one of the best damn splatter-comedies I've seen in a painful golden age. It was tense, sick and twisted enough, very well-done, and VERY, VERY funny. I guess I went overboard when I, too, went on about it being revolutionary (it really isn't). I will instead say that, whether it's revolutionary film or not, it's definitely one of my favorite recent films, and I just could't help but love it more every time I've seen it. There are multiple threats in this, with a flesh-eating virus, dumb, vicious rednecks, and a dog that craves human meat, and nobody comes staggering in like a self-knowing model who took too much vicadan. This movie is the real deal. It starts off a bit slow and I was worried that it was going to go downhill for a short while instead of getting better. Boy, was I relieved when this turned into one of the greatest horror films of all time (in my despised opinion). Not many movies can get under my skin (no pun intended) without truly frightening me, but this one did. Even fewer horror films that get under my skin actually made me feel like I was having fun, even some of my favorites! Some old school-tribute horror movies like "The Dead Hate the Living!" and the aforementioned "House of 1,000 Corpses" just turned out to be fun (but very mediocre) time wasters, but this is one movie I'm sure is going to remain close to my heart in the same way that classics like "The Evil Dead" have (or at least "Bad Taste"). Wanna know why Peter Jackson liked this movie? See his first three, "Bad Taste", "Meet the Feebles", and "Braindead" (a.k.a. "Dead-Alive"). If I laughed my ass off at those, I can enjoy this one as well. Yes, it's more of a dark comedy than a straight horror film. Get over it if you like early Peter Jackson! By the way, more great horror comedies I recommend: "Phantasm", "Bubba Ho-Tep", "Evil Dead 2", "Cemetery Man" (a.k.a. "Dellamorte Dellamore"), "The Toxic Avenger", and may other genre-hybrids that get the same deserved respect that "Cabin Fever" deserves, so COME OFF IT and quit hating over it! (There's always better reasons to hate people than fun movies.)

Its true that this movie doesn't really have a direction.  It kind of meanders around a bit.   But, all its meandering is HILARIOUS.  Party Cop, Grim, man, the characters that pop into  this film are great.  This movie has an identity problem, it doesn't really decide whether  it is a comedy or a horror, but overall, its excellent.  Buy some Miller High Life, get together with people who have a sense of humor and you will enjoy this movie!

reviews.review_title: Cabin Fever: Accidental Comedy; AKA Dumbest Movie in 10 years.
reviews.content: If you sit through the first 20 minutes or so of Cabin Fever, you might actually be sold on the idea that you are in for a decent ride. It's funny in a high school, Stifler sort of way, and the shots of the woods have definite creep potential. Then the 'killer' comes and everything falls apart. I say killer in quotes because we don't have Jason or Freddy charging the horny teens down, but rather 1) An ill conceived disease that afflicts a dog, then a hick in the forest, 2) A German Shepherd who randomly charges them for no reason and runs off every time a clumsily executed gunshot is fired in its general direction, and 3) A random assortment of inbred looking rednecks. This movies cuts scenes so randomly that it looks like it was filmed in 2 or 3 random locations. For example, the cabin they stay in is a tiny box in the middle of a forest, yet a scene between Rider Strong (porn star name?) and one of the females has French doors and tapestries and wallpapered walls. Then there is a random kid sitting on a bench in front of the random general store, who randomly bites Rider in the beginning of the film. As an perfect culmination of everything stupid and random about this movie, towards the end this kid jumps off the bench, screams "pancakes" repeatedly and attacks the air in a variously assorted pattern of Bruce Lee like Kung Fu moves, and bites one of the teens.This film will walk you out of the theater feeling closer to your fellow theater go-ers; like any crisis situation you feel the instinct to band together with and hug your fellow human beings. You will, for perhaps one of the few times in your life, feel the need to approach random strangers and warn them not to see this movie.

Cabin Fever, the debut film of now well-known director Eli Roth, really split oceans amongst horror and gore fans. Was this just a ripoff of classic slasher/zombie/gore movies, or was this something brand new to scare the decomposed flesh off our bones? In my opinion, it was neither. What we got was something far more interesting.Cabin Fever documents the journey of 5 friends who travel to the woods to relax in an old cabin. One by one, they become infected with a flesh-eating virus and tensions within the cabin rise as they try their hardest to ensure that the disease doesn't spread. The film makes great use of relatively unknown actors; Rider Strong makes a great 'leading man' of sorts, trying desperately to keep his friends together while battling the deadly virus. Joey Kern is the prissy boy who is amongst the first to lose his composure when faced with the possibility of death, and he pulls off his characters attitude perfectly. James DeBello is wonderful as the typical friend-who-no-one-likes-but-comes-along-anyway, and his ultimate fate is ironic, especially when you consider how he behaves throughout the film towards his friends. The female roles, however, could've been casted better. Cerina Vincent spends a lot of time naked on screen, and I can't help feeling that she was cast mostly because of her looks. Jordan Ladd was an exact average; nothing spectacular, but nothing mind-blowingly horrible, either. The film is shot and edited very nicely, and the occasional atmospheric shot of the cabin, filtered red, was a great little touch. Cabin Fever also features one of my favorite opening credits ever."But this was advertised as a horror movie. Is it scary?" I watched this movie knowing full well that I was not going to be scared in the same way as if I were watching The Ring, partly because I felt the director knew it too; he wanted to make an R-rated movie to be released in theatres at a time when movie companies were largely creating PG-13's, and he did something quite unusual; he scared his audience, not with fear, but with disgust. I was delighted by the makeup and special effects featured in Cabin Fever. If you're watching this movie for anything, do it for the decomposing flesh. The image of the leading ladys' half-rotten face has been permanently imprinted onto my retinas, and it's there to stay. The fact that the virus and its symptoms are based on a real disease makes the experience much creepier.So put the popcorn in the microwave, crack open a can of your favorite beverage, and lean back and enjoy Cabin Fever. You've probably heard more people condemn it than praise it, but give it a shot and you'll see it's not bad at all.

reviews.review_title: Makes me hot just thinkin' about it
reviews.content: This movie was just a hell of a lot of fun. I should preface this (anddate myself) by saying I grew up in the horror boom in the 80's.Other fans in their 30's... remember when movies like this cameout ALL THE TIME? Remember when animatronic, not CGI, werethe norm? Remember when you didn't have to wait for DVD forsomething fun like this, when you knew it would play in a localtheater that wasn't a huge pain in the ass to get to, you could justgo catch a matinee alone if you couldn't wait? I grew up buggingmy parents (till I was 17) to take me to see The Thing, TheHowling, American Werewolf in London, Evil Dead 2, Scanners...and I got spoiled, because I figured horror flicks like that wouldalways be the norm. Young, naive, I thought things would alwaysbe this great.So I guess it's sort of bittersweet that when I heard about thismovie harkening back to the 80's and even 70's good old gory funguilty pleasure horror flicks, I got so excited I almost peed mypants. I read about it in Fango (I've been a subscriber and readevery issue cover-to-cover eagerly since 1986, that should give youan idea of my horror fan credentials) Premise? A group of teensare trapped in the woods, hunted not by a boring slasher, but aflesh-eating virus. OK, sold me right there. That right there isenough to make me want to see it. Then I heard it had animatronic, no CGI, the filmmakers were about the same age asme and grew up on the same films, just wanted the movie to beentertaining like the good old days, and got more excited. Thebittersweet part, I guess, is how much I had to go out of my way tohunt down info about it and buy tickets in advance to see it atSeattle International Film Festival (Since I missed out on BubbaHo-Tep, by God, I was NOT missing this one), though I didn't mindthe line around the block an hour in advance (more nostalgia,especially for when I saw Dead Alive at a midnight show there--gulp--ten years ago).The audience that night in May of 2003 was packed with fans likeus, who were also, how do I put this, not entirely sober, ready tohave a blast, and we weren't let down. When this comes out inwide release-- YES, they made it into wide release!! see it at a latenight opening weekend for maximum fun and impact. As I saidbefore, I don't remember every single detail of the film (if you getmy chemical drift) but I don't need to, and you can see it sober andstill get every iota of entertainment out of it. A group of college-age kids decide to head out to an extremely EvilDead-style rural cabin, get stoned, have fun. One of the guys has ahuge crush on a blonde, now dating his buddy, he's been justfriends' with until now, and he hopes to change this over theweekend. The way this particular plot thread/character arc endswas probably the most haunting in a movie filled with seriouslynightmarish moments.There were plenty of laugh-out-loud moments-- the audience,including me, roared through the whole film and cheered withapproval so frequently (at the gruesome as well as the funny parts)that I missed many lines. There were also groans of anticipation(that sounded pornographic, didn't mean it that way) when wecould all see foreshadowing of something satisfying to come. Butthese weren't the  `Well, I can see THIS coming five miles away'predictability- type groans-- instead, the audience were made up ofsavvy horror fans who saw a great payoff coming and got it.It's not perfect (though damn close enough for me). It wasgruesome, but the buckets of gore' had been hyped so much Iwas a little surprised it wasn't bloodier. Plenty of gross-outs,though, and keep in mind this is a reviewer who has seen thedeleted scenes from the UNCUT version of Dead Alive and is thusvery, very jaded and almost impossible to shock. I doubt most gorefans will go away unsatisfied. An ending that I thought left one plotthread hanging (and not in a set-up-for-a-sequel way, just in ahuh? way) but again, I could have missed it.For me, though, the single scene worth twice the price ofadmission is a campfire tale told in flashback early on in the filmthat is a Tales From the Crypt fan's wet dream, about a killer in abowling alley. Kind of a throwaway thing that isn't tied in intricatelywith the plot of the movie, but was the *single coolest thing* I'veseen in any movie all year. The audience obviously was just aselated as we were because they ROARED through the wholesequence. For that alone, I give Cabin Fever 10/10 stars.I also am not a flamer, but I have to say-- those of you calling thismovie a rip-off do not know the difference between a rip-off and atribute. There's tons of rip-offs out there. Cabin Fever is a tribute.And the rest of the flick isn't bad either. Go, and have a blast likeyou used to in the good ole 80's golden years of the horror flick. Isit too much to hope that this will start some sort of nostalgic trend?From what I've read in interviews from the filmmakers (whoworked their ass off making, financing, and pitching the film)expect more of the same from them, at least.

I was lucky enough to see Cabin Fever at a screening in Sydney where there was a Q&A session with director Eli Roth after the viewing.The film itself seemed to have many homages to the classic horror movies of the 70s/80s, which was reassuring. This director knows his film history, and knows how to share that knowledge without ever going overboard.Cabin Fever is relentlessly gory. And considering 'the killer' in this case is a flesh eating virus, it makes the film all the more entertaining and keeps your hands hovering over your eyes- with the occasional peek.There is just enough humor without going overboard- mainly coming from "the jock", who likes to shoot squirrels, because 'they're gay'.As for the discussion after the film, Eli came across as a down-to-earth person who knows his stuff. He has a passion for classic horror. His feet are firmly planted on the ground. My call is that Eli Roth is going to become a household name.

reviews.review_title: The biggest nose dive in movie history
reviews.content: I get the feeling that some one only wrote the first twenty pages of this script, and then just decided to wing it and start filming.  The movie opens well.  Fun loving teens head out to the boonies for a stay in a cottage, but the peaceful atmosphere keeps getting pierced by creepier and creepier characters and events.  Finally disaster strikes and the friends turn on each other.Unfortunately, from here on out the movie turns into a series of go-nowhere plot points that will bore you to sleep.  The gore is of high quality and can really make you cringe, but as the film progresses, gore becomes the focal point until it's so over the top that it's comical at the same time. Once the plot falls apart and the gore no longer commands any interest, the movie drags on like a boring, wounded animal.  When the ending finally comes, it's more like a Wayans Brothers parody of an ending and you'll be screaming in horror that you actually paid money for a chance to sit through this bomb.Fear this movie, but for all the wrong reasons.

Great movie.  It strikes a perfect balance between the laughs and the scares.  One minute you're laughing your arse off, the next you're on the edge of your seat, or squirming in it.  I thought the acting was good, I've definitely seen much, much worse and I don't know why some people are complaining.  Some nice editing and the visuals (containing blood and gore) aren't overdone.  If I had to pick one fault, it would be that Cabin Fever does drag on at the end. A good movie - if you're a casual horror fan or hardcore, check it out.

I heard all the reviews about "Cabin Fever".  I read all the reviews that praised this movie.  Now I have one question......... WHY??? Here are the things good about "Cabin Fever". (1)  Good General Idea (2)  Good Basic Story (3)  Gore/ Gross Out (4)  Decent ActingHowever, that was all the good stuff.  Which, that disappoints me.  This movie could have been so much better.  Like I said earlier, this movie had a excellent idea for a movie.  That idea could have been built upon to mae a excellent movie!!! Unfortunately, they didnt get the idea down on paper right.  The script sucked!!!  The way it was told, sucked.  The way they turned the idea into a actual story.... sucked. This is probably one of the worst movies I have ever set through.  There is one thing that will give me nightmares though,...... knowing I paid $7 to watch this trash.   Granted, people did laugh!!!  However, most laugh werent at the jokes in the movie, they were at the pure stupdity of the movie.SMALL  SPOILER!!!!!!!I did really enjoy one scene though.  ....."PANCAKES!!!!!" as a hillbilly kid jumps off the porch doing Power Ranger moves.I laughed my butt off.

*slight spoilers*Why, oh why, do we punish horror films the second they begin to become good films?  Is it because we're afraid they'll monopolize film?  Corrupt us? Desensitize us?I am sorely disappointed at the critical response to this film.  Most seem to be willing to denounce it as uneven, choppy, gory, and generally garbage. Even the positive reviews come up short, gleefully wallowing in the spectacle of this film's nastier scenes.Hey!  Did it ever occur to you folks that this film might actually have something to offer or *gasp* an intelligent message?This particular horror story has it all in spades.  Not since George Romero's Living Dead films have I seen a horror movie with such a strong sense of its social and political environment.  As a vision and critique of contemporary American society (with all its paranoia and not-quite-genuine altruism), this film outshines anything we've seen lately.  All you have to do is take a step back and examine what you think might be represented by the people at the general store.If that's too subtle for you (though I can't imagine how, given the karate sequence), don't despair.  There's even a conversation which likens the characters' plight to being on a crashing plane.  A crashing plane?  Hmm . .. . It also manages the rather neat trick of making us like its characters, despite their frequently deranged behavior. (with the possible exception of Jeff, but I'll let you make up your own mind).  Even the perpetual screw-up Bert manages to be somewhat endearing in his own way, if for no other reason than his apparent isolation from the rest of the human race.You're free to like or dislike this movie.  Some people are just going to hate this, no matter what.  But please give it the credit it deserves.

reviews.review_title: Thank God I didn't pay for this...
reviews.content: Quite honestly, the only reason I went to see this movie was because I read that the director was a protege of David Lynch.  I later found that apparently he only did research for Lynch on some kind of play. Regardless, this movie was, in a word, bad.The acting was subpar and felt forced.  In all fairness, it could've been better if the script hadn't been so horrendous.  The dialogue was awkward and stupid, conversations would end abruptly with a cutting remark like, "Don't be gay," or they would meander on pointlessly without any damn point at all.The pace of the movie was slow, which was the only similarity to David Lynch I could detect, but it was too slow.  Especially considering the characters were the stupidest bunch of people I've ever seen in a movie.  I mean, even the guys from "Return of the Living Dead" were smarter than they were.  I wanted these asses to die.  In the slowest, most painful was possible.Quite honestly, what with the bad dialogue, the crappy editing, the detestable characters, and the Special Needs slow pace of this little cinematic piece of crap, my friend and I left the theater after about an hour or so.  Save your money and see something decent.

reviews.review_title: hilarious - sam raimi would be proud...
reviews.content: i am a BIG fan of horror and "B movies". this was both. i noticed by the comments that a lot o people DID think it was supposed to be an honestly scary horror film. i did too. i went to see it big screen and was a little miffed that i was watching something closer to ed wood than john carpenter - especially after the "return to the 70s" hype. i left disappointed. when it came out on DVD, i rented it again to give it another round and i laughed my a** off. i got it! i got it! this is homage to the severely laughable. nods at wonderful movies like army of darkness, toxic avenger, phantasm, and rabid grannys as well as the honored nods at raimi, king, craven and carpenter. here is horror for the humorist.

One of the worst films ever made. I never stopped laughing through this entire film. It was so cliché that it was laughable. The dialogue consisted of simply curse words and the characters were immature dirt bags that I wanted to see get sick. They constantly over reacted and were prone to violence that made no sense. They fit every cliché in the book all they did was curse drink and have sex. It was terrible and I am a big fan of horror movies. This movie was a terrible b film that the studios decided to pick up and market and sucker us into seeing it. The studio knew it was terrible but was able to sucker some of us into the theaters and made some nice money on it. Do not give them the satisfaction save your money and go rent a nightmare on elm street flick. This movie is simply deplorable. Also every horror movie now portrays people from the south as crazy old hicks who carry shotguns and hate outsiders. I would think this stereotyping is really getting to the people of the south. Once again that is a cliché and what this movie is based on. What a miserable film. You will lose brain cells watching this movie.

reviews.review_title: Much Better Than I Originally Thought
reviews.content: When I first saw "Cabin Fever" I did not like it, because it seemed unduly cruel and stark for me. No one has any empathy for anybody, the characters are exposed as selfish and, selfishly violent.The story is like any other typical teenage horror film: five kids finish college, head to woods and start dying because of deadly disease that makes them bleed out of every orifice in their body, while creating new ones. The plot sounds silly and when you watch it, the gore can be offputting. While the film is not very violent (few people actually get punched or killed), the effects of the chief enemy, the ambiguous disease are absolutely disgusting. And the film basks in it, mocking the amount of it - it remains detached, showing us cold outpouring of blood.Consider a scene in which one of the main characters finally grows the testicles to allow an old, blond and hot friend of his know how he feels. He does so by lying in bed with her as she rests her head from her headache and massages her neck, then breasts, then navel and then his hand travels into the darker nether-regions of the under-the-sheet-world. The girl gasps excitedly, even though an unsettling I'm-fingering-a-jar-of-peanut-butter sound can be heard in the background. Clearly something is not right. The hero, bright as he is, catches on quickly and his hand returns into daylight from its unlit encounter with the-object-of-its-lust's lower body. Except the return to daylight is anything but reassuring - the hand, soiled with blood and sticky flesh, shocks the hero. The sheets fly off (in what would have inevitably been the course of action anyway, though perhaps with a different result if the girl wasn't gasping excitedly from disease not from approaching orgasm) and lo, behold: a hole in her thigh.This is merely the beginning. The plot commences with scenes like this and ends with the collapse of benevolent human relations between these friends. The sick girl is isolated from the rest of the group who do not want to get sick. Soon, however, they do - otherwise there would be no horror. And they begin vomiting copious amounts of blood, all over their car mainly (something about that damn truck...) and each other, and the terror heightens.Now, by its end, the film has exposed the viewer to really unpleasant events, some involving road kill, some involving blood and gore, and some involving simple lack of human sympathy and a general indifference to the growing tragedy. This final element is particularly gruesome, because though these horrid things unravel, no one really seems to care about anything, but saving their own skin. Or partying like one notably strange character, who is also supposed to be the symbol of authority.By the end, few of the friends are friends and few people are alive. Having witnessed this strange evil character, an ambiguous, omnipresent disease swallow life up (metaphorically and literally) it's easy to be repulsed and disgusted. To feel unclean.However, when the movie ended and I had forgotten about it, it returned to me. Yeah, not one character was likable, not one course of action was honorable, and even the ending was a joke in poor taste. Still, the feeling of uncleanness is precisely what "Cabin Fever" is after. It's very successful at making the viewer uneasy and that's precisely what a good horror film should do. And the horror of "Cabin Fever" is not so much the disease that eats up all that it puts its germs on, but that a tragedy can so easily expose the darkness lurking in people, their truly repulsive disgusting nature. Nothing in "Cabin Fever" is as it appears - that is precisely its point. That's why an officer of the law constantly speaks of "partying" and "crashing parties" and that's why the lines at the end are a qualification of *apparently* negative nature of those same lines in the beginning. And, most importantly, those we love or consider friends suddenly become our enemies, attacking our well-being."Cabin Fever" is about the state of nature, where life is nasty, brutish and short. This is a place where no alliances are forged out of good will, where social institutions like hospitals and police are either useless or inimical in and of themselves, and where friends are friends until they stop being useful in safe sexual gratification. "Cabin Fever" is a scary film precisely because the gore is the context, while the way the characters react to it is its subject. It is about psychological de-humanization (though I don't want to give it too much credit - it is, after all, only a horror movie.)

All I can say was that the kid at the convenience store was..... What was his purpose?  The movie was great up until that point.  He just jumped off the porch and started yelling about Pancakes and doing Matrix stuff!  It was so stupid and pointless.  Everyone I've talked to about the movie brought that up.  It was useless and the movie stunk after that.

reviews.review_title: Possibly the worst film ever made...
reviews.content: I've just watched Cabin Fever for the first (and last) time & I simply cannot believe how bad this film is!! I expected it to be a nice little thriller with a bit of blood and gore but oh how wrong could I be? No wonder everyone in it is an unknown - they're likely to stay that way too, with acting as wooden as one of the trees in the forest they're in!! Is it meant to be hilarious or is it just incredibly bad?? The director tries to make up for the complete lack of plot, (script, acting etc.) by adding gallons of unnecessary blood and gore and a few semi naked bimbos. I stayed with it until the end just out of sheer jaw dropping fascination to see what else might happen but I really wish I hadn't bothered. After an hour or so of watching this film, you'll wish that you too had contracted the disease and rotted alive, as it would have been far less painful than staying with it until the end ;-)

reviews.review_title: I wish I had never seen this movie.
reviews.content: A one sentence summary:  A few corny jokes mixed in between tests of your gag reflex, and all topped off with an ending that didn't explain or solve anything.  I wish I had missed this one, not because it was scary, but because it was just disgusting and there was no plot behind it.  There's no explanation of what the virus is, all you know is that one guy gets it and everyone else starts to get it, too.  There's no real struggle to stop the virus or to stay alive (you know...PLOT), and it's like they go out of their way to make sure that you hate all the main characters and don't care when they die.  I was hoping for something along the lines of The Ring, where there are plot twists and a freaky cause of all of it, but there's nothing like that.  This is just a gore flick.  If you like that, fine.  If not, be glad that you were blessed with an ounce of brains and SKIP THIS MOVIE.

reviews.review_title: Just okay to watch once, but nothing I would ever see twice.
reviews.content: "Cabin Fever" has a plot that is very simple. This is it: A guy cut up a sick infected dead dog. The guy gets infected of course. Then the guy transfers this virus to out-of-towner kids who are coming into town to screw around. The kids then die off one by one with horrible rashes where their skin peels off.Then the townspeople find out about what happened and instead of calling in help to save the kids or quarantine them, they decide to kill whoever is left alive, and burn the bodies. That's the whole movie pretty much.The beginning with the dead dog carcass was kind of a disappointment, because it was obvious what would follow. Although this movie has been bashed repeatedly (sometimes fairly, sometimes not fairly), the one thing I think was pretty scary was the scene was this.... When the couple were about to have sex in bed and he's touching the girl's thigh. It is bloody and then you realize she's been infected down there. That was gross.Overall, this was not a bad movie despite being a little too much on silly side. There were a few good twists that made it worthwhile. The twist at the end was also not bad, and was unexpected. The big problem is that the characters are not likable and you don't care if they get infected or not.

In a desolate cabin, five recent college graduates spend the week off the beaten path. As Paul (Ryder Strong) and Karen (Jordan Ladd) look to start a romance, Jeff (Joey Kern) and Marcy (Cerina Vincent) look to mend theirs. Fifth wheel Bert (James DeBello) has a run-in with a man contaminated with a gruesome disease, who then attempts to get into the groups' cabin. With the risk of infection high and being outsiders in a tight-knit community, the five must trust each other to get help before the disease can spread.Director Eli Roth had a clear vision for his directorial debut, and used every trick in the book to bring a big-budget feel to a low-budget production. The practical effects take center stage, acting as another character in this film as a flesh-eating virus terrorizes the group of unlucky campers. Roth pays homage to many horror films that came before this one and uses shots, camera tricks, story beats, and other elements that made those films successful.The core group of actors all played their respective parts well. The budding love between Paul and Karen, the fractured romance between Jeff and Marcy, and the party time antics of Bert. The way each character handles the crisis in their own way shows the human element. The bit players of the townspeople push the plot along and help drive the isolation factor along, leaving the characters isolated with no where or no one to go to. The addition of Eli Roth's character Grim and Deputy Winston (Giuseppe Andrews) brings comic relief to break up the bleak scenario.As well as the production team pulling off the film's low budget, it also holds the film back at times. The issues are small, but taking a deeper look at the overall product shows some of the downfalls. The film turns one dimensional, with no way of outrunning or beating the virus in the cards. A glimmer of hope would have added an additional layer to give the audience some light at the end of the tunnel.Eli Roth's Cabin Fever becomes a case study in how a group comes to terms with the inevitable. The true horror of the film lies in the decisions every character makes and the measures they will take to keep the virus away. With the exception of outdated jokes, this film will be viewed for years to come as a horror classic.

reviews.review_title: Rehashed teen stereotypes hampered this hackneyed attempt at horror...
reviews.content: I have to be honest.  I only made it through half of this DVD before I had to shut it off.  For horror to be effective, there has to be an element of believability to the characters.  Instead, they were so poorly drawn that I quickly gave up caring what happened to them.  They represented two-dimensional teen stereotypes that any young adult should find insulting. I'd have to say that the best part of this movie was the trailer, which led me to believe that the movie had potential.

Bearing a shallow resemblance to Evil Dead and Texas Chainsaw Massacre, Cabin Fever is closer in style and tone to the Scream franchise. What elevates it is a younger taste in horror-comedy. The fratboy humor is dated and mostly flat, but the shocks are still disturbing and gross. Its not a scary film but it builds in tension and mood about halfway through. Eli Roth is a modest director who isn't great with actors or a shooting action, but he is a smart producer who hires a wonderful cinematographer and borrows the great Angelo Badalamenti from David Lynch. Roth was Lynch's assistant and also worked for Troma's Lloyd Kaufman. Borrowing more than a little from both directors is what made Roth look like a weirdo, sick genius to a generation, but he's really a clever ripoff artist like his future mentor Quentin Tarantino. Cabin Fever is well-produced and weird and somewhat fun, but under the surface its pretty dumb, thin on story and a pale imitation of much better movies. But it ushered in a new class of gruesome horror-comedy and inspired much better movies like Cabin in the Woods and The Evil Dead remake. Its your typical C-grade horror movie but with a much bigger budget.

of all the recent 'horror' offerings of late, this one does indeed rule the roost. a simple premise, one seen a million times before, but a strong premise which comes more fullfilling in this setting. it's homages are endless, but it does have it's own originality, which when it shines through, does impress. the actors are a little sketchy, with a not too great believability in them, but you do eventually end up rooting for them.it's a gore fest. with few scenes capable of making you grit your teeth. and it's for these scenes we are grateful. they make the movie overall.slickly directed, with a familiar spooky score. all in all the best 'new' horror film of recent years.

This had to be the worst movie that I have seen in a long time! Bad Acting, Bad Script...ok bad everything! We left in the middle of it, in fact, half the show left during the middle. I'm surprised we made it that long! How did this movie get such a high rating on here? I'm amazed!

Abominable.  Assinine.  Awful.  A complete waste of time and money. Why didn't this go straight to video?  (and I mean Beta) Boring.  An extremely poor example of film making in every sense. This movie started off poor, and degenerated from there. Inconsistent.  Insipid.  Idiotic.  I wouldn't wish this movie on UBL, Saddam, or Hillary Clinton. Even with this current trend of offering up such completely useless excuses for exposing the public to some juvenile hacks idea of entertainment, one could hardly be prepared for 'Cabin Fever'. Acting?  Poor. Directing?  Very poor. Story?  Extemely poor. Cinematography?  Worse than "extremely poor". How this movie was ever produced will remain a mystery.  Like non-alcoholic beer and courduroy shorts. This was a horror pic alright, but probably not as it was intended. Now excuse me while I barf at the mere thought if this movie.

I hate when non-horror fans review horror movies! They all give you wrong impression about the movie because they don't understand the laws and rules in the genre...You know - in horror few movies are groundbreaking, crucial! Other 90% of the movies are pure fun. They set the standards. They develop (already seen and worked on) ideas. They sum up ideas from few films into one film. They bring you back to theatre! Just remember F13 sequels, A Nightmare sequels, ...they all kinda suck but they all are good fun! So - Cabin Fever IS NOT ORIGINAL, NOT INOVATIVE, NOT GROUNBRERAKING...but Cabin Fever is a great movie which kept me on the edge afraid and loughing! I recommend it very much. Enjoy fun, gore, suspense...You'll enjoy it for sure!Cheers Eli, I hope you'll make some great horror movies in your already blistering career!

As i Stated earlier it was the worst 90 minutes of my life.  The sad is i could have watched astroturf grow and had more fun..................Directly after the film,(the term and all definitions of film being used loosly) I tried to come up with other films that Cabin fever could be catagorized with and only two came to mind(the Majestic and of course Mr.Magoo).  That's when I knew that I really should check out the "star power" in any movie that I think might be a justified way to spend 7 bucks.

I hope nobody gets mad about my comments on this movie ,but I have to let my feelings out .This flim was not good at all.I dont want to get blacklist for telling the truth about this film ,but it was so bad I allmost couldnt finsh the film.It was more funny then scary.I hope theres not a number two Cabin Fever ,because the first one was horrible. Thank You, Debbie

After seeing other movies like this i basically predicted everything that happened well before it did.
not a fan of predictive horrors its you're typical collage kids horror movie acting was good thumbs up story and delivery on the other hand and the script thumbs down 
5/10 productive horror not my style thanks

Really bad film that manages to make 90 minutes seem much longer.I don't understand anyone who likes this mess. The story was thin and really only needed about 45 minutes to cover it all but to bring the running time up to 90 lots of scenes were included that just had no relevance to anything. As for it being scary there was not a single scene that you could not predict completely. Towards the end of the film the director seems to loose track of the plot and although it did not seem possible the film gets even worse in the last 20 minutes.I can appreciate low budget horror films and films so bad they are actually good but this is neither. I shall be remembering the director's name just in case he makes anything else and then I can avoid watching it.

reviews.review_title: Just another b-movie with a budget
reviews.content: I'm not sure where these directors get their kicks. It's probably the gore. Yeah! That's always fun! Lets make the audience squirm and go "EEEEWWWW!!!" Or maybe it's the babes! Yeah! Nudity and sex! That'll be fun. Lets get a girl naked for a movie that really doesn't take itself seriously. That is all and good. Heck I've seen some really great films that have just that. There's only one problem...This film isn't entertaining.This type of slash/gore film should not be striving for anything more than a creepy, scary time at the movies. It should be fun and self referring. It should have people laughing at the moron characters that can't seem to get away. It should never take itself too seriously, or think for a second that the film might be saying something more than it really is. This is Cabin Fever's problem. There is a time where everyone has finally seen all the blood and guts they can handle, and there is really nothing left in the script but badly written characters, a predictable and boring plot line, and gallons of fake blood to clean up.This film attempts homage to the old slasher flicks of the 70's and 80's, but really only reminds us how we wasted our time watching them. Not to mention this film as well.

Eli Roth is the man for making a horror/comdey that actually balances both at the same time.This film rocked on so many levels.This is one of my favorite horror movies of all time and period.It's gross and disturbing.    Jeff(Rider Strong),Karen(Jordan Ladd),Marcy(Cerina Vinent),Paul(Joey Kern),and Bret(James DeBello) go off to the woods for a good old time away from college.Only to find out that a disease is out infecting everyone who comes in contact with it.Not the friends not only have to fight the disease,but each other for who has it.    This film got it's props from THE HILLS HAVE EYES,LAST HOUSE ON THE LEFT,NIGHT OF THE LIVING DEAD,OUTBREAK,EVIL DEAD,and THE TEXAS CHAINSAW MASSACRE.And in some way,it's better than all of them.The film is just plain sick and I love it for that.I haven't thown up like that in the last 5 years.Watch it,you'll have a hell of a sick time.

This movie could have been so good but it goes off into different directions.The horror aspects are very suspenseful and the situation that the characters are in is a pretty terrifying concept.The way the characters react to each other when the virus starts spreading was one of the best elements about this movie.But the thing that ruins this movie is that the director decided to try and be funny through a lot of parts.These scenes are just plain stupid and made me hate the movie at some points.I would have enjoyed the movie a lot more if it were not for that.I hope on his next movie the director will stick to making a horror movie and not a horror comedy.

reviews.review_title: A bad mix of Texas Chainsaw, Evil Dead and I Know What You Did Last Summer... with a rash.
reviews.content: Five friends (Rider Strong, Jordan Ladd, James DeBello, Cerina Vincent, Joey Kern) go out to a cabin in the deep south where they have fun and tell ghost stories until a hermit (Arie Verveen) with a flesh-eating virus comes up to them and they all, as a group, kill him. Now they are catching the virus and the locals think they are murderers. What will kill them first? Well, by what I've heard it's a watch-it-once-hate-it-watch-it-twice-love-it.Well, I watched it once and disliked it. Who knows, maybe I'll catch it again and love it, but for most people, you don't want to waste your time watching the same thing over again just to like it.The special effects are... just alright. I would say really good except for the fact that half of the time it looked like someone rubbed extra chunky ketchup all over their face, but half of the time it look ed creepy and real.The acting is the same... just alright. Half the time, there's some believable acting, half the time it's dreadful over-acting or dreadful bad-acting. (Even though I enjoyed Eli Roth's character) The idea is interesting and original and the script is okay, good more first-timers. The directing is also okay.Wow, I just realized: Everything is just "okay". So I'll give it a 5/10 Watch this if you want, it's just okay.

reviews.review_title: Why did Rider Strong audition for this movie?
reviews.content: He's too good of an actor to be in his tripe. It was embarrassing. Not his best performance either. If you want to see Strong in an exceptional horror film, watch Borderland. The only thing that was impressive about the movie was the production (the cinematography and the very realistic make up wounds). Some of the dialog was funny (for instance, the squirrel shooting). Most of the film overall was awkward to watch and dragged on at times.There's gracious nudity of course, including brief but graphic sex scenes.The film is actually not scary, just lends extended paranoia about going to the woods. Catching the disease, as you watch it, isn't suspenseful much less scary.In reply to "boy meets world gets out frustration," I must correct the review for its extreme falseness. The actor's name is Rider Strong, not Robert Strong. Secondly, his character on 'Boy Meets World', Shawn, NEVER liked the girl he grew up with (Topanga) much less 'couldn't have'. In fact, its the exact OPPOSITE. Shawn and his best friend Cory couldn't STAND Topanga; she was a geek and extremely weird. He was never interested in her romantically either. I don't know where this user got this from, but anyway. I felt the need to correct this error given.

reviews.review_title: Enjoyable, but could have been so much more
reviews.content:
I'd heard alot about this film before I finally had chance to sit down and watch it and to say my expectations were high would be an understatement.
I will say I enjoyed the film - it was well thought out and the SFX were very effective. It just didn't strike me as an 'Evil Dead' for the new generation - I don't mean to sound like a gorehound (though I suppose I am!), but there just simply wasn't enough gore in the film. The basic concept was wonderful and could have lead to much onscreen mayhem and gore, but it did feel rather restrained.
Overall, still enjoyable and as good an effort to get back to the glory days of 70's and early 80's horror as you would have seen in a very long time, but didn't quite hit the mark.

reviews.review_title: Much more believable than Wrong Turn..
reviews.content:
The thing that makes this movie good to me is that it is much more believable that such movies like Wrong Turn, or Blair Witch.  The characters act like what you and your college age buddies probably would act like if you were out alone camping with lots of alcohol and some mary jane. 
   Then it all goes wrong.  There is no predictable plot line which I like. Characters are simple, yet with some degree of personality that they stick with througout the movie..((Minor Spoilers to follow))  The only problem I had is that if Jeff takes himself AWAY from the cabin to prevent infection, Why the HELL does he come back at the end?  And I do not buy to "check up on everyone, or get more beer"  Jeff was so hellbent on leaving, wouldnt he wander back into town and get a ride outta there?   In any case, hey, if you are gonna die, you might as well get some, that probably would happen.  The virus is pretty much an unknown quantity although they discover its source, but never its origin.  Anyway, this movie is good to check out and determine just what you would do in case you come down with a case of the Cabin Fever 7/10

reviews.review_title: No classic, but there's something here
reviews.content: Normally I would not bother to comment on a movie which really did not excite me, but since it seems that EVERY person who bothered to vote a "1" on this thing (and its not even close to that level) decided to write a review about what dreck it was, I thought the least I could do would be to add a little more balanced review.The movie is NOT a classic, or anything close. But its also not total dreck. In a perfect world it would be a thoroughly mediocre dark little movie with splashes of humor -- in the sad state of modern horror, its actually above average. The best thing it does is try to do the "explore the darkness within" thing, as the characters all react with degrees of selfishness to the flesh eating virus which is the "monster" here. The worst thing it does is get confused about whether its trying to be scary or funny, or a little of both. I suspect it was trying to emulate an Evil Dead type mix (the homage is fairly obvious), but it ends up striking a darker note than that. Nonetheless in a horror market flooded by a million cheap slasher ripoffs, and a million and one cheap Alien ripoffs, its nice to get something a little more insidious as a bad guy. And the movie does at times show a little bit of fearlessness long since departed from most major studio movies -- it will go for a random bit of over the top humor or a gross out effect just to keep things interesting.There is too much that is clichéd and not well thought out here to make this into any sort of classic, but when the uneven mix works, its better than most of the REAL dreck in the field. Perhaps more of a sad statement on the state of horror than a compliment for this movie, but you could do much much worse if you were going to rent a horror flick some Friday night. For people who don't have the stomach for it, or those looking for something more sophisticated, this is no doubt an icky "1" (I always wonder when people give that vote have they really seen the true dreck that is out there?). But its not at all bad for an entertaining and vaguely disturbing time waster.

This movie just couldn't build up any suspense or thriller effect. You know what's going to happen and it occasionally does happen. But with a less than 90 minutes movie you'd expect a fast paced horror story.*MILD SPOILER*In this "Virus In Da Woods" movie the usual virusstuff has been re-used. Getting near the end you'd expect a climax, a solution, an escape, an explanation. As it doesn't come, you're left with an unhappy feeling. The acting isn't bad, the visual effects and gore are okay. But I'd rather suggest 'alone in the woods' movies like Black Caddillac or even better Wrong Turn.

Cabin Fever was quite the opposite. I really enjoyed it alot. the film is a basic "old school" about five college friends who end up driving to a cabin in the middle of nowhere. Banal right? But that's where the fun comes in. The film deals with paranoia and angst and it drives all the characters against eachother. They end up almost killing themselves over stupid senseless things. These characters are feeling, and have real human emotions, and the psychological damage is really done in on every single one! What is a real treat, to film buffs is hearing David Hess' "Last House On The Left" score and the redone version of the theme by Hess' two sons. A very enjoyable film indeed. The most fun I've had seeing a scary film in a long time.

My god this movie was really bad! The only reason I watched it through was my fascination with the boy meets world co-star. I guess I was fortunate to see some good horror in my time because this was not scary and it didn't even have a decent plot. Oh well guess we'll all be seeing it on late night t.v. soon enough.

reviews.review_title: complete and utter formula-based clichéd rubbish
reviews.content: Terrible. Utterly Terrible. What a waste of a blank DVD. I want the money I paid to rent it back. This is a total insult to horror fans. What were the people involved in this movie thinking? Money - nothing else. Its what you would call a well-packaged turd. No Plot. No Point. Nobody actors. I'm looking for more stuff to say about it as they tell me you need a minimum of 10 lines to submit a review, but I said it in the summary. There really isn't enough to write about. It all boils down to one word I suppose - kak. Its a word we use a lot down in this part of the 3rd world. Hell, I thought you guys in the 1st world were supposed to set an example!

I listened to the commentary track when the DVD came out. Eli Roth was saying the exact same things as I would with regard to Italian horror and love of movies. That infuriated me. How could someone as close to my way of thinking as possible... make THIS??? It looks good. It's gory. There's nudity. What I like! But every single character is a piece of dirt. There is only one redeemable character and she gets locked in a shed (of course given time, she probably would have been a piece of s#1t too. I had absolutely no care in the world for any of these scumbag characters. You HAVE to have an audience identifiable character in your story! There is none. UNLESS... you too are a scumbag human being. If so, this is your movie!

This is absolutely the most terrible horror movie i ever saw!!! Just awful acting......... an awful storyline, and a stupid ending! I'm really into B horror movies just because their bad and i can laugh about it. But they took this movie to seriously!!! so it's not an A movie because it's to awful........... it's not a B movie because there's nothing funny about it............... So that makes it a Z Movie with a capital Z!!!!!!!!!!!!!! My advise: Don't see this movie!!!!!!!!!!!!! Only if your suffering from sleepless disorder go see it..... It will put you to sleep in no time!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! And if you stay awake, wait for that stupid ending!!!

reviews.review_title: I had a fever after watching this!
reviews.content: Upon recommendation of a co-worker, I rented this movie. I should learn not to do this, as this is the second time that I have been disappointed. Rider Strong (Paul) was the best one in the movie, but he still dies from the virus. The plot has holes the size of craters and make you wonder 'what just happened?' They never explain how the virus got started and why it is contracted via water. To me, too much wasn't covered to be enjoyable.I was worried about drinking my water after it, however! But I have and am fine...wait, why's my skin peeling?Seriously, don't waste your money.

This movie blew.  No, let me clarify:  it BLEW!  Could you hear me?  Do not see this movie unless you want to know what a horrible, horrible film looks and feels like.  There was no discernible fear generated at any point for me during this "film."  The acting was hammy.  I did not care on bit for any of these characters, especially the main character, who's the biggest pansy in the history of leading men.  It was neither funny, nor clever.  I actually yearned for Jason to come to the rescue and start slashing people to bits, just so there would be something to be afraid of for a moment.  Please, please, do not make movies like this.  And who was that director that said this was a great film?

reviews.review_title: Not a total waste of time, but not the best-Potential spoilers**
reviews.content: when Cabin Fever hit theaters, with the recommendation of Peter Jackson splashed all over it, I got suspicious. I searched the net, and read about 60 reviews from various publications on the net. Over 50 of them panned it, badly. Now that its hit pay-per-view, I watched it several times. I guess the director claims it to be his homage to the classic horror of the past. because its all that he says in interviews. Kids go for a weeks vacation in the usual, ugly, isolated cabin. For reasons that aren't ever explained, folks turn up with some corrosive disease, and soon our cast has it too. Unlike the much superior "28 Days Later", there is virtually no tension, or suspense, as the disease breaks down our "heroes", but they are all pretty boring, stupid, and self-centered, so you probably won't really care. The local rednecks eventually try to take the kids out, but they are mostly useless too, leaving this touch of "Straw Dogs" pointless. The comedy is lame, but it is probably the best part of this mess. No explanation of any kind is given, adding to the meager suspense, but robbing it of any resolution. It was filmed in North Carolina, and Los Angeles, but it would have seemed more natural if it had been filmed in Italy, and dubbed (which is kind of how it looks) Probably the least of the current "Horror revival", can't really see how this mess got green lighted. A real script would have been good, this seems like it was filmed from an incomplete outline. The acting was very average, but it was all in focus, which isn't as common as you might think. It's no "House Of The Dead" (a much more fun romp from recent times. just as dumb), but, stripped of a pretentious veneer of self-promotion (from various types who should really know better), there just isn't much here. Occasionally amusing, but pretty tame, with absolutely nothing to add to the vocabulary of fear. Worth seeing, once, for completists, but you could do better.--Judexdot1--

This was better than I thought it would be. My 10 year old wanted to watch and we both liked it.
The old man in the store with the gun being saved made the movie

reviews.review_title: I love horror films but this...
reviews.content: Boring. The worst word I could use to apply to any film, let alone a horror film. Tries to be quirky and off the wall but is just squirmingly transparently contrived. If you rent this on DVD (don't bother...really) you won't even bother to pause it for a bathroom break. The last year has seen a lot of sub-par horror that would normally skulk straight to video appear on the big screen, with films like "Cabin fever" this just seems insulting. Allegedly made by film fans...get back to watching them guys. Dont make any more. And Im not a hater... I just hate having my time wasted.

I happened to watch identity and cabin fever one after the other.  I already knew the votes that the imdb users gave to these movies: identity: 7.1 , cabin fever:5.9.  Well, I saw identity, it sucked! A psychological disaster. A good start which ended into a fake movie, so I thought that cabin fever would be just crap. Well it's not! I really enjoyed it. If you are a horror fan go see it. The first half really scared me, it did.  Tension, and suspense. People don't get it anymore! If they made some old Romero classic today it would get 4 out of 10.  Now intellectual people want psycho thriller and if they see some gore they freak out and the film becomes and instant garbage for the mass.  I like everything that entertains me, without prejudices. I enjoyed the ring for example and that didn't have any blood or violence. Anyway, this movie rocks, period. Goo see it! Ok the last 10 minutes were garbage, i'll give you that, maybe they lost the script or something. But that doesn't ruin the movie at all, like in identity. If you agree with me please write a review because I really think that this movie deserves more than this. 7/10

reviews.review_title: Eli Roth: Saviour of Horror? Maybe, but not yet.
reviews.content: Eli Roth's Cabin Fever (2002) promises a return to the straight visceral horror films of the late 1970's and early 1980's after many years of diluted horror-comedies and the later ironic horror films such as Wes Craven's Scream trilogy. With recent re-makes of the 70's classics Dawn of the Dead and Texas Chainsaw Massacre it seems that the horror film may be making a comeback to the mainstream. Now, I'm no fanatical gorehound, but I've seen my share of such films. Unfortunately, considering the articles in the film press proclaiming Roth as the 'new saviour of horror', I remain to be convinced by this claim. Having watched the extensive interview with Roth on the UK DVD plus one of his many commentaries Roth is obviously a devotee of this genre of cinema and knows his stuff inside out. The guy is obviously great at promoting and expressing his passion for horror and is a very entertaining person to listen to. Unfortunately I don't think Cabin Fever lives up to all the hype.The premise of the film is standard fare: Five college students celebrate their graduation with a week of partying in a remote forest cabin. They are infected by a flesh-eating virus which causes the students to isolate the first infected and soon causes the entire group to disintegrate into self-preservation. Unfortunately there's a major problem even in this basic premise and it's not the virus. The virus is actually a great idea, far easier to identify with and fear than any amount of Sumerian Demons or psychotic killers. No, the problem is with the people. Watching the film I was convinced that Roth had written the most annoying, obnoxious, least likable group of characters possible. I was shocked and amused when Roth mentions in the commentary that we are actually supposed to sympathies with these characters and good third of the film is devoted to establishing the group. So we have a complete numbskull who's idea of fun is shooting squirrels 'cos they're gay'. Then there are the two couples; Jeff, a self obsessed arrogant twit and Marcy, played by Cerina Vincent, clearly hired for both of her 'talents', neither of which are acting. Then there's the other two, Karen and 'Boy meets World'. She thinks they're great close friends, he wants to finally get in her pants. Fortunately Roth's sympathy for the characters only extends so far and a cruel sadism soon takes over, from the spread of the virus through to the arbitrary deaths and a Night of the Living Dead influenced downer ending. In terms of horror and gore the film is pretty tame, only the leg-shaving and fingering scenes really stand out. In fact the whole film is comprised of elements that have been seen before in countless films - from the Evil Dead cabin, the rednecks from Deliverance (although these guys are far too clean to be really threatening), the rabid dog from The Thing, blah blah blah . Although heralded as a straight-out horror flick, Roth has decided to add several doses of absurd humour, which are detrimental to the tone and pace of the film. A young stoner cop who likes to 'partee' is only funny once and a golden-mulleted, kick-boxing kid named Dennis is just bizarre, as is a gag involving a harmonica. Touches such as these along with severely un-likable characters diffuse the tension and suspense created by the main plot. Roth is often compared to early Sam Raimi in the press but Cabin Fever has none of the stylistic flair, imagination, and gore of Raimi's early films. I know this review sounds like I hated the film. I really didn't, it was decent enough entertainment when you're in the right mood. The music was particularly effective, always crucial in this genre. Given Roth's obvious passion and enthusiasm for the genre I was quite surprised and a little disappointed how distinctly average this film is. In spite of this, I'm sure this isn't the last we'll hear of Eli Roth - let's hope his next film is as entertaining as he is. Rate 6/10

What's the deal? I can't believe all the negative reviews this film has gotten. It is by no means the worst movie ever made, not by a long shot. I'm a huge horror fan and this movie was very enjoyable. It had humor and scares as well as great gore and disgusting make-up. No matter how big of an immature, egotistical tool Eli is, I have to say I really liked this. It's intentionally ridiculous, self-deprecating, shocking, disturbing, silly, funny, bizarre and impressive for such a little movie. It has a success story along the lines of the first SAW. It's almost a parody of horror movies from the '70s. Ignore the negative reviews that seem to consist mainly of people going along with other reviewers. If you're a gorehound like me, you'll enjoy this - or at least get a kick out of the behind- the-scenes documentary on the special effects. This is destined to be a cult classic.

reviews.review_title: Thank goodness Eli Roth got better
reviews.content: This is mostly awful. The setup is sort of interesting but it takes over an hour to get even vaguely compelling and then it's just silly. Some of the effects and deaths are okay but that's the best you're getting from me, and I am a Horror genre lover, good and bad. This is bad, nearly from top to bottom.

reviews.review_title: Nah I'm kidding, i'll shoot em if they're gay or straight.
reviews.content: OK, here goes. This film is quite simply, a masterpiece. Relentlessly watchable and better each time it is watched. Initially when I saw the film I thought it was good, then I watched it again and i thought it was still good then I watched it again and it was amazing! Honestly, this is up there with the best horror films ever, but then thats not saying much as there are so many bad ones. This film has it all, hilarious characters with a complementing script; a smattering of blood ( a couple of real cringe- OW painful moments) and a very unsettling atmosphere with nerve shattering music.The premise is simple. Kids in a wood (pretty damn stupid ones) deserted except for a nearby village full of mentalists, a diseased hermit, a "party"ing cop (hilarious....quite simply hilarious) and a crazy stoner (Eli Roth himself- in a fantastic little role) with his vicious almost demonic dog (that, oh, just so happens to want to eat everything it sees). Endlessly self knowing but not to the extent that it becomes irritating because you are too taken in by the no holds barred nature of the film. IT rockets along at such a pace that nothing is even remotely boring. One minute you'll be on the floor in tears of laughter and the next you'll be cowering or cringing (well the most squeamish of you at least, like my friend Sam, haha when i showed it to him the other day); and other occasions it mixes both- for instance the head on collision with a (very fake looking deer) and its subsequent bloody demise; i literally laughed my ass off.SO in conclusion, despite all the hype that has led to people not liking the film; I say, ignore every prejudice you may have about the film. Buy it from amazon UK for like a pound and watch and enjoy then watch again and again, and introduce all your friends to it. THis is a criminally under-appreciated film. IT fooookin rocks! Eli ROth is a legend! Blows every horror film recently out of the water, its just so much fun to watch! Forget wussy "psychological thrillers" like abysmal crap of hide and seek the ring and godsend vein and see this. A TRUE horror film, that'll have you laughing as well. WATCH IT!

Eli Roth delivers a fine flick that will make every horror fan ask for more. Loaded with everything that makes a great horror flick:  gore, blood, nudity, violence, humor, rednecks and few jumps.  What is not to love. Definitely a choice midnite movie.  My grade:  7/10.

Finally, they got one right! Ever since Resident Evil replaced zombies with crazed, decaying plague carriers in the horror film lexicon, I haven't been particularly pleased with the results. RE itself turned out to be just another video-game stinker, 28 Days Later was way too self-conscious to be scary, and so on. But now we have Cabin Fever, a film that remembers that the zombie sub-genre is about helplessness, moral quagmires, and visceral, gut-wrenching effects. (Well, OK, except when it's about Linnea Quigley dancing naked in a graveyard...)Cabin Fever strays further from the old zombie toolkit to further define this new batch of plague movies. In particular, it's the first to notice that carriers don't need to be homicidal to become objects of horror - the prospect of contagion is more than enough to transform a person into a monster in the eyes of others. The fact that, to the camera's eye, they are merely sick, frightened people who desperately want help adds a uniquely new disturbing tone to the proceedings.Like the Romero films that started it all, the message here is less about fear of disease than about ordinary people acting badly when threatened by crisis, and, like Romero, the message is occasionally delivered with a heavy hand (including one rather-too-overt reference to Night of the Living Dead). But, overall, this is a film that will continue to disturb you long after the credits roll, and really, isn't that everything you could hope for in a horror flick?

I saw Roth's newer "Hostel" before this, and I didn't like that very much. But afterwards when I have thought about that movie, it has actually "grown" better in my mind... If I remember correctly, I gave 2 points to that movie. Now I would maybe give it a 5 or 6. And I think I'll watch it again some day.This is couple of years older, I assume it's Roth's first full-length movie. This was a positive surprise. Actually this was very good horror movie. From the DVD-covers I waited for some bimbo teenage horror, but this was nothing like that. The characters are quite good. The story is original (enough), even it's full of homagés to contemporary horror classics. It's very well written, and very well made in every way.It feels really good to see that there are many new/young horror directors making movies nowadays. I'm really expecting something interesting from these guys in the future. In the meantime, these are very good horror entertainment.

reviews.review_title: Boy on porch = funny; Movie = not good.
reviews.content: This movie is really not too good.  The acting is fairly solid, but the story is extremely weak and boring.  If you want to see a good movie about a flesh-eating virus, please, watch 28 days later, and avoid this one.The kid on the porch made me laugh, and having a girly to cuddle made the whole thing entirely bearable, but had I been alone, I might have made this the second movie I've ever walked out of.

reviews.review_title: One hot chick mixed in a bag of poo
reviews.content: This movie outshines dreamcatcher for stupidity in just about every way,which is really really scary.You know that hot chick was the fire thats about it .Acting NO,Story NO,Gratuitous Nudity NO,But i will say at least the dorky guy banged the chick before he went out so that was a plus.Maybe it was my friends gas that made me hate this movie so bad i really think he should have his colon checked. Anyway this was terrible i would rather be floating inside a light bulb on neptune watching infomercials starring Sally Struthers than ever see this celloidic assgas of a flick again.

reviews.review_title: Strange, Weird, Odd, Oh you just saw Cabin Fever...
reviews.content: After viewing Cabin Fever one word comes to mind, "What?" Was that supposed to be funny? Was that an attempt at a horror film? And what was with that kid Dennis? Cabin Fever is a film about a group of young adults who go out into the woods for a little R and R. What was supposed to be a fun filled vacation full of drinking and sex turns out to be a fight for their lives. The film starts out with these unlikable characters that have no depth. Their main purpose in the film is to give the audience something to watch in between the killings. All of the actors in the film would serve better in a more watchable film. There is nothing but wasted talent here. To some this is a work of genus, and maybe that is true, it is like nothing that has been done before. But case in point the story isn't good, the dialogue is corny, and the acting is lifeless. If one wants a few good laughs and something to talk about then I suggest renting this movie. Another reason to see it would be for the character of Dennis. You'll know what I mean after you see it. Pancakes! No really, If your dying to see this movie or you want to know what it's like to see it, I suggest taking the money that you would have spent on a ticket and throwing it away, then spend 90 minutes standing in a corner repeating the word Pancakes over and over again. By doing this you will get the same movie going experience many movie goers were subject to while viewing this film. 1 star out of 38238299938333333922 stars. No Really 1.5 out of 4. (D-)

I had the joy of being able to watch this film in the theater, and it was the most fun I've had at the movies until I saw Silent Hill! I own it on DVD and watch it often. What I love about this flick is the fact that I don't have to like ANY of the characters, or empathize with them in any way. I find them all to be nasty,selfish brutes and I enjoy seeing them scream and rot. I think that's part of the point of it all, like the wheelchair kid in the original Texas Chainsaw, these kids are so bloody foul you ache to see them killed.I also love seeing that water truck at the end, that makes me smile every time. The gore was excellent, the harmonica was hilarious, and the listerine made everyone yelp and grab their pants! Forgive me if I'm not that coherent, I'm getting over mild food-poisoning..at least, that's what I hope it is..there's this scratch on my arm that just seems to be getting bigger..

I avoided Cabin Fever like (ahem) the plague for months, until I was unexpectantly shown it one bleary Saturday night. My preconceptions held true to an extent- the film is hugely derivative and genuinely unscary- but about an hour through something hit me. Eli Roth could become a true master.Cabin Fever's "plot" is pretty much inconsequential. Basically, it revolves around a group of teens who travel into the woods (via a strange yokel shop) and get infected by a fatal virus. So far so '80s right? Yes, to a degree.
