However, how Roth uses this plot in the second half makes for compulsive viewing.It is true, the first half of Cabin Fever is inexplicably awful. The acting is dire, the dialogue and pacing even worse, and despite a few, rather obvious jumps, deeply unfrightening. I've been thinking that if perhaps Roth made the characters a little more vulgar and self-indulgent, then he could have easily twisted the second half into a pitch black comedy. I even thought for a minute, due to Roth being a protege of, of all people, David Lynch, he could be making the first half of this film deliberately banal (a la Blue Velvet) to create a massive contrast to what was about to happen. Then on reflection, I think I give Roth too much credit.If you can tolerate the film's first half, you will be richly rewarded however. The second half is jam packed with numerous great moments, including the most memorable bathroom scene since Fatal Attraction (involving a razor) and some terrific scares. Roth throws it all away again though, for a disastrously unfunny ending which smacks of self-indulgence and time constraints. What we have here is a promising, if massively uneven, schlock fest which just about clinches the status of "memorable". If Roth hones his script writing technique and is more stringent in the auditioning process, he could be untouchable.

WoW. Usually I utter this word after witnessing one of those unforgettable movies that leave you breathless. Well this piece of work left me breathless in that I was dying for it to just end! My girlfriend and I rented this movie hoping to see a good scary movie. In the end however, all we got was an agreed notion that this was the worst movie either of us had ever seen. Oh awful movie, let me count thy ways... horrible acting, a plot line that was just plain LOST, laughable effects, bad directing, bad writing... you get the picture. My brother and I used to make home-made horror films with our friends that were more entertaining than this filth. Try Shaun of the Dead and the Evil Dead movies if you seek a good comedy-horror flick.

Cabin Fever is a bloated corpse filled with various ideas and mistakes.The premise simply follows a group of college students partaking a vacation within the woodlands to unknowingly have contact with a biological virus. They're far from proper medical attention, or any safety in this regard, but this gives them and the film enough time to risk being greater. Unfortunately, the film doesn't properly risk enough when it constantly relies on weird humor, disjointed pacing, and middling storytelling with a severe identity crisis. Throughout the film's time introducing characters, and other strange subplots, audiences learn how limited they are by either not appearing enough, being disposable and tedious, or serving nothing special. However, aside its flaws, it's fairly tolerable when it finally descends into madness and less characters survive the premise's gruesome focus. It's not just an original idea ahead of its time, created at the wrong time, but one of its own kind that unfortunately couldn't become better if a reenactment followed its similar middling direction.It's a nasty virus film that's not very infectious as an actual viral infection.

reviews.review_title: Eli Roth gave me a disease, and I think it was herpes
reviews.content: When I first was introduced to the TV spots for Cabin Fever, I was thoroughly excited by confusion. I asked myself, "What exactly is Cabin Fever about?" I will say that the ambiguity attracted me, as the main part of what I saw was young adults were in constant peril and apparently dying harsh and horrifying deaths. And hell, a slasher movie junkie like me couldn't pass up on the possibility that another franchise was about to come to fruition. I rented the DVD and nestled down to what I thought was going to be horror movie gold. Instead, I think Eli Roth gave me a disease, and I think it was herpes of the horror film.The first thing I noticed about this film was the fact that it was a NOBODY cast, and I mean NOBODY. When Rider Strong (who has an awesome f*cking name), the supporting character from Boy Meets World, ends up being the only one with enough Hollywood muscle to play the lead, it is safe to say that your cast is full of nobodies. That isn't necessarily a bad thing, as some horror film actors begin as nobodies and turn into massive stars (Jamie Lee Curtis, Kevin Bacon, Johnny Depp... and so on). However, this pack of no-names swung the other way with the most horrific acting since Kevin Costner starred in... well, anything. Thirty minutes into the film and I felt that Sleepaway Camp's Felissa Rose deserved an Oscar for Best Actress *shudder*.Since I couldn't depend on acting, I felt I at least had plot to save the film for me. The fact that it wasn't the slasher film I thought it might be didn't bother me. A killer skin disease is actually not a bad idea (thank you Resident Evil for the T-Virus). But ultimately, what did this movie do in terms of plot? The only two things I remember definitively is the girl with the chewed up face, the dead dog bursting, and the worst sex scene ever filmed, and I have seen Pamela and Tommy's video (easy joke). The plot was insanely boring amid the death and paranoia, and the acting made the plot even more ridiculous.After 45 minutes of viewing this film, I was begging the cast to die so I could sulk over the $10.50 I lost at Movie World. I paid late fees so I could watch this schlock. Cabin Fever is undoubtedly a horror movie that should have never made it to a big screen, a small screen... hell, the screen in Eli Roth's mind. Mr. Roth, you have a future in horror cinema, but I BEG, for your sake and mine, that we never have this discussion again

reviews.review_title: Nowhere near as good as its hype
reviews.content: OK I really wanted to enjoy this film, anybody a fan of Evil Dead is OK in my book but its nowhere near as good as its hype. I first watched it not long after it came out and I was disappointed, recently I watched it twice again to see firstly did I judge it too harshly as you generally over judge hyped up films and secondly to see if it's one of those films that grow on you, sadly it's neither. Don't get me wrong it's not a bad film but a decent one. The start is pretty good and the end is also quite good, it just doesn't flow well and losses you halfway through with filler scene's and characters you just don't give a s**t about, the actors are pretty good, they just aren't likable characters, I get that's the point but you need a balance even in a cheese filled horror otherwise you may as well be watching The young and the Restless. For the Cheese fans it has its moments but seems to be trying too hard, without spoiling there is one scene involving a gun and a shovel I'll let your imagination work on that one. Give this one a watch but if your expecting a great gore horror or cheesy horror or comedy horror you will be disappointed set the bar low and you might enjoy this one more.Rating: 5.5/10Cheeseometer: 11/50

reviews.review_title: Plenty of bloody action, but very little else.
reviews.content: Very disappointing horror. A group of young men and women drive out to an isolated cabin in the woods for a bit of a break, and come across a man infected with a deadly unknown virus that turns the unfortunate infected into a murderous maniac. Alright it is a bit of a change from the usual lame brained slasher pic, but this ends up little more than a poor man's cross between "28 days later" and "The evil dead" and it's nowhere near as accomplished or effective as either of the aforementioned. There's little excitement or atmosphere generated, plenty of bloody gory sequences, but there's nothing of any real substance, and no finesse. Humour is tried for but even here it usually fails. Unsurprisingly it ends up disappointing.

reviews.review_title: Every copy in the world should be broken in half and burned
reviews.content: Me and my cousin went into Movie Gallery and he got this and we expected something decent....I knew it was going to have blood and gore in it....but it was so ridiculous....the cursing ruined the movie....every other word was the F word and it sounded so lame.....there was no point....a bunch of people go camping and die from a flesh-eating disease....I didn't get whether the end was supposed to be funny or horrific.....to me it was neither....words can't describe how bad this movie was. It was the most awful excuse for a film that has ever been my disgrace to lay my eyes upon....please don't watch this waste of time, money, energy, and oxygen....why was this ever released anyway? It's movies like this that ruin people's lives....and I DON'T mean by scaring them to deathScary? nope Good story? nope Good acting? nope Should be kicked off the shelves? yepDon't watch this movie and make the same mistake I did.....don't make a decision you'll regret....Listen I would give this movie and negative number if I couldAll in all, this movie is just gross, not scary.....so please trust me and stay away from it....maybe if it stops selling they'll get rid of it

I just rented this movie today on dvd and let me tell you that it's one scary and creepy movie.  I really enjoyed watching it and hope that they make a sequel.  If they do make one, I will definitely watch it.  I wish that more movies like this one could be made because as much as I enjoy slasher type movies, I am getting sort of tired with those kinds of stories.

BEWARE SOME SPOILERSThis movie was pretty gory. I liked how it wasn't hyped like most of the movies. And I didn't even know what it was about. I thought it was going to be a typical in the woods serial killer and had no idea about it being about a virus. That makes all the more creepier and more gruesome. I just don't understand why they didn't shoot Grim's dog the first time it came back and tried to attack them. Although it wouldn't matter because they all had the disease by then in the first place. I like the hill billy guy in the store before they leave. The one that looks like Santa Claus. Also what was up with that kid Pancakes? I didn't get that part. But it ended pretty cool and I think they could get away with making a sequel and it might be worth watching. I like diseas movies and all that and it gave the the creeps the part when the girl was in the bathtub shaving her legs. That was pretty bloody. This is the best HORROR movie beside House of 1000 Corspes and that is in a different range of horror. I give it a 10 for have it's own fresh ideas and all the blood was pretty good. The actors did just fine to me. Keep up the Great work Eli Roth! You are superb.

reviews.review_title: Note to the weak in the stomach don't eat while watching
reviews.content: Spoilers!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! The Ultimate Gore fest, and I loved it. I love slashers, thrillers, horrors, suspense, and comedy cabin fever has a little of it all. kids fresh out of college go up in the woods for some fun time and to go along with Psycho hillbillies, A canibalistic kid, a retarted party cop, and a stoner. they throw a drifter carrying possibly one of the most Fu**ed up desises you can have, decides to spit tons of blood all over the car and the yard thereby spreading a virus that eats Jordan Ladds' characters face off and drives rider strongs' character to murder. before that Paul (Rider) sets the hermit on fire then of course he's gonna look for water but he dives into the drinking water and officially infects everyone. but only paul dies from the virus because if you pay attention to the deaths. Bert gets his head blown off, Jeff gets shot to death, the hermit burns, Paul beats Karen to death, Mercy (After Shaving the skin off her legs,That part still makes me cringe,) is eaten by the stoner's(Directors Eli Roth) crazy dog. and paul does die from the virus but of course he falls into the reservoir thereby infecting hundreds of people. this movie is a thrilling rush of gore that will make your blood run cold. trust me i'm not exaggerating this is the absolute goriest movie i've ever seen it's not for the weak, but if you think your stomach can take it then check it out.

reviews.review_title: Wrong Turn Meets the Black Plague...
reviews.content: Well first off I have to say that the first hour or so of the film is really slowwwwwwww, but the last half hour is one of the quickest I have seen in any recent horror film.The acting in this film is average, which is to be expected.  The majority of the characters are populated by lower rung actors, whose most notable previous appearances include the topless girl in Not Another Teen Movie (and SURPRISE she has no problem baring them again here) and the pothead in Super Troopers.I actually got a laugh out of a lot of the scenes in the film as they are very much in the campy horror venue.  The guy who wore the "FU" hat was basically a total idiot doing tons of stupid things throughout the film. Then there was the little kid who liked to bite people on the hand.  Of course there was also the requisite rednecks in the film who have this gag in the beginning which continues to the end (which has to been seen to be believed and I wont spoil it for you either).As for the movie being a genre buster, not really.  I liked the concept of using a plaque that doesnt actually turn you into a zombie, but just wastes you away into a bleeding skeletal mass.  The whole thing with the vicious dog I didnt really understand, I mean does he just zone in and kill those that are infected?  Didnt quite get that part.  The movie does have one surprise in that one character totally changes from a whimp into a badass beat em up killing machine once he contracts the virus (whereas all the other ones basically act the same).  The ending wasnt shocking at all, as in every horror film if you blatantly brag about surviving it means your doom within 45 seconds (and this film proves that point once again).  For those that remember Night of the Living Dead, the ending of the main characters (not the other WTF? ending) seems to rip that one off.All in all, this film garners a 6/10, better than Wrong Turn thats for certain, but nothing spectacular either.

reviews.review_title: One of the better horror films to be released recently.
reviews.content: (Warning:  Possible spoilers).Eli Roth's "Cabin Fever" was a pleasant surprise, especially after seeing such unscary films like "Freddy Vs. Jason" that have passed as horror in recent years.  "Cabin Fever" is the story of 5 young people going up to a cabin in the woods after graduation to celebrate by getting drunk, high and laid but all of this changes when they receive a visit from a stranger who is vomiting blood with his skin falling off.There is a nice set up to the horror action when we are introduced to the characters and their personalities and how this will determine how they deal with the impending events that will await them later in the film.  The introduction of the creepy hillbillies in the only general store for miles was also a nod to such early '70s shockers as "Deliverance" and "Last House on the Left," the easy listening ballad that plays in the early part of the film is from the latter film and performed by actor, David Hess who also starred in the 1972 Wes Craven film.The suspense build up and the psychological way that the characters react rang true to me and this made it all the more terrifying especially when they easily shun even one of their own who they suspect being infected with the mysterious disease that eats one's flesh.  It is also clever how the cause of infection is revealed to the audience making it all the more suspenseful to see the unwitting characters who are trying to avoid being infected so easily come across the contagion.  Thrown in the mix is the isolation and a mad dog that comes around to terrify them every now and again. SPOILER BEGINS!!!!!!! The movie goes at a good pace but the only problem that I had was with the way that it concluded.  Early in the film, we see the characters delighted by the kindly old man in the general store telling them stories and offering hospitality and when one of them points to a rifle, the old man says matter of factly, "That's for the n***ers."  The shock of the characters and the audience is real since this was unsuspected and it nicely showed the dark side behind a seemingly quaint facade.  However, this line is merely a set up to a punchline at the end of the movie when a trio of African American young people comes to the store and the old man says, "Here, it's all cleaned and like new for you, my n**ga." and they all shake hands and laugh and sing dixie while drinking tainted lemonade well after the main characters meet ugly demises.  The film was an effective, suspenseful, gross out, horror film that created an atmosphere of dread and then goes the comic route at the end of the movie inexplicably.  I don't know if the director was trying to be politically correct or trying to go for a relatively upbeat happy ending.  It is a horror movie and one goes to to be scared and disturbed.  At least it didn't take the self knowing, tongue in cheek route that countless horror films have taken since "Scream" came out.  The film did manage to elicit some scares and squeamish moments from me and that is not an easy task either since I have watched so many horror films and thought that I had become desensitized.  So with the exception of the last 20 minutes or so of the movie, I strongly reccomend this film.

I had high hopes for this movie. But, alas, it disappointed. The story begins, much as many others, featuring teens in the woods, so we already know this isn't going to touch on anything new. But, very soon, the action, and gore, become secondary, as the characters go out of their way to do the most ridiculous, and unrealistic, things. Of course, this being a horror film (or at least attempting to be one), the unrealistic is common. However, films such as "Evil Dead" and especially the recent update of "Dawn of the Dead", have proved how well a film with an initially clichéd storyline, can be woven into a classic. Unfortunately this film has not, opting instead to go with cheap shocks, mundane special effects, and incredibly wooden acting.

reviews.review_title: It Feels like any Proper Horror Film Should Feel, like a Roller Coaster Ride
reviews.content: I wasn't expecting much from a movie coming from Eli Roth, who I've only heard bad things about, but I ended up being surprised by how good this film actually was. Unlike "Martyrs", "Cabin Fever" knows how to show just the right amount of gore, no more and no less. It gives enough fun and likable characters to make it worth the watch, this feels like any proper horror film should feel, like a roller coaster ride.In this tale of survival, a group of five college graduates rent a cabin in the woods and begin to fall victim to a horrifying flesh-eating virus.Quentin Tarantino was right when he called Eli Roth "The Future of Horror" after seeing this film, but not in a good way. Every movie now tries to emulate what they did in this movie with bad results, a recent example of this is the remake of "Evil Dead". If only modern horror movies stopped taking themselves so seriously or maybe if they were a little more creative. Its not that they remake other films, its that they put so little effort in doing so. "Black Swan" is practically a remake of "Carrie" mixed with "The Red Shoes" but that movie is something of its own, it gives a twist on the story we already know and for that it's worth watching, if only more horror movies were as enjoyable as this one I'd probably be watching them all the time.If you haven't already seen it, I can't recommend it any more than I already have, reading the stories about it on wikipedia and IMDb just make the experience even better. Here's one little on-set story about Eli Roth and an actress that didn't want to show too much on-screen so they managed to reach a compromise - Cerina would bare one inch of her buttocks on camera, no more, no less. Eli Roth brought a ruler along to the filming and measured Cerina's buttocks, to be sure he got his one inch.Here's another cool story: Peter Jackson stopped production on "The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King" three times to screen this movie for the entire crew. Jackson was so enthusiastic about the film he gave director Eli Roth publicity quotes.I'd recommend this to anyone who liked "Contagion", zombie movies, "White Dog", "Evil Dead", "The Cabin in the Woods", "An American Werewolf in London"

I can't believe I wasted an hour and a half on this dross.  The spiel would have you believe this movie is about five "teens" in a cabin, contracting a disease and subsequently turning on each other, much like the lighthouse scene in Battle Royale.But no.Five "teens" go to a cabin, one gets sick so they quarantine her.  The rest slowly don't get sick but have several hair-raising "adventures" like escaping a hungry dog, meeting the locals, and having a fight.  They all end up with the virus, the symptoms of which just include really big sores and coughing up some blood, and die in various gratuitous ways.If you're expecting a tense thriller, don't waste your time.  If you're expecting a horror, sorry but this isn't one.  If you saw The Hole and thought "what a load of crap", definitely DO NOT waste your money on this rubbish.And as for the ending - WTF?!!!  I wish I had contracted the disease and died so I wouldn't have to watch this poor, sad little film.

When I think of 70's horror, I think The Exorcist, Texas Chainsaw..., Last House on the Left, Halloween.  Eli Roth has been quoted as saying he was upset that films like Wrong Turn were improperly sold as tributes to 70's exploitation horror.  Well, he can now be upset that his own film Cabin Fever inexplicably falls into the same category as Wrong Turn...false advertising.  This is the same disposable horror garbage as just about every other "new" horror film to come out lately (sans 28 Days Later).  I'm amazed it was hyped like this.  Cabin Fever isn't even a horror movie.  It's a comedy ala Meatballs with some blood thrown in to make it more marketable. If I knew I was going in to watch some more stupid characters that I don't care about get more stupid as the "plot" rolls along, maybe I wouldn't be so hard on this movie.  But with the way this baby has been talked-up, along with Roth's off-the-mark comments everywhere I look, I can't stomach it. And, unfortunately, that's got nothing to do with the "gore", which is pretty tame for a film that is supposed to follow in the footsteps of Evil Dead.Whatever.  I know.  I should put up or shut up.  But when you wait over a year and a half to see a "real" horror movie and all you get is Cabin Fever, you're allowed to be a little more than just disappointed.  Had Roth taken his idea (which was a good one) seriously and not tried to ham it up so much with inane bits, it could have been a success.  But instead, I felt like I was watching the Kevin Smith of Horror Shows.  A few worthy moments ruined by shallow, witless banter and inconsistent tone.

I'll start w/ the bad, reeeally predictable, but in this movie, when exactly what you thought was gonna happen happens, it's AWESOME!  I laughed my ass off to some of the most sick, vile, and harsh biological terror scenes ever put to film.  They planned it that way.  It's not a really serious scary movie, it's a fun romp through the flesh eating, virus infested, hillbilly backwoods with two HOT babes and three average joes.  This director really knows what it takes to make a fun horror film.  Great special effects, professionally creepy soundtrack, nude sex scenes, dumb scary rednecks with guns, comedy, over-the-top violence, and not a lot of survivors.  It was never boring and ended promptly on cue. 92 min w/ credits!  If they had tried to make the characters really in love or have them actually try and conquer the virus- this would've been krap!  Way better than '28 Days Later' It's not an award winning movie but I need this in my collection!

I was really looking forward to seeing 'Cabin Fever'. It received a lot of positive reviews and was said to be the best offering in the recent wave of back- to- the- woods- horror movies. I must have been watching the wrong movie. Because Cabin Fever was bad. And beyond. First of all, it provides far more entertainment if viewed as a comedy than a horror movie. It just isn't scary. Other than that it's just stupid. 'My friends are dying, I have a huge flesh wound on my back... oh, well, I'll just take a nice warm bath AND SHAVE MY LEGS?!' Vanity's a bitch. Truly. This movie actually makes 'Wrong Turn' seem excellent. And that's saying a lot. 2 / 10.SPOILER:Still, I have one positive remark; having hated 'Boy Meets World' for years, it was with great satisfaction that I watched Rider Strong's character die the slowest and most painful death of all.

Although I would never recommend anyone not to watch a film as everyone will have their own tastes, I do wonder what Cabin Fever has to offer anyone. The storyline is wafer thin and barely entertaining and it simply is neither scary. There is a mere one scene in the entire film you may at least give it some credit for but it's simply cringe worthy and not scary.
Towards the end I found this film bordering on comical and when the credits rolled all I could think was what a waste of time and money. The film provides nothing that virtually every other modern day horror film doesn't do 10 times better. Simply put this comes bottom of my pile at the moment when it comes to my choice in films and it will take some beating to lift it from that position.

**POSSIBLE SPOILERS**I heard that this movie was good.  So, once again going against my instincts I let my girlfriend talk me into going to see it(she does that alot). Little did I know how worthless the next hour and a half-two hours would be. At first glance, this movie is horrible.  The characters curse every other word. There's gore for no apparent reason.  There's sex scenes for no apparent reason.  There are sex scenes with gore in them for no apparent reason.  How films like these win awards is totally beyond me(however this movie is much better that 'Irreversible'--another rant for another day). Then I heard something interesting.  I heard that this film was supposed to be stupid.  It was supposed to be horrible.  If this is true, then this is a work of absolute genius. Seeing as I don't exactly know what to believe, I'm not sure how to feel about this film.   I won't watch it again, that's for sure.

WOW!!  My husband and I had no idea that this was one of those horrible B-movies where you feel like slitting your wrists just to end the awfulness!!  This is one of those movies never stops being stupid and ridiculous!!  We had read the plot outline here on imdb.com and saw the trailers and thought "Hmmm, ok.  It looks like it has potential"  Boy, were we wrong!!  The only thing that was horrific in this movie was the acting, misuse of "scary music", dialogue and story line.  We went to a drive-in theater to see this movie hoping that we would jump out of our seats, bite our nails and maybe let out a few screams...however, we ended up watching the other movies around us.  Oddly enough, Dickie Roberts was more entertaining.  Our advice to you:  Sneak in!  Save yourself a few dollars and hope and pray that the film industry NEVER EVER makes another movie like this.  And I'm curious if they will add this story line to Scary Movie 5?? Now that's more like it!!

reviews.review_title: Clearly for horror fans with not so many horrors behind them
reviews.content: I shall present this review as a reaction to other comments.Many of them complain there little of a plot "cuz I dunno where dat disease came from." Come on people. This is meant to be an easy teen horror so such details are totally irrelevant for the sake of the movie.Many of them complain about trashy acting. Well this is somewhat true but it could have been worse. Many of them complain about utter predictability. I beg to differ. There are predictable elements to be sure but fortunately there are plenty of new ideas as well (at least for me).In terms of gore, Cabin Fever is a mess (in good sense). I can't help it, this flick wasn't that ordinary and boring to me. If you want truly idiotic recent horror to fall asleep by, go and see Wrong Turn. 6/10 for Cabin Fever

reviews.review_title: Plagarism + lack of talent or originality = The reason the MPAA doesnt make money anyore
reviews.content: A disappointment 100%, This movie lacks talent, original scripting and the ability to hold the audience in suspense. It relies on sex scenes and low-budget gore to try to score points, but only led to head shakes from me. I downloaded this movie to preview (as i usually do with movies i considering paying for when the dvd comes out..Its been a long time since ive paid for a movie based on reasons like this. Its not fair the MPAA puts out misleading trailers and doesnt tell the viewer what they really get) and I just feel ashamed i wasted the bandwidth.Add insult to injury, LAST HOUSE ON THE LEFT was stripped and exploited of its original soundtrack and incorporated into this 2 hours of garbage. If David Hess did give licensing, he has a lot of explaining to do for this one. Score: 1 out of 10 (for a good movie to fall asleep to)

I would like to challenge everyone who liked this film to read the following description of a real life disease, Bordetella pertussis, otherwise known as whooping cough:"Attacks of a choking cough that lasts from 1 to 2 minutes, often with vomiting, severe facial congestions and a feeling or appearance of suffocation. These choking attacks of coughing happen as little as twice a day or as many as fifty.'Whooping' is a noise that comes from the voice box after a paroxysm when the sufferer is suddenly able to take a breath in again. Sometimes the patient stops breathing after a severe bout of coughing, long enough to go blue. Occasionally the patient faints as well."This description from WhoopingCough.net goes on to say that the disease lasts up to 3 months in Adults and can be fatal in children.  Most modern treatments are ineffective at alleviating the symptoms.
Now my question to you is, why would anyone make a film so boring as this one when there are a host of REAL horror stories that are more interesting?

Is Eli Roth the reincarnation of Ed Wood? Surely this has got to be the worst film made since Plan 9 From Outer Space. It may be the worst of all time. There wasn't a shred of continuity throughout the whole thing. There was not one example of believable acting. The dialogue itself was mostly irrelevant, simply a barrage of excessive exclamations and repetitive swearing. The horror scenes were graphic to the point of being comical. Every scene was entirely predictable , but made no sense in terms of continuity. There's a scene where one character falls into a reservoir with a dead body - you could see it coming from the moment he decides to climb down the ladder. The overall effect: I laughed so hard that the intended shock was entirely lost.I have become quite bored with Hollywood's gratuitous use of nudity to compensate for lousy film-making. In this movie, however, I found myself hoping like hell that Cerina Vincent would be naked for the rest of the film, since that was about all it could offer in terms of entertainment value.The only things I've seen as vacuous as this movie are the the Message Board comments for it on IMDB. How sad that young people can consider this even decent entertainment, let alone say "its the best movie in along time at least of 2003". How sad that such drivel can earn the kind of profit that this one did. How sad that everything points to the inevitable sequel.Save your money; try a do-it-yourself an enema instead.

Ok.  The advertising looked great. The poster in the cinema foyer looks fantastic, but the movie, well, is only average.  It's a shame really.  Poor acting, and over the top make-up effects.  I didn't mind the plot, and the way the movie was played out.  It was just the gore factor.  I actually felt a little uncomfortable and disturbed in some scenes.  A few good scary scenes, a little bit of humor, but mostly gore.  So overall...Sick, Disgusting but probably would be more enjoyable watching in the comfort of your own living room rather than a dark, cool cinema.  At least in your own home you can look away.  And I am not usually squeemish in films. I have sat through numerous gore fests.  It is very disgusting, and a terrible film, but not the worst film ever. 4 out of 10.

A bunch of friends goes out for a short holliday in a cabin where a deadly virus awaits. Expect a gory horror/comedy that pays tribute to some of the classics, like Evil Dead, The Shinning, Texas Chainsaw Massacre or The Omen. The problem is... The first part of the movie feels bland, the characters are laughable, the acting terrible, the music score non existent. But after things take a turn for the worst, the movie improves. It completely changes. The acting gets a little better, we recognize the tributes, there are some funny moments and a few disturbing ones... Even the music gets exciting at last. An overall solid horror movie from then on. A pity it started so poorly. In short, this is not a master piece, but not a waste of time either.

reviews.review_title: ...and I paid good money for this crap????!!!!
reviews.content: Be afraid, be very afraid.... of spending good money on crap like this. Poor acting, poor story, poor everything! Looks like it was made by high school kids for high school kids. I can't believe I paid good money for this......... Well, I guess there's one born every minute.

Pancakes was the answer to this movie.  The beautifully crafted martial arts adds a more unique flavor to this already awesome film.  This film also contained some hot sex.  Santa makes a cameo appearance in this movie, and at first it seemed like he didn't like black people, but we were all wrong.

This movie was entertaining, although I feel like it wastes a lot of time on teen dramas rather than bringing horror to the screen. In itself, it tackles the hackneyed theme of youth murders in a cabin in a somewhat interesting way. Here, for most of the film, there are no demons or zombies, but the enemy is a deadly contagious disease that eats away the flesh and leaves a bloody trace.The film has enough grotesque scenes to satisfy the most visceral hunger, and a good dose of humor, although some scenes are a bit surreal (there is a reference to a classic 70s horror movie).In itself a good movie, perhaps not a classic or masterpiece like The Exorcist or The Evil Dead but fans of b-series horror will have a good time.

Granted, this wasn't my cup of tea. I did not get into the characters, and the story just didn't do it for me. Still, Eli Roth should get recognition for doing this movie.. to show that making independent movies still is possible today and succeeding. Its no Evil Dead though, and I have to admit the humor didn't touch me at all. Some of it was very pale.. I liked the policeman character though, he was so wrong! Ouch.All in all, I didn't think too much of this. A better sense of humor and with a bit of a more fresh plot this could have been a good little indie-flick. To some it probably will too. For me it did only half the way.

reviews.review_title: Eli Roth's first theatrical film's is a lot of fun!
reviews.content: Sure, it's no work of art and of course it's not going to be winning any Academy Awards, but honestly folks, it's horror flick. I personally found this film very fun to watch. You can really see director Eli Roth's playful personality in this film. There are funny scenes and some pretty crazy moments and truth be told it just keeps being entertaining. I heard about this film via a family friend and I can't help but to say thanks for recommending this movie. The trick to really enjoying this film is to just kick back, relax, and have a good time. Don't think of this as if it was going to be the next big movie we're going to remember for years, but just a film that we want to have some fun with on a Saturday night. It's a love-it or hate-it movie so you have to watch for yourself to choose which side you're on.

This movie was praised, so I was curious, but deeply disappointed. It was full of clichés, like the young people driving into the woods for vacation, local people who just get after them, corrupt police. The characters are just stereotypes. Heck, if they were only stereotypes, there would at least be somebody to care about in some way. The characters were scripted in way that makes them totally unbelievable. There is no motivation for them to do the things they do. No one of the five people really cares that they torched a sick man. They dump their sick friend in the shed and wait for the night and half a day to start getting medical help, and abandon these tries pretty soon. The script was totally unbelievable, just lining up events. The actors were not able to transport something interesting either and the directing was dull. It was crap. Why does anybody think this movie is exciting or inventive. Everything has already been done over and over again by other and better movies.

reviews.review_title: Pancakes and gay squirrels. Wow! How original!!!
reviews.content: I'm a fan of horror movies. I like to be scared and I' m not put off by gore. When I heard about Cabin Fever I was anxious to watch it and I was ready to like it. So last night I went to the video store and as soon as I saw it I rented it (even though my girlfriend doesn't like gore). I went home, put the movie in the DVD player, turned off the lights and got ready for a scare. After an hour and a half I was still waiting to be scared but the end credits were already rolling. What was this film all about? Silly jokes, weird characters and lots of gore (although I must admit it was very well done) don't make a movie scary. And if a horror movie isn't scary then it is not a good horror movie. Even my girlfriend wasn't scared (and she gets scared by a bloody nose) except in one scene: (*****spoilers*****) In the bathtub where Cerina Vincent shaves her legs and the razor reveals that she is infected - but I guess that's a woman thing.I won't comment on the acting, direction, photography or anything else in the film, because there's no point. The film fails in it's most basic function - it is NOT scary. So it doesn't matter if the acting or direction was good, or if the story was somewhat original. What matters is that the result is not what it should be. Maybe I didn't get the movie or maybe I'm not easily scared but this is one movie I wouldn't recommend to horror fans. I give this one 5 out of 10, only because it's not the worst horror film I've ever watched and because the story has some potential.

I hesitated to watch this movie for a long time believing it to be very scary. I knew from the synopsis that there weren't any monsters and stuff but the thought of what could result from the combination of human imagination and flesh eating bacteria left me wondering if I wanted to expose my mind to such horrors. It's not that I scare easily but after a long day I'd much rather watch something pleasant or meaningful. Anyway, I mustered up the courage to watch this flick one night and it wasn't nearly as scary as I thought it would be. It was sexier than I anticipated (and I really enjoyed that part) but otherwise, it seemed more or less like any other, 'kids-lost-in-the-woods' type of movie. Personally, I feel it could have been improved in many ways to give the characters and story more depth. You might not expect what you see in the ending and the film will probably leave you with a sense of dissatisfaction but overall, it makes for quite an entertaining ride.

reviews.review_title: I had a flesh eating virus once.
reviews.content: And lemme tell you watching this movie was a worse experience. It was amazingly painful to watch. The premise was ok but i think it was directed by Corky from 'Life goes on'. And the characters were retarded. I think their trip to the cabin was sponsered by Easter Seals.I know there were points where they are trying reallllly hard to be funny. But really all it is sad. I also hear alot of people talking about how the pancakes kid is funny. I am assuming these are the same people that keep the simpson's still on tv.

This movie is awful. There is no suspense no action, mostly just a series of F-bombs dropped by unsympathetic characters. The unbelievable behavior of the characters who make little or no effort to save their dying friends. The complete stereotypical characters. The Horny couple the long time friends who both seem to want and the dumb jock like character. If that isn't enough in walks the skater from California whose sole purpose seems to be to own a dog that later kills one of the main characters. As if that isn't enough the filming techniques used look as if they were learned by the director in last weeks film class. Please save your self from getting sick watching this movie

First of all, I would like to say that I love nothing more than a really good, well-done horror movie. I wouldn't say that I'm a total horror geek, but I can appreciate a movie that manages to scare me. It's not very often that I am scared by a movie, so when a movie actually manages to really creep me out, I see it as quite a feat and an indicator that the filmmakers were really doing something right. While there are moments of "Cabin Fever" that I found to be genuinely creepy, there were still too many elements of the movie that I didn't like at all. With its creepy isolated-cabin-in-the-woods setting (a horror cliché that still manages to be effective), lots and lots of gore, and the fact that the studio that released this didn't try to turn it into a star-studded PG-13 affair to draw in the tween crowd (as is the case with almost every horror movie released in the last 10 years), this film had a lot of potential. Too bad it didn't live up to it.The thing that really bugged me about this movie is the way the characters are portrayed. The things that happen to the young college kids that make up the main cast are truly horrible, but it was kind of hard for me to have an emotional response to any of it since I really hated most of the characters. In most bad horror movies, the characters are shallow, obnoxious, and dumb enough to do things like go for late night walks through the woods when there's a psycho killer nearby. The characters in "Cabin Fever" are as shallow, obnoxious, and dumb as the cast of a typical "Friday the 13th" movie, but they're also selfish. The flesh-eating disease that threatens to kill them is definitely scary, but when the characters react to the threat by locking one of their own in a tool shed so she doesn't infect anyone else (wouldn't a locked bedroom door be just as effective, not to mention more comfortable?), having meaningless sex (because no diseases are ever spread through sexual contact, ever), setting a diseased man on fire, driving a disease-infested truck into town (it's a BIOHAZARD, people), and running out into the woods with a six-pack of beer when the going gets tough, I found that I really didn't care if every one of them decomposed into rotting piles of meat before they died. There are also some very strange and random moments that don't make a lot of sense. with such weirdness as a possibly stoned deputy that likes to "party" and a strangely androgynous karate kid who bites people for no good reason, I found it very difficult to take this movie seriously after awhile.Despite my complaints about this movie, there are still some things that I liked. There are some genuinely creepy moments in the last half-hour or so that almost save this movie, such as a bathtub scene in which an infected girl tries to shave her legs and ends up peeling a layer of skin off, and another infected girl who apparently no longer has a face. The ending is also one of the most evil and twisted endings I've ever seen, which makes it the perfect horror movie ending. Let's just say that it involves contaminated water, kids selling contaminated lemonade, and even more contaminated water being shipped to a nearby town. After seeing what happened to the poor bastards who got infected earlier, the idea of an entire town getting infected is scary indeed.

reviews.review_title: The Start Of Roth's Horror Climb
reviews.content:
When we look at the horror masterpieces Eli Roth has gone on to create, Cabin Fever falls quite short of his best. Whilst the storyline, acting, and SFX are good, it is the script that lets it down. The gaps in the dialogue make it hard to share a connection with the characters, which is a vital part of horror movies.
So, the movie follows a group of college students who rent a cabin in the woods for a weekend of fun, sex, and alcohol. The weekend soon turns sour when a local hermit, who is carrying a strange but deadly disease, arrives begging for help and to warn them away. Of course, the students believe he is just crazy and quickly gets rid of him.
Cabin Fever is Roth's directorial debut and taking that into account it would be pretty harsh to slate the film when overall it is not bad. Minus the gaps in the script, it is still very watchable and defiantly worth your time

reviews.review_title: Watch only if you have time to burn....
reviews.content: Quite a pointless movie... the first 20 minutes of so did promise a lot, but as the saying goes - it came in with a bang and went out with a whimper. This flick makes a weak attempt at being a psychotic thriller... in the end, what you have is a bunch of horny young adults who end  up meeting their ultimate fate. If that wasn't bad enough, the ending is even worse with a bunch of hillbillies prancing away to bluegrass - - - what in the world were they thinking when they put this movie together!?!?!?!?!?!

After the huge hype this film has received, I was really looking forward to it. Sadly, it fell far short of expectations. It's an extremely average horror movie. The performances are adequate, but it's very slow-moving and the few scary moments just, well, aren't scary. Congrats to Eli Roth for managing to parlay this into a mega-release distribution deal -- still, for low-budget brilliance, I'll take Bubba Ho-Tep over this any day.

reviews.review_title: Response to the "last 30min went to pot" guy...
reviews.content: As a response to the guy who complained the "last 30min went to pot."...Dude, you just didn't get it.Eli Roth even points out in the DVD features that such things as: the deer through the windshield, Winston, the bunny suit, etc... Were put in because if they didn't have the audience at the 3/4 mark, who the *#&$ cared? Those of us who WERE with the filmmakers by 3/4 through, nearly died laughing. Oh horror-comedies, why are you so great? Sigh!----------------- And not to beat the issue to death, but *grabbing beating stick*, if a flesh eating hobo-disease, and shooting squirrels ('cause they're gay), and...uh...DENNIS didn't strike you as "over the top" but a guy hitting a deer (albeit a ridiculously fake ones with lovely kicking feet!) with his car did...well...good luck to you sir! You'll need it!

This movie was awesome.  The movie is about a group of people who go to the woods for the weekend.  To party get drunk and have some sex.  But they have no idea about the CABIN FEVER going around.  The movie was so funny too it was really great enjoyable.

When I first watched Cabin Fever I was totally in to that sort of movie.. But when i started to watch it it started to give me a weird feeling, like this is pretty scary yet strangely funny.. Surprisingly the acting was pretty good save for the overabundance of F this F that F you's and so on.. I sort of like how it was made with that psychotic sort of sense of mind, maybe it was the extremely Dark Humor. Personally i loved the very end when the dude who went into hiding returns only to find all his friends dead. He then gives himself a wave of gratitude before walking out the back door and getting shot up by the Homicidal police force..Another personal favorite is the hippie cop... Overall however the movie is crap. It was cheaply made, which is very obvious right from the beginning, and the language is enough to shut it off alone. A complete give away of the lack of funding is the scene with the dear, I don't think I have laughed so hard in such a long time. Watch it once and forget about it.

reviews.review_title: A mixed bag, but the bad outweighs the good
reviews.content: I saw Roth's Hostel and Hostel 2, and enjoyed them both, so I bought Roth's first film, Cabin Fever. This film has its low points and high points, but the bad outweighs the good. The film has some tense moments and truly scary scenes. The setup is pretty good, and the violent scenes are well done. The script isn't terrible for the genre, but it isn't impressive either. The direction and acting are only average for horror films, at best. The biggest problem that ruined the movie for me is the complete lack of emotion shown by all the teens. As their friends, lovers, and companions are stricken with the disease or killed, none of the other characters seem to care at all. Their lack of any emotions make what could have been a pretty good horror movie into a below average movie. Oddly enough, this film as a very high 62% rating at Rotten Tomatoes, especially consideirng critics don't usually like the genre.I give "Cabin Fever" 4/10. See it only if you're a die-hard horror or Roth fan.

reviews.review_title: wow....all I can say, is wow...
reviews.content: What a piece of crap...can't say I was disapointed, cuz I thought it'd be a piece of crap, with all the incessant buildup surrounding it...but by the time the credits start rolling, I literally had my mouth agape at just how hideous this film was.Eli Roth must be the most delusional director to come by in a long time...for all the hype surrounding this movie that he gladly fed with his non-stop yapping in interviews and on the dvd, this movie is a disgrace.  ..an absolutely nails-against-the-blackboard bore, with not one scary moment to be found...for all the hoohaw about the return to gore and sex, the gore is tame and it's impact is lost by the constant score-blasts and cut- scenes that are supposed to pass for scares.  Awful performances, no suspense (at the 40 minute point, I'm STILL waiting for something, ANYthing scary to happen...), and a script that's bad beyond belief...there's a review I read that refers to the 'rifle joke' at the general store, and how the first part of the joke might have been funny, if not curious, on it's on...but to bring closure, and 'explain' the joke the way he does...and as THE LAST SCENE...??  It almost made me wish I had seen it in a theater, so I could have boo'd even louder then I had originally intended on booing it, BEFORE that final scene!!Yeah, it's a first film, but it's pretty clear: Eli Roth is a hack.  He may talk a good game in interviews and he's a protege to a genius, David Lynch, but he's a hack all the same. What's worse, is that with all the clamor to praise this piece of garbage, he seems to believe his own hype.  Like that other horror-film hack WS Anderson, Roth is utterly clueless in how to establish and manipulate tone, let alone go back and forth between horror and dark comedy.  For that, go back and watch Evil Dead or Dead-Alive...Cabin Fever is dismally boring, gutless, and most unforgiveable, excrutiatingly full of itself.

this movie has to be the WORST movie i have ever seen. i have seen almost every movie that has come out, and when i went to see this movie i expected to be scared and enjoy it. but instead i was bored for the whole 2hrs and however many minuets. my boyfriend came with me and half way thru the movie he started insisting that we leave. but i made him stay hoping that it would get better but what happened???? the movie got worse i new with in the first 45 seconds, (including the introduction) that it was going to be awful.. the only part of the movie i enjoyed were the trailers that played prior to the showing. if i could give anyone good advise this would be it.. do NOT GO TO THIS MOVIE, it has to be the worst movie made in the past 40 years... please take my advise dont go see this...

This was one of the worst movies I have seen. Granted I am not a huge horror fan, but that is only because the so called horror movies that come out these days are not scary at all. Many are comparing this to movies like Evil Dead and such and that is why they like it. This movie made no sense at all. It was not scary or all that gory. The actors were not very good but that is not the point in "horror" movies so that did not bother me much. I am not sure how they stretched a movie that is about a virus that kills everyone into a 90 minute movie, oh yeah thats right they put in every 80's horror movie cliche in it and call it a tribute? I laughed through the entire movie not cause it was funny, but because it was that bad. The part with Rider Strong(what a name) and the girl he likes in bed is funny as hell! This movie was a complete waste of time and money. I sure am glad that my theater only charges 5 bucks! IF you are a die hard fan of so called "horror" movies then you may like this. If not stay far away from this nothing of a movie. Go see Open Range if you want to see a good movie!Remember...You are your own best critic (but trust me on this one) lol

This movie is a classic. Hilarious, entertaining, and a little bit creepy.Perfect.To me a horror movie has to have either incredible camp value or actually be somewhat frightening. Cabin fever actually accomplishes a ten on each scale. The character of Winston played by a guy named Giussepe Andrews, whom I haven't seen much of since this movie, is hilarious. They play on political correctness, our unhealthy fear of viruses, everything. My only surprise from this movie is that it didn't garner a lot more attention, that it didn't get better reviews, and that the guy who played Winston didn't become a mega star afterwards. seriously, watch it just for Winston.

Cabin Fever really had potential to be a truly amazing horror film, but overall it ends up being an average B movie. Before seeing this I looked at all the reviews on here and thought it would be utterly terrible, but after seeing it, I thought it to be a really enjoyable fun horror film. It's shocking and some parts were even suspenseful and quite scary. Sure, it's not perfect. The film is very cliché, some scenes are stupid, and some of the logic of the film is undeniably eyebrow raising. The acting isn't perfect, but it's decent. Taking the film as a serious horror film, over analyzing every detail, and keeping a checklist of all the mistakes it made will just end up with extreme hate for the film. I admit, even though you're supposed to take the film lightly, some scenes just can't surpass extreme stupidity. But overall, Cabin Fever is a very entertaining horror/comedy flick to be taken for a night of truly enjoyable popcorn fun.

reviews.review_title: Nothing Like I Expected And I Wouldn't Have Wanted It Any Other Way
reviews.content: I had been waiting about 2 years to see this movie. I remember reading about it when it was in pre-production and thinking it seemed like a good idea. It was filmed right outside of the city I live in so that made me want to see it even more. I finally saw it tonight and it was absolutely NOTHING like I expected...it was better. I had heard it was very scary and very gross. Both are true. Being an avid horror film fan, I have seen so many scary movies that they don't really scare me anymore. I simply watch them because I love them. However, several times during this movie I did jump. If a movie can make someone who has seen EVERY horror movie jump, it has to be good, right? It also had some very gory scenes but, to be honest, I found the scenes that only implied the gore rather than actually show it to be MUCH more disturbing...sort of the old "what you don't see is worse than what you do see" concept. What I was not expecting was how truly outrageous and off-the-wall this film was. On more than one occasion I was left with mumbling "what the f*** was THAT??!" I guess this really SHOULDN'T surprise me because David Lynch was involved with the making of this film and let's face it: ALL of his own movies tend to leave you scratching your head...to say the least! The comedy was also an unexpected, yet welcome surprise. It gave it a sort of "Evil Dead 2" feel. I feel duty-bound to add here that contrary to the rumours this film is not really ANYTHING like the first "Evil Dead" unless you consider that both films take place in a cabin in the woods (and if that is the only reason for comparison then you might as well say that "Evil Dead" was similar to that god-awful waste of celluloid with Morty the giant puppet called "The Fear"). Several of the cast and crew were at the theatre promoting the film (since it was filmed here). It was fun to talk with them and then see them running around covered in blood on screen. I think Cerina Vincent may well have a promising career ahead of her. Overall, my friends and I decided that we may very well have NEVER seen a movie quite like this but we truly loved it. The whole theatre was laughing one second and screaming the next. I highly recommend this film so go see it! You'll be promoting independent films and having a damn good time, guaranteed!!****1/2 out of 5

When I started watching this movie I didn't expect anything great, but I thought it would be a good watch, a solid horror movie.  I expected a B-movie, because what horror movies aren't (other than 28 Days Later). But what I got was one of the worst movies I have ever seen!  The plot was horrible, there was absolutely nothing scary about this movie, and it seemed like it would never end.My advice: don't waste 90 minutes of your life on this piece of crap.

Those looking forward to Cabin Fever for months before its theatrical release found out quickly that this film, hailed as a balls-to-the-wall return to 80s style gore filled horror, was a victim of misleading marketing. While there are some intense moments of shock and gore, Cabin Fever serves more of a self-referential study of horror films of the past. Once one is able to get past the disappointment of watching a different film than promised, it is easy to have a great time with the films comedic elements.Like most good horror films, Cabin Fever begins with a group of young men (with the only real star being Rider Strong of TVs Boy Meets World fame) and women isolating themselves and setting themselves up for later terror. In this particular movie, the young men and women have rented a cabin in the woods to celebrate something or another. The plot doesn't matter, really, as things quickly go downhill.A flesh eating virus is loose in the sleepy backwoods town and is brought to the group by way of an infected hermit that not only scares the daylights out of the gang but also manages to cause the destruction of their vehicle. What ensues is a paranoid struggle of life and death that begins with one girl getting sick and the others worried about the possibility of infection.
While the plot sounds potential terrifying, the movie is often played for laughs. Fans of the genre will appreciate many hidden nods to classics (watch in particular for a homage to Texas Chainsaw Massacre when the camera follows Marcy to a house from behind the actress). This is a messy movie, with much blood and gore. There are also some genuinely unsettling moments scattered throughout, though the virus plot fails to inspire any real terror and much of the horror is left up to sporadic boo-scares.Director Eli Roth has proven himself to be full of potential with this freshman outing. He knows the genre well and has written and directed a solid film that is, while not as much fun the second and third time, extremely entertaining. Go into Cabin Fever expecting a fun examination of the genre through a paper thin plot and you won't be disappointed by the lack of much real horror.

reviews.review_title: Nothing but an excuse for pointless, tasteless violence.
reviews.content: Will a good horror movie ever be made again? Judging by this worthless effort; unlikely.This film stands along side Final Destination 2 as the worst film I can ever recall seeing.The acting was mediocre, the plot virtually non existant and it is not at all genuinely scary. Simply subjecting the audience to endless gruesome special effects, 'blood, guts and gore,' is simply revolting, over the top and nothing more. These things are only there as an attempt to compensate for a shallow, pointless movie. It was boring, repetitive and the characters were so awful that I cannot see anyone caring what happens to them. I couldn't wait for them to be killed off, mainly just to get the film over with! The next time I make such a mistake I will simply walk out. Do not waste your money on this movie.Inevitably though, there are many who will no doubt like this film for most of the reasons I detest it. If you actually liked Final Destination 2 then you will probably appreciate this!Mercy!

Whoever at LionsGate green-lite this movie should have their heads examined.. I would so embarrassed to have my name attached to this movie in any aspect.I'm sorry, but this movie was HORRIBLE. The plot line was week at best. The story was driven by 5 characters you could care less about. At one point a new character was introduced. There was no real reason to introduce this character. Then to add insult to injury-we don't see this character for like 20mins, then he ends up dead. Who cares..I understand that story lines are recycled now adays. But at least add some imagination and creativity. Traditional horror films should contain some scary moments or at least be fun and entertaining. Cabin Fever was neither.
Save your money! Turn on the weather channel. At least it would be more entertaining..

reviews.review_title: Flesh-eating viruses make for a great vacation!
reviews.content: A group of college friends rent a remote cabin for a vacation, but a deadly flesh-eating virus soon ruins their plans. It soon spreads amongst the group and their ruthless selves begin to emerge. Eli Roth delivers an eerie tale of a flesh-eating virus and the way people react when their lives are in danger. This is such a great movie because it's not really your typical "horror" at all. There is no serial killer, mutant zombie, or made doctor, it's just a flesh-eating virus. I think the real horror with this is showing how everyone quickly turns on one another after discovering some may be infected. Aside from some very random parts that had nothing to do with this movie at all ("pancakes"), it was a very effective and disturbing horror movie.

When are the young adult characters in American movies going to learn that no matter how smart and sophisticated they think they are, there's always something shocking to be revealed and learned when you 'lift a rock' in the country. Underneath all those 'rocks' are a lot of things that squirm and bite. These often-dangerous things have absolutely no respect for smug, cynical and foul-mouthed college-aged friends looking for Spring-Break adventures out in the middle of Nowhere-Woods.I found this film thoroughly enjoyable, albeit very often frighteningly disturbing. There's a lesson to be learned here, and I'm not speaking as one of your parents when you were a teenager (or college student). I must accept what I see and hear in this little horror movie, especially since I discovered that the director himself (Eli Roth)was once infected with a similar type of flesh-eating bacteria when working in another country.The plot devices, production values and techniques used in this movie harken back to 1970s horror films such as "Deliverance," "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre" and "The Hills Have Eyes," among countless others. There's even a touch of the old 1968 horror film, George A. Romero's "Night of the Living Dead." I guess the only thing left for me to say now is: if you get thirsty or need to wash, please, for cornsake, boil the water you're going to drink or use. How smart do you have to be to know this?

reviews.review_title: Better than it had any right to be
reviews.content: No better way describe it. Above average from your usual teen horror movies. Maybe a bit too long and dragged by the end. Nonsensical and fun. Decent actors.

reviews.review_title: Finally a great, cheesy horror flick!
reviews.content: With a dash of weirdness a la David Lynch, this could-have-been-run-of-the-mill backwoods horror flick is actually a really fun, tongue-in-the-cheek, gore-filled gem.  The main point here is to pile on the gore and humor similar to what was done in films like Bad Taste and Dead Alive.  Anybody expecting another cliche stalker-on-the-loose horror flick should learn how to read up on horror films before seeing them because not all great horror films follow that theme.  In fact the majority of crap that's been released lately follows that theme because people are dumb enough to go see anything labeled "horror".This film is also more of a nod to fans of old school horror from the 70s and 80s.  That means you annoying teenagers that went to see the film and hated it...you need to realize that there were actually horror films made before Scream.  Decades of them.

reviews.review_title: One gory masterpiece of a film! Well...almost.
reviews.content:
Cabin Fever is one of those films that you'll never quite forget. You really cannot do that, it's too shocking, too graphic in it's nature. There's not that many films that you can compare it with. There's 28 Days Later of course, but that film took the same thematic elements and put it into a much grander scale than this film did. 28 Days Later's fictional disease affected an entire country, which in a way makes this film so much more intimate and claustrophobic. Being that these characters are together from the beginning of the film also makes you feel more for them as they gradually become infected. Supporting characters such as the "pancakes kid", the owners of that dreadful gas-station and the comedic police man with his bike all make this film feel like a part of the family of films that include films such as Texas Chain Saw Massacre, Wrong Turn and House of 1.000 Corpses. A truly frightening film that is. The film is rather gory from time to time, but not overly gory. There's loads of blood and guts spilled and the make-up effects are fantastically gruesome. There's also a "love theme" by genre veteran Angelo Badalamenti.
The only thing that I find to complain about regarding this film is the ending. ** SPOILER**When Jeff comes out of the cabin at the end, after having discovered the fact that he is the only survivor, screaming that he made it, you know what's going to happen as he walks out that door. It's pretty obvious he's going to be shot and thus a bit disappointing. I can't quite seem to remember if this is the final scene of the film or if there was yet another scene after that, but the facts remain as it takes the edge of a film that could have turned out to be a masterpiece if it had been slightly better executed.

This movie was absolutely terrible. I am a movie lover, and I have seen hundreds of films, and this is the only one I can truly say was awful. The virus thing has been done well before, but this was not done well. You knew that it was only a matter of time before they all had the virus. There was no loophole, no way they could avoid it. Therefore, the suspense lay in waiting to see how they realised it, and how gruesome it was.***** SPOILERS *****Now, don't get me wrong, I'm a fan of gruesome killings, but not this. I mean, come on? You're watching her shave her legs. Watching her shave her legs. You know that the razor's going to take off her flesh. You know it's going to happen. She's still shaving normally.... AAAAH... not. Everything was done for gore and shock factor, and not one thing gave me a real scare.However, there was one thing that I did enjoy, and that was the ending. The fact that the guys who simply killed the remaining kids, rather than trying to help them, then dumped the bodies - (very carelessly, I might add. They could have got the clever ones, who realised that dumping a contagious body in a source for drinking water is a no-no, but instead, they get the stupid ones to dump the body) - will now get the disease, and it will spread everywhere, is a very ironic, funny and clever ending.However, it's the only ironic, funny and clever thing in this whole movie. I may also have seen it as the best bit because the movie did, in fact, end. My advice, unless you are a fan of gratuitous gore, very little plot, and no suspense (apart from waiting to see how the next oozing bloody wound will manifest itself) then avoid it. Or just watch the last fifteen minutes. You'll get the overall point of the movie, and the best bit, all in one.

reviews.review_title: One of the best horror movies I've ever seen
reviews.content: I LOVE this movie!!!!!  I rented it and watched it 4 times in a row!!!  I don't understand why people always give this movie a bad rap.  Upon watching the DVD it is discovered (by listening to the director's commentary) that this movie is a TRIBUTE to old horror movies (Evil Dead Series, The Thing and Texas Chainsaw Massacre to be exact.)  The movie from what I saw was a refreshing horror movie compared to the dribble that comes off as being horror today.  From what I saw the movie is PERFECT IN EVERY WAY.  It totally brought the genre back to life and I have since become a fan of Eli Roth.  Keep up the great work Eli!!!  No, I don't think that the movie was scary as I am a seasoned Horror fan, but the entire premise of the movie drags you into it and explodes with over the top gore.  Eli Roth made a masterpiece which has (very) quickly rose in the ranks as one of my favorite horror movies.  Again Eli, keep up the great work!

reviews.review_title: Makes Watching College Kids Die Fun
reviews.content: It took some time after I screened Cabin Fever to enjoy what I watched. It's actually real fun and I think that's what splatter films and Eli Roth is all about. There is some kind of chuckle of surrealism I do at some point in a film like this, usually towards the end of the second act, when I've seen enough buckets of blood make their way onto the screen. It's along the lines of "Come on dude, this is absurd." This happened for me in Cabin Fever, not because of an un-necessary amount of gore but because it becomes so much fun and it's so ridiculous. The film builds itself up beautifully to a great climax. A climax built where you don't give a crap about the kids, or anyone, being killed because it satisfies the sick pleasure that made us watch this film. The five college kids are each more unlikable than likable. I don't know if Roth and Pearlstein gave them the whack-est lines and college slang to say on purpose but I felt good knowing they wouldn't be able to convince me to come with on their getaway. Our "protagonist" has a squeaky voice and is friend zoned by the nice, respectable chick (yes there is a whore to compare her with). We have the husky goon who gets no ass but loves to get drunk and the alpha male who's false sense of tough is derived from the slut he bangs. What Eli Roth and Randy Pearlstein do here is non traditionally infect a character. Traditionally, meaning the unwritten law in horror where "so and so" is supposed to die before "so and so" because of "such and such" reason. Once that happens all morality goes out the door and pretty much we're not rooting for anyone to be safe, we just want to see in which way they succumb to the disease. And it's not in their sleep trying to nurse themselves in warm blankets and hot cocoa. The best part is, if you're infected you're screwed, and the unspecified countdown commences! The title's figurative meaning makes for an intelligent theme in the film as well and that also makes the 5 college students just more the reason to slaughter. As we can see from Roth's filmography he loves to make killing fun and he does that in Cabin Fever, better than he did in Hostel where it's just sick and sadistic. I happen to love the misc-en-scene towards the conclusion that makes you feel like you've caught the disease yourself. I also love Cerina Vincent. In all, this is recommendable if you want to have fun 90 minutes.

I don't understand why people hate this movie so much I love this one, the original not the annoying remake this movie is hilarious I laugh everytime I watch it maybe some people don't like dark humor but for those who do this one is a classic. James debello as Bert is probably one of my favorite characters I grew up with a guy who was the spitting imagine of him and makes me laugh everytime.

reviews.review_title: Please, Don't Take This Film Seriously
reviews.content: Eli Roth is shaping up to be the Kevin Smith of horror films.Mr. Roth, an admitted fan of the genre since he was 8, has shaped his passion for gore flicks into Cabin Fever, a lopsided tribute to the senseless violence and campy thrills of the horror movies of the 70s and 80s.Cabin Fever is his first attempt at a mainstream film. Note: FIRST ATTEMPT.There's nothing in this film that sets one up to believe that this is a serious attempt at horror. In fact, each character is a staple of the horror community. Horny couple? Check. Drunk ignorant party-animal? Check. Clean-cut All-American Boy (Rider Strong, from Boy Meets World)? Check. All-American Boy's secret love interest? Check. Lots of bizarre in-bred rural-types? Checkity-check-check-check.Roth shares his love of bad horror with us via Cabin Fever. All he really needed was the three B's (beer, blood, and breasts), and he delivered in spades. Except for that third one. There wasn't enough of that. Bad Eli. No cookie.Cabin Fever is your basic toss-back-a-few-beers-and-enjoy-the-ride type of film. It only requires enough cognitive function to operate a DVD player. If you're looking for depth, extensive character development, and well-written drama, you're looking in the wrong section of the video rental store.This is also very NOT for the family. As with Kevin Smith, the language is quite riddled with expletives. If it's ever edited to air on network TV, expect it to run about an hour shorter. Of course, Mr. Roth, ever thoughtful of his audience, does include a "family version" of the film on the DVD. It's a must-watch. It's also quick.This film is a tribute to cheese. 100% Grade-A American cheese, to be precise. While I'm certain that Eli Roth has a classic in horror within him, just waiting to erupt, I'm equally certain that he didn't intend this to be it. Just be patient.

It was a little good.The visual affects were good. I think Bert and Paul did the best acting. It was freaky, had a lot of blood in it. Overall I think the movie was a big waste of time. But I can't give too much off.

I saw this with my friend Amber last night not expecting much. Really what I was expecting a pointless movie with no plot and tons of gore and bad acting. So I wasn't let down! It was a bunch of people dying very badly. It ended up being very funny just because it was so bad. The best part of the night was when this girl from a group behind us that wouldn't shut up walked down the stairs of the theater tripped and fell. That was the only thing that really was memorable.

I can't believe some of the other views on this movie.  It was completely outrageous to pay 8.50 to see this.  It sucked.  There was no plot, the acting sucks, the writing sucks.  It wasn't scary at all, just gross and gory.  It had a few humorous parts but other than those the movie just doesn't make my list.  Definitely not what you'd expect for all the advertising they did to promote this. This one builds you up and literally drops you flat on your face.  I was in complete disgust, not just at how horrible this movie was, but that I couldn't get my money back!

This movie is kinda funny, kinda gross, kinda pointless and overall kinda entertaining. You have to be on some sort of herbal medication to actually sit through it though. I liked the gore, I liked the ending, I liked the hicks, and I laughed at some of the lines because they were SOOOO bad. If you really want to see an entertaining movie, watch "Wrong Turn." Now that movie is real horror in some scenes, and hilarious in others. Highly entertaining. I kind of see this as a poor man's Wrong Turn, but adding a horrible flesh eating virus. You'll see. Don't go in with any sort of high expectations. This is nothing but a gory, dark comedy and some would say made in poor taste. Watchagonnado.

Caught this film at the IFP/LA.Eli Roth has a real sense of the genre, I'll give him that.  His story of five college kids on a spring break getaway who contract a deadly flesh-eating virus has plenty of gore and lost of good "gotchas" that make the flesh, well, crawl.My problem with the film is that it hangs a little too much on the conventions and cliches without breaking any new ground.  Also, it tends to telegraph its surprises a little too much--when one of these kids walks through the house pumping his fist in celebration and announcing over and over, "I survived!  I f***ing survived!" you just know that he's going to walk into a demise similar to the end of "Night of the Living Dead" (the original, not the remake).  Other things bothered me, like the inclusion of a young deputy with a peach fuzz mustache who's obsessed with partying; his scenes seem like they were plugged in as an afterthought.Does Roth have talent?  As a director, yes.  He paces his film and frames his images quite well.  But the script could use a lot of work, some punching up and a little originality injected into the narrative.

reviews.review_title: Warning: This movie is not to be taken literally.
reviews.content:
*Possible Spoilers* Sure the acting wasnt fantastic, the plot was ridiculous, and the characters were brainless, but what the hell do you expect from a movie of this type?? This movie wasnt meant to be scary. It goes along with many of the horror flicks of the 80's, such as the Friday the 13th series and the later sequels of A Nightmare on Elm Street. Nobody in their right mind is scared by these movies, if they are a trip to a psychiatrist couldnt hurt. They are meant to be a funny, sex/nudity filled adrenaline rush. For those of you who thought that this movie wasnt gory, it makes me wonder if you shouldnt be checking into your local psych ward. This film was full of splattering, spewing, squirting blood. There was flesh rotting off of bodies, severed limbs, heads, and feet. There were beatings, bodies shot to death, skin torn off a leg with a razor, and one character was torn to pieces by a dog. What else do you want from a film, exploding bodies? Chopped up organs? Maybe the graphic systematic slaughter of children?? I swear there are some true psychos among us!!! I would say that nearly 200 F-bombs are dropped in this film, a bit excessive, but actually pretty close to reality when considering the source, a group of 5 college students.
