The nudity, all of which is credited to Cerina Vincent is a nice addition for the young male viewers. The end of the movie is rather satisfying as nearly every character in the film either dies horribly or will die horribly shortly after the film comes to a close.
Sure some absurd content was added, such as the kung fu by the little boy/girl, the murderous rampage of the lead character at the end, and the whole inclusion of the party animal cop who weakened the already frail credibility of the film, but overall it was a mission accomplished.

yes, my summary says it all! When i decided to watch it, it was because of all the hype and reviews 'terrifying!' said one review. well whoever said that must p*** himself when someone says 'boo', cos cabin fever was one of the worst films i have ever seen. the other comments of this film in this forum have said it's a copy of other horror movies, it's badly done, and it ruined it's potential with unrealistic scenes and weak characters- well guess what? I agree! i sat down expecting a scary disturbing film- what did i get- a load of sh**, that's what. the concept is quite scary (some teenagers in a cabin in the middle of nowhere, being killed off by a flesh eating virus) but it was handled really badly. the films humour is NOT humorous, and worse, it's inappropriate. also, the characters keep making stupid irrational actions, which are unrealistic even if your in a panic. i kept thinking about what it would have been like done well, and it makes me feel disappointed. this Eli Roth needs shooting. 'hostel' a newer horror movie by Eli Roth, again, like cabin fever, looked great, but i'm told it's sh** (i'll have to see it myself). so it seems Eli Roth makes up (or steals) brill horror ideas and then makes a mockery of them. i wish i'd been given the chance to make cabin fever. however, there was one bit that i liked. it's the bit when that blond women is making love to that guy (the more friendly couple out of the teens)and there's that really euphoric sweet music, and then... well i won't spoil it, but it's quite horrific, and it did make me feel quite sad, because they had a closer relationship than the brunette woman and the other guy. and there's the bit with the woman who looks like a skeleton cos of the virus- that was sort of horrific. the ending had quite a good twist, but it was done poorly, which made it absolutely rubbish. see for fun, not to be scared. guess i'll have to carry on my fruitless search to find a 'SCARY' horror film...

reviews.review_title: Watchable but not good at all
reviews.content: I'm a huge horror fan, I've avoided this one until now so I thought I'd give it a watch. Only thing this movie has going for it is the gore. The characters are all unlikable, their dialogue is ridiculous, and their actions are mindless.

Well, it's watchable but that's it really. If you're freaked out by gore then yes it might be scary but honestly 2 hours of blood being coughed up just doesn't raise the hairs on my neck that much. Cabin Fever if nothing else is reasonably original, the 'baddy' being a disease rather than some monster after the typical group of dumb teenage kids who decide to camp alone in some woods. But the film is stupid, in terms of the situation, and the ending is just..... bizarre. Mind you, I did go to the cinema with my girlfriend and so i probably didn't get a complete view of the whole film. But enough to know i'd rather not have gone. This wasn't fever, it was more like Cabin go to sleep syndrome.

reviews.review_title: Hope you're not looking for horror
reviews.content: The first five minutes of this movie showed potential. After that, it went straight from something possibly decent to some sort of illegitimate comedy. The best part is that I couldn't stop thinking of Supertroopers thanks to Joey Kern. I would recommend watching this movie for the sheer fact of learning how not to make a movie. There are so many scenes in this movie that makes one just stop and wonder if the entire cast and crew just stopped caring at some point. The thing that amazes me most about this movie is that it grossed $22 million in the box office and only cost about $1.5 million to make. Congrats to Lion's Gate for being able to pull that one off.

Cabin Fever is a smart, self-aware horror flick that hearkens back to the good ole horror days of yore, learns from it, and creates a whole new beast.For a while, it seemed as though all the innovation in horror had been exhausted.. nearly everything that came out in the genre in the late 90's seemed to be either a shoddy remake of a horror classic, or a shoddy remake of a quality Asian horror in an attempt at making it "palatable" for American audiences. In either case, the results have been mediocre at best. Horror needed a breath of fresh air, a new approach.. and Cabin Fever fits the bill.The trick was putting new twists on the old tried, true, and yet tired horror foundations, such as the basic plot (group of randy teens who go off to a remote cabin seeking a little fun only to find the horrors aplenty), and breathing new life into it. Cabin Fever was so well aware of its "traditional" horror foundations that it succeeded round the board in a satire of the genre, while still being a solid scary movie. It's rare to find a film that can successfully mock the genre it's patterned after and yet still be as effective as standard genre fair. This is probably Cabin Fever's greatest strength. It's an entertaining horror film; scary, good effects, etc, and it is also an effective and quite funny send up of the horror genre. The writers definitely did their homework.That being said, a film like Cabin Fever is destined to primarily appeal to a cult audience. This is a film that was made specifically for horror aficionados, much of the humour is aimed at people who have spent hours and hours watching the old cult horror flicks (Evil Dead, H.G. Lewis's stuff, Peter Jackson's, etc). If you're not someone who delights in (and has spent a great deal of time watching) the old cheesy horror stuff, a lot of the point of the film is lost. But I suspect Cabin Fever, like Evil Dead, 2000 Maniacs, etc, will be playing at midnight movies 20 years from now.

In the seemingly endless chain of modern horror movies Cabin Fever has achieved something of a cult status. This can surely be put down to the various production asides rather than any aesthetic viewing experience.The debut film of director Eli Roth from his own story concerns five college graduates who rent a cabin in the woods. Unfortunately for them a flesh-eating virus has entered the local water supply. After they kill an infected victim things soon degenerate. The group begins to disintegrate as self-preservation and selflessness come to the fore. Matters come to a head when the involvement of both the local population and officials leads to an even higher level of danger.Stock characters are clearly delineated from the start, thus we have heroic Paul (Rider Strong), nice girl Karen (Jordan Ladd), trampy girl Marcy (Cerina Vincent), dimwit Bert (James DeBello) and the egocentric strange one Jeff (Joey Kern).In the old days (i.e. the 70s) we could ascertain with a fair degree of certainty which of these people would survive. In the ways of modern horror, Cabin Fever prefers to give us characters with few if any redemptive or empathic features. Accordingly, the ending - even with any lame twists - fails to either surprise or please. The 90-odd previous minutes contain some gory scenes, largely ordinary acting, some poor acting from minor characters, fairly good special effects and some very poor dialogue interspersed with an overuse of the 'f' word. The plot becomes increasingly unfathomable as the film progresses until it eventually simply runs out of steam. There is a soundtrack which simply adds to the annoyance.Since the 2002 release of this film there have been two sequels (with a third in production) and a remake, none of which were necessary.One further point which most reviewers either missed or chose not to mention: At one point Old Man Cadwell (played by Robert Harris), running the shop, makes a racist comment. Later, almost as if by an act of contrition, there is a 'twist' scene involving the same character. Great horror films almost invariably contain comic scenes. If that was the purpose here, in this reviewers' opinion it failed miserably and merely left a bad taste...

reviews.review_title: If you like your horror films over-rated and pointless...
reviews.content: then this is the film for you!  Get on the hype train and ride this ingratiating film to its boring conclusion.I swear the director went out of his way to watch all the greatest horror films made in the last 40 years and then proceeded to remember none of it.The only thing scary about this film is that people have liked it, people call it a horror film, and that the director will go on to make another film.Not since "Pieces" has their been a more pointless martial arts scene.You've been warned - Cabin Fever has characters out of a bad David Lynch film who would never be friends, no action, no idea of location, zero scares, and a talented DP.Cabin Fever is easily the worst straight to video film that somehow got projected since "Jason Takes Manhattan."Consider yourself warned...

I stopped counting at 15 the number of times I asked, "Why did he/she/they do that?"  The storyline was completely random and meandering. Plot points were introduced, then dropped. The scene cuts were arbitrary and painfully noticeable, as were the music cues. I actually tend to like David Lynch's work, but the Lynchian characters were jarring in the context of the movie. The only real humor was, I'm certain, unintentional.

This movie was so great and traumatizing when I saw it in high school. It's still so fun to watch and has such great horror moments. I cannot shave my legs without thinking of this movie. I hate jumpscares but they get me everytime in this movie and I love it.

this is the worst "horror" movie ever, hands down.  Within the first 5 minutes of the movie I was questioning what the hell I was watching & resisting the temptation to just walk out.  It made no sense, the "actors" were HORRIBLE, and it was not scary at all. A week later, I'm still trying to figure out wtf was up with that kid Dennis & why he started screaming "pancakes" on the top of his lungs & busted out with some Matrix-style karate  moves.  I guess my first clue that it was going to be bad should've been the fact that the kid from Boy Meets World was the first name in the opening credits, b/c it was all down hill from there. If you want to laugh your ass off at the complete retardation of this movie, then by all means, waste your $9 on it.   But, if you think that by seeing this, you're going to be seeing a horror flick that claims to be a homage to classics, then you're sadly mistaken.  This movie sucked as a horror flick, and anyone who says differently is definitely on something.

Perfect example of a non-pretentious horror movie. Scary? Well... it has some nice shockers. Gore? Oh yes, lots of gore and rather convincing too. Plot? Don't mention it. There's a virus on the move that kills you fast. Gruesome too. The inevitable bunch of teenagers (sex, booze, weed, did I mention sex) get contaminated one by one. They fight the virus, each other, the law and the local villagers. And they die one by one. That just about sums it up. But the handling of this simple material is very efficient and I think Cabin Fever is very entertaining. I found it a relief to see this after watching stupid Ring clones like FearDotCom and Gothika.

reviews.review_title: horror is dead, long live the mediocre.
reviews.content: Some animals when caught in a trap gnaw their own limbs off to escape. Its how I felt watching this, I wanted to gnaw my way through the fire escape to freedom. A pointless brew of far better films all thrown into a hat and chosen at random to rip off. Homage perhaps? No, I think not. Everything thats wrong with cinema is in this film, its a checklist of incompetence. A plot line thats moves along with all the coherence of a James Brown interview. Characters you hate 5 minutes before you walk into the theater. No explanation for why things are happening (not that you will care). Nothing is good about this, not a thing. Its not even good in a bad way. The makers obviously were suffering from the flesh eating virus featured in the film, it must have eaten that part of their brain that deals with originality and creativity.Had they stuck to making a creepy little film in a cabin with all the usual stereotypes and a few thrills this might have been a real homage to the genre (is their a stuck in a cabin genre?). Instead they try to be clever. Who lets these people near a camera? Who's responsible for these films? Who in their right mind thinks a Homage to Cujo is a good idea?There are much better films out there to be seen, in fact. Why not hire the old films this heap tries to Homage. Watch Evil Dead again, even Cujo. Enjoy Night of the Living Dead (and its real ironic ending) go now and watch the classics, learn from them. Learn from the past and if your ever given a camera and a budget then you will have a real grounding in the history of the horror film. I get the feeling these folk cheated on their horror exams, thats why they know nothing about real Homage. You have to love a genre not treat it with contempt, this was made by people who probably thought Jeepers Creepers was robbed of an Oscar.Harsh? possibly. Feel free to be your own judge, but as you have read. Ive judged this film already and found it guilty, your reading its obituary. Lets hope it doesn't have a partner in crime......A Sequel.
i will never shave my legs the same againthis movie takes new meaning to no skin off my backPancakes sounded like a good ideai ate some the next morning

reviews.review_title: Gory and funny in equal measure
reviews.content: (Major Spoilers)Some of the reviews I've read of this movie seem to be entirely missing the point. Sure, this movie is derivative (Evil Dead meets 28 Days Later meets Night of The Living Dead) and somewhat predictable (although anyone that says they were expecting the "Pancakes" scene is a damn liar), but so what? The whole horror genre is built on exploitation and homage. There are bad ways to do this (Darkness Falls) and interesting, creative ways to do this, like Cabin Fever. We have the requisite sex scene and shower scene, tons of gore,inbred locals and idiotic law enforcement- all you need for a horror movie! This movie revels in its indebtedness to other movies. It has a great sense of humor ("Don't sit next to Dennis", the hysterical "Pancakes" scene, the classic exchange of: "Why are you shooting squirrels?" "Because they're gay." and a bunch of other weird sight gags (like the Bunny) that show how much fun the filmmakers must have had making this. And that leg-shaving scene, OH MY GOD! Utterly classic. Plus, NOBODY WINS! That's right, they all die! How cool is that? More subtly, nobody actually dies from the so-called virus in this movie if you pay attention: all the deaths are attributable to the characters lack of moral fiber (the bum is set on fire, the first infected girl is dispatched with a shovel, etc. etc.) This movie is bound to be a cult classic and beats the pants off of the boring and predictable Freddy vs. Jason. See it!

I really wanted to like this. But it turned out to be too much of a wink-wink homage to some of the greats. If it's goal was to re-invent the genre, it didn't quite measure up. No wonder it took Roth so long to get this made. While I'm impressed that he did manage to get it completed and distributed, it's fairly easy to see where he went wrong. Roth seems to know the genre quite well, but he's not able to advance the genre. This was more of a gore film than a scary thriller. It's too bad Roth couldn't come up with an explanation of where the flesh-eating virus came from. And Paul having sex with Marcy? No... The wonderful Avie Verveen was very underused (though there wasn't much he could actually do). Any 'cabin in the woods' needs a plot device to disable the car. Here it was... WEAK! And a way to explain the gun. Here it was... WEAK! None of the characters were likable. Was happy when all of them died. Jordan Ladd was some nice eye candy, as was Cerina Vincent. DeBello's character was a one-note overdone awful character. Kern was simply there. And the 'nigger' joke at the end? Didn't add anything to the film. Other than that, i thought the technical aspects of the film were nicely done, but the film does nothing new for the horror genre, cause we've seen it elsewhere, done better.And a specially thanks to Eli Roth for not discussing the film-making proceess of 'Cabin Fever'.

reviews.review_title: One of the Worst Movies Ever!
reviews.content: I stand beside my opinion that "Cabin Fever" is by far one of the most horrible excuses for cinematic entertainment since "Plan 9 from Outer Space" or "Manos: The Hands of Fate". "Why?" your active little minds may ask. I have listed my reasons below and they are threefold (directly related to my rating, too!)Reason 1: The characters. Okay, I know this movie was never meant to be Oscar caliber or even "cult flick" caliber but come on! What were they thinking? If you're unsure of what I mean here, listen to the dialog (especially that of the stoner cop who goes on for 10 minutes about partying) and above all, be able to stop the gastric up-flow that may occur when you finish the flick!Reason 2: The camera-work.I could have filmed something better when I was in diapers. They must have handed the cam to some drunkard from Nova Scotia, 'cause the cinematography was cathartic, clumsy, and above all AWFUL!(note, this is my only praise for the film) Reason 3: The old man at the store.This cat was funny, not quite as much as the story itself, but entertaining nonetheless. He provided some much-needed comic relief which was really a shame because he was only at the beginning and end of the film. So there you have it! I don't care if I ever see this movie ever again but I might have to add it to my collection just for squirts and giggles.

What I loved about Cabin Fever is something many, some or few may have noticed, its utter disrespect for all of its characters. Of course, the characters in this trashy horror flick are cliche and lacking of depth and the movie begins the way a campy B-Horror flick would, but it is truly a fun ride if you aren't too shy to admit that gore and the death of some stereotypical characters are what they are---amusing. The cinematic style and the film's look on screen are also something to be admired. Don't get me wrong this film is not Oscar bound (maybe for make-up), neither is it an arthouse gem or even as serious and bold as 28 Days Later, but it is most definitely a Fun, Fun ride.  Take note, as with all fun rides  you may have to close your eyes or hold your stomach during some of the hills, twists and turns.  Enjoy!

This movie would have been worth the money and time if the audience were given some sort of remote device to pick what was going to happen next. Very easy to figure out. Too bad I can't demand my money back. Total waste.

reviews.review_title: Not Quite 'Last House...' But Up The Same Street...
reviews.content: It should be obvious to everyone by now that there hasn't been a gory, unabashed horror film for a long time. During the 80s, the 'Video Nasties' were on the rise, 'Evil Dead' and 'Last House on the Left' were all met with a icy reception from up-tight, Left-wing campaigners and consequently banned.Director/writer Eli Roth is obviously a big fan of these slasher flicks and he knows his horror films from the looks of his debut 'Cabin Fever'.Written back in 1995, Roth wanted this little number to hark back to the Dario Agento and early Wes Craven era and with due respect to the guy he's almost there.'Cabin Fever' tells the story of five college students who rent a cabin in the woods for a week (they should have turned back when they realised that said cabin passes quite a resemblance for the legendary 'Evil Dead' cabin, but hey... this is a horror film!) It's not long before the kids are getting themselves into trouble and building animosity between them and the local inbreds, but as all teenagers do they take the troubles in their stride.Although a log cabin in the woods of some out-of-the-way town might be an all too obvious setting for a horror film, it works well. Sometimes the clichés need to be there.Roth builds up a very comic script, which makes it a pleasure to watch during the beginning stages unlike a lot of other horror films that take so long for any action to start that by the time it does, you've lost all interest.'Cabin Fever' however takes you along with the gross-out gore and "crude" jokes and by the last fifteen minutes you kind of "get" what Roth is trying to achieve. While wanting to scare the pants off his audience and gross them out completely the guy wants to make us laugh as well. Whether or not the humour transpires to all people is obviously questionable, but on a minuscule budget of around $1,000,000 the film does very well.I love a low-budget horror, and these days it's hard to find one, but Cabin Fever (along with recent psycho hit Saw) is an example of how money can't buy you talent. Roth does more with 'Cabin Fever' and a million bucks than other directors can do with $30,000,000 and if you're a fan of 80s slasher flicks that this is a must. It might not measure up to 'Last House' and 'Texas Chainsaw Massacre', but in this day and age, it comes pretty damn close.

reviews.review_title: Original, but not a good film
reviews.content: Cabin Fever has got something good going for it. It has an original story of horror, not with a human being the killer/villain, but a deadly disease. A bunch of college friends go camping in the woods where one by one they are infected with a disease that causes their bodies to rot and burn. The movie is pretty gory, but not much. It has good performances from its cast. The biggest problem with the movie is that it is way too cheesy and comedic. Horror films these days try to mix horror and comedy and it just does not work. The sets and some of the characters make me laugh rather than scare me. I didn't like the ending and hope there won't be a sequel. Eli Roth you can surely do better. Cabin was a good attempt, but not good enough.

reviews.review_title: Funny, But Not At All Scary
reviews.content: I'm not sure what sort of drugs and/or alcohol the person who typed up the review for this movie was on, but please, for the sake of American's everywhere, don't listen to them. This movie was not scary, at all, in any way. It was actually quite funny. They got the suspenseful music down, and stuff like that, but overall, it just made me roll on the ground with laughter. Pancakes! Other than Rider Strong (Sean Hunter from "Boy Meets World") the acting was atrocious. Definitely worth 50 cents tops, but no more of your money should be poured into this comedy-posing-as-a-horror film. If you are in the mood for a decent horror movie, then check out Texas Chainsaw Massacre, House Of 1000 Corpses, or The Devil's Rejects.

I want to sue Eli Roth for the 95 minutes of my life he cheated me out of. Points that need addressing:1. Where is the explanation of where the virus came from?2. Why were other people not effected by virus. Don't they drink or use water?3. Why when the blonde tart first contracts the virus did they not walk to the neighbours house with her. She could still walk4. Why the hell am I bothering to discuss this film any further?One good thing I noticed, several songs taken from 'The Last House On The Left' which is and always will be a PROPER horror film.

I'm usually in to most kinds of movies.  Having lived with a film student, I have seen lots of movies, and can usually understand what the meaning of each one is, even if it's a little off kilter.  But this was the first movie in a long time I felt robbed of time, could not make rhyme or reason of, and want my eight bucks back.WARNING SPOILERS BELOWWhen you think of good horror, I usually think of ghosts, beings, entities, monsters, beasts, killers, things like that.  But I don't know, something about a CONTAMINATED WATER SUPPLY didn't really qualify as a good basis for a good horror flick to me.Not to mention all the ridiculous sub-plots that ALL felt tacked on. Like Paul liking Karen since eighth grade.  They kiss, and then nothing else happens, she immediately goes for the guy showing up with the weed, which also never goes anywhere.  They go to the house and find the diseased man's name was 'henry', and you'd think they're going to solve some sort of mystery, only they never mention it again.  And then a dog(?) shows up and kills people.  Do they ever what's the matter with the dog.  Winston the police officer made NO sense.  And then after the ending, I felt like the whole movie was an excuse to use the 'shotgun for the n-word' joke.All in all, the whole thing was a disaster.  The dialogue was terrible, their sudden irrational fears of a disease that may or may not have existed to their knowledge yet.  Think about it, a guy comes and asks for help. Would your first reaction seriously be, "keep him away, he may have a disease'?  And then hit him with a bat to get him away.  Absurd.  I just didn't understand what this film was trying to accomplish, other than possibly being an allegory for AIDS, but that comes over 10 years too late.Save some money, don't see it.

I love horror and Gory movies. But this one was awfull. I can't beleive I wasted my Saturday night and my money on this Crap. No time in this movie did it ever make sense. Where did the sickness originate from, Grim, WHY? No cure, no explanation, nothing. I almost fell asleep, But then, It get's good. YEAH RIGHT. It starts to get going then it just stops. What a waste of time. The movie "They", and "Battlefield Earth" are like Best Picture nomanies compared to this. I HATE IT. I want my 2 hours back.

This was possibly one of the worst horror flicks I have seen in years. I tried to enjoy it on every level possible; serious, comedic, even on a B movie level. Guess what? It is a terrible movie, if I could get my 8.50 back I would. A sterotypical movie about 5 unrealistic and stupid teenagers renting a cabin in the woods. They have just graduated from college (why is it Fall then?) and they are out in the middle of no-where (I know that because their is lots of rednecks around). A guy vomiting blood and has skin falling off him shows up and they proceed to shoot/beat him away (they also shot and beat up their own truck, stranding them) he goes off and dies but they now have the virus. They all die one by one, and lots of people show up in between deaths just to confuse you. The ending is terrible and any attempt at humor fails miserably. Let me put it this way to you, I have never written a review on a web site for a movie before. This movie was so terrible I was compelled to warn others! Take your 5 bucks and spend it on crack before watching this movie.

Friends graduate from college and go to the woods to drink do drugs and have sex to celebrate.  Then a mysterious hermit comes out of the woods with a disease that affects everyone in the group then the town.This is not worth the money.  The acting was poorly, poooooooorly done. There were sub characters in this movie that just didn't belong and acted that way.  Then for some unforeseen reasons they paste on situations instead of taking care of the main problem.  I spent most of this movie laughing at it instead of being shocked or frightened.  If I wasn't on a date I would have walked out.  The ending and most of the last half of the movie is extremely predictable.  Save your time and your money.

reviews.review_title: Buckets and Buckets of Blood, and Few Laughs
reviews.content: Saw "Cabin Fever" last night.In "Narc" there was a better example of a head being blown off with a shotgun. In "Underworld" and "Ghost Ship" we saw heads cut in half with the upper part sliding off - more interesting than horrifying, actually. In "Blade II" I saw actor Ron Perlman, the current "Hellboy", cut in two from crotch to scalp with both halves falling to either side.When you've seen that, where else do you go? Do the non-CG FX and buckets of Karo syrup and red dye in "Cabin Fever" shock me? Hardly. And director/writer Eli Roth surely is obsessed with blood, and more and more blood.So, it was not really horrifying, although it was somewhat gruesome and very gross. The idea of a skin-eating disease randomly and unexpectedly striking down people, who then begin and inexorable slide into blood and decay, is not that scary. Scary means somebody - some maniac - out to get you and you never know when he will.So, did I like it? 2 1/2 stars out of 4. If you see the DVD check director Roth's sanguinary claymations - "Rotten Fruit", which are also steeped in blood. It was worth a rental.I should add the lemonade scene at the end of "Cabin Fever" was pretty good. By then Roth and everyone was having a good laugh, which is fine and entertaining, but also tells me no one walked out "horrified".

The only thing I would have to say about this flick is that I am glad Dish Network gave me a coupon for a free pay-per-view movie so I didn't technically waste any money on this piece-o-crap of a movie.My wife and I sat their and just looked at each other with that deer in headlights on some parts of this movie.  Not to spoil anything that is already spoiled about this flick...but all I can remember about this flick is looking at the clock wondering when it was going to get better or end.I am a big fan of horror movies and love the evil dead series and understand that this was suppose to be funny...but it wasn't even that...

reviews.review_title: This movie was WRONG on so many levels! *spoilers*
reviews.content: My husband and I are avid horror fans so we were excited to get the movie started. Sadly we new it was going to be a flop after the first 5 minutes. 1st: The acting left little to the imagination, the only exception was Ryder Strong. He did better than the rest. 2nd: I don't know where the heck the virus originated from or what it was. 3rd: Who in the world would climb down a rotten latter to poke a dead body with a stick??? 4th: WHAT THE HECK WAS IN THE KIT??? Thats really all I have to say about this movie other than every other word was the "f" word.  I am not offended hearing it in movies but geez they got a little carried away with it in this one.  I would have to say I enjoyed Freddy VS Jason more than this flick, even though it was utterly predictable!LOL

reviews.review_title: What a Sorry Excuse for a Movie!
reviews.content: REGARDLESS of the comments of people here who assert that this sorry excuse for a movie has ANY virtue, it does NOT. What an absolute waste of my time and my host's money. This was a pathetic effort on the part of all people involved on this belabored piece of crap. There ARE, however, two "pluses". The old storekeeper dude is cute as hell, but delivers his lines as if they were yesterday's stale fish. The "let me shave my legs in the tub before I die" scene is absolutely stomach-churning. Why doesn't she wince as she drags the razor across those fresh pustules? I am not a rifle expert, but the kids seem to come up with three different weapons. How could the "cop" ride a BICYCLE out into the woods, if the main characters couldn't seem to walk out themselves? SAVE YOUR MONEY! I went to see this thing because the Greensboro News and Record "hyped" it, and it was filmed in this general area. What an embarrassment to the North Carolina film "industry".

I watched this pointless, tediously narrated movie with growing restlessness. Has some ideas and bursts with ambition, as it tries to deliver characters and relationships(rarely seen in a horror/gore - flick), but drowns them in trash and subterranean execution. The whole mullet kid/making fun of hillbillies part is totally cliché, the horror story gathering momentum is just uninteresting and without suspense or even shock. The rudimentary love story was completely useless and ineffective, as was the hermit with his dog, the young cop etc...What did the writer/director think when he made up the local residents around the lake. What was the point in finding out who the hermit was? Or what about the pig slaughtering lady? No point in that! This movie leaves so many loose ends, as it leads to nowhere. You get quite some story fragments, none of which are developed/used/revisited throughout the movie. It's just linear/twist - less narration. All the time you exactly know what is going to happen next... The ending tries to be pessimistic 70ies horror with a cynical/humorous edge (which before dragged through the entire movie).The only wish that rose in me watching this was to see everyone die so it can end...

reviews.review_title: This is the WORST horror flic ever made!!!!!
reviews.content: This is the WORST horror film ever made!!!! I love horror films, but this is the worst I have ever seen!It is a poor excuse for a horror film, the acting is non-existant and it's just a gore fest.

reviews.review_title: This is a pretty good horror movie...to say the least.
reviews.content: Horror is subjective. Some people like jump scares, some people like building tension, some people like slasher films, some people like vampire. You get my point, and if this doesn't illustrate it perfectly, my stepbrother likes jump scares and while I like gore, I prefer the thinking-man's eerie kinda horror movie. Hence he prefers Feardotcom to The Ring, and I chastise him about it. And he doesn't care, he hates the Ring but loves Feardotcom, it's his kind of horror.Cabin Fever is for horror fans who like the fact that not all of them take themselves seriously. The Evil Dead is in my opinion of the twenty greatest horror movies ever made...and it's hilarious. Dead/Alive also. You get what I'm saying. Cabin Fever is of that mode, not particularly being SCARY in a traditional sense, but gory as all get out (on a budget of 1.5 million, no less) and funny. If you watch Cabin Fever thinking it is going to resurrect horror, then you would be wrong. What it did was begin the writing/directing career of Eli Roth, who is one of the people resurrecting horror. This was the predecessor to Hostel, which is brilliance in horror. Interesting enough, I still like this more. Can't wait to see what he does with Cell.

Simply put, one of the worst horror films I've seen in a very long time. Characters are beyond stupid and the humor falls totally flat. This tries to be a homage to the classic horror flicks of the 70's and early 80's such as TEXAS CHAINSAW MASSACRE and EVIL DEAD but unlike those great films there is no intensity, no characters we give a damn about and worst of all no scares. Not even one. Yes there is gore and a few fairly gruesome moments but it is nowhere near as bloody as the films most hardcore horror fans have seen. Director Eli Roth recently did an interview where he totally trashed the fairly recent WRONG TURN. WRONG TURN was miles ahead of CABIN FEVER however. It actually had some intensity and halfway decent acting. On a scale of 1 to 10 CABIN FEVER gets a 2 from me.

reviews.review_title: not the kind of disease you wanna have...
reviews.content: well well my friends... from my point of view we have a funny entertainer movie for your Saturday evening... don't worry, it won't make you throw up the dinner, although it'll make you think that drinking that river's water the next time you go summer camping can be quite a risky thing... hum... actually this movie seemed like a modern remake of evil dead 1... common, 5 guys, two couples, a psycho friend, a caban... well, similarities don't lack here, but we're dealing with other demons called bacteria... anyway, the story develops quite OK and it has its science... although i think that the deaths due to the infection are quite fast... and why all these strange phenomena always happen on the most isolated places in the USA where you can only find weirdos??? i've never been in the states, but people, tell me, are people from remote zones like that??? oh man oh man oh man... what about Winston, the cop??? damn it, he made more crack that gg Allin!!! :O what the hell is that guy doing on the movie??? i can't understand him!!! it's not that he didn't make me laugh, but man, that's a freaky-crazy character!!! the film's last minutes are quite OK and the death of the only non-infected of the group is really one of those stupid things you'll remember for some time... eheh, i must laugh, the film is comic... and the killing spree of the 3village weirdos is a great scene man!!! hammer, shotgun and screwdriver!!! oh man, i love gore stuff!!! ahah!!! by the way, what the hell was the screw-driver butcher guy role on all this thing??? what a freak!!! if you're looking for easy entertainment without scary scenes but with blood this is your movie... gets 6 out of 10 cause i see it as a good average entertainment film... ah!!! the girls are quite OK, specially the brunette one... ;)

This movie was beyond gross. I can handle some levels of gross, but this had some truly disturbing parts. It left images in my head that pop up out of nowhere and creep me out. I gave this movie a 5 out of 10 because the plot wasn't even that substantial. I wasn't impressed enough for the grossness to be worth it.
Simple and entertaining, Cabin Fever is a fun throw back to the days of classic horror pictures. The plot flowed smoothly and followed a logical premise. Nice 90 minutes of cinematic indulgence.

reviews.review_title: With 20 miutes to go in the movie, I was laughing out loud at how bad it was...
reviews.content: This was advertised as a thriller/horror film and I am always game for a movie like that.  I don't care what it was supposed to be, it was a miserable pile of crap.  There was no character development and even fewer scares.  If I ever went camping with friends like that, I would expect nothing less than to end up dead in the woods.  Forget the unbelievability of the movie, the thrills and chills were just not there.  I don't know what the makers of the movie were trying to accomplish, but they have me completely amazed that I actually spent money to watch this filth.

I was very excited to see the preview for this movie when I went to see 28 Days Later. It seems as if the return of low budget horror/gore films is finally here. Although I was extremely disappointed with House of 1000 Corpses, the fact that I was able to see it in the theater was a plus... Lions Gate Films should be commended. Then I got to see 28 Days Later in the theater... a zombie movie!!! And after reading about Cabin Fever in Fangoria for a while I now got to see that... again, thanks to Lions Gate. Unfortunately, I was pretty disappointed with the movie. I guess I was expected some zombie carnage or something... there was none. I was expecting a certain visceral thrill, Evil Dead style... not there either. The film is about a virus that eats it's victims flesh... and that's the only flesh eating... no gut munching zombies or demons. It also takes quite a while before the virus starts to spread to really pick up the pace. This being said, the film does have it's positive points: a decent sense of humor and some great make-up effects, and when the final victim learns he has the disease he gets pretty violent. I might have to view it a second time to appreciate it more now that I know it's not the ultra-violent splatter-fest I thought it would be (I mean it is only rated R). So while Cabin Fever isn't quite up to films like The Evil Dead, The Texas Chainsaw Massacre, or even the excellent 28 Days Later, it's certainly better the House of 1000 Corpses and more importantly it's a step in the right direction... back to the hey-day of gore MAKE-UP EFFECTS and not crappy, cartoonish, and cold CGI. Hopefully, one day we will see the return of the Unrated horror film to the theaters... like The Evil Dead, Dawn of the Dead, and Day of the Dead in their days... HEY... GEORGE ROMERO... YOU GOT THAT? GIVE US TWILIGHT OF THE DEAD... UNRATED!

Eli Roth didn't wait for opportunity to knock... instead he kicked in the door and sent splinters flying everywhere! This is his calling card and many of the elements seen in his later films have been established here. 1) Good looking thespians with little or no range 2) Ultra violence mixed with college boy frat humor 3) Tarantino-esqe cultdom 4) Gruesome violence and subjects not handled as deeply as they could be exploredbut here is how Roth uses all of those elements to his advantage and creates a unique experience.1) Jordan Ladd (underused since Gregg Araki's Nowhere) has built up a nice IMDb resume since appearing in this flick and is destined to become a cult icon in the same circle of Tarantino/ Rodriguez/ Roth circles. Rider Strong found life beyond Boy Meets World where later in the show they started exploring his character's darker side, and this was his spring board for meatier roles in Tooth & Nail and Borderland, 2 interesting genre submissions. Cerina Vincent beyond being eye candy has the strongest pressence in this film and is actually the film's femme fatale leading to the demise of 2 male characters eventually leading to her own demise in the film's most explicit scene. How come she is not offered more roles is a head scratcher 2) Gore porn is handled in a more dramatic way in some of the Splat Pack's films (High Tension, Devil's Rejects) but Roth handles his in a dark comedy fashion that it is not tended to be taken serioulsy rather the humor is numbing the already numb vision that has been seen. Look at this film, Hostel I and II, and Thanksgiving trailer (his most accomplished and critic-fav submission) 3) The fact that he knows that he is not the greatest actor aside, he is actually not annoying when he appears in his films unlike the fore-mentioned director. In fact he becomes the most welcomed director cameo since Hitchcock. And he has actual acting chops seen in Death Proof and Inglorious Basterds 4) Flesh eating diseases and tourist killings can be intriguing documentaries but in Roth's hands it is nothing more than the McGuffin for the ensuing violence. And besides, isn't fact always more frightening than fiction? Who's to say that what has been depicted in his films haven't' already been done in real life? Plus Roth brings back the frightening and haunting horrific images that once embedded itself in the subconscious of minds from the '70's/ '80's horror flicks. Roth is bringing it back and this was the original spring board but be prepared to be divided; either you're on this side of the fence or the other. There is no middle ground

This is one of the worst movies I have ever seen!  It almost seemed like a knockoff of Texas Chainsaw Massacre.  A bunch of teens are driving to a house (log cabin in this circumstance), are having a good time.  Then they get stranded, and everywhere they turn for help they find nut cases.
Worst movie ever!  Don't buy or rent it.

I am really aggravated by the stupidity of the user comment reviews.  Cabin Fever was a horror movie not a comedy.  There were some laugh out loud comedy moments, but I am bewildered why this is a complaint against the movie.  It's almost like "I would have liked it more if i hadn't have laughed."  Unless you were laughing because the flick was accidentally funny, but it wasn't, every laugh was intentionally put in.I enjoyed the virus as sort of a monster as opposed to something tangible and ultimately able to be killed. The five main characters were all realistic, and four out of the five were like-able.  The townspeople were highly amusing as well, the best being the Santa look alike at the local general store.  Give him his own t.v.show. Overall there is not much to review about this movie, except for that its amusing, fun, and executed very well.  Go see it if you haven't and ignore these bizarre negative reviews. I don't think people know what they want from a movie, except for to be able to complain about it later.

Cabin Fever is 1/3 away from being a pretty decent film.  It is a horror/comedy about a group of friends who go to a cabin on a weekend get-away.  They encounter a strange virus that drives them to test the limits of their trust and friendship.  It starts off promising and even grabs your attention throughout but the ending is something left to be desired even though it leaves it open to a sequel (either theatrical or direct to video).  Good special effects and makeup work capped off by decent direction.  The acting is pretty good by horror film standards.  I expect to hear good things from Eli Roth in the future.    6/10  (In the collection DVD)Peace..Buggieblade

I write reviews under the nickname of Gorehound-1, but I also write reviews under the nickname of ~PL~. My reviews, as Gorehound-1, are there to give hints to gore fans, to help them in their choices for viewing or buying a gore movie. I advise you that I am a very strong stomach, and it's almost impossible to gross me out. My ratings are a mark between 0 and 10 for the gore (its quality and amount), the violence, the sadism, and the brutality.(Spoilers warning)Gore quality 3/10: Alright, the scene with the dog split in half could have been nice, if we actually saw it long enough instead of moving the camera to the actor's face and just showing an ugly little chunk of blood sprayed on his face...the prosthetics are pretty fake looking (the girl with her jaw exposed is awful), and even the gun shot wounds are not convincing. 
Gore amount 4/10: What have we got here?  A dog being split in half (much of it is not seen), a man being shot repeatedly (with some of the most amateurish looking bullet effects), a man shot with a shotgun, people vomiting some blood, bruises and scars due to infection on people's skin, a woman shaving her legs and removing some skin from her leg (looks fake and bad, no skin seems to be peeled off), an afterview of a girl that's been eaten by a dog (we see pools of blood and a severed foot, WOW), some pork intestines, a deer being hit by a car (some blood once again), and other moments where we can see blood on people, with no apparent wounds. 
Violence 6/10: People are shot, killed with a shovel, burned, hit, etc.Sadism 0/10: None.Brutality 4/10: The shovel scene...that's about it.Gore film to rent 4/10:  Eli Roth has a big mouth...he said he couldn't believe his film was able to get an R rating instead of an NC-17 rating because it was extremely violent and gory, and gnah, gnah, gnah...Well, Mr.Roth, you know what?  Your film is not gory at all, and the few gore scenes that are actually in it plain suck!  Congratulations, so, that's what you call a film with "juicy, bloody red meat"???  Well, maybe you should watch something else than American main stream horror movies, because "Cabin Fever" is NOTHING compared to any German hardcore horror film...hardcore horror?  That's probably not a notion you know...Anyways, very few gore...Gore film to buy 2/10:  As a horror film, this is entertaining and it does set a good atmosphere and everything...but here, we're talking about gore...and gore it lacks...a lot...MPAA says: Rated R for strong violence and gore, sexuality, language, and brief drug use.GH1 says: should be rated R for violence/gore, sexual content, language and rief drug use.

Please, please, please DO NOT waste your time or money on this movie. Having been an avid movie fan for many years, I have NEVER walked out of the cinema during any movie.. except this one!The acting was so bad I couldn't even laugh at it, the characters were bland, dull and pathetic creatures, hey, if they had of been killed off in the first half hour the film would have dramatically improved in my book. How many times did they have to swear?  If its required fair enough!! But EVERY sentence?I have no idea how this got any positive reviews whatsoever, it is the worst film I have seen since Monkeybone (remember that one?).  I gave up after 35 minutes, I honestly couldn't take any more, so do yourself a favor, don't waste your time!

reviews.review_title: Didn't they know? Didn't they know how bad it was?
reviews.content: Greetings all, I've just watched Cabin Fever, over a few drinks. I've arrived at the conclusion that these people - the producer, for one, as well as the writer, the director, and the poor, poor players, simply didn't know how /bad/ the film was. Brought on by heady mix of alcohol and indignation, the red mist has set upon me and I have been filled with the angry motivation to make a comment here on the IMDb. Perhaps a few unsuspecting souls might be saved; you never know. If in doubt - if you take nothing else away from this - don't rent the movie. Don't buy it. If you can see it somehow without paying a penny for it; take the time to watch it, if only as a lesson in /how not to make a horror film/. Ensure a sufficient supply of Jack Daniels. Ice is optional.Dear gawd, ladies and gentlemen; as a film lover I am disgusted, and as a human being I feel more than a little insulted. We paid for this, my friends and I; we paid good, honest money, and what did we receive for all of our hard-earned moolah? Tripe. Silly, insulting tripe. Quite /how/ this messy, incoherent, creatively-bereft script made it all the way to film - and then to the box office - escapes me. Somehow, somewhere, a couple of years ago, legions of /fabulous/ people celebrated this travesty. I can see them now, clinking their plastic cups of cheap champagne; well-fed men in all-too-tight t-shirts, men with unkempt beards and expensive shoes, men with caustic accents, second-hand German cars and third-hand German wives. You can see them too; just close your eyes and visualize, kids. They must have known. To make it this far in the business, they must have known, all of them; the story was entirely without merit. A couple of nice, cheap jokes were thrown in there - but the comedic elements serve only as a distraction - and an obvious distraction at that - from the story's overall lack of substance. Watch the film; nothing much /actually happens/.Nothing. Throw a handful of tired clichés into a grinder, add a few jokes (which knock the viewer /very quickly/ out of any suspension-of-disbelief), and cringingly poor dialogue as seasoning, and there you have it. Cabin Fever. Oh, don't forget to add a few bulbous, porcelain breasts; let's face it, it's a genré movie, right? That's the excuse, right? That's how it has /always/ been done, right?The actors - and, gawd help them, it was hardly their fault - must have been rendered unemployable by the film; but don't blame them. They didn't have much to work with, the poor, beautiful, deluded fools.As someone who enjoys film and the process of film-making, I would /love/ to know the whole story behind Cabin Fever. Perhaps the original screenplay was pretty good, but it suffered the death-of-the-thousand-rewrites; that's certainly how it feels. Perhaps the director was changed halfway through. Who knows?Discuss!Alright, the drink has caught up with me; sorry. Leave this film well alone. Thank you; apologies for the tirade. This rant is over.

reviews.review_title: Not scary enough, funny enough, or weird enough
reviews.content:
Cabin Fever just tries to be too many things.  I thought first and foremost, it would be a horror film.  Well, it's not really.  It is, but it's just not scary.  In order to be scared for victims, the viewer has to empathize with them.  How can you feel empathy for characters as cliche as the friends since childhood who secretly pine for each other, the sleazy couple who just wants to have sex, or the frat boy-esque party animal (who surprisingly enough, comes the closest of the whole bunch to being a sympathetic character).Empathy doesn't really matter if you just make a splatter film where the payoff is watching everyone get killed.  Cabin Fever, however, asks us to care about the moral indiscretion and suffering of these people.  That's something you need empathy for.  If I don't care what happens to the characters, it really doesn't matter what kind of situation you put them in. The film fails to scare because I really don't care what happens to these people.  I don't feel as if I know or even like them.  This problem is exacerbated by the complete idiocy of the characters.  If a plague is infecting your cabin and your friends are dying, you don't just try to find neighbors and go back home when you don't find a phone...you get on that road and start walking, even if it's 30 miles to the next town.  If you pay attention, too many days pass for these people to be stuck.  Which brings me to another question:  where exactly are they where nobody has a telephone? Are they even in America?  We need a much more plausible explanation for why they are stranded.Another place the film fall short is on something I will call "weirdness." As a David Lynch fan, I was expecting a certain degree of artistic vision from a director who worked with him.  Indeed, Cabin Fever does have certain elements that feel Lynch inspired.  The trouble is, they feel completely forced and done for absolutely no reason other than just for the sake of doing them.  These moments of "weirdness" do not have to advance the story or even make sense.  They should, however, at least be appropriate for the scene where they are taking place and not just completely out of context. 
For the good news, Cabin Fever does have some well written dialogue, and most of the actors do the best they can with the lousy story they were handed.  This at least makes the movie watchable, but can not save it from failing overall.Cabin Fever tries to be too many things and as a result fails at all of them.  Not scary enough to be horror, not disturbing enough to be creepy, not funny enough for comedy, and not artistic enough to be art.  The best thing Cabin Fever offers is decent dumb fun good for a single viewing on a late night rental.  Though with 28 Days Later out there, I can't imagine why anyone would bother.

Okay, so the plot was kind of contrived.  It still was somewhat reminiscent of the tension that built up so much in The Thing under similar, yet completely different, circumstances.  The acting was nowhere as bad as other reviewers here would lead you to believe.  In fairness to the young actors, none of them were really given a lot of opportunity to do more than just regurgitate at various intervals.  The concept behind Cabin Fever was an interesting one. 
Potential Spoilers Ahead:Still a faceless killer at work, as is the staple of most "teens in peril" films but, this time, the killer is a disease, not a maniac.  How the disease came to be initially was, to me, of no concern (unlike a few of the other reviewers here).  Were I to have been one of the teens in the cabin, it would not have mattered to me in the least how the disease came to be, only that I not be unlucky enough to contract it.  Had this information been something that, if learned, would've made any kind of a difference, it'd be another story.  But that was surely not the case here.The gore, for the most part, was more of the slimy and gooey variety.  Not nearly as bloody as a lot of the slasher films that have been made, to be truthful.  But there was enough of it to catagorize the disease itself as something more than just the common cold!  I could've done without a lot of the peripheral characters;  none of which came across as anything more than just extras with speaking parts.  The ending was less than I thought this movie deserved, as well.  Though I understand that they had to tie up the loose ends somehow, it still seemed as if they could've put a lot more thought into it.  Personally, I would've had the final character escape and go back home, believing himself to have cheated death, so to speak, only to cough up the tiniest trace of blood and let the movie close with the look in his eyes as he realizes that he hadn't gotten away, after all.  To me, that would've been a more fitting end but, all in all, Cabin Fever does, indeed, deliver the goods.  It may not be up there with some of horror's classics, but it does hit all the right notes at the right times.

reviews.review_title: Starts slow but makes a big comeback to win it all
reviews.content: You start watching CABIN FEVER and you're like, "What the...this movie sucks!" But then you keep watching and a chick gets torn to shreds by a dog. A dude gets a screwdriver shoved into his brain. And you think, "Hey! A real horror movie!"When the movie first begins, you think it looks pretty promising. Something about the opening credits has sort of a 70's horror film style to it and you think it might be going somewhere good. But then you see the stupid teenagers (including Shawn from BOY MEETS WORLD, God forbid) and you're thinking, "Oh great, here we go." And for a while, it really does seem to be going there. The teenagers are unbelievably annoying, they do unbelievably cliché things, and you want them to be killed in unbelievably painful ways.Now, see, this is where most horror movies would fail. We know that, certainly, the teenagers will be dispatched with in various creative ways. But in most cases, the camera shies away from the carnage and what you've got is a boring, annoying movie. But CABIN FEVER does not shy away. It is surprisingly brutal for a film made in 2003 that was actually shown in theaters. Yes, the dialogue will have you wanting to throw up and the over-acting will have you rolling your eyes, but when it is time to kill off the teens, its serious business.You've got people throwing up blood all over the place; you've got guys getting set on fire; you've got the flesh rotting off people's faces while they're still alive; and you've got the aforementioned creative use of a screw driver and some mean dogs. This movie really does come right at you and earns your respect that it originally did not have.Eli Roth directed this picture and he hasn't done anything of any particular note prior to this, but it is clear he knows where he's going. There are many plot points presented that you are fully expecting not to be tied up. But surprisingly, he nails down (with really sharp nails and a big sledge hammer) every single one of them by the end. It's because of this the movie seems to go on forever, even though it has merely a 90-minute runtime. But I mean that in a good (RETURN OF THE KING) way.And you know what? The ending is great. I don't often say that about horror movies, but this one has several payoffs that are very clever and quite funny, actually. It shows simultaneously how fair and yet brutal this film is. No doubt there's a lot of camp. But if you miss the days of horror movies that went straight for the throat, check this one out. It's worth a rent. *** stars (out of ****)

reviews.review_title: Think: Tobe Hooper Meets the Lynch Man
reviews.content: This is what happens when an inexperienced film maker with a genuine passion for the horror genre is let loose with a camera.Cabin Fever has some interesting ideas let down badly by poor direction and acting.  Any tension is scuppered by the hadhoc way so many characters are introduced and despatched for no or little reason.For secluded woods, there were more people walking around than Picadilly Circus at the height of the tourist season.  I found myself exasperated at the nth appearance of yet another new character only for them to disappear again.Affectionate nods were made to all our favourite 70's and 80's horror movies: The Thing; Night of the Living Dead; The Evil Dead; The Andromeda Strain; Texas Chainsaw Massacre with liberal doses of Deliverance and Twin Peaks thrown in.And here lies the problem.  The un-selfconscious way he introduces these tokens to other movies is admirable and shows the promise of a great and subtle director of the genre.  However, it also shows how poor Roth's movie is in comparison to these seminal greats.Where the movie works best is when he is in David Lynch mode and the characters in and around the shop are working at full throttle.  Here, Roth gives a genuinely disturbing and very funny character studies of the secluded mountain folk.With more focus and discipline in the direction, this could have been a great movie.  Instead, it only shows promise of a director with a genuine passion of horror films who wants to break free from the shackles of 90's horror parodies such as Scream.  And this is not a bad thing.

reviews.review_title: Cheap but effective. Everything that makes a cult classic.
reviews.content: From the very start, 'Cabin Fever' promises to be a formulaic horror film for moviegoers that like to be surprised, but not too surprised. No attempt was made to identify the main characters, five young adults celebrating the close of their college career. All of the characters are exactly what they appear to be, with very few exceptions. The title spells out the premise pretty well. These five young adults rent a cabin and run into a diseased man from the woods. The double entendre serves the film well, as the plot is the film's greatest asset. It deals with Xenophobia on many levels. The unique angle is that the real scare revolves around what it would be like to be the subject of xenophobia, especially if the people who were afraid of you were people you needed if you were going to survive. The illness serves up plenty of gore. The actors believably communicate the fear of being fatally ill. Less believable, but still effective, is their portayal of people who want to avoid getting ill at any cost. All I will say is this: Cabin Fever, catch it!

Cabin Fever wasn't at all what I expected based on the title. I thought it would be a slasher movie. I would have rated this movie higher if it didn't go overkill on the gore. Movie has sort of a nostalgic feel to it. Especially when the movie sets up the story. It has a 70's exploitation flick feel to it including the gore. Not a slasher flick at all. The water is tainted with a nasty bacteria. Anyone that comes in contact with it winds up losing their skin literally. They also spit up blood which can infect more people. Very well done movie even with the gore factor. I'm not sure I like the set up for a sequel though. You see a lot of people get killed by this stuff and no one really understands what caused this so you get the idea that there may be plans for another movie.

reviews.review_title: Can We Spell LAME?...all together now...LAME!!
reviews.content: The first thing you notice about this movie is its similarity to Heather Donahue in the Blair Witch Project...every other word is F***...brilliant script there.Several teens go into the backwoods to party in a cabin and right from the get-go, there are blatant warning signs that would have had me considering Disneyland instead of roughing it.The old guy in the store is weird, they got a kid right in front of Ye Olde General Store that comes across as a bit carnivorous, and a genuine hayseed deputy who looks and acts like he's still in 7th grade?I look for even the slightest speck of realism in any film and this movie has none!  In my book, when someone asks for medical help, it is not customary to shoot them.When you discover that you are the last one alive in your group, it is not customary to shriek to the heaven's "I made it" until Cousin Hirem and Cousin Jethro conclude that they missed one and decide to solve that problem.The plot was pretty well non-existent, fragmented and some scenes seemed to have been cut, copied and pasted from other movies.Old re-runs of The Beverley Hillbillies are more entertaining than this loser.  Don't waste your money.

reviews.review_title: Not as good or as bad as I thought...
reviews.content: After reading other reviews I both expected this movie to either be great or aweful.  I went out and bought it today on DVD and after watching it I would say it is neither.  I like the homage to older, classic horror films, but the acting wasn't the greatest and the plot seemed pretty diluted.  It did keep my attention and I did enjoy it.  The gore was pretty well done and there were some pretty funny part.  Overall, I would say the movie didn't ever really scare me or convince me very thoroughly of the reason why I should care about the characters or their plight.  6-7 out of 10 for gore and homage to classics.

Me and a few friends decided to go see this movie a couple nights ago, thinking it would be another stupid teenage horror flick.  I figured we would all walk out of the movie afterwards commenting about how much the movie sucked and dogging on me for suggesting we see it.  Boy was I wrong, this movie kicked ass.  This is one of those movies that is so delightfully cheesy, gory, and odd that you just have to laugh and groan along with it. Just when you think the movie is starting to go into standard horror movie plot mode, some odd character will show up out of the blue or some odd event will happen to keeps things quirky and fresh.You may enjoy this movie more if you are older and have a more cynical view of the blissful ignorance we all had when we were young.  The end result of the budding romance was priceless yet so screwed up, especially with that dream sequence at the end that goes from happy times through a soft filter lense to the stark end result.You also have to love the way the movie has all the elements of the old horror flicks: gore, violence, nudity, strong language, adult situations, etc., that the more recent teen horror flicks have been whitewashed of. Definitly not a movie for the little ones, but a refreshing reminder of the dorky ways of one's youth where my friends would be too embarrassed to rent a straight up sex flick so we would rent horror flicks instead just to see the brief shots of naked chicks, though we would never admit it.  It's amazing we didn't turn out more screwed up that we did, now that I think about it.So many delightfully odd characters in this movie too, with Dennis obviously stealing the show.  Hell, any movie that has a kid with a mullet and a penchant for bitting and kung fu is a winner in my book.  The big redneck with the little box was also great, you have to love characters that just make you scratch your head.All in all, a good flick for those of you that like a good tongue-in-cheek horror flick with odd characters.  One of those movies best watched with friends, making smartass quips at the screen that only your friends would find funny.

reviews.review_title: This movie is worth calling Amnesty International for cruel abuse of the viewer.
reviews.content: -> teens decide to rent a cabin in a forest -> a man is infected by a mysterious virus -> man infects teen -> teen infects teen2 -> teen2 infects strange man -> strange man infects his dog (?) -> teen3 is infected, because man with mysterious virus fell into a water reservoir -> teen3 infects teen4 -> teen4 infects teen5 -> everybody is dead -> viewer survived movie (surprising but true!)I don't know who made this movie and to be honest I don't want to know, because I truly regret viewing this flick ... please oh god make me forget this awful flick :[ Go watch The Ring if you want a good thriller/horror which is not horribly bad.

Eli Roth promised he would bring back the good days of horror with Cabin Fever, promising lots of gore and nudity, in his mind, this is what horror should be all about.The premise of a flesh eating virus being the danger, rather than some masked chainsaw wielding nutter is a good one, and, for the most part, is used effectively enough.The introduction is standard stuff - a bunch of horny teenagers head to a remote cabin to drink beers, smoke weed and have sex. Blah Blah. The origin of the flesh eating virus is never revealed - we just see a hermit staggering through the woods with his face hanging off, but its no biggie. When the film gets rolling though, the infection of our teenage buddies is gradual, creepy and effective. The acting is convincing enough on the most part, however aside from Rider Strong, the male roles come across as rather untrained, nervy performances.But hey, since when have kids in horror movies been good actors right? Roth's script is good enough for its type 99% of the time, but there are some silly lines, and daft unnecessary events that take away from the movie big time. The 'Police Officer' with the persona of a 17 year old party obsessive is beyond stupid, and could have been played way more effectively as a suspicious older lawman. Then there's the 12 year old inbred hick karate expert who shouts 'pancakes!' and bites people - im sure it was a funny idea at the time guys, but surely someone must have said "well yeah, but thats going to ruin the entire film Eli, you big, big fool you?" Shame.There are plus points though. The gore set-pieces are top notch, a few of which had the audiences in the cinema i work in screaming out loud, or grinding their teeth and whimpering at the now infamous 'leg shaving' scene. The scripting/acing errors arent quite enough to ruin the film though, however the ending very nearly is... Roth for some reason extracts all the menace out of the story once again by parading a bunch of dummy dummy rednecks ingesting the virus, to some very dummy dummy redneck music.
All in all though, Cabin Fever is still one of the most entertaining little horror films to hit our screens in recent memory, because it doesn't hold back, thank God. It does remind me of the time when horror was good. And had breasts. Its worth a watch for the jumpy moments, and decent humour, but only just. I just hope more skilled actors/directors realise that horror is making a comeback, and capitalise on it.6/10

reviews.review_title: A Great Genre Effort, Think "Evil Dead" meets "Outbreak"
reviews.content: I was lucky enough to catch this last year at the Alamo Drafthouse's 1st Annual Dusk Till Dawn Horror Show.  Not sure if the film has been edited any, but the original ending is outstanding and really unconventional (and compensates for what I would have earlier deemed unnecessarily objectionable content).  The performances are outstanding, particularly Rider Strong (who has come a long way from "Boy Meets World"), with other standouts including Cerina Vincent, in a role that redefines the often stereotypical "bimbo" persona (her character, Marcy, is both sexually aggressive and likely the smartest among the film's protagonists), Joey Kern, in another redefined archtypcal role (group leader turned coward, showing the same comic skill he demonstrated in Broken Lizard's "Super Troopers") and James DeBello and Giuseppe Andrews making most of the audience forget their earlier roles in the regrettable "Detroit Rock City."Alternately scary (what wouldn't be with an original Badalamenti, assisted by Nathan Barr, score) and funny with outrageous gore effects rivaling earlier work by Sam Raimi in the "Evil Dead" Trilogy and Peter Jackson in his earlier work (pre-"Frighteners). You'll never look at bottled water the same way again.Don't miss this.

reviews.review_title: Too Many Questions After Watching This Movie!
reviews.content: So I just watched the DVD and I really didn't enjoy it. I can certainly appreciate (after reading some of the other IMDb member reviews) that it's a B-movie now, so that explains a lot of it. But there were just too many questions in my head once I was done, to say I really enjoyed the movie. I was left at the end wishing that we were at least told (1) where the disease originally came from and (2)whether or not it's ever stopped. I was led to believe that it WASN'T stopped, because the police bought and drank lemonade from those kids, who made the lemonade from contaminated stream water. You also never find out what the "party man" deputy does with the kid from the hospital at the end, either. You assume he's going to kill him, but... I was also really curious about what was in "the kit" that the hillbillies brought with them when they went after the kids in the cabin. The one carrying "the kit" got it in the ear with a screwdriver before he could open the box! If anyone could shed some light on all of this for me, I would greatly appreciate it.

cabin fever is an excellent movie for anyone who truly appreciates horror movies made in the 70s and 80s. if you want a special effects tragedy, go watch something made by bruckheimer.the movie is quite artistic, has a great and new storyline, and has redeeming value for it's humor. when you watch cabin fever you almost want to yell to the characters don't do that, don't do this... just like the early 70s slasher movies (think halloween, Friday the 13th, Texas chainsaw massacre). in fact, it pays homage to a number of the early classics horror roots. the music is wonderfully composed by one of the industry's greatest composers angelo badalamenti (twin peaks, lost highway, muhulland drive) and the sound effects as well as visuals are impressive given the budget.if you want to see an interesting, humorous and funny tribute to old style horror flicks, cabin fever is a winner

I just got back from Cabin Fever, and I'm happy to say it lives up to the hype.   It's a throwback to the fun thrill-ride horror movies of the 70's. Very well done and not OVER-done like most of the recent attempts to recapture the era.  A no-name cast, but they do the excellent script justice.  Just remember, Do NOT sit next to DENNIS!

reviews.review_title: one of the greatest horror films ever
reviews.content: Possible spoilers(kinda of): i love horror films that offer no real set-up and no real ending.  Horror i feel is the only genre that can do this. There was no explanation for the virus and that is fine, it is better than some scientist showing up at the end and saving everyone.  films that feel they have to explain everything can get annoying. let the imagination play a little.  Although i am aware that the general public enjoys crap where everything is explained to the minute detail and there is no thinking involved.

reviews.review_title: Gore, lust, stupidity - every addle brain's desire.
reviews.content: In my opinion, this movie was the most senseless and chaotic piece of work I have ever seen. The script was unimaginative and pointless, and the insertion of the occasional porno scenes only served to make this movie worse. The movie rating system is really lacks something to be desired, and I am getting tired of renting movies that don't mention nudity in the ratings for my family to watch only to find that it is a sex fest and a waste of money. I couldn't tell if the movie was about porn, diseases, or how people in backwoods small towns are morons. Adding nudity and sex scenes to a movie implies that the writer has no imagination or adequate intelligence to write a complete script. I was so bored with the movie that I fast forwarded through most of it just to get to the end to see who would survive. The only part of the movie that I did find somewhat entertaining was the gore. I would compare this movie as similar to the movie 28 days later, which was also about a plague. I suggest you pass on this movie as a complete waste of time.

In a funny way I actually became obsessed with this movie. The main reason being because it was so bad. I had to watch it again and again and kept talking about it because I couldn't believe just how stupid some of the script was. It will make you laugh but also cry because of how pathetic some bits of it are. However, if you enjoy watching gory stuff, this is a good one. I have to say that side to it matched up to my expectations. I absolutely hate "Teen movies" so maybe this is why I found the script terrible but perhaps if you like those kind of films you won't think it is that bad. In all, it is one of those movies that is a good one to rent out but only watch it once (and if you are feeling depressed then don't watch it at all)

Just as I am impressed when a film transcends a problematic low-budget and becomes an effective piece of cinema, I am dismayed when a good film is hindered, however slightly, by such a budget. "Cabin Fever" is Eli Roth's loving nod to the horror genre; Roth, a well-spoken man whose defense of this genre on Fox News is perhaps the best I've ever heard, loves films and understands a fact that many are resistant to admit: there are few ideas that have not already been done to death, especially in horror. Rather than attempt (and, no doubt, fail) to reinvent the genre he knows and admires, he is paying homage to it here; connections to such films as "Night of the Living Dead" and "The Evil Dead" are rampant, and Roth uses them with an aura of gratitude rather than thievery. It is unfortunate that such a good film is kept from being great due to the limitations of its decidedly small budget.Read My Full Review Here: www.thechrisclarkblog.blogspot.com

This movie was not at all what I expected. I was looking for something very scary and suspenseful, not a drip. BUT, when it was all said and done Cabin Fever was pretty entertaining and had good macabre humor.It is a great example of early Eli Roth's horror visions (before he became a lap dog of Hollywood production). The acting is a bit thin and the character actions are contradicting. But what you ultimately get is a strange world full of goofy and most times annoying characters and a slight twist of the regurgitated "teens on a camping trip from hell" idea. This is a cult classic and that is enough to be said. Go in with no expectations and enjoy.

Cabin Fever was possibly the worst film I have seen in years. Far, far, far worse than House of 1,000 corpses (which I actually quite liked) and even worse than Crossroads.  Now that's a pretty woeful comparison! I did not care one iota about any of the characters, they were all one dimensional cutouts of carictures.  They had *nothing* origional, and they were ugly as well.  The film was tedious, and boring.  The best thing that can be said about it was the dialogue blew festy goats except for one line - a girl said, "He asked us for help - and we set him on fire!"That is not much of a high point for a movie. 0 out of 5 stars

reviews.review_title: Terrifying and is a possible scenario
reviews.content: If your'e looking a gory fun and disturbing movie, look no further than Eli Roth's Cabin Fever. It is a bit slow but in between that are suspenseful moments. This film could also be a scenario that is likely to happen to anybody.

reviews.review_title: At last! A film made FOR THE SQUEAMISH!
reviews.content: It's sad that so many movies have been labeled "NOT FOR THE SQUEAMISH!" If I had been raised Squeamish, I swear I would have run away and become a hell-raising Methodist as soon as I was big enough to hook up the buggy to the horse.But at last! Cabin Fever! A (kind of) horror film FOR the Squeamish!If you are easily grossed out, this one's for you. Because of the set-up and setting, it is easy to confuse Cabin Fever with the mean-spirited horror classics of the late seventies and early eighties. Not the same thing. This movie plays for laughs and gets them. You must absolutely see it in a theater with a good-sized crowd to appreciate it. (Check other comments for proof.)Viewing Cabin Fever is quite a lot like watching a stand-up comic perform.
