This film is truly awful and has moved to No.1 in my "all time worst films at the cinema" chart.  Not sure what I expected but was at least hoping for a Fright - some gore, some jumps, some screams.  But it was all a bit lame.There was just so many loose ends - where did the virus come from?  what happened to goatie bloke with the bag of weed?  why did they bother making this film?  why did I bother going to see it?But the good news is they left it nice and open for "Cabin Fever 2" - yippee!Mind you, it was almost worth it for the freaky kid outside the store who did the karate stuff and shouted 'Pancakes' - funny as hell!Anyway, for anyone who hasn't seen it then don't bother...its lame!

reviews.review_title: Not Quite What you Would Expect
reviews.content: If you are going to Cabin Fever to see one of the latest in a line of more intelligent, thinking horror movies, THINK AGAIN. While there are a few interesting points of social commentary in this film, it is REALLY meant to be the following:A cheap, cheesy film, with sex, nudity, drinking and drugs, extremes of gore and violence, and some humor.THIS is what the film is about. If you do not want to see this, don't go to see this movie, it's about these things, sorry.And, it's rather well done, for what it is. It's a return to an old style of horror, that of the 80s, where they don't really try to make you think too much (we don't go in to the origins of the protagonist here, nor what exactly it does), and they just present you with some characters who show off their naughty parts, glorify the pollution of ones body, and then end up bloody. I was much reminded of older horror movies, and I did get a bit of a kick out of it.In the way of social commentary, yes, there are things to think about. Major themes hit on are paranoia, our fear of the sick (very much akin to the leper of The Bible, if you are familiar with that story), and, my favorite as I am a camp counselor, just how much parents love to blame others for their childrens' problems.So, in essence, don't expect to think to much, but you can at least get something out of this film, and I would advise seeing it, as it is interesting enough.

When I saw the previews for this movie I was expecting a really great horror movie. Starting out the movie is all right. But it doesn't really go into detail about this so called "disease" these teenagers are contracting. Overall this movie was a huge disappointment, espcially for horror movie buffs who were fooled by the previews.

reviews.review_title: A movie any horror fan would be proud of...
reviews.content: This movie is exactly what a horror movie should be.The movie shows the teens, Jeff, Karen, Paul, Marcy and Bert as they embark on a vacation deep into the mountains. They drive to a remote cabin to enjoy a few days offside. Karen starts to get sick, the others are afraid they will too so they move her to a shed outside with nothing but a blanket. Some of them begin to feel guilty for abandoning her and some of them don't, meanwhile a down and out seems to have the same condition that Karen has, they give him a bad reception when he comes looking for help. One by one the gang start to suspect each other of becoming infected, their minds plays tricks on them. The scenario goes from bad to worse to the worst case scenario.This movie is a must for any horror fan, very little modern day horror dare to go where Cabin Fever goes...

I'm starting to believe that most of the people submitting reviews to this site have not actually paid attention to the movie they are supposedly reviewing or even finished it. 8 reviews in the 13 I read here had false information or simply stated nothing past the first half hour. I on the other hand have seen this movie in it's entirety more than once.First off, it must be known that this movie doesn't take itself seriously. Anyone else that tries to take it seriously will just be put off by the dark and tasteless humor and gore interspersed. If you go in thinking this is going to be a very serious movie, you're in for a very serious disappointment and rightfully so. Second, it seems people don't understand the logic of movie at all. It's actually not hard to follow and doesn't require a lot of thought process to understand both the character motivations and the plot as a whole. In fact, most of the characters verbally just say "I'm doing this because of this". It can't get much more clearer than that. Third, it's a gore movie. The movie's about a flesh eating virus. It eats flesh. Underneath skin is muscle and blood and bone. It's gross when it's not where it's suppose to be. In a gore movie, this is shown for shock and scare. So I repeat, this is a gore movie. Now for the actual review...overall, it's a fun movie. I think the main character (the kid from Boy Meets World) was chosen specifically so you'd see him in these horrid situations. Before this movie, he was nothing but family friendly comedy material and here we see him perform atrocious acts while defending himself from enemies both seen and unseen. The other characters are good, too. There's the girlfriend- who's-not-a-girlfriend, the nympho who has sex just to hold on to any shred left of normal life, a cocky jerk who cares of no one else, and the 'tough' guy who isn't really tough at all. This sort of movie is what I've heard referred to (and like the term) as a 'pressure cooker' movie...a small group of people is put into a situation where they can't or won't trust each other yet they cannot escape each other either. Between the absurd locals and the virus, the group is caught between the proverbial rock and hard place and watching them get crushed under the gravity of the situation is just as fun as watching them physically get destroyed by the situation. The comedy itself is hit and miss. One of the ones that was a good idea but should've been left on the cutting room floor is the 'nigger' joke. I don't object to it because it was a cheesy joke but rather to the fact that it bookends the movie, almost as if the whole movie was a joke...the setup was when we first meet the weird shop keeper and the punchline was at the end. But then, maybe this was the full intent...thinking about it, the 'hero' was telling a story about a man who's decapitated head ends up in a bowling alley ball return and no one listening to the story can help their laughter at the whole thing...maybe that's the point of that story and the point of this one...just have a good time and enjoy it. Leave your brain at the door, please, before turning this one on and you'll have a much better time.

reviews.review_title: Now this one is scary, cos it's real
reviews.content: Wow, as a doctor in the UK I must say that i absolutely loved this film. I love horror flicks but i always find that they do not scare me. The predictable horror characters fail to thrill..although the jeepers creepers movies and the scream movies deserve to be seen. After seeing 28 days later (a movie that set it's opening scene in a United Kingdom population wiped out by a virus) I was a little intrigued by that plotline. In no way does the movie "cabin fever" rip off that plot. It's very gory, very scary and will make you itch very much after this film. I take the point that a lot of people have complained about the lack of actors or acting ability in this film, but i must say that the story line more than carries this film, and in modern society i think this is a greater threat to society than random babysitter killers or horrible mutants anyday - as virus warfare is very real! now this film really is scary and is done in a very good way - this film is very anti-cliché and I think it should get the credit it deserves See this film please it's great and certainly doesn't fail to shock..it gave me nightmares and horror movies NEVER do that to me!

reviews.review_title: We don't need no stinking pancakes.
reviews.content: This scriptless movie was merely a practice in gore and poor acting. With the exception of the amazingly out-of-place pancake kung-fu scene, Cabin Fever was the opposite of entertaining. The only people that I would recommend this movie too are aspiring filmmakers, so they don't waste their time making a similar piece of garbage.

As far as I'm concerned, watching a Horror film is one thing. Rewatching is another. The Horror's I enjoy rewatching are normally blood-soaked rhapsodies full of black humour and snide references to everything under the sun. This is one of those films and I will gladly rewatch this film any day.Beginning with a simple enough premise of 'woodsman gets infected with virus, begins to infect a cabinful of good-looking teenagers partying in the woods,' this film spirals out of the normal cliches and conventions: making an original movie whilst still giving a wink and a nudge to Friday the 13th, Texas Chainsaw Massacre, Evil Dead et. al. Within thirty minutes of the beautiful title sequence, people are shaving skin off themselves, firing BB gun pellets at squirrels, drinking beer all holiday, quarantening each other in shacks, and killing a disease-ridden hobo. I mention such specific things because this is a film that does not 'broaden' things over with large Spielbergian brushstrokes: every character has a life of their own and you will walk away discussing the old Shirley Temple bottles in the bottlestore or a rung of a ladder breaking instead of the artful references to your favourite movies.A good Horror should have original kills. Check. A good Horror should make people laugh whilst making them jump out of their seats. Check. A good Horror shouldn't give away its punchlines or sporadic murders early. Check. A good Horror should always feature a badly written review from a gobsmacked 17 year old who can't figure out how to describe the fun he just had watching this movie and meeting the director afterwards at the Wellington International Film Festival. Check.Go see this on September 12. You won't regret it... that is, provided you have nothing in your stomach. 9/10.

reviews.review_title: Not bad, actually scarier than jason movie
reviews.content: Well, as I read the comments on this movie, I can see that some people just about write a thesis.  Come on, it's an entertaining movie, put together well, but for goodness sake, it won't stand the scrutiny of endless analysis... take it easy folks...it's just entertainment after all... 8-)

This movie was opposite of boring. You're either freaked out or laughing. I thought that this movie, and all other movies made by Eli Roth are always quite different....but the best horror stories I have ever seen....besides "The Shining". In addition, you watch his movies and you think that it could never happen, although you will learn a bit more of reality that most people just don't know about these days. Watch his movies and you will know what I am talking about. Take my advice and go rent "Cabin Fever" and "Hostle" and you will appreciate what you saw. Put it all together, if you are young and love to laugh see this movie a.s.a.p. If you are over 18 (its almost x-rated) and you love weird, odd, freaking movies then go check out "Hostle". Trust me, my boyfriend and I were both in shock when we saw these two movies with how great of a horror movie they actually were, and can't wait till hostel 2 comes out!

Spoilers contained within.I'm aghast at the comments here, I adore this movie.  I think there were a bunch of folks who went in with expectations that went unfulfilled. Perhaps viewers don't like their expectations being messed with -- I certainly do. A film that looks shallow at first glance but has good depth is always welcome.  I can't believe that other viewers didn't see the thought that went into this well-made film that I did.It being way to early to tell, I won't gush over Eli Roth's genius or anything, but he is a student of horror.  His script is a horror script and not intended to be particulary scholarly or thought-provoking.  It's uncomplicated and serves to move the plot along, it's not the focal point. It also guides the viewer into perceiving who the characters are and establishes the necessary fatal character flaws that get everyone killed. The plot, as well, is horror-uncomplicated: after the setup, everybody run from the menace, we're all going to die.It's Roth's juxtaposition of menaces that makes this movie fabulous.  The virus is scary enough, but what about the rampaging hillbillies or incompetent police?  How about a drifter's mad dog growling at the perimeter as they fix the broken truck?  Tainted water passed around by characters, blissfully unaware?  Even an over-the-top horror tribute to the original Texas Chainsaw Massacre which turns out to be nothing but a fireside ghost story.  It is in the combination of threats and the innocent characters' confusion that the real horror begins to shine through, and the audiences fear starts growing.Then there's the gore -- truly horrifying gore in shocking clarity. Scenes are often established with enough preamble to encourage the viewer to anticipate the blood; when it comes, it roars past your expectations and sends you into tense discomfort.  Best makeup effects of 2003, truly awful to behold. [An aside: one viewer I recommended it to vomited after the shower scene. Granted, he was a bit hung over, but it serves as example: this film is not for the weak of stomach.]The love interest between the main character and his longtime friend at first glance seems banal, overdone.  But the cinematic shots that set it up and the nearly-consummated romance undone by blood help increase the romance's potency.  The stupendous review montage at the end of the film sends the beautiful blonde offscreen in horror glory.  Without the jaded impression the viewer gets of the initial romance, the shock at the end has nowhere near the force.In what I see as a tribute to Blair Witch Project, the characters all begin to turn on one another, which helps prompt audience anxiety.  There are several particularly effective scenes as their friendship decays into survival instinct.  As the turmoil increases and the frienship decays, there are several cathartic moments where individuals realize the shaky base of their relationship in the first place.And, of course, there's "PANCAKES....  PANCAKES".  Good old Dennis, I laughed and laughed.  Truly great horror films are interspersed with grim humor.  Cabin Fever is exceptionally funny in parts.  Without this, the ride never lets up for the viewer and a constantly, ever-increasing fear factor becomes numbing.  This film makes sure to pull the viewer up for "air" with laughter, before plunging you back into the bucket of gore for more fear.At some length, let me sum up by saying this is worth a look if you like horror.  Do not be swayed by the nearly universal antipathy here, many of these bad reviews may stem from offended sensibilities.  Oh, and there's a coda at the end of the credits.

reviews.review_title: Finally, a horror movie that delivers
reviews.content:
So often you come across horror movies promising blood, guts, suspense, trills, etc. and so often they fail. As a teen who has been watching horror movies since before I can remember, I've seen A LOT of crap.  "Cabin Fever" is a horror film that contains all the necessary elements of a good horror movie.  It's not just another ordinary slasher, nor is it a zombie flick.
The acting isn't great, but the creepy atmosphere and the gore should be enough to make up for it.  Besides, who watches a horror movie for the acting?Overall, a good rent if you want a horror movie above the rest.

this movie was way over advertized and so not original actually this movie is a mix between rot and the original night of the living dead. the whole story and suspense plot was good but the whole part about other people outside of the first 5 was boring. but there was something good about the movie the effects and the suspense. other than that it was pretty boring i mean i was more scared watching childs play 2. and one more thing if you have watched the original night of the living dead then you know that most of the ending of cabin fever was the same. and if me a 14 year old girl and my friends are in no way amused by this movie and think that its a total bore let alone a total copout then i can just imagine what you think.

in my rankings of the worst movies ever made.  I wish I could have voted a zero.  Actually, I asked for my money back from Blockbuster as they should have a sensor to remove films like this one.  I think the people who voted anything above a 1 were just upset at the time they wasted and wanted to trick other people into seeing it so that their misery would be shared. Bad plot, bad acting, bad special effects, yada, yada, yada.  My wife insisted on watching the whole movie in the hopes that it really couldn't be that bad, and something of substance had to be in the next scene. Unfortunately, we both just ended up wasting our time, which we would have much rather spent shaving potatoes.  The only redeeming quality of this movie is that it makes me think of pancakes, and I love pancakes. ps - The Messenger is #1.

SPOILERSNot one for your average MTV demographic, this is a subversive, genre-blending horror film which manages to be both exciting and very funny. Although some posts have compared the film to A Clockwork Orange, its joyously apocalyptic ending is closer to Dr Strangelove.  The characters are introduced as an initial sop to the teenaged viewer: then gradually, and in degrees, undercut and exposed and finally killed off.  Those viewers who, like myself, were alienated by the arrogance and rudeness of the archetypal American characters will be delighted by the resolution: every one of these appalling Californian children meets an end which they can truly be said to deserve.  An argument that beauty is truly skin deep, the movie reverses popular cinematic trends and reserves its grisliest fates for the prettiest, most 'popular' inmates.  The small, mainly young audience with whom I shared the auditorium seemed confused by this film; being conditioned to entertainment which flatters and assures, this piece, in contrast, unsettles and satirises the very people it is marketed to.Betraying an obvious passion for the genre, and a wicked, intelligent sense of humour, Cabin Fever is a film destined to be misunderstood.

And the best of both worlds. For any horror fan, this movie rocks the house, or should I say cabin. Eli Roth's direction is right on the button. He knows what makes horror films good; sex, violence, and unknown actors. This is the anti-Urban Legends, or any of those other knock offs of Scream. Eli Roth yanks the horror genre out of PG-13 pop territory and plants it firmly back in Cult-land.The actors are all capable. The gore is delicious. The audience will laugh hysterically one moment, cringe the next, and scream to end it all. The music is perfect and ominous. The location is eerie. The writing is snappy.This movie is certainly going to gain cult status when it hits dvd. A must see/must own for any Horror fan.

reviews.review_title: Peter Jackson, we hardly know ye
reviews.content: Peter Jackson likes this nonsense?What a complete waste of time. It's trite in every way that the traditional slasher films are. The one piece of originality is the brainstorm to make the killer a virus, and everyone already knows that.The fact that Peter Jackson commented so favorably about this dreck tells me that -- for all the interviews and commentaries on the "Lord of the Rings" DVDs, most people still don't know much about this director and his "tastes." I count myself among those people. And really, I don't want to know. Don't talk about this being a throwback to the greats of the genre. I thought we had progressed to the point that we could all pretty much agree that "Night of the Living Dead" was ridiculous fluff.As for director Eli Roth, what a sophomoric sense of humor. Please. Note to Roth: Doing a walk-on in your own film doesn't make you M. Night Shyamalan.

You can't get much more satisfied than this walking out of a horror movie. It truly amazing stuff that has your heart racing as the film delivers one shock after another. This movie needed to be made to satisfy all those desperate to see plenty of gore and originality in a horror film. 10/10

reviews.review_title: highlight of the Toronto Film Fest
reviews.content:
It was the last film of the fest, and was a perfect finisher for me.  I haven't seen a horror movie this engaging since the 80's, back when humour and horror weren't mutually exclusive (unless, of course, you're wimp enough to consider Scream and its rip-offs actually scary.)I actually originally wanted to see this movie because it has a similar premise to a movie I wrote (which is now in editing), namely, 5 20somethings go up to a cabin for vacation, get trapped there and are beset by horror. Mine has nothing to do with the flesh eating virus, of course, but I'm ever so glad that I went now, as I wouldn't have wanted to miss this--especially as it won't have a theatrical release for another year apparently!Like in every good horror, the gore and the sex are both gratuitous. (that Celina girl should have drum machine start up everytime she walks, cause damn those hips swing!) Like in every good horror, everyone is suspect, everyone is dangerous, there is no one to trust.  Like in every good horror--and this shouldn't ruin the ending for you, this is to be expected by any horror connoisseur--everyone dies.  And this film, in a notable mark of its brilliance, takes the 'everyone dies' concept to a whole new level.
Highly recommended.  Except for those with high strung nerves or a weak stomach!

reviews.review_title: Horror as it always should have been
reviews.content: God created Eli Roth, and he saw that it was good.Im not going to say too much about Cabin Fever, other than watch it watch it now.Its the film I have been begging for, for the last 10 years. If you love Horror, you'll love Cabin Fever. If you respect early Raimi, Craven, Fulchi, Carpenter, Hooper, Argento, Jackson,  then this movie is for you.Thank you Eli Roth for bringing Horror back to the fans.If there is one horror film you watch this year, make it Cabin Fever.

reviews.review_title: The most awesome horror movie of the year!
reviews.content: This was shown at the Frightfest festival in London on Sunday 24th August, and simply blew me away!This is a rare example of a horror movie that DOES NOT disappoint!  After all the hype I was reading on the Net about this, I was hoping that I wasn't going to be disappointed, and I wasn't at all.  It was even better than I'd dared to hope.Yes, it's a homage to THE EVIL DEAD and many other movies from the 70's and 80's, but WHO CARES!!  That's not the point - what true horror fans like myself want is a movie that'll shock, thrill and delight an audience of like-minded people.And this movie does that.  This is easily the best movie I've seen in the genre this year, and deserves to be a success so that the director, Eli Roth, can continue to make other horror films that are as good as this one.Miss this at your peril - a real cinematic thrill ride!!!(10 out of 10)

This was quite a shallow movie, barely delving into the question of what people would do when faced with the fear of a horrendous death. Without the addition of the redneck store owners (and Denis who was possibly the funniest character) this movie would have been entirely predictable. Wait it still was entirely predictable. The acting was fairly good for this level of horror movie, the makeup was detailed and the splatter patterns were ever-increasingly excessive however this movie failed in both possible aims of a horror movie. It did not scare its audience, nor did it make the audience laugh at the unrealistic splatter and throw popcorn at the screen.

The leg shaving scene made me gag. It was pretty disgusting and the actor was so mournful and seriously average. I was keen to seen what happened in the end but had to hide my head throughout the constant blood and gore. Was it really necessary to see a picture of the girl, nearly dead, with her teeth jutting out of her skeletal face? Eww. My mates wanted to turn it off but the way they leave you in anticipation for ages is just annoying. And the pancakes guy...what can I say about him? I don't get what positive addition he gave. I did think that the irony at the end was clever but the way it was portrayed was disgusting. A good spontaneous plot but seriously lacking talented actors and a moral.

reviews.review_title: Point made, and well done at that
reviews.content: Cabin Fever has been given some pretty poor reviews by a lot of people who are watching it to be scared, sickened, and shocked. I sat down to watch it very skeptically, not a fan of horror movies, or the grotesque in general. But Cabin Fever proved itself to be more then meets the eye.First, let's get the essential stuff out of the way. The characters were well done, even though some may not take to them. Anyone who's been through college in the past 5-10 years can tell you the depictions are (unfortunately) quite accurate. The cinematography was great, and gave the movie an appropriate feel.Now on to the important stuff. The movie, marketed and filmed as a horror film, is really about the human condition. Of course, the premise is simple. Kids in the woods. Car broken down. Strange Disease. But what's really brilliant is how Writer/Director Eli Roth turns this setup for a white-bread film disaster into an excellent movie.The themes are obvious to anyone who's watching it for more then blood and boobs. Canadian-made, I began to think that Roth was trying to tell Americans something. Perhaps it's because I agree with him that I catch them so easy, but the point is well made, and the message is well needed today. I'd rather not give away the vehicles Roth employs, and leave it to the viewer to see for himself. Of course, the point-to-grotesque ratio wasn't quite in balance, but I suppose, had it been done tastefully, it would have defeated Roth's entire point.In short, this was a great movie, with a lot of thrills, but to be fair, I'm giving Roth the benefit of the doubt on his characters and plot. To really appreciate this as more than a horror film, be looking for more then a thriller when you see it. Hopefully, you'll be more than pleased.

reviews.review_title: Not as good as I expected
reviews.content: Cabin Fever by nouveau writer/director Eli Roth is the story of five college kids (three male, two female) who, after finishing their final exams, go off into the woods to a cabin where they'll spend a nice holiday of drinking, sex, and the usual stuff college kids do. Instead of finding the perfect way to top off the end of school, one of them finds a hermit man in the woods with some kind of serious disease. Let me let you in on a little secret: it's NOT SARS! You can guess where it goes from here. This film started off fairly promising, but in the end the lack of real character development really hurt what was potentially an interesting idea. You don't really care for characters who are all clichés of what we've seen in too many other teen horror flicks. There was a good opportunity with the lead male and his love interest for the writers to develop that relationship so we could understand it more and thus feel sympathy for both of them. But, it never happened. As for the rest of the characters, what little we get to know about them only reveals they are pretty shallow and one-dimensional. Thus, making them pretty cliché-like.It's very similar to other far better films such as: "The Thing" (1982), "28 days later" (2002), and "The Evil Dead" (1981). What made these films work was dark humor, which this film has shades of, character development, and effective creepiness and scares, which "The Evil Dead" has in spades compared to this one. "The Evil Dead" is given homage to in the end credits here. Out of these three "Cabin Fever" is most similar to "28 days later." What that film has that really makes it stand out from this one is two dimensional and realistic characters who are actually smart (a rarity in horror films). Instead of creating two-dimensional characters the director here would rather gives these characters every opportunity to have sex. This film does have a dark humor type ending that works okay. And it manages to be kind of creepy in some places. But, as I said before, you don't really care that much about the characters so it doesn't matter who dies and how they die. It did have the potential to have some pretty interesting psychological warfare going on with the characters alienating potentially "sick" friends and thus echoing how paranoid and cruel mankind can be towards one another. But, it didn't manage to pull that off as well as other films have in the past, namely "The Thing." Some places in the film did manage to be pretty humorous and so it succeeded at times in that respect. Overall, the film is mildly entertaining and it's a decent first film for Eli Roth. I just hope that his new film, which is produced by Tarrantino, is better. The "fake shemp" used in the end credits is an obvious reference to Sam Raimi. This film even though it tries comes nowhere close to achieving what Raimi did with "The Evil Dead." He pulled that off for a measly $150,000. And so, referencing Mr. Raimi seems like a cheap way to put yourself in the same category as he is. The bottom line is: this is a decent horror film that is worth seeing, but don't let your expectations run too high. James Sutherland.

reviews.review_title: The Blair Witch Project Surpasses This One..
reviews.content: I'm sorry. But this movie was a waste of time. I could have used that our and a half doing something more significant with my time, watching a better movie or saving an endangered country..Seriously, this movie was terrible. I can't begin to describe how poorly put together this flick was. The acting, characters and scenes were atrocious. The gore was disappointing, the sex scenes were disappointing, the jokes were enough to make prozac takers cry.And Ryder Strong. You all know him from Boy Meets World as Cory's best friend. In this flick, he looks and acts the same as he does in the sitcom. If you're a Ryder Strong fan, you wont be after watching this movie.

When I first saw the trailer for cabin fever I immediately thought, bloody,unoriginal, teen horror movie. But to my surprise Eli Roth's low budget directional debut was an impressive re-invention of the cult 80's horror classics. The movie's shire simplicity and originality set It aside from the rest of the old cliché horror films and made out to be an enjoyable one-watch flick.The low-budget is recognisable when it comes to the special effects and the cast but the original script made a decent change from all them brutal slasher movies set in the woods. The basic premise of the film is about a group of college kids who decide to travel to a isolated cabin to get drunk and high, nothing special there. But when they start to get infected with an unusual flesh eating disease the group turn on each other and it becomes a battle to survive.I wasn't expecting much from the film but considering the low-budget and quality of filming I was pleasantly surprised. The movie made a name for director Eli Roth who won multiple awards and became a big hit with director Quentin Tarantino.

I love cheesy horror-flicks, so I was pleasantly surprised when a colleague brought this movie into work for the night-shift. Sadly, I was extremely disappointed!I get what Eli Roth was trying to do - create a homage to the cheap gore 'n' giggle films of the 80's. But boy-oh-boy, didn't he miss the mark on this one! To create a true homage, the direction has to have intelligence... this, however, was just plain awful in EVERY respect!In short, it resembled an un-entertaining parody of 80's horror devoid of any humour or smarts.Avoid at all costs!

reviews.review_title: This movie is so bad my dog won't eat it
reviews.content: I only give this film a 2 because it did have a lot of gore. It was pretty good until it got halfway through the movie then it took off in about three different directions. I do not know who was smoking dope, but it must have been everyone to let that movie get released. There are few movies I would like to get my money back for, but this is definitely one of those movies. It was so bad by the end I had to lie down and take a nap. Hopefully the director (the one responsible for this travesty of good movies) had his eyes and mouth sowed shut, he should never direct again. I hear now that they are going to release a Cabin Fever 2, God save our souls. I would not watch it, even if they sent me a copy for free. Who licks their own butt then goes back for seconds. Not this camper. I still have a bad taste in my mouth, and it is from the movie. My girlfriend says I should tell everyone it is a horrible movie, but I do not think that says enough about how bad it is.

I have to say: this movie managed to be absolutely disgusting and horrific to me which is pretty hard to do. I've tried watching the worst of the worst, but this movie managed to mess me up emotionally. I loved it. I've never had a movie take my appetite away, but this one managed to and trust me: I was very hungry beforehand. Props to this movie for accomplishing what so many seek out to do, yet completely fail to actually accomplish. I enjoyed it, and would recommend anyone into horror films to view it as well. Definitely do not recommend watching while eating or before eating unless you're on a diet..
Hey this movie is not super bad. But still... It doesn't work that much. But still isn't super good.

reviews.review_title: THE WAY HORROR SHOULD BE DONE. (Finally, a tribute to old-school horror!)
reviews.content: Put simply, it's about FREAKIN' TIME.I had just about given up on the horror genre -- too many years of "Jason XXVIII" and too many teen soundtrack vehicles had come and gone for me to pay attention. I can list on one hand the horror films that ACTUALLY scared me: The ORIGINAL Friday the 13th, the ORIGINAL Halloween, the ORIGINAL Texas Chainsaw Massacre, etc. -- see a pattern here?Hollywood had forgotten a simple lesson: LESS IS MORE. You DON'T need a $45 million budget, half an hour of CGI, and a soundtrack featuring MTV's Buzz Bin / TRL to make a decent horror film. Whatever happened to woods? Whatever happened to country folk and stillwater ponds? A big THANK YOU goes out to Mr. Eli Roth for giving today's X-Box brats a healthy dose of what they'd been missing for years: old-school horror. Do yourself a favor and see this gem when it hits the screen -- you won't be disappointed.Later, freebie_grabber

this film i saw in theatres, without knowing what i was getting myself into. throughout the movie more than half of the people walked out at random intervals and never returned, others who stuck it out, walked out shaking their head with a friendly smile towards the ones around them who seem to wonder collectively, 'where you there with me right then or was that all some ambrose bierce inspired wet dream of teen horror?' so of course i have found memories of this movie. the director is an obvious horror movie buff and it comes out in the intense black humor of the film. as illustrated in spinal tap, more likely in the quote itself, "there's a fine line between stupid and ... clever." this film is too good to do it justice in this review, or any review for that matter. i like films that are so out there, you refuse to think of ways you'd like to direct or write them yourself. this is one of those films, you must simply enjoy the ride.

reviews.review_title: Evil Dead : Tarantino and David Lynch style
reviews.content: Evil Dead : Tarantino and David Lynch style. This movie has to be viewed as a comedy or else you will not enjoy it. It will become a classic just like Evil Dead, Pulp Fiction and Twin Peaks.....At the theather everybody were cracked up, especially with weird characters like Denis and the policeman...

Just saw this film at MIFF, and I've got to say I'm disappointed.  Sure we laughed, we jumped, but we left unimpressed.Eli Roth has done a very good job of putting together a great college death trip, but it is far from horror.  There is some gruesomeness, one or two shock scenes (but I'll get to that), but very little in the way of horror... I mean what is so scary about watching some dumb US college kids klutz around as they wait to die of a flesh eating virus.The humour was very hit & miss, some of the subtle ironies (ie the main character unwittingly giving his lover virally infected water) were fantastic, but most of it seemed over played for gratuitous yuks.But the whole thing smacked of Eli Roth's ego, and a sense that he was trying to prove that he is cleverer than the audience.  There are two moments that triggered this thought, for me:1. The whole town turning from 'inbreds' to jovial country folk is a bit off key.  OK, the whole thing is a joke, and played purely for laughs, and without any horror apart from, again, the subtle irony of simple folk quaffing deadly lemonade.  I can't help but feel this was thrown in so Eli could go "betcha didn't see that coming".2. The one jump-out-of-the-seat moment in the film is the introduction of Eli Roth's cameo.  You are expecting to see the infected hobo, but no, we have Eli turning up with a bag of dope.  Yup the scene was mildly funny, but completely out of touch with the rest of the film.  In fact, completely unnecessary in the whole film.  Why not have a drunken grizzly bear, or a swarm of squirrels seeking revenge.  It seems that Eli did this to make his own appearance more memorable in the whole film.I wanted to like this film, and there were moments that I was laughing with the crowd, but too many moments where I laughed at the film and without the crowd.  And it wasn't the gore that put me off, I saw this a day after seeing "May" another, and far better, Lions Gate release.

Obvioulsy this is a B movie that some how by the grace of god made it to the movies.  It's a great B movie, but the acting was excruciating.  The whole begining of the movie was horrendus, there must of been 4 or 5 different songs crammed into the first 5 minutes of the movie.  And the "grim" guy was absolutley pointless, he came out of no where.  The cast was just wrong I think, it seemed like they were just reading lines, espeically the 2 girls and the dumb friend with the rifle.  But  I have to say it's not bad for a first time writer/director.  I would like to see what else he can do.

Truly one of the most dire films I've ever sat through. I've never actually taken the time to write one of these but felt compelled to after witnessing this affront to film-making and feel somewhat aggrieved to be wasting my time on such a piece of turd to be honest. There were so many parts that infuriated me with their complete randomness and lack of sense (e.g. when would the police force ever shoot people with infectious diseases? When would hospitals ever through out such people for lack of a cure? Why was the guy who spotted him spying on his wife wandering around outside in his dressing gown whilst carrying a gun as she rolled around on the bed?). Also, the characterisation - as we've almost come to expect in such films - was awful (e.g. the way the blonde guy - I don't remember his frickin name and don't give a toss anyway - completely turned against his girlfriend and ran off to leave her) and I ended up wanting them all to meet grisly ends! The production was horribly disjointed and the cinematography nothing to write home about.

The following comments are what you will find yourself saying out loud throughout the whole movie, "Yeah right", "What the hell?", "Oh come on." and "Yeah like that could ever happen." Im not lying. It was that lousy. A group of college students go camping in a cabin to celebrate the end of final exams. Then they meet some sick hobo who infects them all with a flesh eating virus. Don't get confused, it may sound like a good movie but it isn't. The director tried to hard to make it scary but just adding a lot of blood and a few gory scenes. They tried to hard. Simple as that. Alfred Hitchcock could scare the crap out of you without showing you hardly anything!

reviews.review_title: Eli Roth...you are NOT Sam Raimi!
reviews.content: This is one of the few movies that made me want my $7 back.I'm not some cynical film snob who always tears apart movies. I just expect to be entertained when I go to a movie. And especially, I expect to be scared, or at least grossed-out, when I see a horror movie.Sure, the actors weren't so great and it looked cheap, but it's a low-budget, B horror movie, so those are easily understandable.What I really, absolutely HATE about this movie is how much better it might've been if Eli Roth had suddenly decided he was going to remake "Evil Dead 2." Unlike Sam Raimi (the director of "Evil Dead 2," but I'm sure most you reading this already know that), Eli Roth CANNOT interject comedy into his work and still maintain the suspense and dread of a good horror film. In fact, most every single scene that might've actually been legitimately scary was completely marred by Roth's schlock attempts at comic relief. Every time, it was a complete mood killer and felt totally out of place.And the absolute worst part, the part that actually made me turn to my date (and her towards me) in the theatre and say, "What the F*CK!?!?!?" was the ending when the redneck store owner (who you think for a minute is about to shoot a couple of black people who've come into his store), suddenly starts pounding fists with them and talking in ebonics. Even remembering it makes me say, "What the F*CK!?!?!?" Do yourself a favor and just rent "Evil Dead 2" and skip this pale (and I mean ghost-white pale) imitation. Make those 2 hours actually be good for something.

I bought this movie, I remembered the trailer and thought it was going to be a really good movie. It looked like it was going to be really scary.In my opinion, it really wasn't that good a movie. They used a lot of foul language that served no purpose whatsoever, and the gratuitous scenes were pointless, with no connection to the plot at all.It was gory and disgusting, and not really scary. I mean, the idea of getting a disease like that was scary, but the way they played the characters, they were just so unlikable that you couldn't get scared because you didn't like any of them really.I think this movie is worth it if you can catch it on TV, or if it's on HBO and you already pay for it, but to rent or buy it, I don't really think it was worth the money.

Director Eli Roth has proven he's as much as a horror movie fan as he is a horror movie maker with his first feature Cabin Fever.  With obvious references made to Evil Dead, Last House on the Left and Romero's Dead series, Roth has added enough originality to have it stand on its own. Quick summary, six kids rent a cabin in the woods to party after graduating. Some freak comes by with a crazy disease that has his skin deteriorating and has him spitting up blood.  The virus this guy was carrying is contagous. Cabin Fever is a horror movie that sticks to the rules: teenage partying, sex, drugs, and lots of gore thanks to KNB Effects Studio.  While David Lynch was not credited as excecutive producer I've read he was involved with the picture.  Eli Roth has filmed for David Lynch's website, and his influence is present throughout the film.  An added bonus is some of Angelo Badalamenti's music to carry the movie through its eerie moments. During the screening at the Toronto Film Festival, Roth announced that Lion's Gate has picked up the movie and it will see the light of day at theatres in the near future. Don't miss it.

reviews.review_title: A flick about human stupidity and urban fear of the contry folk
reviews.content: Today I took in a double feature of first run films. Jeepers Creepers 2 and Cabin fever. I chose to watch JC2 because I was "saving the best for last". I had heard a TON of good things about the film Cabin Fever and was actually looking forward to seeing it. I often agree with the reviews in the NY Times (though not always) and there were several other reviews comparing it to that of Evil Dead 2, etc... In the end I found myself curious as to what movie they were watching.*** The following is to discuss plot elements within the movie and does contain spoilers ***I like a good horror flick. No, wait.. I LOVE a good horror flick. But the probability of finding a good one is growing more and more dismal. What writers/directors/producers seem to forget is the fact that it's not the blood and gore, though fun and cool in and of itself, which scares people. It's the ability to relate to the main characters then feel for them as they face the horrors presented in the course of the films. To this end I believe Eli Roth started off quite well. I went to college. While there I went on various road outings with my friends. Camping, Spring Break, Mardi Gras, etc... Yes at this point I can relate. I imagine most other people can to since I am not the single target audience on the United States of America. Where things began to go wrong for me was when the entire group was approached by the first infected man. Not a one of them had a rational thought. Now of course in the heat of the moment they all could have had a group panic that resulted the way it did. Fine. But then the movie proceeds with each main character making a series of idiotic decisions which can only be explained away as methods to keep the plot moving.For example, if my friends were in danger I would not hesitate to walk 5 miles, 10 miles, even 100 miles at night down a country road to find any sort of help what so ever. But the actors in this film walk to a house in broad daylight, find it empty and decide to go back to the cabin to drink beer. Also upon finding that their friend is infected with a serious disease decide to stick her in a shed then wait till morning to seek help. Hello, start walking someone! So yes there was the plot element of the mad dog that might have been placed there to keep them in the house or something. Give me a break. Also if they are so afraid to catch what the blond chick had why didn't they quarantine her in the room she had already bled in so much? Why move her to a shed? It's not like they are going to sleep in that bed. It wasn't gallows humor, it was just dumb. Also after being in the shed for more than a day instead of hitting the pavement during daytime and walking to the nearest town to find help, the love interest of the blond and some other chick decide to have sex. These events and the events similar lead me to one conclusion. Eli Roth made a film portraying humans in general as being selfish.Should I disagree? Should I impose upon Roth's vision of general natural human selfishness by saying at least one person should have been selfless and tried to help their comrade? The answer is no. As an artistic vision if the Writer/Director wishes to deliver a certain message then so be it. That's what art is all about right? But then other problems arise in the course of this film that go beyond artistic license and enter the realm of stupidity. Eli Roth also wishes to add an element of urban fear of the rural folk. By rural folk I don't only mean the hillbillies that run the local shop and teach their young retarded children Wu-Shu Kung fu, but also the law enforcement agencies. When the law learns of the disease the put out a radio call to shoot anyone they see infected on sight. Ummm, yeah. Then when they actually have one at the hospital the local physician suggest they take him to a bigger hospital, where the sheriff decides it'd be better to have the infected person killed. Ummm, right. What about the Centers For Disease control in Atlanta? EVERY law enforcement agency in America knows about this. EVERY hospital big or small knows about this. If an infectious disease breaks out they leap at the freaking phone in an effort to get it off their hands and get the hell out of dodge. It wasn't even mentioned and explained away in the film. It's just stupid stupid stupid. Stupid. Did I say stupid? It was ignored to create the silly irony at the end of the film. I don't know what's more goofy about that ending. The fact that the body was bleeding out into the river which would then contaminate the lemonade... or that those dumb kids found it easier to fill a 9 gallon Gatorade cooler with river water than just run tap water into it! How do you make lemonade from river water with leaves and fish and water moccasins and crap? What is this? Funny?Funny is the noise I made when the black people finally showed up. Actually no I'm not even going to touch that. That was just an ill-conceived disaster.Sorry if there are allot of type errors in this. I wrote it quickly and I'm fairly sure that my 8th grade English teacher would berate me for not having a driving focus through out this commentary. I suppose this is just my general disappointment with the film. What surprised me after my little movie marathon was that I found I disliked JC2 allot. But I expected to. What was unexpected was my dislike of Cabin Fever. That took me by surprise. Sadly.Frank

Cabin Fever is AWESOME!! Without a shadow of a doubt, one of the premier horror films ive seen in quite a while. Ryder Strong is perfect for his character, and James DeBello is amaizingly hilarious. Great acting jobs by everyone involved -  a definate 4 out of 4 stars on this one.

reviews.review_title: Doesn't live up to the hype
reviews.content: I had very high hopes for this movie. Maybe that lead to my opinion of the movie when it was over. First of all this movie should not be mention in the same breath as The Evil Dead, Texas Chainsaw, etc. It is an ok low budget horror movie at best.With that said there are a couple of things I did enjoy about Cabin Fever. I thought the acting of the five main people was pretty good for this type of movie. The premise was great, it was refreshing not to have teens running from masked killers with knives. I really liked the fact the movie did not tell you how the virus came about of where it came from. I think it is way better if you're in the dark having to guess about.However, I did not care for the script at all. I thought most of the dialouge seemed forced and mechanical. Also for all the "hype" about how much gore this movie had, I was greatly disappointed. I was hoping for Dead Alive gore and this movie did not deliver anything close to that at all. The worst thing about the movie was the secondary actors. Except for the guy who played the general store owner they were some of the worst actors ever filmed.In the end this is a good movie to rent if you've already seen Halloween, Evil Dead, Texas Chainsaw, Zombie, 28 Days Later, Dead Alive, Nightmare on Elm Street, John Carpenter's The Thing, Night of the Living Dead, Dawn of the Dead, Day of the Dead, Alien, American Werewolf in London, Dog Soldiers & The Blair Witch Project a hundred times...

We all like horror movies right?  I pretty much go see anyone that comes out, love them.  Slasher flicks, suspense, Sci-Fi you name it.  There is generally a common thread amongst the really good ones, the villain, whether perceived or actual, is scary.  At first look this one has all the hints of a good movie; it has gore, hot chicks, guns, creepy woods, and even rednecks!  How can it go wrong you ask?  Well, it has no villain.  Just some contagious flesh eating virus.  Ooooo...  Cover my eyes, I can't watch.There are some ethical, samaritan implications to the characters in the movie, which is probably why the critics dug this movie.  But really I don't care, and I didn't care about the characters either.  There are some obvious comparisons to "28 Days Later...", but this movie never reached that level of spookdom.Catch this on a matinee, or wait for video.  Save your money for a horror movie that has actual horror.

I've been reading a lot of the user comments and it seems that 90 percent of people are completely clueless about this movie.  Eli Roth is making fun of horror movies, not trying to make the next "Halloween."  In fact, I think this movie is better than any of the "Scary Movie" films, as Roth mixes in the humor with an actual horror story.  If you can't see this from the abundance of jokes and the hilarious ending, than I feel sorry for your stupidity.  Great job Eli Roth and I can't wait for the dvd of "The Rotten Fruit" to come out.

reviews.review_title: the classic cabin in the woods
reviews.content: But now with viruses and some good looking young people getting chomped from the inside.

I saw the whole movie, and it just shown how nothing happened. Kid bit a man, but that lead nowhere. Girl got her face eaten, but that lead nowhere. Guy who didn't get infected gets shot. Infected guy infects water. Guy who dropped N-bomb is friends with random black people. The black people, by the way, are pretty much just giant stereotypes. Don't worry, they only appear for five seconds just for a joke. In short, people get flesh eating virus, they die. End of story. Everybody go home.

reviews.review_title: Catch the cabin fever and you'll get a few hours of fun!
reviews.content: I'm wondering how people can hate this movie?When I was on my way to order this movie,one friend told me:''Please,don't buy that movie,it's awful!'' I decided to buy it,because I wanted to see if he's right.When I saw the movie,I was shocked!Fever,which has come into these people on very unusual way,totally freaked me out!I couldn't believe that someone can have so sick ideas for movie like this.And,I like sick things.Horror is genre of the movie which has to scare and fright people!I don't like horror movies that are very passive and that doesn't have a point.But,boy,this movie has a point...And it has a very good point!Really,is it possible to catch the fever?Of course it is.So,this can be very possible in the real life and that is something that scares me a lot.I also like movies with zombies,unreal creatures,but also I know the doesn't exist.But the fever does,so...?I hope you can understand me.This movie is very sick (in right meaning of that word) and I loved it! I give this movie 9/10 because there are some things that I didn't like too much.But,disregard this,the movie rocks!

There's a new King of Horror, and that guys name is Eli Roth.  This is how a horror film should be made.  Tight, funny and keeps you pinned to your seat. You have to see it for yourself to understand Roth's brilliance. Totally blows away those Hollywood gumball horror flicks.

reviews.review_title: Disappointing would be the only word to describe this movie
reviews.content: I saw previews for this movie when it came out and it genuinely looked good but at the time I wasn't old enough to see it in theaters, so when it came out on video I decided to rent it. BIG mistake, I'm not really sure if it was supposed to be a horror movie or a comedy. Its the story of 5 friends who go camping in the woods after finals and they catch this flesh eating virus that kills them. This movie lacked substance and special effects the gore wasn't "gory" it just looked like bad make up. The only remotely interesting part was when the kid screams out "PANCAKES!" and that's not saying much. The acting was sub par, this should have been a straight to video movie. Bottom line don't waste you're money renting it, just watch it at 3 a.m. when nothing else is on TV.

This is the most enjoyable horror movie ive seen since Evil Dead, it has blood guts girls comedy and best of all rider strong who was sean in boy meets world he totally rocks in this movie and hope to see him in scavanger hunt. I am 16 years old and would also like to make a movie as bad ass as this one was. thanks 4 the movie Eli

I saw this at SXSW in Austin with five friends.  It was amazing.  We all loved it.  It's funny, grotesque, and scary.  Half of the fun was hearing all of Eli Roth's crazy stories in the Q&A.  I will definitely buy the DVD to hear all these stories again.  I highly recommend that everyone in the entire world view this movie.  I hear it's coming out August 2003.

reviews.review_title: WHAT THE HECK IS THE MATTER WITH YOU PEOPLE!!!
reviews.content: Ok, so this movie wasn't Night of the Living Dead, Evil Dead, or TCM, but for this day and age, this is about as close as anyone making films has the guts to do, aside from Rob Zombie.  You people who are knocking this probably think Scream & I know What You Did Last Summer are good "Horror" movies....and to that I say NOT!!  Those movies SUCK!!!!  Come on people; have you all forgotten the great horror movies from the 80's and 70's? Those were truly horror movies.  Today, film makers try and try again to make movies that don't offend mom or dad, and call them horror movies!  At least Eli Roth has stuck to the theory that there doesn't need to be an in depth storyline, plot, or solid character development when all of the character are gonna die anyway!!!!  He just dealt with the mass hysteria of what happens when there is a disease that is killing your friends and you don't want to get it!  Good lord, I bet all you people knocking this don't even appreciate the Evil Dead Trilogy!!!  I bet if ya'll watched them, you'd be like this sucks and stuff when to the contrary they are some of the best genre movies of ALL time!!!!!It just never ceases to amaze me when I go catch a good horror flick, then come here and read all the reviews repeatedly bashing it.I think all ya'll that think this one sucked need to get a membership to NetFlix, and catch up on REAL HORROR MOVIES!!!!!

I saw this movie for the first time because i was intrigued... i had heard mixed reviews.  I heard that the ending kinda sucked (which it did a little, but the scene with the african americans made me laugh really hard, just because it wasn'twhat i expected).  the beginning dragged.  It was an hour into the movie before anything REALLY happened, and being it was only an hour and a half moviethey packed all the gory stuff into the last half an hour, interesting tactic and it scared the hell out of me.  I watched this movie with my boyfriend at midnight and for half of the last half i closed my eyes.  SPOILER: the scene where Rider Strong is rubbing Jordan's leg did me in.  After that when i knew there was going to be a gross part i turned away.  Mind you this movie isn't that scary but you really don't expect half of the stuff to happen that does and when it does happen it's extremely gross and disgusting, I have disected a number of animals incollege and don't have a problem, to say that this movie grossed me out sayssomething for it. I would indeed reccomend this movie to people: it is a good movie to watch with friends.  If you're looking for a movie that is scary watch it, if you're looking for a movie with great acting throughout the entire movie, you may not want to watch. the beginning is a little rough, especially the scene when the guy comes with the weed. Overall i give this movie a 4 out of 5, it did what it intended to do, but there are rough spots that everyone criticizes the entire movie for (let's just say the movie should have ended five minutes before because the last scene didn't follow the darkness of the previous 45 minutes)

reviews.review_title: At first I disliked it, Watch more than once and you realize that it is brilliant!!
reviews.content: This is one of the movies that requires more than one viewing to understand the brilliance behind it. Listen to the commentary of the director, it is hilarious! I don't know if he realizes it but the line stroke after stroke in the shaving of the legs scene in commentary is intentionally or not, funny as hell. I have always been a horror movie fan, as is the director, Obvious upon viewing. This director is destined to great things and well deserved. This is only my second review, I only write when I feel strongly upon a subject. This film needs more than one viewing to appreciate it, the not in your face underlining humor! I wish the director much luck in the future, he didn't quit. I wish I had it in me to have followed my dreams like the director has (I think at 41 it is to late, to start over) . Do yourself a favor watch the movie repeated times to appreciate its true brilliance. It is amazing how you dislike a movie at first and then watch again and see the underlying brilliance. Don't miss this gem!!!!

I must have missed the promotion campaign around this movie, I went in without any expectations. I found myself holding my hand in front of my mouth throughout the movie, it was so disgustingly well done! I think I heard some people toss their cookies in the theatre :) The special effects and atmosphere redeem any fault to the plot (Where did the virus/bacteria/plague come from, what's the story behind the hillbillies/strange child, there was more potential here) Also the acting held up for the whole cast, compared to half the other teen-horror movies around. I wouldn't mind sequel (Maybe with the new visitors from the ending?)7/10 Grosss!!

reviews.review_title: too gruesome to be hollywood, too exhausting to be cult
reviews.content: cabin fever was without a doubt one of the worst movies ever made. most people who say "this movie is going to be a cult classic" or "it was meant to be ridiculous", honestly i don't care, i'm a fan of indie/cult movies but this movie was so set on being bad that you can see exactly when the writers give up...right when the dogs stomach spits blood on the first infected guy. gay and f**k are probably heard more than the screams the sometime actors and actresses scream so effectively. sarcasm is dangerous. if peter jackson said this was one of the greatest horror movies of our time i don't want him making any kind of horror movie. the out of style social commentary and the usual slack jawed yokels appear in the film as well as a campfire story that has nothing to do with anything really, oh yeah watch out for the stoner guy who has no signifigance except his pot, and the kid who screams pancake and bites people, it's really quite nice. try to laugh if you're not to disgusted and if you're not disgusted try to laugh. i spent my time looking up at the projector. the trailer for kill bill is ok and there's some sex here and there. sex, drugs, beer, blood, guts, rednecks, sluts, innocence, guns, squirrels, and ravage dogs. people like eli roth are killing the horror genre, danny boyle will save us all.

Those of you that have seen both of these movies will know what I mean when I say they are too simliar for it to be a coincident.  Both are about remote locations and extreme cases of violence and murder.  The thing that I find most simliar is the tone and style in which the murder is presented.  The movies also show what happens when normal people meet extreme situations. The music is also very simliar as it is almost ticking away at disaster. The movie also does what few movies of quality have the gonads to do, they end the movie without a point being made.  Movies are meant to entertain while some do educate or provoke discusion some just have no point and were never meant too.  The only meaning I see from  both movies is that when we are in stressful situations it cause us to do the wrong thing.

reviews.review_title: Just please put them out of our misery!
reviews.content: This film lacked the one important thing that I like in my films.....entertainment!!The characters were flat. The storyline was unexciting. The entire movie had me shaking my head at the end and realizing that those were a couple of hours of my life I would never get back.What did I like best about the movie? Some of the cinematography was great. Those lovely fall leaves in that outdoor setting. However, I don't go to the movies to see the same setting i can get by taking a walk at a forest preserve near my home.What did I like least about the movie? Well it started at the opening credits....and seemed to last until the final bonfire was lit.This movie seemed to lack a consistency, a solid plot, solid acting (but I don't blame that on the actors as they had nothing to work with), and just a desperate need of something to cling to making it interesting in any aspect.And what was in that darn box? There were too many attempts to introduce something interesting and then it was just left unfinished each time. There seemed to be many paths the writers were taking us on but we only were led down yet another tangent each time there was hope.

reviews.review_title: If you like horror and fun check this one out!
reviews.content: I don't understand why people are so critical of this film. There are countless tributes to older horror films, and it brings back a certain light heartedness and fun to horror films that have been absent for years. The gore factor is unbelievably superior to any film in the past 5 years. The important thing to remember though is that this movie was not made to compete with other films for best picture. The director (whose appearance in the film should clue you in that hes not taking too much serious ) is not making a film to bend your mind or scare you more than any other film, he is just trying to make you have some fun. Which many of you obviously never do considering your opinions on this movie. Just remember the film is called Cabin Fever and it has a member from Boy Meets World in it. It is not supposed to be "Citizen Kane". Overall i rate it an 8/10!

reviews.review_title: True American film values at their best
reviews.content: A display of true Americal values; shot with quintessential American intelligence and displaying the finest of American acting talent.Thank heavens for British cinema!This film has absolutely no redeeming features, save for the fact that all of the main, valley-speak, clichéd characters end up dead. Perhaps the greatest tragedy here is that the 'actors' themselves will of course remain very much alive to spawn similar rubbish. Like most American film these days this complete waste of time offers no artistic value whatsoever. The one-dimensional characters do not even offer a parody of Americans today, as anyone who has had the misfortune of encountering dumb American youth can attest to.

reviews.review_title: Clever Slasher Flick, Doesn't Follow General Formula
reviews.content: Eli Roth uses clever techniques to produce a picture called Cabin Fever that brings about a fear of a flesh-eating disease that the kids catch throughout the movie. The characters are done quite well, the standout though is Rider Strong with this big-screen performance as the helpless-hero. The twists and turns this movie brings the audience through very much help the idea of the virus having a life and being able to influence others. Eli Roth did a great job with this film and this picture should not be missed by fans of great clever horror films that don't follow the general formula.

Half the time we were laughing, half the time we were going, "Ew."  There was no fear here.  The gore effects were awesome, if you're into horror FX, but I wouldn't say this movie was scary.  You barely cared about anybody in the movie and, in fact, most of the people, we openly wished would die painfully soon.  We kept wondering if it was a black comedy, but it missed the mark about 60% of the time.  Bottom line?  If you want to see something gross and halfway funny, watch this.  Want to watch a scary virus movie? Try 28 Days Later.

reviews.review_title: One of the funniest movies I have ever seen.
reviews.content: I know this movie is a horror movie, but it was more funny than scary. First of all, Bert's constantly funny (squirrels are gay,dog story,etc.),but the main humor comes from Dennis,the little handicap kid with a mullet doing karate Matrix-style in the air and yelling "Pancake!"  for no apparent reason. This flick was disturbing (it's no Exorcist though), however, and incredibly gruesome, but I still recommend it to anyone who wants to laugh so hard they cry,get their heart beating fast,and feel queasy within an hour and a half.

"Cabin Fever"......well, it was ok because it went back to the old days of horror movies where everybody died and there where no heros....but it wasn't ok because there was no plot what so ever. They never gave you a history of the virus or the town. They told you why the people in the town weren't dieing and why the kid on the porch at the store was crazy? Anybody understand that? Ok horror movie,lots of blood and death....but terrible......terrible plot.Mike

I didn't know much about this movie, but I love new horror so I watched it. Sure, it borrows a lot from classic horror flicks, but Eli Roth mixes it together in a unique blend. I was really surprised at how much I enjoyed it. Just the right mix of all the things that make horror fun.

I just want to say that this movie is totally awesome! It is one of the best combinations of horror and comedy into a film that I have seen in a long time! I am disappointed that so many people are willing to so quickly judge it... and also that people include inaccurate statements in their reviews (they aren't sweating blood... a duh, they have a flesh-eating bacterial infection which would obviously cause sores!!)People try to take parts of this movie way too seriously. It is obvious that the writers put in certain characters purely as jokes (for instance Deputy Winston or Dennis {the hand-biter}). And they most certainly succeed! I was laughing my pants off during the "Pancakes!!! PANCAKES!!!" scene. They also do an awesome job at atmospheric horror, something which not too many screenwriters and directors accomplish these days. The whole movie leaves you uncomfortable in your seat... starting with the opening credits and the background music.All in all, this is one kickin' movie!!!!

Please children, stop slamming great horror achievements unless you've done your homework first.  Everyone in the know will be championing this for some time and with good reason.  See kids, those of us who grew up watching all the B horror movies from back in the day realize what real horror movies are supposed to achieve.  Like how funny it is to see someone cut up their girlfriend with a chainsaw or how refreshing it can be to see zombies eating "BRAINS!" out of a bloody skull.  Get it now?  No, I didn't think so either. Eli Roth and crew have opened up a can of maggot infested worms with this gem.  I think everything about this flick is incredible e.g. plot,acting,dialogue and deserves its place in any horror fans collection. It pays homage to all the greats by extracting the essence of old school horror and laces it with a nu skool twist.  To all the disbelievers, stick to jeepers creepers and resident "what a great plot" evil and tell Flo to kiss my grits, noonch.  Blaze up for the rotten fruit and support indie horror.  nuff said.

This film in my eyes when I watched the first time I was ticked about wasting time on it. I went back and forth form liking it to hating it and back and forth. For me that was the rise and fall of it what's worse is when I got done with the movie in the first place and I knew I didn't like it I wasn't positive on all the reasons why. Then in an effort to either to understand why I didn't like it or try to like it I watched it a couple more times. Now I can tolerate it, but I have some serious issues with it.This movie seemed like the kind of film that wanted to strike a cord with us that this could really happen. But the film is bogged down by moments of unrealism or drastic stupidity on the part of the characters in the film. The gore and the subject matter were great and not ever really explored in the film and the paranoia in the film is almost indicative of "The Thing" and for some of the smarter characters you genuinely feel sorry for all the stuff that they go though but for those good things there was a bunch of things which brought the film down for me.The biggest of it is that the characters are stupid and the main characters only together seem to have a full brain between them. They seem to do the dumbest crap in trying to survive this or cope with this, why I can only speculate. Examples are this (spoiler alert); if there is a flesh eating virus would you shave your legs? No one would this was added just to add gore, I like gore but not for stupid reasons or the sake of adding it. If there's a flesh eating virus around and you find a body rotting in a lake would you climb down a splintering ladder to get a closer look? I would have accepted the idea he got the disease randomly better then this, until this moment I thought this character was smart and worth surviving. If you have a flesh eating virus would you AIM for people to vomit contaminated blood on? And NO DOCTOR in any hospital (I would have bought a local doctor), have let a contaminated patient to be gotten rid of, EVERYONE in the medical field knows about the CDC. Those are just some of the examples of unrealistic stupidity, or things done for stupid reasons for the sake of other reasons. Some stuff was just too stupid for thought; "Pancakes!", Harmonica (stupid, unrealistic and sadly done to make us laugh during a truly messed up (in an almost cool way) scene.I wasn't sure if I was watching a horror, comedy or spoof; but it didn't balance in the slightest. The only reason I give this a 4 is for the subject, gore and cool partsand I final thought on it, I wonder if Jordan Ladd was the only character with a brain and never got to use it, because the characters seemed doomed from the start. Worth a watch but it's on TV or it will be; great gore and cool subject try and enjoy :)

I thought it was going to be a gore fest, with the usual silly supernatural junk, but instead it had no supernatural nonsense at all, and was a disturbing horror movie in the old time vintage. I enjoyed it, and what I think is the killer touch, is the  "rotten fruit" stuff on the DVD -- if you haven't seen that, you gotta get the DVD and see the rotten fruit stuff -- it ROCKS

I thought it was going to be a gore fest, with the usual silly supernatural junk, but instead it had no supernatural nonsense at all, and was a disturbing horror movie in the old time vintage. I enjoyed it, and what I think is the killer touch, is the "rotten fruit" stuff on the DVD -- if you haven't seen that, you gotta get the DVD and see the rotten fruit stuff -- it ROCKS

This movie rocked!I was expecting another mediocre teen horror flick, something along the lines of the Texas Chainsaw Massacre remake (which over-shadowed Cabin Fever's release here in Australia), what I got was slick, in-your-face horror, that didn't take itself too seriously.Director, writer and producer, Eli Roth's directorial debut pays homage to classic horror films of the seventies and eighties; 'The Evil Dead', 'Texas Chainsaw Massacre' amongst others. His admiration of former employer David Lynch is apparent in Roth's eerie mise en' scene and kooky camera work. I have to recommend watching the film more than once, and if possible, getting your hands on the DVD version with featurette and director's commentary. Roth (who is only 32) provides a witty and entertaining insight into his warped world. Look out for the 'finger-bang misfire', 'Jake the dog' and 'the shaving' segment.Roth's script is funny in itself. The lead characters aren't particularly likeable, (who is nowadays?) but appearances from quirky minor characters make up for it. Look out for Dennis the Kung Fu kid, The partying cop and the quirky townsfolk. Also watch out for Roth who plays 'Grim' in a cool cameo. The blood and gore factor is enough to satisfy even the most seasoned horror fan - It is amazing what can be done with a bit of syrup, some KY jelly and food dye.What makes this film enjoyable, on repeat screenings, is that it becomes evident that no-one takes it too seriously. It isn't afraid to poke a little fun at itself. Horror is Roth's passion. His love, and his enthusiasm appears to rub off on the rest of the cast and crew. There is no wanky pretentiousness about it, you rent a film like 'Cabin Fever', and you aren't expecting 'art' - Roth has no illusions about this, and it's is incredibly refreshing.You won't enjoy this film if you are squeamish, or don't enjoy horror in general. It *is* violent, it *is* in you face and it sure as hell will make you cringe at least once. But if horror is your scene crack open some beers, turn the lights down and watch it with some friends. Don't try to over-analyse it, or read anything into it, just sit back and ENJOY it!(Oh... And stay out of the woods)

Well, seeing as this comment comes way down the list it's debatable whether it will ever get seen. But anyway, after seeing this film torn to shreds by many of the other comments I really felt the need to say something.It seems that those taking pleasure in trashing the film are blissfully unaware that this film "is" original, that it "is" funny and most importantly that it most certainly "is" worth watching.Having worked in many video shops and enjoying the darker side of humour it's safe to say that I've seen almost every horror film that's been produced. With the exception of very few films. I've seen things that have genuinely chilled me, scared the pants off me or just those strange films which you don't really understand, look like they've been created with a budget of £2.50 which was spent mainly on Tomato Ketchup and were worth watching purely because they were SO bad. Then I've seen things that were, just bad. Truly awful films not worth the packaging they were in.I'm not going to spend paragraphs comparing Eli Roth to anyone else, or the film to anything else. I could if I wanted to, yes. But I'm not going to.OK... It's a horror film, it contains many elements of horror, things of a horrible nature. It's not a pretentious film, it doesn't claim to be the next best thing or totally unique. What it is a superb homage to the classic horror films of the 70's & 80's. You might say, "Oh, how unoriginal". To which I'd reply. "Shut up". There are many little gestures to classics such as "Dawn of the Dead", "Evil Dead" & "Texas Chainsaw Massacre". Note I said gestures, this film is not a rip-off, in any way. Just because it has a flesh eating killer disease in it doesn't mean it's ripped from Outbreak. It makes me feel sad on the inside because I need to point that out to some people.I can name at least five films containing a deadly virus, ten with a group of teenagers facing death by various methods etc.. etc... Happy teenage holiday death by number films are a genre in their own right nowadays and Cabin Fever adds the extra spice, the flood of bloody gore and the all important touch of originality to the aforementioned HTHDBN's scene.Eli Roth has made a fantastic directorial debut with Cabin Fever, it's refreshingly different, the filming is beautiful, the score is absolutely fantastic, the acting is perfect for the genre and yes it's a group of teenagers getting killed off one by one. But.... (By God!) they do it with style. The film doesn't rely on the effects, which are amazing (no CGI, just good old fashioned make up, instead they're there to make you grab the person sitting next to you as hard as you can and go OHMYGOD! That's DISGUSTING!. Rightly so, they are.
