It's not just shock value, they're necessary and damnit they're perfect for the nature of the film.I've noticed that many people are unhappy because the origins of the virus were left unclear. Umm, so what? This wasn't supposed to be a documentary, it's not a film that will provide the answers to life's deepest questions. You decide where it came from, go on, be creative. Don't expect people to do everything for you. Much though it would be fun to argue the technical points of the flesh eating virus and where it came from, it really is unnecessary. It's not important, it's just there and film comes into it's own when those poor happy teenagers have to deal with the effects of the virus on their friends and themselves. The disintegration of the group as a whole and on an individual basis, per character, was extremely interesting to watch and stunningly acted.The plot... the plot is there, it doesn't wander there's a distinct thread that's carried through the entire film. From it's beginning to it's ironical end.Cabin Fever is one of the best horror films I've seen for a long time, I love the gore, I love the humour, I really love the music and it's definitely worth watching the DVD for the extras which were excellent and included one of the best "making of" featurettes I've ever seen.If you're a fan of "real" horror films then you'll love Cabin Fever. If you're not I'm terribly sorry for you because you'll just feel sad, cheated and you'll have an overwhelming desire to complain about everything because the film wasn't your kind of thing. Meh.

reviews.review_title: Not TOO bad of a fever to catch.
reviews.content: *may contain spoilers*I saw Cabin Fever in the theatre with my friends when it first came out. All three of us came out of the theatre saying, "Eh..."  But when it came out on DVD, and I actually watched it again, I didn't think it was that bad.For one, it's a break from the standard "guy killing people" movies.  It's a virus that has no origin, and no way of stopping it, which is a scary thought in it of itself.This movie is more aimed towards the teenage generation.  I don't think my mother would enjoy this movie.  There are more modern elements of sex and drugs present that adults might not want to see.It's funny in some parts.  The scary parts make you grossed out more than they make you scream.  I.E: there's a lot of blood and gore, such as a guy's head blowing up (by a shotgun) and splattering on the wall.I give credit to Eli Roth for the directing.  The special effects are wonderfully done, as is the editing and the cinematography.Rating, probably 2.5 stars out of 5.

First off I love Eli Roth and if you are a fan of him, you are going to be a fan of this movie. Second every single actor in this movie played their characters perfectly. Phenomenal jobs! The movie has everything I love in a movie. Gags, thrills, scares, comedy, love, sacrifice, etc. The love story is what made this movie sad. I mean think about it. Your going camping to a cabin with all your best friends because you just graduated college and all of a sudden their fleshed diseased skin starts pealing off and they become outraged in killing sprees with each other. To be terrified of my best friends because I don't want to get it is one thing but to have to kill them too in exchange of them suffering from it any longer is horrifying. It was awesome in the theater and even better watching it still till' this day.

Cabin fever is about a group of college friends who rent a cabin in the middle of the woods for a week. one by one the friends starts getting a mysterious disease that eats away at their flesh! This movie isn't much of a horror but is very entertaining. There is a good amount of gore and is quite funny in places. I really enjoyed this movie and would definitely recommend watching it. i hear the second one is rubbish so i wont bother watching that! i know a lot of people hate cabin fever but i don't see why?? i think the sex scenes were pretty pointless but every film has its downfalls! I'd give this film a 9/10. i highly recommend it!!! :-)

me and my friend were in tears throughout this film, especially towards the end! it just kept getting better and better! this is one of the best horror-comedies i've seen. i was really surprised that it was so good, i was basically expecting another teen-actor-vessel. but this is very much old-school and definite classic material! i couldn't believe they made a movie like this in our day and age, it's comparable to golden oldies like maybe even The Thing (70s version)... or Creepshow 2's The Raft with a much better spin on it. it's kinda twisted, gross and sooo hilarious, and unlike too many horror movies, the actors here don't take themselves too seriously. lets face it, this movie is for fun-loving people who love gore, sick humor and beer!the effects are also great! my friend is a make up artist and she was also really impressed.

reviews.review_title: a great film made on a tiny budget
reviews.content: having watched films such as phone booth, Blair witch and cabin fever you can only come to the conclusion that the majority of good films are made with smaller budgets, this is especially true for horror films, the 70s and 80s were perfect for basic horror films with basic effect that looked raw and realistic. once u start messing around with CGI etc you lose the effect. Cabin Fever does a superb job of going back to the old school with a very minimal budget Eli Roth manages to achieve a film that is sickly disturbing with a good plot and interesting characters. just goes to show what you can do with the simple necessities: a good director, a relatively unknown cast and simple special effects, a great film well worth watching!

OK, so it maybe 5am, but this is a movie worth watching. It isn't your typical gruesome horror flick but instead a gruesome comedy full of laughs. It starts like many slasher movies, five college students off to a cabin in the woods. They start their partying and then...in enters the hermit, who turns out to have a gruesome flesh eating illness - that you guessed it - proceeds to infect the kids one by one. Instead of ending up like the usual slasher movies, Eli Roth takes you on a roller coaster of feelings from shock to laughter. You are never sure what you will be feeling or seeing (a guy in a bunny suit?) from one moment to the next. A never ending ride all the way from the start to the very end and beyond. I am still laughing!

IF you loved SAW, SAW2, House of Wax, Freddy vs Jason, alone in the dark, fog(2005) etc.. then this film probably isn't for you. This film is aimed at those who like alternative horror, its a p**s-take of the current wave of absolute dire remakes and re-workings of the 'bunch of teenagers running around screaming' type. If you love the evil dead films then you'll know what to expect.The film starts out like any other teen horror film. Bunch of annoying kids going on a trip(i didn't want to watch any more at this point as i though i knew what was going to happen). As not to spoil it i won't say too much but the film takes an abrupt turn and messes around with the protagonists in all manner of insane situations. This is not a horror film it is a comedy horror. I hadn't laughed so much in ages. This is not ripping off anything, its almost a homage to Evil dead, night of the living dead and any other gore fest. It doesn't have to have a point of a reason for everything just treat it as a bit of fun.

Usual horror stuff in this one. Only really watched it because Marcy has great boobs!! But it was very good and funny. If the outback of America was like this, no one would go there! The special effects were good and the acting excellent for a low budget slasher. The plot line is a bit out there and the ending gives someone a reason to make Cabin Fever 2. And the rednecks at the end drinking the water mans that they all get infected and then spread it to their family and friends and so on and so on! This could be the next black plague when it gets out of the out back of the US and then onto the world. Doesn't take itself too serious and of course Marcy is a knockout! Pity she gets infected and ends up dying like every one else.

this movie was great sort of until the end. i didn't like it. it ended on a down note. which is usually good. Like in the empire strikes back. but i Ryder Strongs character dies nobody listens and where do they throw him back in the lake and the kids make lemonade. i mean what was the deal with the grandpa and the uh black no African Americans.( so nobody is offended.) can anybody explain the little Dennis boy. the stupid Winston or Wilson cop. the leg shaving scene ouch why did that chick keep on shaving. and i was wondering where Eli Roth (grim) was the whole plot was missing until that ending happened. all of this was crammed into a so-so movie but i heard a rumor that there is a sequel.

I actually found Cabin Fever quite amusing after I realised it wasn't going to be a scary horror movie. I guess it is occasionally frightening, in that way you expect from this genre, in semi-darkened scenes with that eerie music. It does remind me of the "Evil Dead" movies in terms of over-the-top gore, but I was still hoping for more of that somehow. Similar premise to the first Evil Dead movie too, in a way - a bunch of college kids go stay in a cabin in the woods somewhere remote and bad stuff begins to happen.I was expecting to be blown away by it and so was initially disappointed, but on coming back to it - to particular amusing scenes - I get dragged back into watching it, it's somehow very addictive. I've forced a few people to watch a couple of my favourite parts of this movie, and they've generally cringed and laughed and probably wondered what the attraction is... It is very stupid at times, but that's becoming a plus for me.I really like the occasional random stuff and the strange dialogue at times. The characters might not have been very well developed, but they work well enough for me in this film. And there are moments of shocking gore, which is really what I was after in the first place. It seems to have been very well made - well much greater quality than Evil Dead #1 and Bad Taste - which was all I was hoping for. I'd give it 6.5 if I could.

OK -- you'll be horrified by what five college students find 'round their lonely cabin deep in the the woods. And you'll enjoy the homages paid by the the director, cinematographer and music director to every other film in the genre. But see this film in order to find out what the 85-year-old gay shopkeeper/arms-merchant calls his African-American clients; what food the 12-year-old porch potato and Jackie Chan wannabe obsesses about; what the sheriff's deputy with the unchecked libido uses for wheels; why the unsuccessful shoplifter stole the Snickers bar; what Henry's butch sister has hanging in her garage that upsets her so much; why the general store has a sign that says "Don't Sit Next to Dennis," and why Eli Roth told the audience at the San Francisco International Film Festival that they were "sick."

This is a great ribald comedy / horror flic in the tradition of Evil Dead ( which was itself misunderstood when it first came out ). You pretty much despise all the characters the moment you set eyes on them. They're there for the directors disposal ( literally and otherwise ! ) in various gruesome but funny scenes one after the other. In some ways it is more subversive than Evil Dead in that we are almost on the side of the flesh eating virus and the locals. Po-faced critics attack scenes as "ridiculous" or "that undercut the horror" - it's obvious that they don't get it what this film's about ! The movie is almost worth seeing for a joke which starts at the beginning of the movie but whose pay off we see only at the end - and it's a classic ! If people are still watching with a straight face by the end of this film then ... well, there is no hope for them !

saw this movie at a sneak preview.  follows many of the classic horror film formulas.this movie was so bad that i found myself loving every minute of it.  the audience seemed to have a lot of fun.the only thing better than a great film is a really bad one...this definitely qualifies.

reviews.review_title: Amazing rehash of the horror genre
reviews.content: I cant believe all of you morons writing a review for a genre you obviously don't understand. Cabin Fever is great on all accounts. In an era where Hollywood is trying to capitalize on everything and ruining the Horror genre (aka Texas Chainsaw remake, Freddy vs. Jason, etc,), CF totally gives its nods to classic genre defining films and directors (Romero, Hooper, Craven, Jackson, to mention a few). The key era of Horror in my opinion, and most other Horror enthusiasts, was the 70s and 80s (low budget B movies to be exact). Where do you think such amazing directors of Hollywood got their start? Peter Jackson- from "Bad Taste" and "Dead Alive" to "The Lord of the Rings," and Sam Raimi- from "Evil Dead" to "Spiderman." Why remake classic movies into some horrible high budget blockbuster (Texas Chainsaw, Amityville Horror, etc.) when you can just remake the genre in a way? Everything is all about being retro these days. Musically for example, the whole "garage rock" movement is being regurgitated through the likes of horrible bands like the White Stripes and the Strokes trying to be a new version of the Stooges. At least Eli Roth (director of Cabin Fever) knows where he is coming from. Cabin Fever is for the true fans of B Horror. If you respect movies like Zombie, Basketcase, Maniac, Night/Day/Dawn of the (Living) Dead, then Cabin Fever will be your new favorite. I was honestly skeptical about seeing the movie after new mainstream horror movies, but buying Cabin Fever was the right choice. Humor and gore make horror. No matter what you say. Cabin Fever is hilarious and gory enough for horror lovers. I am looking forward to seeing Roth's movies that he is planning currently. on a footnote...I was so into this movie that I watched it approximately 5 times in the first couple of days I had it. As a matter of fact, I'm watching it right now.

I am in love with this movie!!! I got it because I love James DeBello and I was very pleased with how well it turned out! I think all the actors were perfect for their roles and the story line was amazing! I like the idea of doing a horror movie without just a killer you have to get away from. I also thought that the humor fit perfectly with the movie and I loved the acting done by James DeBello! He was by far my favorite actor in this movie but I thought all the actors did an amazing job and made the story very believable! I was so sad to see all the characters die in this movie! This movie got you to know and like the characters, and it was sad to see them die. But it worked for the movie and I enjoyed it very much! I watched this movie over and over again and I think I will in the future! Well mad props guys and I hope you love watching it as much as me!

reviews.review_title: Best original horror movie of the 00's.
reviews.content: Cabin Fever is excellent horror flick, and it does a wonderful job at what it sets out to do. It's a (genuinely) funny horror movie with an original plot (which is rare these days), good acting, GREAT gore, an excellent score, and some fantastic all around weirdness thrown in for fun. I honestly don't understand the negative criticism this movie receives. What is it that people don't like? The tension? The nudity? The death scenes? The violence? The humor? The hopelessness? If so, then what the hell are you doing watching horror movies!? This isn't Final Destination. It's a real deal old school style horror flick. I can only assume the critics were born post 1990 and unfortunately raised on garbage such as Jeepers Creepers. Sad.

This was one of the funniest movies I have seen recently.  I liked the gore-humor combo and the special features and multiple commentaries are entertaining.  Just want to say this movie isn't for everyone, especially those that can't watch a movie without analyzing everything.

This is one of the first horror movies from the US that's actually frightened me in a long time, and also strayed from the usual recipe...Basically four friends go off to a cabin in the woods as an end of term treat, they open the door to a man asking for help, however due to his appearance they refuse to help and then beat him when he tries to steal their truck, and end up setting fire to him. This, along with a local family of rednecks with a wierd son who has a biting fetish adds to the story...What a film!

It's a fun horror film to watch but certainly isn't the best. What it lacks in plot and storyline it makes up for in very, very gory deaths. The start is good but towards the end it sort of loses it. Funny in parts but not enough to make it an amazing film.

This movie has the ability to spawn hundreds of inside jokes and inspire night after night of shenanigans. I think the problem that most people have with Cabin Fever is that they take it too seriously. I feel the same way about this movie as I do about Shaun of the Dead and other movies like it, there are countless nods to Horror classics, buckets of gore, randomness galore, and more soda-spewing-laugh-out-loud moments than you can shake a stick at. Not to mention, a ridiculous plot, and a former sitcom heart-throb for a main character. Oh yeah, and one more thing... pancakes!!! How can you go wrong?Get a bunch of your campy-horror loving friends together with tons of snacks and possibly alcohol, preferably sometime around 3ish in the morning, and pop in the DVD. Try not to cringe as the flesh-eating virus ravages the college students one by one, then try not to pee your pants as Dennis launches into impromptu kung fu, Bert shoots squirrels, and you experience the very first on-screen death by harmonica. Whoever said this movie is a waste of time is seriously disturbed.
If you don't like this movie your dumb...prove me wrong

I loved this movie.  Nauseating, unnerving, funny, gross, and cool.  Well worth my money and definitely worth a second viewing.  I enjoyed the off beat pacing and homage paid to different great horror movies from the 70's and eighties - each nod with a unique spin making the movie it's own.  The story, performances, and effects present a unique patchwork of paranoia, fear, hopelessness and isolation.If your brain absolutely needs each and every movie you see to follow a strict formula so as to not challenge your ritalin addled, ADD mind - stay home and watch football or "scream 12" or "I know what you did last friday in the ring".  You will probably focus on the fact that the "killer" is not a conscious being, or the odd humor and characters that the director throws in here and there and then, unable to handle any departures from the cookie cutter world of entertainment you've been weened on, begin to whine and complain that this is the worst movie ever.
While it has a new and interesting premise behind the story, it ultimately relies too much on homages to better films and feature awful characters that you can stand to watch.

Most of the movie is set in daylight or artificial lighting - this takes guts, but it pays off: most decent horror movies have an element of this, but Cabin Fever excels in it. A nice change.Most of us associate (in a psychological context) the dark with fear, evil etc.... therefore, in my case, I find 'horror/thriller' movies containing predominately dark scenes largely predictable and hackneyed.Three great horror films which reject (mostly) this dark staple:1 Dawn of the Dead (Romero) 2 Rosemary's Baby 3 The ExorcistWhile Cabin Fever is not in the same league as these classics, it certainly holds its own as a refreshing addition to the very tired horror movie genre.

I have mixed emotions about horror movies. the VAST majority are lame and far-fetched, but a few break that exception. Cabin Fever does! The concept of a fast & dangerous virus is highly plausible... and Cabin Fever summarizes things well. I recommend Cabin Fever to anyone who at least kinda/sorta likes horror flicks, but finds most to be stupid and far- fetched. (I'll admit a bonus for me is Diane Ladd. Her Mom was my favorite "Angel": not Farrah Fawcett. :-) )By the way, a variation over plausibility involves the movie 28 days Later. I never got thr concept behind zombie flicks, the the "Rage" virus seems highly likely.

reviews.review_title: A hilarious and shocking experience at the 15th International Toronto Film Festival 2002
reviews.content: I caught this at the 2002 Toronto Film Festival. It was the final 'Midnight Madness' movie and it sure was one hell of a note to wrap up the festival on !The shooting was fresh, the music Badalamenti and the effects superb (v.v.little -if any- CGI). As a shock-horror it was very effective, causing me to jump in my seat several times (and anyone who knows me will tell you that that is no mean feat !), and the humour was so damn fast and laugh-out-loud hilarious that if anything it increased the sense of unease felt at the build-ups to the magnificently timed scenes of suspense. The script turns a few cliches on their heads whilst at the same time grabbing others by the throat and running with them, and the entire film darts about with a real sense of contemporary flare. It is a long overdue rare gem which harks back to what made the classic favorites like the Evil Dead series fun, with real gusto and guts.The young principal cast are clearly skilled and highly watchable (incl. the versatile Mr Roth), as are the partly unknown support, and being lucky enough (after the Q & A)to meet Eli Roth and one of the producers after the screening (both really genuine and friendly guys), it is clear that a lot of enthusiasm and enjoyment went into its production which is certainly reflected in the finished work.Not being a connoisseur of the genre, I am unsure how Cabin Fever fares in comparison with other similar titles, yet for laughs and shocks, Fever is hard to beat, and I thank Eli and everyone else involved (not forgetting the simply stunning Cerina Vincent) for producing such an enjoyable and memorable experience. A loud and colourful closing party for the festival in itself, 10/10.

I have seen this movie at Toronto Film Festival"s midnight maddness program.I love watching films in film festivals and ths one was the last film that festival showed that day.I was very sorry festival was finishing ,it hearts sooooo  much.However film was very well done horror.Ijumped a few times from my seat.It was a closing movie for midnight maddness program. If Eli roth himself contact me ,I would be very happy ,I would like to ask a few questions to him. Elvan

reviews.review_title: True colors come shining through when a flesh-eating virus infects a group of college graduates trapped at a cabin in the woods.
reviews.content: I was shocked by Eli Roth's 'Cabin Fever'.  From the title sequence all the way to the ironic tag out, I was enthralled.  Roth had me on a leash.  He understands the horror genre.  After the movie, my girlfriend vomited and vowed never to return to the theater with me again, unless it's 'The Lion King' at The Pantages.   Mark my words, we will see great things from Eli Roth and we all might vomit.

A fine thrill ride with a good blend of scares and laughs. I saw it on opening day with a crowd that clearly got the jokes and were scared out of their seats on occasion. It would be a ten, and a horror classic, if there wasn't a smattering of screenplay thuds from trying too hard. These broke the trance of beleivability so crucial to the horror experience. Even so, this may become one of those midnight movie staples like Rocky Horror or Eraserhead.

reviews.review_title: Pure Entertainment- a great-time = don't miss this one.
reviews.content: I saw this movie at the South By Southwest Film Festival, and it rocked! It's the perfect blend of comedy and horror/suspense.  I had the most fun I have ever had at a movie!  Words cannot do it justice, so go see this movie, if you have any sense of humor whatsoever.  I can't wait to see it again, for the first time!

CONTAINS SPOILERS Nothing beats a really well made b-movie, but unfortunately, films with its tongue firmly planted in its cheek always seem to get slated on IMDb. Starship Troopers gets 6.7, Cabin Fever gets 5.1, and it's a real shame that people just don't get it.This is NOT a proper horror film; it is a proper b-movie and should be judged on that. This film has no pretensions - it is not trying to be Godfather II. This wasn't made to scare, it was made to be laughed at and enjoyed. And it's pretty hard not to enjoy this film - all the elements of a good b-movie are there: backward red-necks, pretty teens, gratuitous sex scene, lots of gore, an isolated cabin etc.There is a great supporting cast providing laughs all the way through, not least from Eli Roth's cameo and, of course, the rednecks. Add to that some very memorable scenes (the leg shaving) and some superb photography and you have a winner.Sure, there are plot holes (the disease is never explained), but this film does not for one moment take itself seriously enough to care. If you feel unfulfilled because you need to know, then you really should be watching something else.Once again, this is a tongue-in-cheek teen b-movie that is pure entertainment. If you are after a cathartic experience or genuine scares, you are not going to find it here. But for 90 minutes of fun, there's not much better. This film does exactly what it intended to do, and should be praised for it.8/10

CABIN FEVER REVIEW - SEPTEMBER 13, 2003 ---------------------------------------------------------------Sad as it may sound, I was really looking forward to Cabin Fever. The trailer looked good. Overall opinions and reviews of the film were generally positive. The Toronto International Film Festival marked it as a highlight, some claiming it to be the best film present. So what went wrong?One thing I think we can all be assured of (if not all, then just me) was the growing hype around the film. At least that's what I felt in the weeks leading up to its release. I was generally excited to see Cabin Fever. The film starts out good, and goes along at a good pace, but never really gets any kind of build up to something satisfying. No parts scared me, and very few were startling. In fact, the only scene that really got me was the image of Karen missing her lips. And that's just a general thing I have against people with no lips. That will always bug me.To say Cabin Fever was down right bad is unfair. While the events that happened depicted gore and violence, in certain scenes (like when Bert gets his head blown off) it seems to be scaled back. And by scaled back I'll present an example. Jeff finds Bert on the floor, dead, with his head (assumingly) blown apart. However, we never get to fully see the headless body because a chair is in the way. Nit picking, yes I know, but with a balls out horror flick, I was expecting it to be, well, balls out. Which it wasn't.The two scenes towards the end (with the pancake kid and rabbit headed doctor), not to mention the ending itself, make you wonder if this film was even constructed as one single film. Or in fact had ideas and scenes sewn together from other failed script attempts. This idea is very present, specifically during the ending credits where `the ending credits' are divided up based on the scenes in the film. Not to mention the detail that is put into the campfire stories that are told. To Eli's credit though, I would have to say this was a great attempt in the right direction. Even though it misfired on so many occasions.That said, after the film had finished, I wanted to like it. I really did, but something was holding me back. I was undecided the entire ride home from the theatre. Alas, after much thought I would have to look down on the film. And mainly because I felt the story never materialized the dread the title Cabin Fever is supposed to make you feel.Two films I find dreadful, creepy, and just down right scary are the `Blair Witch Project' and `Session 9'. Despite the flaws both films house, people reading this might be able to pick a part, those are the two films that do it for me every time.(I included the last part as insight to readers to get an idea of my tastes in horror.)

reviews.review_title: One of the best films of the year, no bull.
reviews.content: I'd have to say this is one of the best films of 2003. After watching horror films when i was younger its great to see this film and it is excellent to see horror making a comeback. Go the gore! . Excellent effects and production values top off a great story and great night out!

reviews.review_title: Horror Fans should be happy with this one...
reviews.content: I was suprised how much I liked this flick, I was kind of doubting it because of all the hype around it but it was a good decent horror movie. You all know the plot so let's just skip that part. Overall it was a good movie, a good date movie. If your into watching a deadly flesh eating disease whack off a bunch of people. The gore isn't that great, I mean come on its rated R you can only go so far with a rated R movie, the few "gory" scenes that were seen were very quick and most of the time we got the old "close up to the actors face looking horrified and 'scared" look. hopefully there will be a Directors Cut with more and more blood and gore. I'm a big big horror fan and if your one too then you should be very happy.

reviews.review_title: Sorry, kids, but this is one of the better horror films out there right now
reviews.content: Actually, since the ones that have came out our Freddy vs. Jason, Wrong Turn, House of the Dead, etc... Cabin Fever and House of a 1000 Corpses, were really the only ones worth my three bucks to rent..So the acting was bad, what campy horror film has phenomenal acting anyway?  The main thing here is the special effects were cool, the blood, the gore, the actual fact they used actual make-up artists and not high-tech computer generated crap. I'm an older person and have to say I was impressed by Eli Roth's directorial debut.

reviews.review_title: I love this movie, maybe you didn't get it
reviews.content: I absolutely adored this movie. A lot of it was paying homage to other Horror movies, so if you are not a big fan of horror from the 70s and 80s you may not get it. The last 3 minutes are probably some of the greatest moments of film ever.

reviews.review_title: This one goes up to eleven!
reviews.content: Saw the screening of "Cabin Fever" at the Boston Film Festival last night, and all I can say is that it was without a doubt THE best movie I've seen at the festival *ever.* Apparently, I wasn't the only one interested in the movie as they had to open a whole other theater to show it.  "Cabin Fever" is brilliant, funny, full to the brim with reverent yet hilarious references to others of its sadly overlooked genre and well worth the second viewing I intend to give it on opening night this Friday.  Even if you are not a big fan of horror movies themselves but know a little bit about them and have a pretty strong constitution, I highly recommend this movie.  10 stars are NOT enough!

i like this movie because its really gory and has a real good pace the plot is these 5 kids go to a cabin and get a disease what i don't like is that no one dies from the disease which i don't like.that is the whole point of the movie thats like Friday the 13th without Jason killing anyone but it kept me on my toes in most horror films there's 1 thing killing everyone like in nightmare on elm st. Fred Krueger kills everyone but its still a good film.the nerd (Paul)kills a lot of people in the movie like when he puts the stick through tommy which i think is a reference to Dracula by putting a stake through his heart.one thing i don't like is this scene it just shows Paul holding the stick putting it into tommy it doesn't show like it going in him.but i like all the deaths like eaten alive by a vicious dog screwdriver in the ear is my favorite so the deaths are a step in the right direction

I watched the documentary first. Understanding what Eli Roth was trying to achieve with this film made more sense than watching the film from scratch. He is definitely affected by David Lynch. The Bunny and Pancakes. Are we really supposed to get that. I want to see more from this young director.

Saw the film the other night. The entire cinema was loving this flick. If you enjoy the dark and groteque humour some of us humans posses. Go and See this film.I loved it. Haven't been that entertained in a cinema for a while.

reviews.review_title: A Flick True To Its Horror Roots *Minor Spoilers*
reviews.content: The average movie-goer will not like this flick---it takes on a "serious" tone while delivering the gore and humor one expects from a good horror film.A good horror movie can amuse and entertain while horrifying at the same time.  While Cabin Fever is somewhat weak on the scare-factor, its entertainment, coupled with some pretty solid gore, more than makes up for it.  The flick does succeed at creating a serious horror tone, and this is integral to its entertainment value---if Cabin Fever were just another parody (Scary Movie I, II, etc.) it would be trivial and hardly funny. But its tone can make the awful things that happen often downright hilarious (something any avid B-Horror movie fan can appreciate), and this is clearly done on purpose (as certain ridiculous characters and a self-deprecating ending will show).Nobody is watching: Jack Frost (the original, pre-Michael F'ing Keaton), and Leprechaun 4: In Space, for Oscar quality writing.  Cabin Fever embraces this ideal, it's not a mistake that it's hilarious when some chick is torn apart by a randomly appearing rabid dog or a bunny rabbit appears in a hospital.  Plus, there were a couple flagrantly bloody scenes that had an old horror vet turning away.  Someone looking for the average movie will be sorely disappointed here, and be complaining within 15 minutes.  But anyone who has rented Monkey Shines will appreciate it immediately.  Not because it's bad, but because it embraces the humor of the horror genre.P.S. Gotta love the dude from Super Troopers

Loved this one - sneak preview - expected to hate it - was in line for 45 minutes to get in to this one - it was 2 out of 4000! films chosen from Toronto Film Festival
I was on edge of my chair and kept trying to get up and go to rr - but kept having to hold it because good stuff kept happening.  Scary as @#$% - intense as @#$%the people around me screamed and said they loved it too - a nice surprise...you will have lots to talk about when you leave the theater...going to see it again, but rr before film this time

I see all these people writing in about how terrible this movie was. You're dead wrong.  This movie was great.  Just because you were expecting something lame like The Ring or Scream, and instead actually saw a GOOD movie, you complain.  You saw that it was a horror movie and then saw it and didn't see someone in a mask chopping people apart.  This movie was different for a reason, it proved that the bad guy DIDN'T have to be a person in a mask.  But it has become so ingrained in people that you can't see that this scenario is actually scarier.  Imagine you and your closest friends up there.  Imagine locking YOUR girlfriend in the shed because you're so scared.  Imagine YOUR boyfriend running off into the woods, leaving you alone.  That is what is scary.  But you missed that.  You were too busy looking for the man in the mask.  I guarentee that the majority of people who saw, and didn't like, this movie went into it with a certain perception.  And because of a drastic amount of close-mindedness, couldn't accept that it was both DIFFERENT and GOOD.  Personally, I thought that the concept of an inhuman killer was much better.  Look at the main character, he snapped.  Because of all the death he saw, and inflicted.  I realize that many of you will scoff at this just as you scoffed at the movie.  And I bet you also decided to reject my opinions as soon as you saw that they differed from yours.  But just keep an open mind about things like this, you'd probably end up liking it.

reviews.review_title: A good movie but Gro-O-O-O-O-O-OSS!! Nastiest I have ever seen
reviews.content: Cabin Fever is the natiest movie I have ever seen. I knew it probably would be going into the theater because its about a flesh eating virus and I had a feeling the director wouldnt hold anything back.When I first saw the commercials, I thought it was going to be terrible on the sole fact that Sean was going to be in it. But after a while i was sitting there and I was like "wait, this actually looks pretty bad assed" and it was.A lot of people are going to be crap ass nay-sayers and player hate on it. That happens with every horror movie. They will say "the characters should have done blah blah" or "if i made the movie it would have been wikid good. i am wikid good at re-writing other people's movies" Yeah, the characters make some bad decisions. But thats what characters in horror movies do. You cant watch it from a 3rd person perspective and say you have all the answers of what should be done. Life doesnt work that way.One problem some might have with Cabin Fever is that it gets so graphic and nasty that it is a little hard to watch. Although I enjoyed the movie, by the time I left my stomach felt queesy and I couldnt get some of the most disturbing images of the film out of my head for about a full 24 hours.It has good cinematography, wonderfully disgusting skin rotting away effects, and cool direction and i liked it.Was it an awesome movie? naw. Was it good? yeah. I would rank it after Identity and 28 Days Later but definitely before Freddy VS Jason or Wrong Turn.If you're reading this, than you have probably have just read or are about to read a lot of negative reviews. Well, ignore those people. It definitely doesn't deserve the overly-negative reviews a lot of people are giving it. Go see it once with an open mind and a strong stomach.trust me.

reviews.review_title: Very impressive first time effort. Bravo Eli Roth!
reviews.content: Borrowing from several genre favorites, Eli Roth has made a most impressive debut.Mixing dark humor(very dark) with splatterpunk sensibilities,Roth, for the most part, hits the nail squarely through the ear, er, head. For fans of the Evil Dead trilogy this is a must see. Having read about this film months before, my friends and I were eagerly anticipating it's release. High expectations sometimes lead to a let down, but in the case of Cabin Fever, the reality far surpassed the anticipation. I couldn't recommend this film higher for horror fans or genre fans in search of a bloody good time.

The credits roll, the audience clamber out of the seats and head back out into the lobby. `What the hell was that?' I'm asked as I try and salvage my half eaten popcorn from the stampede. `Certain commercial success', I reply as my fingers take a stomping and my popcorn leaves a job for the cleaners.And I'm right too, with a Box Office gross of almost twenty million in the U.S and Canada, and set to do the same in the UK, Cabin fever is pure cinematic indulgence guaranteed to make writer, producer and director, Eli Roth, a very rich man.His hybrid of laugh-out-loud comedy, sickening gore, and more curse words in it's first 15 opening minutes than the entire script of Reservoir Dogs, does it's best to deliver exactly what filmgoers want from their movies, piling on the humour, which often ranges from quirky to out and out ridiculous, and copious amounts of blood, guts, flying limbs, stabbings, shootings and beatings thick and fast, hardly giving the audience a chance to breath before forcing another kooky hillbilly or piece of rotted flesh down their throats.And there's sex too. Sex which on only one occasion seems to actually hold any relevance to the script, a scene in which Paul (Rider Strong, Starship Troopers) pleasures his love interest Karren (Played by Jordan Ladd, Never Been Kissed), only to discover that her skin is bloody, full of scabs and rotting. The other two sex scenes appear to be placed in the film for no other reason than to boost ratings by having Cerina Vincent's (Not Another Teen Movie, Power Rangers) character Marcy get naked. This is most apparent when Marcy says to Paul 'It's like being on a plane, knowing it's going to crash, everyone screaming 'We're Going Down!', when all you want to do is grab the nearest person to you and f*ck the shit out of them', and five seconds later they're naked and making love, all of which has no relevance on the rest of the film.And as if sex, comedy, gore, Violence and swearing weren't enough to make a top selling film, Roth, and writing Partner Randy Pearlstein have thrown plenty of inter-textual references to some classic horror films into the melting pot, just to keep the horror enthusiasts happy. The setting, a cosy yet eerie cabin isolated in the middle of the woods paying homage to Evil Dead and Friday The 13th, the low angle shot of Marcy's walk to the farmhouse referencing the classic Texas Chainsaw Massacre, Paul's scene in the hospital a nod to Stanley Kubrick's masterpiece `A Clockwork Orange', not to mention the crazy hillbillies darting round the woods with shotguns, from at least ten `Lost In the Woods' horror films.Now, I know what you're saying: `Hey, you haven't even mentioned a plot yet'. That's because Cabin Fever's actual plot is a small concern. Telling the story of five college leavers heading into the woods for a vacation, who contract a deadly skin virus from a reservoir polluted by the dead body of a deranged and infected man who asked for the groups help, then turn against each other in paranoid hysteria over `Who Has The Virus, Who Doesn't?' and one by one die varied and gruesome deaths. Paul is our lead character here, and we watch as he survives through attacks by rabid dogs, crazed hillbillies and the virus itself, before ending up in hospital and having the local police force `Take Care of Him'.However, Cabin Fever isn't about plot, it's about indulgence, it's about entertainment, it's about cramming as many elements of successful films into one as possible. It's about deaths, diseases, violence, laughter and sex. Not everything makes perfect sense, Such as a little boy named Dennis who, towards the end develops a fondness for `PANCAKES!!', and let's rip with some impressive, Matrix style kung-fu before taking a bite out of college jock Bert, who played, quite excellently, by James Debello (Scary Movie 2). But then again, not everything about Cabin Fever has to make sense.Had Roth abandoned script-writing all together, turned up on the first day of shooting and yelled `Ok, I want Sex, I want Violence, I want Blood, Guts and Gore, I want some Comedy, I want you to reference a couple of films, and I want you to swear like your lives depended on it. Now go for it', then simply let his cast run wild in front of the camera, my guess is that the Cabin Fever he would have made with that approach would have been no different from the Cabin Fever we see today.Christopher Skoyles. 12/10/03.

While I admit that I laughed harder while watching this movie than I have in years, something still bothers me. The whole rotting to death thing could have been avoided if that group of ass-clowns had any sense. I mean, if I ever contract some horrible flesh eating virus, I hope that my friends would not think that the best thing to do would be to lock me up in the wood shed and leave me to either rot away or be eaten by a psychotic dog. Then beat me with a shovel instead of shooting me to put me out of my misery. Also, they only tried once to get a signal on their cell and made no real effort to get to town because the truck wouldn't start. Getting help just didn't seem like a huge priority. It was like every character in the movie made the worst decisions possible, at all times. Right down to the kids that made lemonade to sell out of river water, which was obviously much easier to gather than water from the tap! Jeez!

This is really a movie to watch when u just want to be entertained. When u dont wanna think bout characters, plot-lines etc.. It had great gory scenes, terrific humour, some sex. What could u wish more?

Okay, I saw this movie, and was like: Great, I haven't seen a scary movie in a while, this should be good. This was like one of the funniest movies I have ever seen!!!! That Denis kid, and the ending!!! I don't think I have ever laughed so hard in a movie that was supposed to be horror. If you don't get grossed out by blood, and you want to see a funny movie, rent this one!

reviews.review_title: Good film that doesn't really appeal to American humour.
reviews.content: Cabin Fever, first brought my attention after getting good comments from director Peter Jackson of the unbelievable LOTR trilogy.  However, I severely doubted his laurels until the end of the movie, but after all was said and done it was clear it was not completely unwarranted.  The humour and overall message of the movie is undoubtedly Canadian which would make it hard for most Americans relate to.  Other than that, the movie has some standard teen movie elements, which how could it go without?  Its a horror movie after all!  And a bit of classic horror movie cheesiness.  But the fact that the movie offers a bit more than to just take it for what it is, something most horror movies lack, makes it certainly worthwhile.  A good movie overall.

This movie was great.  Did the genius that reviewed this movie forget to pay attention to the beginning?  The arrival at the little country store to pick up beer, and food allows the viewers to realize that they have now entered the land of the hillbilly rednecks!  This movie was not meant to be a big budget film with a titanic plotline.  It accomplishes everything that Eli Roth set out to do.  It revisits old horror-gore films of the 70s-80s. Not to mention that it takes more of a realisitic twist than your typical Friday 13th / Nightmare on Elm Street flicks.  The cast was great and they had a script that allowed them to show a lot of potential.  We get to see Rider Strong (every little teenage girls fantasy) hack and slaughter people towards the end of the movie.  This says a lot because his character starts as some wimp that is trying to score with a girl he has known since 7th grade.  The flesh eating disease does more than destroy their outer appearance, it also manages to destroy their friendships.  I hope to see more movies from Eli Roth soon.  I was excited before, during, and after this movie.  The DVD release turned out to be just as worthwhile as the theatrical release.

Everyone is taking this movie much, much too seriously.  I think the problem is the trailers.  When this movie first was released, the trailers made it seem to be something that it is not.  It's only downfall is the way it mislead viewers.It was meant to be this way.  It is a high-grade B movie that was made in the spirit of "2000 Maniacs."  The randomness of supporting cast is just that, meant to be something random.  Made to make you say-WTF?Because it was meant to be a shlocky gore-fest, and clearly an homage to so many great 70's horror films, I give it a ten.  Yes, people I said a ten. I actually felt like I was watching a movie that was made in the 70's.Just rent the DVD, sit back and allow yourself to have some unadulterated fun, you just might enjoy yourself.

reviews.review_title: boy meets world gets out frustration
reviews.content: Did anyone like the parallels between robert strong's character, Paul, and his character on boy meets world? they make it painfully obvious that he has pursued the chick hes with since they were really young but could never have her (TOPANGA); and it seemed he was always playing second fiddle to sweet lou (aka jeff) much like he played to corey. *spoilers ahead* it also seems that since he could never have the girl he subconsciously murdered her. case in point, he was the only person to ever give her any water, and he chased the rabid dog from the girl only to smash her still breathing body with a shovel! what would mr. fenny think!

reviews.review_title: A Master Tribute to Some of My Favorite Films
reviews.content:
There was a time in the history of American horror film during the 1980s when certain ingredients seemed to add up to gut busting, skin crawling fun. This movie is the proof that there is some merit behind those old formulas (Evil Dead, Phantasm, any movie where you can discern who is going to die by their indulgence in sex, drugs, or sex), and not all horror or thriller films need to be edited like an MTV video or Japanese anime, be as serious as conflict in the Middle East, or as "clever" as Scream or the Blair Witch Project (that one is subject to debate).If you are concerned about believable characters and intricate plot points, watch Magnolia. If you want a virus movie that explains the virus, watch Outbreak. But this movie is ten times as fun and doesn't take itself too seriously, which is a trait that I find increasingly frustrating in film, mainstream AND independent. They are only movies after all, why not exaggerate and boil down reality some of the more entertaining and shocking elements? Otherwise we'd just make documentaries all the time.
This movie is required viewing for fans of the earlier work of Stuart Gordon, the Evil Dead series, and people who are able to separate reality from entertainment enough to know a damn good roller coaster when they see one.If you aren't at least that tall, don't get on the ride!

It's a very strange film in regard to the sequence of scenes, characters and villagers' scenes(some have nothing to do) and the final scene with its music seems from another movie, only good thing about this film are Cerina Vincent's breasts whether covered or uncovered, the only 3 good shots are making when Cerina (Marcy) is being revised in the mirror for herself looking for the fever, second is when it appears part of her butt when she has sex with Rider Strong (Paul) and the best shot of the film is the sequence with reduced speed without slow motion slow motion especially the Phantom type that is using on action movies and sports, of Cerina going to a house for help, the rest is a mess of artificial blood literally tasteless and not because I do not like Gore, but the blood is of poor quality and they no attempt to make internal organs look real, finally I think on a "horror" movie filmmakers should never do that girls on film have suffered in their physical out by what happens in the plot, especially if there are only two girls in the movie.

Pure horror. And I don't mean that as a compliment. I now dedicate my life to warning people about the pure travesty that is the motion picture. "Cabin Fever" has plot holes large enough to drive a Mack truck through. I expected a cliché ridden popcorn flick but what I got was one of the most laughable excuses for a film I've seen in a long while, maybe ever. The rather pedestrian acting and infantile dialog are but just two points that make this film a complete waste of time and money. But the worst thing about this film is the writing and "directing". I have seen more competent storytelling in films lampooned on Mystery Science Theatre 3000.Sure, it looks OK. The film stock is nicely treated and it looks crisp on DVD, but. the big question is how did this project get greenlighted? A mishmash of half-baked ideas and long sequences where nothing happens are peppered by a "plot" that never develops satisfactorily or competently.What was this "virus", if it was a "virus" at all. No why's, no how's, nothing! And that (I assume austistic) cretin who bites folks assuming they are pancakes? Huh? And Guiseppe Andrews? What a pompous nothing hacktor! Someone got this kid a job at Wal-Mart.The lame attempts at humour never illicit anything resembling a slight twitch of the facial muscles. And yes, I understand black humour, folks. This humour lacks all pigment.It makes me wretch to think that the makers of this movie have probably recouped their investment in the gullible teen market. So many other films deserve as strong a push as this stinker. yet they languish unrented in your local video shoppe.So, teenyboppers, go rent A Clockwork Orange or Fargo and see black humour done correctly. If you want to see a great film about teens having sex in the woods maybe Meatballs will suffice.

reviews.review_title: A couple of reasons why this bird don't fly!
reviews.content: I guess it didn't meet my expectations.  I think Eli Roth is more capable than this movie... I think Rider is above it too.  Though the director wanted to pay homage to the late 70s and 80s horror films, they produced a gore flick instead.  I'm not going to mince words... as much as I like the cast and all, the movie's main drawback was in its plot. Simply put, if you want to make a good horror movie, follow the rules of the game.  The closest movie that works in the paradigm is John Carpenter's The Thing.  In the Thing you are studying something extraterrestrial which is borderline supernatural and you learn about its motives, wants and needs. Cabin Fever's phage is organic, and causes its victim's flesh to become putty and fall off... there is no knowledge gained, so its just plane ol' flat.  Its a gore flick relying mainly on bloodsyrup/mix, and it misses horror completely. I recommend the book The Philosophy of Horror for this director.  I think it will benefit him in identifying what it is that makes horror movies work beyond gore.  Eli Roth, uses a flesh eating phage as his "monster" that quickly eats away his unwilling and unmotivated victims.  There is no mystery as to who is infected or what the outcome will be. Roth doesn't do an effective job of turning his group against each other and breaking their trust. IMHO, There is very little motivation for the characters to do the things they do, or feel the way they do... a girl gets eaten by this thing and I'm left flat, because there is really nothing I feel about wanting her character to stay alive, the relationship hasn't been identified as something worth saving. Now, if Rider's character, Paul, was able to resist the virus because of interferon produced from the bite he received on the onset of the film... an immunity from a competing organism that counteracted the phage, then you might have something: a story about one guy trying to keep his group together and his film alive. Again... Roth needs to do more R&D on the script end before bringing it into production.

reviews.review_title: This movie has everything: Blood, Sex, and PANCAKES!(a few minor spoilers, but nothing big)
reviews.content: This is one of those movies that is so bad, that it is great. The plot half makes sense, but who really cares. It's not meant to be pondered on too much, but it can create days of conversations. My friend and I happened to see it on the same day and talked about it for an entire month, if not longer! Whenever we passed each other in the hallway, we would yell out PANCAKES, and just got used to the weird looks. We even thought of naming a band Don't Sit Next to Dennis. How great would that be!Anyway, I haven't even really talked about the movie much. The gore is absolutely fantastic. It was overdone so realistically... But if you think about it, what would it look like to see all of your skin fall off and your body basically decay from the inside out? Whatever you do, don't shave when you're in that situation (how stupid was that?) But besides the sickeningly awesome effects, this movie is hilarious. There are crazy hillbillies, a disturbed child that can do karate, and a random guy in a bunny suit. What more could you want. I bet you didn't even know that you wanted it. : )If you want to be grossed out and laughing for days, you'll love this movie. It's bound to become a cult classic, if it isn't already, much in the style of Evil Dead. It's great to watch with squeamish people without warning them - you'll laugh even more, well until they vomit on your carpet.

I will admit I am not a huge horror fan, but I do enjoy the genre and this is a movie that I felt really pulled it off nicely. The thing that makes this movie so frightening is the real factor. In most horror movies we see today it is the masked maniac or a possessed doll or even a freak show who gets into your dreams, but this movies "enemy" was an actual flesh eating disease. Now I'm not a medical expert, but I would assume the virus wouldn't spread that fast, but it's a movie you have to pull some strings. I thought Rider Strong did a great job with his role especially how his character changes throughout the movie and after recently having watched Grind I thought Joey Kern did a great job too playing a very different character. Now no movie is obviously perfect and the movie does have certain flaws, but I really thought it came together nicely and kudos to Eli Roth for a new approach. To sum it up I'd say it's at least worth a rental especially if you're into the genre and I suggest you approach the movie with not great expectations which seemed to happen after all the praise the movie got which left many people disappointed because when they saw it they were expecting a perfect movie. All and all 7/10.

I'd say 'Cabin Fever' is worth watching, amazing make-up work I might add, but I'd have to say that '28 Days Later' is a much better movie. In a way, 'Cabin Fever' ripped it off, with worse results, and I thought the ending of the movie was just dumb, not to mention it left me wondering what would happen, and not in a good way. At the end, with the old man selling a gun, well, that made NO sense AT ALL!!! And another thing was that dog that was in the movie. I didn't understand it. Why was it even in there in the first place? Anyways, I actually thought it did have a pretty okay storyline. I liked how everyone got the virus by the drinking water. But, was the virus the Ebola Virus? I'd wish the movie could have explained itself better. Predictable at times, I'd say it was a pretty good movie, but, like I said, I'd rather see '28 Days Later'

I seriously don't know wtf people are talking about when they say this movie is bad. 'Cabin Fever' has been one of my favorite horror movies ever since it came out, and I think Eli Roth is a great writer and director. It amazes me that people go into watching ANY horror film expecting good acting. That is not what they're about. Go watch 'The Shawshank Redemption' or 'The Godfather' if you want to see first-rate acting and writing.Horror films are supposed to scare you, gross you out, and be nothing more than pure fun, and that's exactly what 'Cabin Fever' is. I think the humor in Cabin Fever is what puts a lot of people off. People aren't used to seeing funny horror films, so when they do see one they automatically think it's weird and stupid. 'Cabin Fever' is hilarious from beginning to end, and it's completely gross and over the top.All of the best horror films I've ever seen got bad ratings thanks to people who watch them and don't even like horror films in the first place. But that's okay, because real horror fans know that 'Cabin Fever' is up there with the best around.

As they say, critics have the right to express what they think. But do they have to be so harsh and so... like... hello?! With all those things that they say about movies being "a pile of crap!", GIMME A BREAK! Give em a chance will you?! It's not like you own the whole movie world or something! Okay, okay... so that's a bit too "touchy-feely" right? But thats beside the point. The point is... some guys out there( or maybe even girls ) just can't seem to cool off or relax a bit. I guess that's what they say about spoilers, "spill of whatever you want and get all the attention you deserve!". For me, that is SOOOOO SURREAL! How low can other people get huh?! Well, okay, enough about emotional distress and psycho-speak, lets move on to business. This movie was downright disappointing at the start. For me, it had a lot of downfalls. There was a lack of motivation, the characters are bloody boring, and the village perks are a total insanity. Why did they have to get all those set-ups when its not so significant? I mean this movie could be better if they worked on it much more. But overall, Cabin Fever somehow got my eye(i don't why) I mean if i didn't like the movie, why put up this comment anyway. This is why i prefer to stay in the middle despite everything negative about it. There may be hope for Cabin Fever if the viewers could learn to understand a little more. And for the last bit, I'm now a fan! I don't know why! It must be worth something after all those reactions. I still liked it in the end... And because of Cabin Fever, i'm now writing a revised version of it in another style. you wanna see? Well, hope you could! I made this story all of a sudden because of a weird vision! And... its a TRUE STORY! Only, no IMMORALITY ALLOWED! Just something i wish could come out well soon because i'm still working on it. Hope Eli Roth could read this! Godwilling! I really want him to read my own story out of Cabin Fever and see what he thinks about it! But I can only hope... If ever there's a chance! (",) PS: Just watch it if you want to, not by what others say about it. Its all up to you if you want or not; all that matters is that you'll have fun or have the bore of your life! Don't get tricked into changing your own perspective of this movie by just a mere comment on this site! It's all in your own hands! Just don't be too hoggish and too immature to understand some certain things... This movie still has a bit of "thang" in it. YOu'll see soon enough... Things may turn out different you know! Have fun! OR better yet.. Good Luck!

I have a habit of loving films that are so dumb and so terrible that I should feel ashamed that I love them. Cabin Fever is one of those films. The gore (which I was expecting a lot more of, having seen Hostel) didn't scare me one bit, and I'm easily freaked out by horror standards. The characters were all idiots, except the whiny blonde guy Jeff, who actually did an incredibly smart (although somewhat gutless) thing by running away from the rest of the gang and NOT drinking the water. (I'll admit, I was actually pretty annoyed that he died eventually, if only because I had a slightly twisted little crush on him.) If they'd all just stayed away from each other and drank beer ... well, there wouldn't have been a film, but it was the one thing that made the most sense in a pretty much senseless film. I wouldn't recommend anyone watch this film - unless I knew them well enough to know they wouldn't want to harm me for making them waste 90 minutes of their life. But I love it, because it's just SO BAD. In fact, if they made it better in any way at all, I would have just been bored. So, don't watch Cabin Fever. And if you do, make sure your expectations are very low, and you don't have something you could be doing for the length of the film - you'll only wish you'd been doing it.

When i first picked up this film i definitely wasn't expecting what i got, from what other people have told me and the words 'TERRIFYING' on the front cover.Though it is one of THE worst horror movies i have ever seen, it was surprisingly funny(Apart from the annoying brunette who decided after nearly all her friends had died that it was the right time to shave her legs, because you know a girls gotta look good) Funniest moment was def. Dennis (Creepy Boy who looks like a girl) with the whole pancakes panCAKES PANCAKES !And then the little matrix routine before he decided that what he had just tucked into wasn't actually a gigantic pancake.Also Paul (One of the main characters) who started off as a normal pathetic young man and ended up as a person who enjoyed poking dead bodies with sticks,turning them over,looking disgusted and then hitting them over the head with a shovel of some sort.Would recommend if you have an odd sense of humour.
Why is the cast info for this all wrong? Same on Google. Matthew Dedarrio isn't even listed and he plays Jeff.
